name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Annie Schreijer-Pierik, Matthias Groote, on the Zika virus epidemic. Boleslaw G. Piecha, José Inácio Faria, Katerina Konecná, Martin Häusling, Piernicola Pedicini, Joëlle Mélin, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000030/2016 - B8-0119/2016) (2016/2584(RSP)).

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Chairman of the ENVI Committee. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the Zika virus epidemic began in May 2015 in Brazil and has since spread to forty countries. The virus has infected about four million people in South America. On February 1, 2016, the Emergency Committee of the International Health Regulation declared that the Zika virus outbreak constitutes a public health emergency of international importance. Experts agree that it is highly likely that there is a causal link between zika virus infection during pregnancy and microcephaly in newborns, although this has not yet been scientifically proven. Unlike the much more dangerous Ebola virus, which needed contact between people for contagion, the Zika virus is transmissible through mosquito bite.  These premises have led us to call for this debate and for debate in this House with the European Commission. The subject of our oral question is the request for an overview of the current situation with regard to the outbreak of the disease and the incidence of microcephaly in the Union, as well as the real risk of transmission of Zika virus infection in the European Union. In this regard, we know that the vector, the Aedes aegypti mosquito,, is currently not active. But we also know that in the summer, and already in the spring, if we think of the countries of Southern Europe, it will become active. In addition, we must consider the presence of the Olympic Games in Brazil, an event that, due to the already planned displacement of large numbers of people, will generate and could generate the multiplication out of proportion to the spread of the virus. In addition, when the Rio 2016 event begins, there will be, as a result of climatic conditions, the greater development of mosquito populations, which are precisely the vector of the disease.  In view of this, the Commission, ENVI intends to ask the Commissioner what action has been taken to prevent the spread of the disease on European territory and whether the necessary measures have already been put in place to deal with a possible emergency, should it also occur in Europe. I would like to ask whether the Commission, for example, intends to advise the HEALTH AUTHORITIES of the Union to cooperate with the transport sector in order to ensure the disinfection of the cargoes, cargo carriers, cabins and passenger compartments of aircraft coming from the areas affected by the virus. If it also considers spreading the use of insecticides and if it is tried to sterilize, as has been proposed, mosquitoes to avoid their production through the so-called sterile male technique.  With regard to the financial part, I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he considers the sum of EUR 10 million made available to meet the scientific challenge of the virus and its neurological complications to be sufficient, as well as the need to develop diagnostic tests, vaccines and treatments for the disease.  Finally, we know that the EMA has organized a task force of experts specializing in vaccines and infectious diseases, to provide pharmaceutical companies with scientific inputs and regulators for the development of medicines or vaccines against the virus. On this issue, I would like to ask the Commissioner where we stand with the study of the vaccine, whether we are making progress and whether we can expect positive results in the short and medium term.  As you can see, Commissioner, a number of issues are being put to the Attention of the Commission in order to prevent, because we know that prevention is the best strategy to avoid damage to the health of European citizens and, above all, to reduce the possible effects of an infection such as that of the Zika virus.

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Mr La Via, the Commission fully shares Parliament’s concern on Zika and we agree that we need to have a forceful response to this outbreak. The Zika virus is a model example of the threats that we face in today’s globalised world. Suddenly it made its way around the world and reached the Americas and the Caribbean. And as always when a virus is introduced in a new area we can see some unexpected symptoms and effects. While the uncomplicated Zika infection causes only mild symptoms, this virus seems able to infect unborn children in utero, potentially causing microcephaly. In the light of this, the World Health Organization has rightly declared a public health emergency of international concern and in the European Union we have mobilised our structures of cooperation with the Member States. The epidemic has arrived in Member States’ overseas territories; in continental European Union we so far only have cases in travellers returning from the affected areas.  So that is why the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) has developed information for travellers and for EU residents in the affected areas, and that I know is one of the points for action mentioned in your resolution. We have also shaped advice to health authorities to help Member States increase awareness amongst clinicians, something else that your resolution stresses. It is likely that more infections will occur in Europe. We must be prepared for local transmission of Zika as temperatures rise, building on our experience in controlling the spread of mosquitoes, which is being brought together by the ECDC. We are already gathering knowledge from countries with experience in mosquito control, as you rightly call for. We are ready to address Zika by using tried and tested systems under our legislation on serious cross-border health threats, which gives us the mandate to coordinate the response to a threat together with Member States. As regards surveillance of the epidemic, we are on track and we are working with Member States to reinforce laboratory capabilities for early detection and diagnosis based on the ECDC risk assessments. It is the Health Security Committee which is the structure we have in place for risk management to cross-border threats. This committee has so far met three times to review the Zika situation and we are constantly exchanging information on Zika through our early warning and response system. As regards another important point you raised, the disinfection of ships and airplanes, we have developed specific advice to Member States on this, again based on ECDC risk assessments. We share your concern at the fact that there are no vaccines or medicines to protect people from the Zika virus or to treat them, and that is why we are stepping up our efforts in this area. The European Medicines Agency has established a task force of experts to advise on scientific and regulatory matters related to the development of medicines against the virus. The Agency will also contact companies planning to work on vaccines and offer advice. We are making available an additional EUR 10 million of emergency research funding for Zika-related research. These are only the first steps in our response. We will continue to support the EU Member States and the affected regions in close cooperation with the World Health Organization and today’s debate and Parliament’s motion for a resolution come, I think, at the right moment to focus attention on the urgency of the situation. This is particularly true as in the coming spring and summer mosquitos may pose a danger for the introduction of the virus in Europe, so we need effective vector control measures. Let me assure you that the Commission is ready to address all aspects of the Zika virus challenge and is ready to deploy all available instruments and means to this end.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – A question to the Commission: have you ever seen a photo or video of a baby born with a small head? That's microcephaly and according to the WHO probably caused by the Zika virus. According to the latest reports from the American study, the virus can also damage the nervous system. It is therefore important that we get to work on this.  The virus is drawing a trail of misery through tropical countries. Infections have already surfaced in Europe. And therefore the question: what is the state of play now? Do you agree with the WHO? The ECDC is more critical. What is the risk of infections in Europe? What measures do you intend to take? You have mentioned several: planes, ships, etc. But what else are you up to? You have committed EUR 10 million, or is it EUR 65 million? Is that enough for the enormous challenge of developing a vaccine for this virus, if it is the cause and to really protect the world's population? In Europe alone, 5 million women are pregnant every year. Together with hundreds of millions of other women worldwide, they are waiting for an approved vaccine.  In their interest, we call for more research into the Zika virus and for more precautions. Because be aware: a single bite of an infected mosquito can plunge mother and child into misery for life. Finally, we are now two days after International Women's Day. It must not be that we have already forgotten the women of the whole world. I'm counting on you!

name: Matthias Groote
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has We postponed this debate because we in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Social Affairs had a quiet discussion about what a resolution should actually look like, what must actually be done, because we did not yet have the information. The information is sparse. Since 1 February 2016, we have had the state of emergency declared by the World Health Organisation in connection with the Zika virus. I would again be interested to know what the financing should look like. In total, according to who figures, the fight in Central and South America will cost up to EUR 50 million by June this year. The European Union gives ten million. Are the Member States giving extra money on the spot? After all, the call for the European Union to get involved is always very quickly there. But we are mostly chronically underfunded. In this respect, I would be interested to know what the Member States are doing and how other regions of the world will be involved in the fight against this terrible virus. Much has already been said about the transport sector. We live in a globalised world, and we must, of course, also see what travel flows look like. But Zika has really spread around the equator; Within 40 days, this virus has actually gone around the world. What is the situation in the Member States? We also have regions of the EU that are in crisis areas. What about dissemination and what are the preventive measures in the respective regions where the EU is responsible at the end of the day? What is particularly important here, in the very context of the Zika virus, is important to mention – we have been talking about pregnancy, about the malformation in infants: what about the whole area of women's rights? Two days after Women's Day, I believe that we must also express our strong opinion on this in this opinion, which Parliament is giving.

name: Julie Girling
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, firstly may I take this opportunity – one I did not think I would have with my portfolio – to welcome the Commissioner to the Parliament?  Like many people, until a month or so ago, I had never really heard of Zika. When I started to read about it I kind of assumed it was something very new and I was quite surprised to find that actually Zika has been around a long time. What is new is the rapid spread. So it is surprising that we have, in fact, so little information about how it is spreading and, indeed, so few inroads made into research, into preventing that spread, into a vaccination, etc. So I am delighted to hear that we are going to be speeding that process up.  So my question really is: how will this ongoing information – we have heard about the work that is going to be done, and I am sure we will hear more – be transmitted to Parliament, and will the Commission be setting up a mechanism for regular reporting, be this via ECDC or not, to Parliament, and also to Member States, because we would very much like to be kept updated?

name: José Inácio Faria
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is very worrying that we have been following the news about the Zika virus outbreak, which has been spreading rapidly in different countries, especially Latin America, and which could spread to the European continent and which has become a real global health emergency. According to the World Health Organization, this virus could affect about four million people on the American continent alone in 2016. News of this outbreak is increasingly alarming and there are high suspicions that this virus could cause birth defects and neurological syndromes. At the moment, there are already cases of travellers who have been infected with the Zika virus in third countries and diagnosed after returning to Europe. Fortunately, for all of us, the disease has not yet spread to the European continent.  However, with spring and summer, the risk of this spread in Europe will necessarily become greater. In countries where the Aedes aegypti mosquito is present, such as Portugal - more specifically in the outermost region of Madeira - there may be a serious risk of spreading the Zika virus. The lessons learned during the Ebola outbreak indicate that we need to act more quickly and effectively in global health emergencies.  As Commissioner Hill said, Member States must and can cooperate scientifically and operationally with each other, also with the Latin American countries most affected by the virus. It is left to establish the best measures to prevent, control, diagnosis and possible treatments against the disease, as well as to share information about research that is being carried out. It is essential that these studies include the possible links between the virus and congenital malformations and neurological syndromes.  However, it is also necessary to analyze possible alternative causes for these malformations and not exclude any hypothesis before due proof and scientific investigation. I am referring in particular to the possibility of a causal link between the cases of microcephaly found and pyriproxifen larvicidal added to drinking water. So, ladies and gentlemen, we can find answers that contribute to a final solution to this very serious problem for global public health.

name: Martin Häusling
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has When you hear the figures, you are very frightened: four million people, 40 countries are now affected. The WHO said again yesterday: the spread has not stopped, it will continue. That is why all the measures that are now being taken – including the declaration of an emergency – are imperative if we do not fall into the same trap as Ebola, that we respond too late to an almost global threat. Nor do we need the very last proof of whether the tiger mosquito is now responsible. Action must now be taken, although other matters must, of course, continue to be examined. The fact that there is a connection with skull malformation, with microencephaly and also with Guillain-Barré syndrome due to the spread of the mosquito is, I believe, now undisputed. Now the question is: what are we doing? Do we not react until Europe is affected? I believe that we must now also support the countries concerned in taking precautionary measures, in hygiene measures and in improving waste water disposal;  for example, where the mosquito spreads, usually the conditions are not correct.  We must also remember that, of course, we will continue to press ahead with the spread of the mosquito if we do not finally do something about climate change. We do not have to wait until it becomes a problem in Europe. It will eventually become a problem in Europe, we will not be able to stop it. What I do not think we need now is for us to shoot at the mosquito with large chemical cannons. We cannot eradicate it - we have to live with it. I can only warn against the fact that genetically engineered mosquitoes are now being used. That, too, will not solve the problem, but we may be creating quite different problems, which may be more serious.  That is why the central question is: is EUR 10 million really enough? I believe that we need more, and we need a joint effort by all the Member States so that we can really make a difference.

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since the end of this epidemic, many issues still remain unclear. There is still no solid scientific basis for the connection between the Zika virus and microcephaly, nor between the Zika virus and Barré syndrome. It seems clear to us that diagnostic tests have yet to be developed to reduce misdiagnosis due to the presence of dengue, and it is not yet clear whether transmission of the virus can also take place by sexual means or by blood transfusion.  Yet, with all these undeniable uncertainties, the usual vaccine is being developed, although we know that full vaccination coverage would not debelle a virus that can be transmitted, changing from mosquito to mosquito and knowing that the time to test it is, in any case, too long.  Therefore, let us avoid making these pharmaceutical companies enrich these pharmaceutical companies again and unnecessarily with a vaccine that is not a response to this epidemic, and instead look at alternative strategies, such as the sterile mosquito technique, which would have a real and efficient effect on the spread of the virus.

name: Joëlle Mélin
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, on 1 February, I had asked, on behalf of my group, Europe of Nations and Freedoms, for the Zika epidemic to be included in the agenda. The presiding officer had refused me this on the same day that WHO declared it an emergency. The debate therefore begins six weeks later. In our view, the wording of the oral question is a good, acceptable basis for questioning the Commission. Indeed, the urgent, comprehensive and maximum assessment of this potentially pandemic viral epidemic is one of our prerogatives, but above all one of our obligations. It is the apprehension of maximum gravity, which we must identify under the principle of medical and scientific precaution, which we owe to our fellow citizens and especially to our fellow citizens. It does not matter whether the current state of knowledge of the virus, its complications, its cofactors is piecemeal or even debated. It is a true reproducible protocol for any epidemic that we must encourage. Our financial assistance must be proportionate, controlled and evaluated. The centralisation of international data - medical, technical, biological - should be a priority as early as this spring, in Europe overseas, in the Mediterranean and around the world, depending on the areas of expansion of the mosquito vector. The least toxic means of mosquito prevention and eradication in places of life and transport must be multiplied, screening kits, vaccines, for which research is three years behind, and preventive and curative treatments, must be developed. The challenge is immense, because the viral risk is global, and we must be aware of it, one of the most worrying risks there is.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, the lesson we have learned since the international community's initially unsuccessful response to the Ebola viros epidemic is that we need a comprehensive emergency response and coordination mechanism, so I welcome the Commission's decision to introduce a European Health Unit to facilitate the mobilisation of medical and public health teams and emergency equipment inside and outside the EU. Measures to respond more faster to emergencies are needed.  But we must not lose sight of long-term solutions. Although different in many respects, there is one link between the Ebola virus epidemic and Zika. Both are mostly and at least for now diseases of the poor and marginalized. The health systems of the affected countries in West Africa in case of Ebola are weakened, and in the case of Zika, the lack of access to adequate sanitation in vulnerable Communities of South America has been an important factor for the spread of the virus. The outbreak of new similar epidemics in the future can therefore only be better prevented by eradicating extreme poverty, and EU development policy plays a key role.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: Mr. President, zika virus is a danger that threatens women above proportionay. Calls to refrain from pregnancy are inappropriate, as pregnancy is often not a matter of choice especially in poorer and underdeveloped countries.  I support the UN recommendations regarding access to sexual and reproductive health services. Women in poorer areas often do not have access to information, tests and medicines. I therefore call on the Commission and the authorities of the affected countries to take into account the specific challenges and difficulties faced by women.  Currently, the danger to Europe is relatively small, but with the arrival of warmer and wetter weather, there is a chance that mosquitoes will start spreading the virus in our part of the world. If this happens, it will not be stopped by national borders, so Member States, regional authorities and the Commission must be ready to respond in a coordinated and effective way.   Furthermore, prevention is the best medicine and that is why I call on the Commission to strongly support efforts to find vaccines and to provide all necessary assistance to countries struggling with this virus.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in my opinion, there is a real need for internationally coordinated action. For the international community to coordinate fully and for the European Union to be at the forefront of this coordination. I am very glad that the Commission is not underestimating this issue. That we can say that not only do we belong to the scientific peak and we can provide our capacities, but that we should also coordinate not only these scientists, but also the Member States, to coordinate different crisis plans. We really expect this from the European Union's approach.  We need to learn how Ebola has been managed, for example, and that is what we are going to do in this particular case. I sit in the Czech Republic in the National Council for Sport and I can tell you that indeed many athletes are very frightened of what the situation will be in Brazil in particular. We should reassure them and offer our solution, which will contribute to solving this international problem.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am speaking to you on behalf of the countries of Latin America. I am president of the EuroLat Assembly. On 2 February, the Ministers of Health of fourteen Latin American countries met and moved us two messages, especially to the Commission, which I would like to convey here. First, they are asking us to establish a humanitarian emergency from the European Union to help countries, mainly in Central America, as well as Brazil and Colombia, combat this very serious epidemic, which can affect four million people by the end of this year. We are therefore asked to enable an emergency civil protection system of the European Union. And we are stressed that the European Union's research efforts, which is central to Zika research, must be concentrated in order to find the vaccine. These are the two ideas I wanted to convey today on behalf of many Latin American countries.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I echo my colleagues’ concerns on the Zika virus and the EU must support the scientific research to conclusively establish the link between the Zika virus and microcephaly, but we must also be cognisant, as has been said earlier, of the fact that simply telling women to delay pregnancy is not good enough. Many of these countries deny women access to information on their reproductive rights and concrete steps must be taken so that women have the information, support and services they require to exercise their right to determine whether and when they become pregnant. As the UN Human Rights Chief said: ‘in situations where sexual violence is rampant and sexual and reproductive health services are criminalised, efforts to halt this crisis will not be enhanced by placing the focus on advising women and girls not to become pregnant.’  So while I welcome the EU funding of EUR 10 million, I believe we must also proactively support those organisations which are trying to help women in these regions.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the Zika virus is an international health emergency, as is also reflected in the question to the Commission. Commissioner, you made the Commission's point today, recognising the urgency of this issue. I am surprised, because in most cases the Commission's reaction is late. Prevention and information of the population are known to save lives. The population must be well informed and timely and the measures presented must be taken on time. I ask you a question: I do not know how you set the sum of EUR 10 million. Why ten and eight or twenty? Do you have a study that resulted in this amount? Are there any solutions to counter the virus? What does the population need to do to protect themselves? I believe there must be much more European institutions focused on measures to protect the state of health and much more in common policies with the Member States for information and prevention.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, according to the World Health Organisation, the Zika virus epidemic, which recently occurred in Brazil and was transported from Africa, is a public health emergency of international interest, since it is expected to spread to the Americas and Europe. It should therefore be noted that the Zika virus concerns a mosquito-borne infection linked to dengue fever as well as an increase in cases of microcephaly. The European Union should therefore immediately consider the possibility of this virus being transmitted to Europe and take the necessary precautionary measures. This means that a vaccine and/or treatment against the virus will have to be found and it is necessary for the European Union to increase spending on health services in all Member States in order to offer free diagnostic tests for people with the virus symptom. Finally, the Zika virus should be a challenge for the European Union to conduct diagnostic tests and research to find the vaccine to treat the epidemic.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I too, in this speech, would like to give voice to other organisations; I have in my hands a report from Doctors of Fumigated Peoples on dengue, Zika and spraying with chemical poisons. That's why I think that before we finally take women accountable by telling them not to get pregnant, we have to have evidence.  It will allow me to read only three paragraphs from this report: "Brazil's dengue epidemic is endemic to the marginality and misery of millions of people, especially in northeastern Brazil. Now the circulation of the Zika virus is added.  Increased congenital malformations are detected in a very striking way, especially microcephaly in newborns. Brazil's Ministry of Health quickly links it to Zika virus. Although it is obvious that in the area where the sick have lived for 18 months they apply a chemical larvicide that causes malformations in mosquitoes, and that this poison (pyriproxyfen) the State applies it in the consumption water of the affected population.  Previous Zika epidemics did not lead to malformations in newborns, despite infecting 75% of countries' populations. Nor do countries like Colombia record cases of microcephaly and a lot of Zika."

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this infection is a new infection. It is a major outbreak which, in some cases, reaches the European Union and has therefore alarmed us. But it has been affecting countries with disadvantaged conditions and special weather conditions. That is why I believe that there is no alarm from the European Union, but there is no alarm, but there is an alarm to inform and make protocols for the population. On the other hand, I do believe that we are obliged to provide humanitarian aid to these most disadvantaged countries from the point of view of sanitation and public health, while at the same time put at their service all our research infrastructures to achieve the necessary vaccine and eradicate this disease. And I do not want to fail to call for the promoted and promoted respect for the sexual and reproductive health rights of all women, and especially latin American women, who, as we know, have in large part, in their countries, co-armed this right, so that, in the event that microcephaly or malformations are detected , whatever origin they have, their ability to decide whether or not to continue with pregnancy is respected.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the Zika virus outbreak has shocked the world, and once again another life-changing epidemic brings suffering to hopeful and unsuspecting families. Yesterday, in this House we called for compensation for the victims of the thalidomide tragedy. We recognised that the terrible side effects of that drug given to pregnant woman should be morally and financially compensated. With great urgency, we again look to the pharmaceutical industry for help – this time not for compensation, but for prevention.  I am surprised to see that the solution offered by the commercial abortion industry is to lobby national governments and the United Nations to introduce abortion on demand up to delivery, which goes against the moral and cultural fabric of our society and, indeed, of all humanity. Christian nations which uphold the love of life should never be bullied or bribed to kill their children. Abortion is not healthcare. It harms the mother and kills her child.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Thank you very much for the opportunity to have this exchange of views with you today. I would like to start with two points. One of them has already been mentioned many times today, namely the right of women to their own bodies and thus all questions of reproduction. This also means having to make or be able to make the decision to have a child or not to have a child, and to use all accompanying measures for this, that is to say, investigations. However, when a judgment is made in the sense that one knows that the child has been harmed, then one must also be accompanied in the decision that one makes afterwards. That is one point. The second point, which is very important to me, is the fight against the virus. I believe that we must focus on research into prevention, prevention and then treatment. However, we must now, in prevention, ensure that excessive, uncontrolled use of biocides does not in fact have the opposite effect – that, on the one hand, it may reduce the risk of the Zika virus, but on the other hand it generally brings new risks through the biocides, not only for the health of the individual, but also for our biodiversity in general. I would therefore ask that all measures here be balanced.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, it is a fact now that there is an epidemic in Brazil, but it is going to cross borders and that Southern Europe is going to be affected by Zika. I therefore believe that measures must be taken to inform the population, in all the languages understood by the population - we can see the interest in Latin America as well as in other countries - and to allow access to contraception and abortion , because we see that the blockage at the level of Brazil is that abortion is forbidden. There really needs to be a follow-up of women to see if or not they can have children with microcephaly, which is not obvious, because it is often detected at birth, but not during pregnancy. Then there is prevention. I find the example of Reunion on dengue fever quite interesting. The population has been informed and mosquito populations have been reduced. We now see that there is research on natural insecticides, that there are fish, etc., that can kill the larvae. On research, Barack Obama has pledged to spend 1.6 billion euros and you say 10 million. The only recommendation I could make is that, if a vaccine is developed, it should not be protected by a patent, since it will have been funded by public funding.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: –Mr President, let us also look at an a point in this matter that was not discussed very much in this debate today. As it happens, when a virus, a well-known virus, a virus that has been well known for decades, suddenly begins to cause strange diseases, then I think there are other things to watch out for. In particular, suspicions have been raised, and there have been reports from several places that residues of a certain insecticide from a certain multinational company can be found in the water that people normally use as drinking water at certain points. I think that the Commission should also pay attention to these contexts, if only because if a particular virus causes very serious diseases in a given region at some point, there must be other reasons for this.

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of the Commission, I have listened very carefully to this debate. It seemed to me that there were some recurring themes, themes of urgency, of comprehensiveness, and the importance of coordination, prevention and information all playing a vitally important role. I can say, on behalf of the Commission, that we will certainly take all of those into account as we continue our action to address Zika in the months to come.  I do believe that our experience of past epidemics and the structures that we already have in place stand us in good stead to make an effective and swift response to developments. Right now, as many honourable Members have stressed, we need to focus on preparing for the summer and on finding effective vaccines and medicines, both to prevent and to treat Zika virus infection. So far as the question about the sum of the money that we are able to make available is concerned, one part, as I have said, is to mobilise EUR 10 million from the EU budget. This call for research has been approved by the Member States, is expected to be launched on 15 March and will address several knowledge gaps that we have regarding the Zika virus.  Most importantly, it will examine the potential link of the virus with the epidemic of congenital brain malformations and other neurological complications observed across Latin America and French Polynesia.  Additionally, it will allow for diagnostics development and the testing of potential treatments and vaccines. That is going to be done in cooperation with the World Health Organization and other agencies, including the CDC. I think that this research should provide evidence to public health authorities on the best prevention and clinical management strategies, particularly for pregnant women, which is another of the themes that we have heard today.  This call for research will be complemented by other open Horizon 2020 calls on vaccine development with a budget of EUR 40 million euros, on vector control infrastructures with a budget of EUR 10 million and by continuing projects, including on dengue. I was asked particularly about the sterilisation of mosquitoes. My understanding is that the issue is still at the research stage, but it is one of the options on the table. So I think I am happy to pledge the Commission’s full support in addressing the challenges posed by Zika virus infection and raised today. We will of course want to keep Parliament informed. I think that this resolution is a very important element in this debate and I would like to thank Parliament for the contribution that it has made.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the next part-session. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. – It is known that the transmission of Zika virus to humans is made by the sting of an infected Aedes mosquito, especially Aedes aegypti, present in tropical areas. The rapid geographical spread of this virus, particularly in South America, requires EU support measures for health authorities in the affected countries, with a view to implementing control area strategies aimed at reducing Aedes mosquito populations. At this point, it is necessary for the EU to invest in preventive measures, which translate into scientific research to create vaccines. I am pleased to know that this is the direction the Commission is heading, and I hope that it will regularly inform Parliament of the state of the research. I am pleased to hear that the Commission's approach to the Zika virus is based on measures against serious cross-border threats to health and will work with the Member States in this regard. We need close cooperation because, in the context of the installation of summer in Europe, citizens' health may be threatened by the activation of the Zika virus in mosquito populations on our continent. The objectives we need to work on are clear: prevention and treatment of the epidemic, and the cooperation of the Member States will form the basis of these actions.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – On 1 February 2016 the World Health Organisation declared the Zika virus outbreak to be a Public Health Emergency of International Concern. I hope that we have learnt our lesson from the recent Ebola outbreak and that our experience of the past epidemics, and the structures we already have in place stand us in good stead to make an effective and swift response to developments. I welcome the EU funding of EUR 10 million to examine the potential link of the Zika virus with the epidemic of congenital brain malformations and other neurological complications observed across Latin America and French Polynesia. At the moment, the ‘risk of transmission of the Zika virus infection is extremely low in the EU’ since during the winter season the climatic conditions are not suitable for the mosquito which carries the virus. However, we are still not aware of the implications and risk of transmission of the Zika virus. We should take urgent measures on preparing for the summer climatic conditions and on finding effective vaccines and medicines, both to prevent and to treat Zika virus infection.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. – I think it is very important for the European Union to be able to respond in a timely manner to situations such as the outbreak known as Zika. I support the Commission's position and trust that together we will be able to put in a strategy that is effective. I consider information and prevention to be my number one priority. For example, the Olympic Games in Brazil are approaching, with many Europeans visiting every year. We must be sure that our citizens are aware of the way and consequences of the spread of the virus before heading to vulnerable countries. At the same time, we must support research into the development of vaccines against the virus and all possible forms of prevention.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Roberto Gualtieri, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the Banking Union - Annual Report 2015 (2015/2221(INI) - (A8-0033/2016)).

name: Roberto Gualtieri
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, the Banking Union is the most important step towards a genuine EMU since the introduction of the euro. A single supervision and a single resolution involves a significant transfer of responsibility from euro area Member States to the European institutions. This is necessary to ensure stability and restore confidence in our banks and in order to reduce and share risks by enhancing financial integration. Such a transfer or responsibility requires, however, an appropriate level of parliamentary scrutiny, of which this report represents the first concrete expression. I would like, in this regard, to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation, as well as the secretariat and all the staff for their work. I also appreciate the transparent and open dialogue we had with the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM) and the Commission. The report considers the establishment of the SSM a success, both from an operational point of view and in terms of supervisory quality. At the same time we identify some problems and margins of improvement in both areas. In particular, we underline the importance of effective coordination between micro and macro-prudential policies, as the SSM is fully part of the EU macro-prudential framework, the need for stabilisation of the supervisory and regulatory framework, as well as improving the comprehension among banks of a common supervisory approach underlying the concrete individual micro-prudential measures. We stress also the need for proportionality.  The markets need clarity and predictability on the setting of capital requirements; this has not been the case with the maximum distributable amount (MDA) threshold. The report says that the legislation’s lack of clarity on this point should not prevent the SSM from using a margin of flexibility in order to avoid too-rigid solutions that can negatively affect the AT1 bond market. For this reason, we call for a legal clarification of the MDA and the function of pillar two, which is to address only ‘bank specific’ risks. We welcome the note provided yesterday by the Commission in order to start the review process, and we think that the SSM should take it fully into account, in particular where it makes a distinction between pillar two capital requirements and capital guidance. We support the revision of options and national discretions in order to achieve a homogenisation of practices and standards. We make also some specific comments on some of the issues which have been put into the consultation.  Further steps are necessary to reinforce supervisory scrutiny of banks’ financial activity, in order to improve the capacity to look beyond credit risk to all forms of bank risks, including an in-depth analysis of financial portfolios, especially level 3 assets. The report supports the bail-in principle and its implementation. At the same time we recommend that the various choices at the disposal of the Board on the basis of the EU legislation be assessed carefully, including different resolution tools as an alternative to the liquidation of the bank, and to apply always the appropriate proportionality, fairness and flexibility which is in-built in the legislative framework, keeping in mind the importance of safeguarding financial stability and maintaining confidence in the banking system. Finally, the report calls for the completion of the Banking Union, guarantee of deposits and a common backstop. Parliament welcomes the recent package from the Commission, the European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS) proposal on the one hand and the commitment to work on risk-reduction on the other. On the former, we are working in the appropriate legislative procedure format; on the latter, it is important to emphasise that risk reduction is a broad concept which refers to a number of different possible measures. On the most controversial, related to sovereign exposures, we take note of the work of the Basel Committee and consider that any possible change should carefully be assessed and, in any case, should be done in the medium-terms in the framework of international bodies (Basel Committee on Banking Supervision) and should not affect the financing capacity of Member States and financial stability.

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Roberto Gualtieri very much for this report on the banking union. I think he gave us an excellent reminder of how much has been achieved as we have worked to overhaul Europe’s regulatory and supervisory framework in recent years. The banking union is absolutely central to this new architecture. The Single Supervisor and the Single Resolution authority already feel very well established, and it is easy to forget now that the transition of supervisory tasks from national authorities to the SSM only took place one year ago, or that the Single Resolution Board only became fully operational in January this year. So we have taken big steps forward, delivered in record time. We have helped make Europe’s banks stronger and better capitalised, and Europe’s taxpayers better protected. I would like to thank members of this committee, and also my predecessor, for the part that they have all played in this. The report covers a lot of ground, so I will just highlight some of the main points raised by Mr Gualtieri.  We agree on the need, both at EU level and of course within Member States, to tackle the non-performing loans that continue to weigh negatively on parts of the banking sector. I very much agree that we must check that our legislation is proportionate, that it is sensitive to different business models, and that it avoids unnecessary compliance requirements, particularly for the smaller banks. That is what we will look at in our review of the CRR. I also agree that we need to do everything we can to support lending to SMEs and long-term investment in infrastructure projects. So far as strengthening the banking union is concerned, here the main focus is on our proposal to create a European deposit insurance scheme (EDIS) by 2024, and that is a key part of the broader plan to deepen economic and monetary union. It will give the banking union the third leg that was always intended. We have sought to come up with a balanced approach, an approach that seeks to reduce risk as well as to mutualise it. It is vital that we pursue both sides of this equation in parallel. We need to keep up the pressure to ensure that the Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive and the Deposit Guarantee Scheme Directive are fully transposed into national legislation. We are nearly there on that. We will soon consult on the key differences in insolvency and early restructuring regimes across the EU and we will come forward before the end of the year with a proposal to apply the total loss-absorbing capacity (TLAC) standard in a way that works for Europe.  Mr Gualtieri highlighted a moment ago in his remarks his concerns about the Pillar 2 capital requirements for banks and their relationship with the capital buffers. We know that there are differences in how these rules are applied by supervisors and that is why we have now started the process of reflecting on this with Member States and here in the Parliament and with others, so that the legislation can work as it was originally intended. There needs to be a clearer difference between the goals of Pillar 1 requirements that apply to all banks and Pillar 2 requirements that are institution-specific and depend on the level of additional risk that banks bear. I am very grateful for what Mr Gualtieri said and I look forward to continuing the discussion on this very important issue.  So these were just some of the areas that struck me in the report. I share the view that we have got strong foundations on which to build and, overall, I am optimistic about the opportunity we have to refine our legislation so that we can continue to meet our prudential objectives while also supporting growth and investment in Europe.

name: Eva Paunova
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, a stable banking system means growth, jobs and stability. Recently, we have seen the largest financial institutions in some Member States experience financial turbulence. This shows that we still have a lot of work to do. This report sets the right tone and direction for reforms in the banking sector. Importantly, it calls for further risk reduction measures, which will prevent moral hazard. We clearly state that if the costs for bank failures and insolvencies are to be mutualised, the risk must be contained to the maximum extent possible. I would also underline that risk reduction should not be seen as a vague concept; there are concrete steps that can be taken. This is why we encourage the Commission to propose such measures, and the Member States to implement existing rules. The consolidation of the banking sector must come with legal certainty. This is why we also ask for clarification of the existing Maximum Distributable Amount (MDA) legislation, making it clear banks need to comply with both level I and level II capital requirements. But the key role of this report is providing a clear incentive for reducing sovereign exposure and a balanced approach towards the third pillar of the Banking Union. With this, we have made a strong statement for a prudent and forward-looking system. Having achieved an overwhelming majority in committee, I hope that we will vote in favour of this report today. With this, we would set the beginning to an important dialogue that would help us build a Banking Union in the best shape possible.

name: Elisa Ferreira
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, the banking union is, in fact, the only complete project that the Eurozone has thought of in response to the 2008 crisis. The report of the four presidents, the Commission's blueprint, the Thyssen report, all in 2012, launched the banking union and the purpose was renewed in 2015 in the report of the five presidents.  The banking union is absolutely essential for the stability of the single currency and the European financial system and it is this awareness that justifies the fundamental involvement of this Parliament. The so-called Common Rule Book, the equal rules, the single supervisory mechanism, and the single resolution mechanism were finalized with extraordinary success before the deadlines.  But let's be clear. This is an original design, it is a high risk project, it has to be refined in its details and depends on mutual trust. Similar systems we know only two, the FDIC in the United States and the German system. Both are based, as a starting point, on deposit guarantees as an essential condition of financial stability. If we do not quickly implement the stabilisation components of the banking union, in particular the third pillar, the common guarantee of deposits, at least in the version already very diluted but which we thank edis, but also the revision of the ISM, the constitution of a backstop and a common credit line, we will run serious risks of dismantling what we have already built , because in an incomplete architecture the existing pillars become dangerous factors of imbalance and not stabilization. A well-baked cake is a pleasure, but a half-baked cake is an indigestible and even dangerous meal. That's the moment we're living in.

name: Beatrix von Storch
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the We are talking today about the Banking Union. So far, this has two elements: the communitarisation of the costs of the resolution of bankrupt banks – in the end, taxpayers pay again, the Germans in particular – and a uniform banking supervision that does not work. Worse still, banking supervision and monetary policy are now mixed. We no longer have an independent monetary policy. Mr Schäuble, the CDU, has criticised this and called for an amendment to the European treaties. Ladies and gentlemen of the CDU, you unfortunately did not support my amendments in committee on the separation of supervision and monetary policy.  The third element is now the so-called common deposit guarantee. Again, my dear colleagues from the CDU, but also from the CSU, the SPD and the FDP: today it is a question of whether you want German savers to pay the losses of foreign banks in principle. The days of Sunday speeches are over. Today you have to profess color. I have requested that we vote in a matter of call on the European Deposit Guarantee Scheme in a very similar way. Then the voters, and especially the voters in Baden-Württemberg, Rhineland-Palatinate and Saxony-Anhalt, can see where you stand before the important elections.  The Alternative for Germany is opposed to the so-called European deposit guarantee.

name: Sylvie Goulard
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, the report on banking union should not be an opportunity to campaign for internal use. This is an extremely important subject on which we can finally have an overview - I thank Roberto for the clarity of his work - of what has been done in recent years. This is probably the only issue on which Europe can boast, in the last two or three years, of having taken a considerable step on extremely sensitive subjects. I'm not going to go back on what was done. I too would like to focus on the issue of the deposit guarantee system (EDIS), of which I am one of the shadow rapporteurs, to tell you a couple of things that I think are important. The first is that we urgently need to rebuild mutual trust, because this text touches on sensitive issues - the relationship of savers to their money - and, personally, I do not want to be nationalised. There are no countries in which it would be important to protect the savings that are placed in the banks and others where it would be less important. It is a matter of common interest. Health in our banking sector is also a matter of common interest. Within the euro area, the links are close enough that we are extremely vigilant. Nor should risk proposals give the impression that, overnight, we will make a difference. So we're going to have to work on trust and the conditions we can bring. In this regard, Commissioner, from my first discussions on these subjects, I note that we must guarantee that the Commission is really ready to play this role of guardian of the treaties, to provide for conditions that will be respected in the texts. Thirdly, of course, we will also be able to play on the calendar, because I believe that we need to do a good job, that this work will take a little time and that, again, for it to be a success, we have to have restored trust between us. Thank you very much for making this proposal, which is the third pillar of the banking union.

name: Rina Ronja Kari
text: gue/NGL Group. Mr President! When the big banks were rescued during the financial crisis with taxpayers' money, it was because the banks had become too big and too important to go bust. These were the so-called 'too big to fail' banks, which would draw the rest of society with them if they had gone under. A first step towards protecting taxpayers from future banking crises is therefore, of course, also to prevent banks from growing so large that taxpayers are forced to bail them out if they go bust. But the banking union does nothing about that problem! Eight years after the financial crisis, the European banking sector has become even bigger and even more concentrated, and there is still no legislation that actually addresses 'too big to fail' or looks at scaling down banks. Banks can continue to grow bigger and bigger under the banking union's false assurances that we will never have a banking crisis again. This first annual report on the Banking Union was an obvious opportunity to put "too big to fail" on the agenda. Unfortunately, Parliament has not seized this opportunity. Nor does the annual report raise any criticism of Mario Draghi's membership of the G30 Group. It's a special lodge for the banking world's top executives. Can this parliament really allow Draghi to run around a club with the directors of the very same banks that he is supposed to oversee? I really do not think we can do that, and that is why, unfortunately, we are also voting against this completely uncritical and innocuous annual report.

name: Sven Giegold
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First of all, I would like to say that it is sad how we are trying to make party politics with untruths before election campaigns. It is not a question of taxpayers being liable for deposits. It is not a question of taxpayers being held liable when banks are wound up, but rather the banking union is precisely to protect taxpayers by making creditors liable in the future and by putting the principle of the market economy back in place. And that is why it is wrong for Mrs von Storch to stir up panic here with untruths. Unfortunately, we now have to endure this in Germany as well. I must also say that I can only be surprised if you, from the left, express such strong criticism of the report. I would be pleased if you were present at the meetings in which negotiations are taking place and if you were to present your positions there. It is not right to criticise here in plenary afterwards, while the open negotiations conducted by Roberto Gualtieri are not present. This has to be said here. I would like to say one more thing to the Commission: I welcome much of what you are putting into the works. I would ask you for one thing: there are a great many points in the report that are not yet in your work programme. You have said little about them here, Mr Hill. So what are you doing about shadow banks? We explicitly ask you to do so. What are you doing to reduce arbitrage in regulation between insurance companies and banks? Finally, I am particularly interested in one subject: how do we ensure that the various signals to lower or weaken capital requirements do not ultimately come into play? We must not repeat yesterday's mistakes.

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, a point of order: the interpreter during the course of Mr Giegold’s speech said that the lady, Ms von Storch, had committed an untruth. In English, that is a lie.  Is it parliamentary language in this Chamber to call another Member of this Chamber a liar? Is it possible that the interpreter was wrong and Mr Gielgold did not say that? If he did, I have no course with that. Should we be allowing lies?

name: Presidente. –
text: We take note of your comment.

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to start by saying to Mr Giegold that German taxpayers, on the other hand, are still very exposed to banking risk, even with the introduction of the first two pillars, because, since we have not made the first real pillar – and I am addressing Commissioner Hill – namely a real banking separation, we still have universal banks that can speculate on the one hand and then have the guarantee of credit and savers. This still exists. No separation was made.  Strong powers have been heard and so we now have a second pillar that introduces the concept of the current account as an investment. A company, think that it has more than EUR 100 000 in its account to pay its employees once a month, finds itself exposed to bail-in, that is, it can be 'shaved' above EUR 100 000, provided that a solution is found for this EUR 100 000, since the ECB cannot be a lender of last resort. So we end up with an extremely fragile system.  We have acted without thinking about the causes of the banking crises but about the consequences; That is to say, this is a truly paradoxical situation with a monstrous instability of the European banking system. The markets are not stupid, they have noticed. From 1 January -40% on the stock. That is the situation we find ourselves in. And supervision does not work the way we are doing it now, because we focus on credit and credit risk and not on financial products – and I always cite Deutsche Bank and the French banks that are full of derivatives.  That way we're not going anywhere. The first pillar should be banking separation.

name: Bernard Monot
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Commissioner, if I were to take stock of the banking union for 2015, I would say that your institutional scam to save, once again, the banking lobby has worked very well for you so far. Indeed, your legislation has fallen behind the backs of citizens. In France, for example, the ratification of the banking union was done in August by ordinance, while the French were at the beach. When the insolvent banking system fails, bank customers will be trapped and will have to pay the final bill for the bailout with their savings. This disastrous "bank resolution" directive (DRB) is the theft by the European Central Bank of the banking sovereignty of the Member States and the establishment of a genuine financial totalitarianism to save, again, your euro. The deposit guarantee system, the third pillar of the banking union, planned in eight years, is a democratic decoy that will never see the light of day, because Germany does not want it. We have already seen in 2015, with the bankruptcy of the four Italian regional banks, what small savers bear when a bank resolution applies: the majority of customers are ruined and some commit suicide. The European Union is subservient to an ultraliberal ideology, that of the banking lobby. In the face of this democratic danger, the only solution is to put an end to the scheme of universal banking. Banking union is a machine for crushing peoples with insane legislation, which will only exacerbate risks and problems. But beware, Commissioner, that the anger of the sovereign peoples in their country does not turn violently against you and your fellow Eurocrats!

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). – You claim that the banking union makes the banks healthy without burdening the grassroots but supposedly the shareholders and the large depositors. It's a lie. For example, red non-performing loans, a crucial aspect of the banking union, are increasing with geometric progress in Europe and greece of the three memorandums, a result of unemployment and widespread popular poverty. The evaluation of quartet and SYRIZA government leads them to international for-profit funds, tightening the noose further and intensifying the chase in popular households. They paid for the recapitalisation of the banks by memorandum; now they will also pay for their liquidation with the loss of their housing, with thousands of auctions released. Capitalist development doesn't come your way. Your banks are in trouble, which is why the banking system is being concentrated, alternative funding from the Capital Markets Union or from assisted private insurance, which, like crows, is taking advantage of the demolition of social security. That is to say, the crisis and the recovery of capitalism will be paid for by the people if they do not choose their own path to serve their own modern needs against their capital and power.

name: Burkhard Balz (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The report on the Banking Union is a look back at the past year. It makes it clear that there are still construction sites in all three existing pillars of the Banking Union.  But before we continue to build this banking union, we must first finish what has been done so far. First and foremost, the Member States are called upon to implement and apply them. Here, however, the Commission must also monitor better and put pressure on the Member States. Because if the foundations of the banking union are not stable, every house we build on it will end up being unstable. I am very concerned to see that voices are growing in this House, which are already calling for more flexibility in the rules and more communitarisation of risks. We must first enforce the rules that we have adopted. The requirements for creditor participation are not fair-weather rules. We have adopted it because the citizens should no longer be liable for the risks of the banks. We need consistent application of creditor participation. We need a strong bail-in instrument. We want to protect the taxpayer; That is what our group stands for. We call on the Commission to implement its announcement in the communication on the Banking Union. We believe that further risk reduction in the banking sector is absolutely necessary! We are also asking you, Commissioner, for legislative proposals on this. We want to work on a stable and effective banking union, but there is still a lot of work to be done. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: Blue card question. Do you know that rules have been introduced on banks? State aid has not been possible since 2013. Four banks have recently been bailed out in Italy, on which the Commission has been very strict.  What I am asking is why it was not as severe in the rescue of a German regional bank, HSH Nordbank, which, just in October, at the same time as the Commission was strict with our banks, was granted State aid of EUR 3 billion to the German bank.  I wanted to know whether the rules only apply to the Mediterranean countries while Germany can do what it wants? How do you interpret these decisions?

name: Burkhard Balz (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. First of all, the interpretation was somewhat confusing. However, I would like to make it clear that I believe that the strict treatment of Italian banks is absolutely right. The same must apply to other banks. However, I believe, Mr Valli, that the best thing to do is, of course, to put this question to Commissioner Hill, who is also here today and can speak on the commission. I believe that, in any case, the Commission has acted absolutely correctly in the case of the Italian banks.

name: Jakob von Weizsäcker (S&D).
text: – Mr President, my thanks to Roberto Gualtieri for presenting an excellent report in which the main message is that the glass is half—full with respect to the Banking Union; half-full and not half-empty, because so much has been achieved, but half-full only because much more needs to be done to make this a workable arrangement. And because the glass is half-full the Commission’s regulatory review that is planned must not be seen as an invitation for regulatory rollback, but rather as a review that will help us to fill our regulatory glass properly. In the area of banking the challenges are obvious: the problem of non-performing loans has not yet been fully dealt with throughout the Banking Union. Capitalisation remains uneven and in particular for systemic banks not always fully satisfactory. And of course that is one of the reasons for recent market turmoil. The Commission’s proposal for bank structural reform needs to be properly implemented rather than watered down beyond recognition. Sufficient levels of MREL need to be implemented so that the 8% bail-in requirement will not be disruptive but will truly protect taxpayers. A workable European deposit insurance scheme needs to be implemented while taking into account national specificities and making certain that this goes hand in hand with further risk reduction in the banking system. One important element of this will be a credible strategy to reduce sovereign exposure of banking. So, summing up, Roberto Gualtieri’s report gives us good guidance on how to fill up a half-empty glass. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I have one very simple question. We have a Banking Union report. Is it your view that there is only one method of looking after banks in the European Union – that is, the Banking Union – or could there possibly be other methods or options available for improving growth and jobs and dealing with inflation that could be used instead of banking union?

name: Jakob von Weizsäcker (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Improving the Banking Union is neither a necessary, nor a sufficient condition to produce economic growth, but it is very important for the long-term sound functioning of our economies, and so it is important for sustainable growth. As you know, not every country in the EU is part of the Banking Union. All members of the euro area are part of the Banking Union, and that is why we are a little bit challenged, as you know, between the requirements of a currency union with respect to banking regulation and the requirements of the single market. That is what keeps our work and our committee very interesting.

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: – This report on the banking union contains some very good points. I am thinking, for example, of the fact that the stress test for large banks in the euro area is being looked at very critically. Let's go back to 2011: at that moment even the bank Dexia passed its stress test and everyone knows how that story ended.  If we want to make banks in Europe safer, we need more control, better control, stronger control. This is also important for the dossiers that we will be discussing in this House in the future. It's already been cited. The dossier on the European deposit guarantee scheme, for example, is very relevant in the context we are discussing today.  Finally, However, I regret that this report is too rosy on a number of points. For example, too little is addressed about the situation of junk loans, which banks - especially in southern Europe - are facing today. I also think that we are moving a little too quickly into Mario Draghi's statements and policies, and certainly on a day like today, that is regrettable.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I am grateful for the excellent work of the rapporteur and the co-rapporteurs on this subject. On the other hand, I regret hearing frivolities here that I don't know if they just demonstrate a bad demagogic and easy idea or an encyclopedic ignorance even about what democracy is.  The truth is that banking union is the most substantial, probably, that has been done against the demagogigic, destructive renationalisation of the future of European citizens, and the most substantial thing that has been done in recent years for the prosperity and security of future generations of Europeans.  I know that progress is being made, I know that it is technically complex, and we will not go into detail, since here we are to talk about politics, but it is important to have the public informed that we are moving forward, towards greater security, which is what democracies are based on. Faster, more zealously and with more fair-play in the treatment of countries; However, I urge the Commission to continue firmly without hearing renationalising siren chants.  (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – Mr President, I, too, agree that this is a very important achievement: the Banking Union. Although, as we've heard, it's not complete. However, I would like to ask you whether you really consider it to be such an achievement that you lack a few pillars, such as the third pillar: the common deposit guarantee scheme and, in general, a common safety net. How much do you still see them as necessary?

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon (ALDE)
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Szanyi, I think it is a success in construction, but certainly a success, so far, the mere fact that you have started the journey. Let's do it better and faster.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, eight years after the start of the crisis, banking has received almost EUR 700 billion of public funds – equivalent to five EU budgets – and yet the big banks in the north are now the main black hole in the European economy: Deutsche Bank has exposure to high-risk products of EUR 60 trillion , twenty times the German gross domestic product.  The European authorities have proved useless in planting the big bench, to end its disproportionate dimensions and to put order in their accounts. When the insolvency status of the big banks brings us closer to a new financial crisis, it is delusional to say, as the report does, that the first year of banking union has been a success. For what has been a very effective success this project is to help impose structural reforms on blood and fire in the southern countries, without it being important to violate their sovereignty or plunge their populations into misery.  In this sense, the role played by the supervisory body in the financial coup against the Greek people in June 2015 was disgraceful. The result was the closure of Greek banks with catastrophic consequences for greek economy and sovereignty. Today's report tiptoes over this scandal.  Ladies and gentlemen, your institutions are a danger to Europe's sovereignty and stability. We can change this situation. Let's get down to business.

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, a long, long time ago in a distant age before man landed on the moon, before the internet and mobile phones, even before the Eurovision Song Contest, there was an idea of a new country rising out of Europe, a new empire – the United States of Europe. In that new empire there would be a need for a new currency and also a new bank – the European Central Bank. That bank would improve the productivity, the employment chances, the opportunities for European citizens.  We will move ourselves forward to today. We have unemployment averaging 11%, youth unemployment in many countries over 30%, productivity down, GDP down. Today the world has moved on, but the European Union and its ideas have not. They are stuck in the past. There are very talented people and it is very sad. There are very talented people like Commissioner Hill, who are trying to complete an old idea from an old past into the modern world. All of which should give us one solution. Think of those countries outside the euro area that are prospering. There are ideas better than the one that you already have today. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – I hear that you are looking back to the times of Hastings and 1066, but then you had the Vikings over you. One would think, listening to you, that all problems come from Brussels. But if you look at the problems of the United Kingdom, was it not more Blair and Brown than Brussels that caused the problems in the UK? Would it not be a fairly good idea, if you have banks covering the European market, not to have a jungle of different regulations, but one regulation in common that we decide on together? Can you tell me, do you prefer a jungle of different national regulations to one common one that is opening up the market?

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – It is always a pleasure to receive questions from you, Mr Hökmark. One of the things that is very important is the idea that you say a jungle – while I say competitive regulations across the globe – which is resulting in the fact that in the euro area you have high unemployment, negative inflation, almost deflation, and low productivity, when those countries, like the United Kingdom, which are outside of the euro area, which has a more flexible competitive basis , are the ones that are seeing high growth, high employment levels, high productivity, much better than those in the European Union.  The question you have to ask yourself is, by having one single set of rules, why is it that that one single set of rules is destroying Europe, while those who have competitive rules are improving across the globe?

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the major problem we face in the Banking Union is the transfer of authority to the Single Supervisory Mechanism. We have all seen what it means that, in tense situations, you cannot make decisions on internal issues and have to wait for a centralised decision from Brussels. I would like to point out that each Member State has a banking market differentiated according to standard of living and consumer behaviour. I consider it a priority, at this stage of the report, to clearly highlight those instruments which will remain at the disposal of the Member States, in order to be able to ensure independence and security in the event of crisis situations. The second problem is the economic gap between Member States. The Banking Union will not be able to achieve it as long as the European Commission has not met its objectives of standardliving and, in the event of future crises, I believe that it is necessary for the banking security of the Member States to be ensured exclusively and independently of national banks, because they have historical experience, adapted to the internal problems of those countries.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – Mr President, the Banking Union is a tool for an integration process that seeks to use the economic and banking crisis to justify the creation of an ever closer Union. In a report published in June 2015, the five Presidents outlined the characteristics of a genuine, close, equitable economic and monetary union. Monetary union cannot function because it is not possible to develop the same monetary policy for such different countries. The trade surplus of the central countries has caused huge imbalances, and thus the Union has disintegrated into a group of creditor and debtor countries, and they are not trying to find a solution to this issue. A united Europe cannot be achieved because there is no unified European people who can empower a democratic European government to manage its affairs.

name: Werner Langen (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the This report is a good work of hard work: with positive things in the first year of the Banking Union, but also without sufficiently critical consideration. I would like to start with the first point: the separation of monetary and political and banking supervision is not guaranteed. We need treaty changes here. You can see where that leads at the moment. While equity ratios have risen across Europe, lending, especially in southern Europe, has declined.  The second point is that large banks and small and medium-sized enterprises must meet the same conditions. This was not planned from the outset, but it is now a practice.
