What this bureaucratic burden leads to, for example, is shown by the Ana loans, according to which every loan from EUR 25 0000 onwards is to be reported to the ECB – one can only shake one's head. There is no risk-based valuation for government bonds – and this has not been sufficiently appreciated in the report. Mr Giegold has ridden his favourite horse: he wants a level playing field for financial services and insurance benefits, even though they are very different and we have decided something completely different in the legislation.  That is why I would like to conclude by reminding you of the history of its creation. The banking union was created because Spain did not want to go into the bailout fund. France, Belgium and Luxembourg have taken this opportunity to save Dexia. I remember that within 24 hours Mr Almunia approved state aid to Dexia amounting to EUR 24 billion, and now all this is to be covered by the deposit guarantee. I am convinced that this is a mistake.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to agree with Mr Balz, who says that we must continue what we have started, because if we do not do so, then, according to a nice formula: 'we do enough to take the blame; but we don't do enough to take the credit'.  If we think we need to get to the bottom of what we have started, then, ladies and gentlemen, we are still missing more than you mentioned. We need a back stop and a deposit guarantee, otherwise what we have acquired will backfire. I want us to be able to really move forward in a determined way in this direction. I intend here or there to set up a debate on the theme "we must reduce risks in order to be able to share them". But behind this pretty concept lies a fundamental debate about the place of sovereign debt. I am surprised that the same people who refuse to take into account an international approach in this area, at the same time, want to eliminate the consideration of sovereign debts in a sustainable way and, for themselves, refuse to make sovereign debts a tool that escapes speculation, by subjecting them to taxation on financial transactions. It seems to me that there is a time when to choose.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: – Mr President, are we ordering more bills from southern Europe again? I can guarantee that they will start to come if a euro area-wide deposit guarantee scheme is introduced. I understand the concern expressed in the Gualtier report, and of course I will sign it myself. Trust is the foundation of all banking. Citizens do not deposit a single euro into their savings account without confidence that the money will also remain in storage. The banking sectors in the north and south are very different, the risks are different. A common deposit guarantee scheme covering the euro area would bring stability and faith mainly to those Member States where alarm bells should actually ring. That is why I am opposed to the Gualtier report.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, mr. Colleague, when you talk about paying the bill for the countries of the south, think carefully about what money was being moved from the countries of the South to the countries of the Centre, in particular to save European trade banking, and in particular German commercial banking. But having said that, after €700 billion from taxpayers directly buried in European banks, much more needs to be done than to continue to justify the unjustifiable. As it stands, the banking union is nothing more than a commercial, but misleading. Note: the guarantee pillar for the common deposit guarantee, which would be the most important, is yet to begin. If we think about what is the single mechanism of resolution, the least we can say is that it is insufficient and still a mirage, and if we think about the existence of the single supervisor who was what came into force in the first place, then it is not even worth talking about.  About two years ago in force and when it was needed it didn't work. Look at what happened in my country, Banif, a bank that was bankrupt two years ago when single supervision came into effect, and yet no one noticed it. What's the matter? No one explains. Responsibilities? No one does. Let's stop the misleading advertising, please.

name: Esther de Lange (PPE).
text: – I hear a colleague say that we must finish what we started. And indeed, the banking union was one of the greatest achievements of the last parliamentary term, with the aim of not making citizens pay for irresponsible risks from banks.  If I were to give most of my colleagues here a blank sheet, they would undoubtedly sign a banking union with three pillars: supervision, resolutions and also the guarantee of deposits. But a great deal has happened in times of crisis and trust between Member States has been very much affected. Moreover, we should not pretend that the guarantee of deposits is not already regulated through the national systems we have. Now that the third pillar is in a hurry, while that trust is still broken and the risk reduction, even the agreements we made with each other in the first two pillars, would not be guaranteed to build on quicksand.  So we don't just have to finish what we started. Above all, we must do what we agreed with each other. And just as we have a no creditor worst off criterion, we also need to have a no member state worst off criterion. I am for a third pillar, but not in haste! So do it carefully, or we'll build on quicksand. [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, I am very sensitive to your arguments, but the question I am asking you is this: you keep saying that we must avoid charging taxpayers. Do you consider that taxpayers do not also have bank accounts and that they will not be called as collateral on their deposits or even their savings, as happened in December 2015 in Italy, in the banks that went bankrupt? So "taxpayer" for me, equals "customer in the banks." What do you think?

name: Esther de Lange (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Exactly. Therefore, look at the rules. The rules already are that deposits of up to EUR 200 000 are guaranteed through the national schemes. If banks are irresponsible and give their clients products that are high-risk without informing them, that is a consumer issue, but not a deposit guarantee issue. What I am afraid of is if Member States – and I do not mention any – try to find a way around the ‘bail in’ principle, which we actually have in order to reduce risk and to reduce moral hazard, then that is basically saying that we do not want bail in, so we want to give the bill back to the taxpayer and back towards the state. I am afraid that some Member States do not want to send the bill to their own Member State, but to another one. This is why I said we should work towards a third pillar, but with no Member State worse off.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on this magnificent report, Roberto Gualtieri, who I think very well synthesizes the progress of recent years in the construction of this banking union; of this truly Europeanist project, which, in addition to Being a Europeanist, has allowed the euro area to be stabilised in recent years, although it is obviously still far from recovery, for which we would need stronger fiscal policy. In any event, this report makes clear the need to move forward, as all my colleagues or most of my colleagues have said, and I am grateful that a large majority in this House is perceived in favour of building that third pillar of the banking union that we need, with that deposit insurance, and that we also need faster and more stronger than the current timetable that we are shuffling in this House. In any event, such a debate can never be linked to a review of the legal nature of public debt. I think it is important to reduce the risks; that it is important that supervision of financial institutions reduces and minimizes risks; Transparency of banks' balance sheets is important; but really, bringing about a qualitative change in the definition and treatment of public debt could once again trigger the financial fragmentation of the euro area, which is exactly what we are trying to avoid with the banking union. Therefore, that path goes directly online contrary to the banking union; therefore we cannot move forward there, especially if we take into account that it would be only for the banking union, having a common market and therefore different substantial treatments for financial institutions within the Union. So thank you very much and let's push that deposit insurance. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Werner Langen (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague for his work You said that the banking union was a huge success. Now, however, we have the problems that monetary policy and banking supervision are not separate, and that the ECB is now determines the level of risks and therefore wants to limit cash. That is one side, and the second is that it wants to abolish the EUR 500 notes. Do you think this is a success, this project, or how do you see it? Do you see this critically or as a success that the ECB now wants to introduce negative interest rates because the economy in southern Europe is not getting going?

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Langen, I believe that the banking union has gone in the right direction and that the problems between monetary policy and supervisory work are present or were previously present in many countries like ours , if there are those problems, because supervision is really autonomous from the exercise of monetary policy.  In any case, the problems we still have in recovering growth in the euro area are not due to potential monetary policy problems but, essentially, to the absence of a fiscal pillar in the euro area and, above all, to the absence of commitment to the euro area as a whole in some countries, which continue to maintain budgetary surpluses , huge current account surpluses that complicate and hinder the exit from the crisis of many southern economies.

name: Stanisław Ożóg (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Due to the short time limit only a few issues. In theory, the Deposit Guarantee Scheme initiative is, from the euro area's point of view, the logical consequence of work on the next elements of the Banking Union. However, a number of concerns are raised, inter alia, by the planned rules for collecting contributions to the common deposit insurance fund being created. It is very likely that the costs of creating this system will be borne by the customers of the institution.  From the perspective of my country, Polish, as a country with a significant share of foreign capital in the internal financial market, I consider the actions of these bodies to be unfavourable in this situation. Customers of these banks will bear the costs of creating the system, even though Poland is not a member of the Banking Union. We also have no guarantee that the DSA will reduce the risk of costs resulting from mis-management and bank failure in other countries.

name: Fabio De Masi (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the A new financial crisis is looming. The casino is growing faster than the real economy because the EU is falling into a coma and the cheap money of central banks and the super-rich does not know where to go, despite negative interest rates. In Italy, a pensioner even hanged himself because the bank had turned on risky Coco bonds and he lost his life savings. But this is a failure of banking supervision. Small savers must be protected, but not by creating loopholes again. The liability of bank shareholders and creditors is only credible if ticking time bombs like Deutsche Bank are smashed, as US central bankers demand. Deposit and credit must be separated from investment banking so that zombie banks cannot continue to blackmail taxpayers. We need a state guarantee for small savers, for pensioners, but not for casino banks. Only then can a deposit guarantee, which is certainly necessary, be responsible, but savings banks with their own institution insurance must be exempted from this.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first to those colleagues campaigning for fragmentation. You could have a campaign theme: ‘we want more bureaucracies because we love bureaucracy’ or ‘the more bureaucracies the better’; something like that, I am only trying to help.  Regarding the discussion here about banks, my thanks to the rapporteur, but the main problem we see today in Europe is not the lack of regulation in the banking sector but rather the other way around, because we are now seeing an adaptation, an adjustment, to the decisions we have taken and that are now entering into force. What we see is the lack of growth, lack of investment, and in that perspective to hinder banks from market-making, investment-making, from creating liquidity would be to create even bigger problems because there is no regulation that can compensate for the lack of growth or unemployment. So let us be clear: we will not solve any problems by separating banks, and there is no majority for that. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Elisa Ferreira (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Hökmark, thank you very much for all the work you have done on the BRRD. My question relates precisely to that. It implies bail-in, so costs to the owners of the banks. But are you aware that a substantial part of the European banking industry is safeguarded from this – and I am speaking in particular about the German banks – because there is a kind of big IPS that hides, through so-called ‘private’ funding, all the bail-in mechanisms and protects them from the pure application of bail-in? There is no transparency in relation to the state aid mechanisms that, through this, are being introduced in the market. Are you aware of that? Do you follow that? Does this concern you?

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for your question, Mrs Ferreira. First of all, the idea with the bail-in is that the taxpayers are not to be required to pay for the losses. In this legislation, which I was happy to be responsible for in this Parliament together with you and others, I say that we together revitalised capitalism in the banking sector and I would like to thank you for those efforts. But this also means, in Germany or in Sweden or in Portugal, that there will be no taxpayers’ money involved in the bank until you have dealt with the 8%. How you do that can be different. Of course, we shall follow up and see what is happening and that all member countries are adapting to the legislation. I think that is important to do in Portugal, in Italy, in Germany and in Sweden.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the single supervisory mechanism set up within the banking union to supposedly contribute to the stability of the financial system has proved not to be sufficient to reorganise banks. As a result of the economic crisis trillions of euros of public money has been allocated to rescue the banks by burdening the public debt of the states, all at a time when the funds allocated to unemployment are scarce. In Greece there were three recapitalisations of banks that increased public debt and socialized the losses of banks. In fact, the third memorandum again sold the banks to private individuals and crows instead of a lentil plate, resulting in the state being damaged by thirty billion euros. And as if that were not the case, the banks, after being rescued, are now selling the red home loans to for-profit funds and crows preparing to hammer the houses of the Greeks. But this is something that the Greek people will not allow.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 149(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: Blue card question. I wanted to ask my colleague whether he believes that, in this increasingly globalised world, few banks are better but very large, rather than many small banks on the ground? We're actually seeing that the little ones on the ground are being incorporated to create bigger and bigger monsters.  Do you think that what is happening now is better in economics, or would there be another solution?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), answer a question with a blue card. Mr Buonanno, in Greece the solution given to small banks, and in particular to small housing banks, is unacceptable, and it is unacceptable because several of them should have been supported. However, these small banks were not supported, resulting in liquidation. I believe that the banks which are in the region, the cooperative banks, should be supported, because they are the ones that contribute to the real economy. In relation to the recapitalisation process in Greece, what we saw was that private individuals who had before, and thus the state lost thirty billion euros, should be taken back instead of a lentil plate.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I thank Mr Gualtieri for this report and those who contributed to it: a very good report! I would also like to thank Commissioner Hill and the entire European Commission for finally having a legislative proposal on the table for the third pillar of the banking union which, of course, is also the most difficult: the achievement of this 'European bank deposit guarantee mechanism'. I would like to point out, however, Commissioner: I have been surprised to hear statements by some presidents of major European banks, who say that we should no longer continue with the efforts for the Banking Union, because the European Union has enough problems. The word "disintegration" was even used. I believe that, here, the European Commission should talk more to these bank presidents to clarify why the banking union is still needed. Finally, another point that I want to highlight. In my country, banks are ready to sell packages of non-performing loans at 10% of face value, but do not have an openness to borrowers to renegotiate loans with them, especially for housing.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Originally, the Banking Union was originally intended as supervision. Of course, we all thought that the more people talk about the banks and supervise them, the better. It is now clear – from the point of view of German savers and pensioners: we are dealing here with a communitarisation of risks. In plain language, this means that the German saver is liable for the rip-off of foreign banks.  My experience in my life has always been the same: if everyone is responsible for everything, then in the end no one is responsible! This banking union in this constitution is absolutely irresponsible. Incidentally , here comes my ceterum censeo, as you already know – I believe that the euro in Europe only leads to strife and discord and must therefore be abolished.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. When we take stock of the Banking Union, we have to state critically that the Bank Resolution Directive has not yet been transposed by all Member States, that the current Deposit Guarantee Directive has not yet been transposed by all Member States, and at the same time new proposals are being made. That is why I urge you to ensure that the rules that are adopted are implemented, implemented and applied in all Member States before we get further proposals, such as the completely wrong proposal for EDIS, on the table. A second point I would like to make briefly: the principle of proportionality. Not every problem in Europe needs to be solved by European supervision. I would mention, for example, the contributions to the resolution fund, where the Commission is now suddenly coming up with proposals that the big banks will have to pay less and the small banks will have to pay more. I would like to mention the keyword remuneration guidelines from CRD IV, which should also apply to the smallest bank anywhere in Europe. And I want to name Ana-Kredit, this database that triggers a passion for collecting and generates no economic added value at all. So there is still a lot of work to be done before new proposals come along.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the Banking Union has been, in my view, the most important European project to have emerged from our common European reflection on the crisis. It allows us to leave the bailout era and enter a bail-in universe but, with this shift, new obligations and conditions for debt and capital-holders are being created. There has been some time to adapt to these changes but they appear not to have been fully assimilated yet.  The immediate challenge is therefore to communicate better on the new regime to investors and other market participants. In particular, I believe retail investors, who are likely to be the most vulnerable, should reach a better understanding of their rights and obligations under the bail-in regime. We can see also wide divergences today in the way the BRRD has been implemented, in particular as regards the provisions relating to the order in which the creditors of a bank in resolution are repaid.  The system would gain in efficiency, credibility and predictability, and we would move closer to a level playing field, if more harmonisation was brought into this area.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D). Mr President, I congratulate the rapporteur on this important report. I will begin by saying that before I got involved in politics I had heard that in the European Union we have common rules but many times these common rules are not impartial, and that is what we have before us now.  When the banking union was designed in the first place, Commissioner, the banking union had and will make sense since it will include all three pillars and of course the deposit guarantee. I remember when you were appointed and we had this conversation. Without the third pillar, the union is not just lacking, it is biased against small banks and small Member States. Depositors must be treated in the same way, which they do not, banks must be treated in the same way as they do not, so the longer it takes, the more risks they face.

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The Banking Union is indeed a difficult test that we are facing. I would like to add to what has already been said: on the one hand, I believe that, as is customary in politics, we must start with what reality shows. We have the euro area, and that is why the comments made by colleagues in the ECR Group here that the euro area is the problem are somewhat unworldly, because we need to see how we can find a solution from today's reality. The banks, the financial industry, are there to serve the real economy. This has been forgotten a bit after the scandals in the banking crisis. A great deal has rightly been created of new regulation. Commissioner, I am also very grateful to you for wanting to turn your gaze back in the direction of how we can strengthen the financial sector in such a way that it is once again more able to serve the real economy unbureaucratically. That is what our efforts must be directed towards. I would like to thank the rapporteur for the fact that there are corresponding passages in the report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, this banking union does not solve anything. The supervisory system is ineffective, the resolution system and its fund are short and insufficient, even after shareholder losses, so taxpayers will surely be called back to pay to save the systemic banks. Just read the legislation, the regulation says, and I quote: "an effective resolution regime should minimise the costs to be borne by taxpayers", or another expression, "with minimal costs for taxpayers and the real economy", is the regulation itself that says so. It is, moreover, significant, that this banking union should proceed before the promised restructuring of the banking system with a pseudo-separation which represents another scoff.  Let us be clear, for us there is no solid solution without a recovery of public control of banking and the financial system. Only then will we have a financial system at the service of the economy and truly safe for citizens.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Gualtieri for his report. I just want to make three brief points to the Commissioner. Banking Union is crucial for jobs and growth, especially across the eurozone. We need to have a strong Banking Union. Where we need to retrofit the project and improve the project, we should do that. I also believe that the Commission is right to now initiate a review. Where changes need to occur, we should be honest enough to admit those changes need to occur. I do not think we should do it in a partisan way. We have had to do this very quickly. It has been an extraordinary project – the mandate of the previous Parliament – but we should always be prepared to change what we have if it is not working. My final remark is this, Commissioner: it is all about the lending environment. We see too many banks still not in a position to lend to SME growth and development across Europe and across the eurozone especially. It is important that we keep capital reserves, that the new architecture on SSM is correct, and that the new stress tests are right, but we have to make sure that the final high street banks actually start delivering real growth to the European economy. Otherwise, we are not going to see progress.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, this week in Ireland, our Central Bank destroyed EUR 500 million, the legacy of being forced to bail out two non-systemic banks and also the legacy of the fact that what we are doing here is trying to erect pillars that should have been put in place when the euro currency was actually launched back in 1999. Last year we similarly destroyed EUR 2 billion, in 2014 EUR 1 billion, and in 2011 EUR 3 billion: a total of EUR 6 billion. The Bank is still holding EUR 25 billion awaiting the same fate.  I want to know what the Council, the Commission and the ECB will do to apply these new rules retrospectively and save Ireland and the Irish people from this obscenity – this destruction of EUR 31 billion. This is the fifth time I have tried to get an answer about this. Can the Commission please listen? Stop chatting among yourselves and show a bit of bloody respect for the people who get elected here, rather than looking at your coffee and looking at the internet while we are talking to you! Answer the question: what are you going to do to retrospectively help Ireland, which is being forced eventually to burn EUR 31 billion? It may not be a lot in your economy, but it is a damn large amount of money in our economy, and there are people hungry because of it. So answer the question and respect my mandate and everyone else’s please.

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for the debate, which I think has covered a range of issues, some of them on the Banking Union. I think it is worth reminding ourselves, as Mr von Weizsäcker did, of this question of whether the glass is half-full or half—empty. I think it is a good opportunity to remind ourselves of how far we have actually come and to think of the process, for instance, of the stress tests and the fact that our banking system is stronger, more resilient, better capitalised than it was before this work started.  In terms of the question that was raised about trust, I think this lies at the heart of how we are going to be able to address the work we need to do on Banking Union if we are to go forward. I think that underlines the approach we have taken with the EDIS proposal and the associated Risk Reduction Communication, because we are going to have to build trust and take both sides of the equation forward together.  I agree with the points that were made about the importance of implementing existing legislation and honouring commitments that have already been entered into. As I said before, there is progress being made on the transposition of that regulation. We return to it regularly in the Ecofin Council every time we meet and the Member States are nearly there with that.  On the question of sovereign exposure, which was raised by Mr Gualtieri in his remarks, I concur with the prudent line that I think was set out in his report on possible prudential treatments of sovereign exposures. Our approach should be part of a coordinated effort at the global level and that issue is currently being discussed at the Economic and Financial Committee and in the Basel Committee. Any future Commission action would obviously be informed by those discussions.  The important issue of the backstop was also raised. Member States agreed on an approach for bridge financing and have agreed that there needs to be an appropriate backstop by 2024. That issue was also mentioned in our Communication on risk reduction measures.  With regard to the question of shadow banking, I will make a couple of points on that. Firstly, the Securities Financing Transaction Regulation came into force last year and that is a big step forward for monitoring shadow banking. The MiFID legislation will also play a role. I hope that we will be able to make some more progress on the money market funds file in the Council where I think we have greater prospects of progress. Obviously, I will stay alert to any emerging risks that there are on the shadow banking side.  Finally, one of the recurring themes there has been from all sides of the House is points made about proportionality and that does lie behind the thinking for having the call for evidence and wanting to look at the effect of the legislation that we have already passed, not to bring the architecture of that legislation –architecture like the Banking Union – into question , but to ask ourselves, as Mr Hayes said, whether we have got everything right and whether the legislation is working in the most effective way to encourage investment, make it possible for businesses to lend, make it possible for capital to flow to businesses that want to invest and grow. That issue of proportionality will be looked at as part of that call for evidence. It will also be looked at as part of our CRR review and I think the need that we have to balance micro- and macro-prudential requirements is one that I have very much in the forefront of my mind.  I am very grateful to Mr Gualtieri and the shadow rapporteurs for the report and for the work they have done for this debate. I look forward to future reports and I hope that we will be able to demonstrate more of the progress that I know colleagues are keen to see and that we keep up the pace on strengthening our banking system.

name: Roberto Gualtieri
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it has been a lively debate, which has touched on many aspects, which obviously should not make us lose the fact that the main characteristic of the report and its fundamental purpose was to analyse in great detail and precisely the various aspects of the actual exercise of this first year of single supervision, to identify what worked but also the one that worked least well and that must be corrected. In this respect, there are many specific proposals, as Sven Giegold mentioned, and we naturally expect the Commission, the SSM, the SRM – which we would also like to invite to a special meeting of the ECON Committee – to give us precise answers on the points we have raised.  Then, of course, I understand that the SREP methodology, the optionals and national discretions, the MDA threshold – I very much appreciate what the Commission has said – the need to maintain the support factor for SMEs are issues that may be less passionate about a debate in this House than the major ideological disputes about bail-in, bail-out, the separation of banks and all the issues that we should be discussing. , although this debate should be based on reality, facts and a little less ideology.  Therefore, we must not lose sight of the fact that the report states that the rules must be respected but that, at the same time, the rules fortunately also contain the possibility of taking measures that do not have a negative effect on financial stability, and this flexibility, which Mr Balz mentioned, is positive. What is happening in Germany is a good thing, where an institution is being set up that can prevent bail-in and in some cases also provide refreshments for bondholders. That's a good thing.  We must welcome the intelligent use of the rules we have set ourselves, because I believe that financial stability is a primary asset. Just as it is worth recalling the facts, namely that the Euro-area wide deposit insurance scheme (EDIS) does not provide for any use of taxpayers' money and, finally, I very much welcome the fact that the Commissioner appreciated the cautious approach taken by the report to the issue of sovereign debts, an issue that should only be addressed within the framework of Basel.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place today, Thursday, 10 March 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. – In the field of banking, we need more Europe. That is why I support the creation of a European Banking Union. This is a way to manage cash flows better and uniquely and strengthen monetary union. This will also create the necessary stability of the banking sector. An additional argument is certainly the possibility that through a uniform high level of deposits, financed from the financial sector, it guarantees citizens that they will not run out of their money and that banks will not be saved with taxpayers' money.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – It is important to ensure that the direction towards Banking Union is maintained. However it is equally important that the impact of changes Banking Union brings in its wake are tracked in an effective way, and for corrective measures to be taken as necessary and quickly, not when it is too late.  It cannot simply be assumed that moves towards Banking Union will be uniformly beneficial. On the contrary, if seen as ‘one-size-fits-all’ solutions, such changes may not effectively address the different economic and financial realities present in Member States.  More attention should be paid to the impact of the new rules introduced with the Banking Union, especially on the changing operating costs of banks and on bank lending propensities, in view of the investment gap that has persisted in the Union over the past years. An in-depth study of the impact of the Banking Union as it is being implemented on bank credit in general and SMEs in particular, needs to be carried out with the aim of mitigating any negative consequences in this regard. Most importantly, we should ensure that the needs of certain Member States are not taken into account at the expense of other Member States.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is a debate on seven motions for resolutions on cases of violations of human rights, democracy and the rule of law — Freedom of expression in Kazakhstan.

name: Tatjana Ždanoka Vice-Chair of the Delegation to the EU-Kazakhstan EU-Kyrgyzstan EU-Uzbekistan and EU-Tajikistan Parliamentary Cooperation Committees and for relations with Turkmenistan and Mongolia.
text: – Madam President, I will speak now in my capacity as Vice—Chair of the Central Asia Delegation. In this capacity, I prefer mutually respectful, equal dialogue with Kazakhstan. The EU has a vital interest in stepping up strategic cooperation with such an important international actor as Kazakhstan. Therefore, I would like to pose the following question to my colleagues. Unless it decently calls into question Kazakhstan’s ambition to be a candidate for a non-permanent seat on the UN Security Council in 2017-2018, do we have the moral right, as cavalierly as is made out in the resolution, to teach Kazakhstan on the questions concerning freedom of expression while we ourselves behave badly in the very same area? Last December our Parliament accepted the resolution saying that measures taken over the past few years in Hungary have led to a serious systematic deterioration in the situation as regards the rule of law and fundamental rights, inter alia freedom of expression. This January we hotly debated the rule of law and media independence in Poland.  In my own country, Latvia, the parliament has just adopted at first reading new provisions in criminal law which are aimed at sentencing to imprisonment for even non—violent actions against the state, that is independence, sovereignty, territorial integrity, and also for cooperation with foreign organisations against the security interests of the state.  I myself sharply condemn attacks on freedom of expression elsewhere in the world. Therefore, I am sure that we have to fight for these freedoms together, but not against each other.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Kazakhstan continues to be serious despite its recommendations and trade relations. Minorities continue to report harassment by the police and local authorities. Some opposition politicians continue to be arbitrarily detained; security officials have been accused of systematically using torture and ill-treatment of civil society activists. The Kazakh Government severely restricts freedom of assembly, speech and religion.  Despite numerous requests from the international community to make progress on freedom of expression, the government has adopted new legislation which de facto restricts it even more. We express our deep concern at the state of civil society, anti-government opponents and journalists in the country. We call on the European Union, including through existing bilateral agreements, to demand effective investigations and appropriate sanctions from the Kazakh authorities for the culprits. We would not like to think that the different sensitivity we show in similar cases of human rights violations is dictated by the presence of interests that are placed on a higher level.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: Author. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I will not talk about the situation in Latvia, like President Ždanoka, I want to talk about Kazakhstan. In this country I was seven times, I was not only in the capital (first it was Almaty, now Almaty; now the capital is Astana), but I drove two thousand kilometers by car. I think I know this country and in general it would be good if we spoke when we know the specifics of the country. We recently had a debate about refugees. I was in refugee camps, so I also knew what I was talking about. The situation in the region is specific: there, freedom of expression and freedom of the media are perceived differently than would be perceived by our European standards. This amendment should therefore be adopted, but this resolution also states that Kazakhstan is our very important strategic partner.

name: Tunne Kelam
text: author. – Madam President, I would say to Commissioner Hahn that we are deeply worried about freedom of expression in Kazakhstan. The recent signing of the enhanced PCA was actually a welcome and mutually beneficial step, but such a relationship must be based on shared values and democratic reforms. This is not lecturing a partner; this is about shared values. Vladimir Kozlov;  journalist Seztkazy Matayev; bloggers Ermek Narymbayev, Serikzhan Mambetalin and Bolatbek Blylov.  There are signals of increasing repression of critical voices. It is especially alarming that just around the signing of the PCA last December, criminal cases were launched against independent journalists and editors of the Nakanune.kz website, Guzyal Baidalinova and Yuliya Kozlova, who were merely accused of spreading false information. I also called for the release of the opposition leader Vladimir Kozlov, several journalists, such as Seztkazy Matayev, and bloggers, such as Ermek Narymbayev, Serikzhan Mambetalin and Bolatbek Blylov. Even if their names sound like they come from a faraway country, we feel very close to them in a spirit of solidarity. We demand that they be able to exercise their freedom of expression with the dignity of truly free citizens.

name: Urmas Paet
text: author. – Madam President, the situation on the freedom of expression in Kazakhstan has deteriorated in recent years. Independent media outlets, journalists and bloggers frequently suffer arrests and pressure from authorities just for doing their job and exercising their right to voice an opinion. People are even harassed for being active in social media. We call on the Kazakhstan authorities to ensure that human rights are respected and that the media and civil society be able to carry out their activities without fear of harassment.  EU enhanced relations with Kazakhstan are linked to concrete human rights improvements. The Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) with the EU must be linked to developments in democracy, rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms in Kazakhstan.  While I am most delighted that Kazakhstan has joined the World Trade Organization, it is also important that Kazakhstan fulfil its international obligations in other spheres and follow the rule of law and guarantee legal certainty for international companies operating in Kazakhstan and the protection of their investments.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: Author. – Madam President, Kazakhstan is the richest non-European post-Soviet country, mainly because of its oil reserves. The European Union considers it a key ally for geopolitical and economic interests. However, inequalities in Kazakhstan worsen, corruption soars, and politicians and businessmen get confused. Kazakhstan is drifting into an authoritarian regime. All criticism is pursued, whether it comes from political opposition, journalists or bloggers. Labour rights are in dramatic recession, ILO standards are systematically violated and trade unions are criminalized. The situation in prisons is very worrying. The mistreatment of political prisoners is constant. In this context, the European Union is reviewing its Central Asia Strategy and appears to be simply based on geopolitical and economic objectives, regardless of human rights, once again. It is urgent that we start to worry about the human rights situation in those States that we consider partners. The European Union should not partner with human rights violators.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the arrests and detentions of journalists and bloggers last December, in some cases, just a few days before the signing of the strengthened partnership and cooperation agreement between the EU and Kazakhstan, which contains clear clauses on respect for human rights and freedom of the media and freedom of expression, are a very worrying sign for the European Community.  In addition to the recent cases which are mentioned in the text of the resolution, it seems that the Kazakh authorities are also moving internationally, seeking to silence the media that had already been banned in Kazakhstan, but which continue to work abroad, such as Res publica, which is currently fighting lawsuits brought by Kazakhstan in American courts.  The frequent use of the article in the Criminal Code on the inspiration for social hatred, which is very vague and often used in the event of a lack of evidence and valid arguments, against individuals critical of the authorities, remains particularly worrying. For all this, it is essential that this resolution be adopted.

name: Jiří Pospíšil
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I want to join my pre-speechers and the authors of the text. I think it is right that we are debating the state of human rights and freedom of expression issues in Kazakhstan.  At the moment when Kazakhstan, as has already been said, has signed a strategic agreement with us on an enhanced partnership, then we must be interested in how our partner is opposed to fundamental human freedoms, the right to public expression, the right to assembly, etc. This is important at the moment, when in a few days early elections are held in Kazakhstan. This must also be said, in a few days there are early parliamentary elections in Kazakhstan and we should monitor whether they will comply with the basic principles of free and secret elections. It has already been mentioned here, and the resolution details the suppression of the rights of journalists, bloggers, opposition politicians. Kazakhstan must be challenged if it wants to continue to be our strategic partner, and we want it to release these imprisoned politicians, bloggers, journalists. Otherwise, it is difficult to work closely together in the future.

name: Marju Lauristin
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to express my sincere in/ 20 – I would like to assure the Social Democrats that, on the one hand, the Kazakhs' aspiration to be a partner for the European Union is very important and we support it, but on the other hand it further increases our demand for Kazakhstan to follow and follow the principles that are in our cooperation agreement. And the current situation here shows a very sharp and growing contradiction. The Kazakh authorities are engaged in the pursuit of opposition leaders even when they have gained political asylum in European Union countries and are taking every opportunity to trace, as has already been said here, the media that has actually gone outside Kazakhstan.  So we very much hope that, in this situation, where the cooperation agreement with Kazakhstan must be approved by the parliaments of all the Member States, and also by us here, we would pay close attention to the fact that Kazakhstan actually fulfils these obligations and all the democratic freedoms and fundamental rights for the protection of all the democratic freedoms and fundamental rights provided for both in this Treaty and, by the way, in Kazakhstan's own Constitution. I therefore very much support this resolution and also call on all our Members to pay attention to the current situation in Kazakhstan in their Member States and to the possibility of improving this situation now through our pressure.

name: Илхан Кючюк
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Like all countries in the region, Kazakhstan is a country with a rich history that has been part of the Soviet Union for many years. Our relations with Kazakhstan are of particular importance, given that the country was the first in Central Asia to sign a cooperation agreement with the European Union, as a result of which we have significant joint projects. And although 25 years has been searching for its democratic identity, we cannot ignore the fact that the political system is showing signs of oligarchy. Moreover, in recent years we have seen a deterioration in overall respect for democratic standards, human rights and fundamental freedoms in Kazakhstan. The arrest of journalists and bloggers for performing their functions are acts that the European Union must strongly oppose.  In this regard, I call on the Kazakhstan authorities to act in accordance with international obligations and their commitments to the OSC, to refrain from using politically motivated accusations against critical journalists, independent media and citizens who are unreasonably detained, to be released immediately. (The Speaker agrees to answer a question asked by raising a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Dear colleague, as you know, the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and Kazakhstan still has to be ratified by some of EU Member States’ parliaments. Do you not think that, taking into consideration this situation, we should call on some of the Member States’ parliaments to slow down the ratification so that Kazakhstan implements the EU recommendations on the protection of freedom, freedom of assembly and the respect for human rights?

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – I totally agree with you. Kazakhstan must fulfil all its commitments, all international standards, respect human rights and freedoms, and then we can enter into a deeper conversation with them.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). Madam President, after the overthrow of socialism and the dissolution of the Soviet Union, it is revealed what is the so-called democracy and freedom imposed on its peoples. We categorically condemn the state violence of the Kazakh government, the suppression of democratic rights and popular freedoms, the class labour movement and the communists by banning the Kazakh Communist Party. The report, the joint report of all the political groups, silences these facts. It does not mention a word about the murderous police attack on the striking demonstrators in the city of Zanaozen, the death and injury of dozens of them, the pogrom of persecution against dozens of other militants, nor does it mention anything about the law on suffocating control of trade unions.  The supposed concern of the European Union and Parliament is hypocritical and selective, as similar measures are also being implemented in its Member States with the help of these bodies. We express our full solidarity with the communists and the Kazakh class movement.  Hands off the Kazakh communists!

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, we all know in this chamber that freedom of expression is a prerequisite for democracy, not only for individual citizens, but especially for journalists. Defending a free exchange of views is not only undemocratic, but also counterproductive, because the dissemination of independent information can be reduced, but it can never be completely suppressed.  It is doubly reprehensible if, to suppress freedom of speech, the state uses vicarious charges such as drug possession, as is the case in Kazakhstan. I myself had the opportunity to meet personally with representatives of independent media in Kazakhstan and I would therefore like to draw attention to the inaccuracy in recital D of the preamble to our resolution. Journalist Julia Kozlova has not been cleared of all charges. She is still accused of spreading false information, which can lead to a conviction of up to seven years. It is therefore necessary to continue to monitor and support her case and all others who are fighting for freedom of expression in Kazakhstan.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Dear Commissioner, Mr Khan, honourable colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Han, for his excellent work. Of course, the situation with freedom of expression in Kazakhstan is far from ideal. There is still much to be done here, both for the Kazakh Government and for civil society. I know a number of blog resources and journalists, including Vladimir Kozlov's wife, personally, because before I became a Member of the European Parliament here, I gave them the opportunity to speak and express their views as a journalist, because they did not have the opportunity in Kazakhstan. But in reality, this is something else. How can we teach Kazakhstan, given what is happening to us in our own homes? Recently, in my country, Latvia, a man named Maksim Koptelov was sentenced to a real half-year prison sentence just for having written on the Internet about the possible addition of Latvia to Russia, which was a joke, he added. We Socialists condemn this position, but it is also a huge violation of freedom of expression.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Kazakhstan has become the first country in Central Asia to have an EPCA with the EU. We expect these enhanced bilateral relations to compliment Kazakhstan’s efforts on political and democratic reforms and to go further within this framework. Despite the strong relationship with Kazakhstan, we have to point out the growing pressure on independent media outlets and the environment in which civil society works.  The extensive list of journalists harassed by the authorities is worrying. Even when fighting extremism and terrorism, freedom of expression cannot be compromised. This should particularly apply in a pre-electoral environment so that voters can freely choose their candidates. With respect to the upcoming early parliamentary elections already taking place on 20 March, I would like to underline the importance of full OSCE/ODIHR recommendations.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the state-controlled economy in Kazakhstan has been severely affected by the fall in the price of oil. The national currency has lost half its value since last summer and all indications are that the crisis will continue during 2016. In these conditions of harsh economic crisis, the people's dissatisfaction is expressed. The rights of minorities, in particular the Russian element, must therefore be respected, as must the will of the People of Kazakhstan. But the regime silences freedom of the press, civil society organisations, violates workers' rights and collective freedoms.  The European Union must send a decisive signal to Kazakhstan, which is an important trading partner of the Union. In Central Asia there must be stability and development, but this goes through respect for human rights and the peaceful coexistence of Christians and Muslims.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as always, we are commenting on a very serious situation of profound violations of human rights. Inhuman and degrading treatment, torture, an increasingly pressing denial of freedom of expression, media which are in fact controlled by administrative manoeuvres, on the pretext of national security. Not to mention the constant harassment and intimidation suffered by journalists who, in some way, try to continue to do their duty, as happened for example to the Adam-bol newspaper in December 2014.  By now, the Attorney-General in Kazakhstan even has the option of blocking access to Internet content if it is deemed extremist and is even a threat to national security without a judicial ruling. It was in 2015 that the crime of incitement to discord was introduced into the new criminal code, which also punished representatives of NGOs, who are eventually prevented from playing their part in civil society. This is the picture of Kazakhstan.  I now call on you, as always, not to apply double standards. As always, we must not allow our values and the defence of human rights to be sold off per cubic metre of gas or a barrel of oil, and I hope you will remember this as in so many other cases. Consistency!

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I will be going after my colleague Castaldo. Indeed, the new criminal code adopted in Kazakhstan is of great concern and great emotion. My colleague mentioned here one aspect of the offences that is in place, I would mention the other. That's a restriction on freedom of association. Kazakhstan is clearly afraid of the ruling regime there if people can gather if they can demonstrate. Of course, independent media are the main feature of a free democratic rule of law, but freedom of association is also one of those essential components of the rule of law. Parliamentary elections were also mentioned here. Well, I'm worried about how the parliamentary elections are going to go, when the presidential ones that were going on, the candidates who were against Mr. Nazarbaya, themselves in the campaign, said that he was the best candidate. It is just a semblance that, unfortunately, Kazakhstan presents to us as a semblance of the rule of law. This idea, this idea is of course very remote. And it is important that the European Union is simply active in this matter.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the European Union closely follows the human rights situation in Kazakhstan. Freedom of expression should be guaranteed under Kazakhstan’s constitution. It is a matter of international human rights – and we see human dimension commitments – and this is priority for the European Union. The European Union has been at the forefront of calling for an improvement of the situation, and has consistently raised issues related to freedom of expression in its bilateral discussions with Kazakhstan.  The European Union is concerned at the increasing pressure on the independent press. Over the past two years a number of publications have been shut down or have received disproportionate fines. We believe that this not only has an impact on the publications concerned, but also leads others to exercise self-censorship. There are also limitations on freedom of expression online, most recently seen with the arrest and prosecution of a number of bloggers for statements made on social media. We welcome the fact that three of these bloggers were recently released, though we deplore that they were released with restrictions imposed on their movement.  Our concerns focus not only on specific individual cases, but also the legislative framework which provides for criminal sanctions, for defamation, denigration of honour and dignity. In particular, we have urged Kazakhstan to consider revising Article 174 of the Criminal Code, which imposes criminal sanctions for broadly worded offences and has been used to prosecute activists and bloggers. The European Union consistently emphasised the importance of freedom of expression for the development of a democratic society in Kazakhstan throughout the process of negotiating the enhanced partnership and cooperation agreement. During her visit to Astana on 21 December last year to sign this agreement the Vice-President/High Representative raised with her counterparts the importance of strengthening the resilience of societies through the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms. The European Union has also been consistent in empowering civil society in Kazakhstan and promoting press freedom and the freedom of expression under the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights. The European Union stands ready to work together with all partners concerned in addressing this particular issue.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place today, Thursday, 10 March 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The EU-Kazakhstan partnership is gradually growing stronger with the ambition to become a strategic one. In order to achieve this it has to be clear that both sides share the same basic democratic values and principles. Freedom of expression is one of those principles that we have to protect and promote. Cases of imprisonment of opposition politicians such as Vladimir Kozlov, and convictions of journalists and bloggers show that Kazakh authorities must be urged to respect these rights. That is why I support this motion for a resolution.

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Kazakhstan is a member of the UN, the OSCE, the Venetian Commission of the Council of Europe and a party to the Eu-Wide Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, which not only concerns trade but also places great emphasis on democracy, the rule of law, the protection of fundamental rights and the independence of the judiciary. Regardless of all the international obligations and standards that a sovereign state has voluntarily adopted, respect for democracy and human rights in Kazakhstan is of concern to the international community. The arrests of journalists, bloggers and human rights defenders disenfranchising them violate the foundations of democracy. Without independent media, there is no rule of law. The political situation must be assessed on the basis of actions, not declarations by the governing bodies. Already in June 2008 and again in May 2009, following kazakhstan's forthcoming OSCE presidency, the Country's Foreign Minister committed himself to improving the human rights situation in Kazakhstan. Over the course of 8 years, the only thing that has changed has been the names of subsequent detainees and political prisoners, as exempled by European Parliament resolutions, reports of international organisations and the accounts of persecuted citizens. It is time to take real measures to enforce the declared reforms.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is a debate on eight motions for resolutions on cases of violations of human rights, democracy and the rule of law – the case of Egypt, notably Giulio Regeni.

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: author. – Madam President, the human rights situation in Egypt is dramatic and getting worse. The Egyptian authorities are repressing fundamental freedoms. Demonstrations are de facto banned. Human rights defenders are harassed. NGOs are threatened with closure.  Anyone who is arrested in Egypt is at serious risk. People are arbitrarily detained and held for weeks without contact with the outside world. Human rights organisations have recorded many cases of so-called ‘disappeared detainees’ in cases of Egyptians who died in detention. Torture is widespread and prison conditions are appalling.  Those responsible for human rights violations against detainees are almost never brought to justice. When I visited Egypt a few weeks ago the dead body of the Italian researcher Giulio Regeni had just been discovered. I found it very telling that in my meetings with very different people – activists, journalists and diplomats – they related his death to the many incidents of human rights violations in the country. Many suggested that members of the security apparatus were responsible.  The EU has to send clear messages to Egypt. Repression of fundamental freedoms will not lead to a prosperous and stable Egypt. As long as there is no substantial improvement in Egypt’s human rights record, EU Member States shall not become complicit and shall maintain restrictions on weapons exports to the country.

name: Bas Belder
text: Author. – The horrific murder of Italian scientist Regeni has the potential to affect relations between Egypt and the EU. It is therefore essential to avoid premature conclusions and await the outcome of the joint Egyptian/Italian investigation. Under President al-Sisi, 90 destroyed churches have been restored and that deserves credit. One concern is the blasphemy legislation, which recently gave four young Copts severe penalties. The EU should press for the cancellation of this blasphemy legislation and president al-Sisi to visit pardons. Finally, the EU accession candidate should address Turkey on its subversive policy towards Egypt. Because from Turkish territoir, Egyptian Muslim brothers in television broadcasts call for the killing of journalists, judges and even President al-Sisi in Egypt.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Giulio Regeni was a European boy, a boy driven by the desire to contribute to the construction of a better society, a free society. His research work has led him to handle uncomfortable topics for the Egyptian authorities, dangerous truths systematically obscured by the media and politics. His desire to give a voice to those who cannot have it has led him to be barbarically tortured and killed in circumstances that are still uncceptably obscure. Giulio Regeni could have been our brother, your son or your nephew, a European boy thirsting for truth.  The European Union must adopt, despite its very strong links with Egypt, a firm and decisive position, which will lead us to ask for clarity on the circumstances of Giulio Regeni's death, because there must be no doubt that the smell of power and interests is the stench of Regeni's blood. We dedicate this sign to his friends and family. Truth for Giulio Regeni. .

name: Mario Borghezio
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, of course, truth and also justice for Giulio Regeni: I tried to ask the AFET Commission for it but I was blocked. Mr Mogherini was present and did not say a word about the Regeni case. The resolution that we have not signed, signed by all the parties, is a little stump: it seems to be an indictment only against this regime, which in this case has certainly been responsible for highly recensorable behaviour.  But, I wonder, when Egypt was under Morsi's leadership and those Muslim Brotherhood democrats were in power, the European Union made no criticism: they were democratic, they were for freedom of the press, they protected human rights. Well, we are tired of this alternating current human rights protection and something should also be said about trying to involve a poor boy, a decent person like Regeni, in activities that have probably been guided by research centres linked to British Intelligence.  But these are sensitive issues and therefore should not be dealt with.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: Author. – Commissioner, we consider this case of Giulio Regeni to be a real deterrent, because it raises concerns in all of us about the security of staying in Egypt. The European Union is still working intensively with this country and is counting on it as a strategic partner on its side in the future. So such cases are all the more shocking in the context of Egypt's further development and the new constitution. I am glad that, for the first time in history, Egypt has committed itself to admit to an investigation by a foreign team, that is, an Italian team. This is certainly a clear step forward, but it is not enough. I would therefore like to call on the Egyptian authorities, on the part of the European People's Party, to make every effort to ensure the safety of all citizens of the European Union, regardless of their political or religious affiliation, and to investigate this very serious case.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: author. – Madam President, as we mourn the lost life of a bright Italian student, the injustice and the torture that occur too often in Egypt hits home. The push for justice in this case should be as strong as in all cases of forced disappearances in Egypt. There were 1 700 instances in 2015, according to NGOs, who see the involvement of security services in the methods of torture inflicted. We will hold the Egyptian authorities to their promise to fully cooperate with the Italian and international experts in this case. We need independent and credible investigations, which is something that does not happen at all in most cases in Egypt. There is more impunity than justice, unfortunately.  I am very concerned about the large-scale campaign the Sisi government is conducting to detain critics, journalists, human rights defenders and political opponents. Since 2013, more than 22 000 people have been detained, according to the Egyptian authorities themselves. It is high time that the EU speaks out and at least stops the export of technological systems that help human rights violations. It is an illusion to find in Egypt a strong partner and an ally in fighting terrorism, without safeguarding the rights and freedoms of Egyptians. I truly wonder why the lessons from the recent past are not more decisively guiding EU policies because the reasons for the uprisings in 2011 are still present and we need to take those into consideration.

name: Curzio Maltese
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, five weeks have passed since Giulio Regeni's death and every week the Egyptian authorities have changed their minds to this tragedy, which now has the full appearance of a political assassination carried out on the orders of the Al-Sisi regime against a brave young European researcher. At this time, my government has not found the dignity to denounce this macabre mockery and the strength to act accordingly, breaking off many political and economic relations with the Al-Sisi regime, signed in the name of a common fight against terrorism.  A promise that sounds grotesque on the mouth of a dictator who makes everyday terrorism his main instrument of government. Today, this Parliament is voting on an act of dignity: that is a good thing, but it is not enough. We must stop considering liberticidal regimes such as Al-Sisi's Egypt or Erdogan's Turkey as allies of Europe and provide them with resources that are used to oppress their peoples. By denying our values in this way, we are not fighting against but in favour of terrorism. .

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament not only condemns the torture and murder of Giulio Regeni, but also calls for all documents and information to be handed over to the Italian authorities in order to conduct, together with the Italian investigative authorities, a rapid, transparent and impartial investigation, in order to obtain truth. Egypt must stop the practice of enforced disappearances and torture, it must review the repressive law on protest of November 2013, used to quell peaceful dissent. Egypt must also release those detained only for reasons of freedom of expression and ensure that civil society organisations and independent trade unions operate freely. I would like to address you, Mr Hahn: Egypt is undoubtedly an important partner for the European Union. But it can't be at all costs. And we cannot and do not want to close our eyes to what has happened and is happening.

name: Stanislav Polčák
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, it must be allowed that the current Egypt is not in a simple situation. However, this in no way justifies disproportionate actions by public authorities to grossly interfere with fundamental human rights and freedoms. Giulio Regeni's case is extraordinaryly tragic, but perhaps even worse is the fact that it is one of the cases of institutionalized practice. This is because state authorities deal with uncomfortable people in a way that in no way conforms to the standards of the modern state. This is what Egypt wants to be, given the content of the January 2014 Constitutional Charter, but it is not. The reason is clear. The contradiction between what is written in the Constitution and how it is applied is intolerable and must be condemned. Hundreds and thousands of people have disappeared at the hands of Egyptian security forces. No conclusion is given other than that the scheme does not meet the requirements of the democratic rule of law.

name: Isabella De Monte
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are talking about a resolution on the violation of human rights in Egypt, but in particular it talks about the issue of Giulio Regeni, his death. Giulio Regeni was a young researcher, a fellow country man of mine who was full of hope and who had his whole life ahead of him. Giulio had gone to Cairo to deepen his studies, but unfortunately there he died as a result of unspeakable torture.  Egypt has returned the body but has not yet returned the truth and I think it does not exist in its trade or strategic relationship that can allow us to back down in the face of the search for the truth. I believe that we owe this to him, we owe it to his family, to his friends, we owe it to the community of Fiumicello, his country of origin, but I also believe that we owe it to the many young people who have yet to be able to believe in freedom and who must be able to believe in the right to life, which no one can take away.

name: Klaus Buchner
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Human rights and the rule of law are central values of the Union, and it is part of the trade strategy that we pay increasing attention to ensuring that these values are respected by our trading partners as well.  Unfortunately, however, we have to admit that human rights are being trampled underfoot almost everywhere in the Middle East. But the special situation in Egypt is that the situation has deteriorated dramatically in recent years. The government seems to want to stop all political activity, even activity in the sense of that government. That is why this resolution, which I hope we will adopt today, is here at just the right time. I urge the Commission to ensure that the trade restrictions proposed there are actually implemented.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are here to condemn a barbaric and atrocious murder, a senseless horror. We consider intolerable the attempts at misdeeds just hours after death, the ambiguities and murky manoeuvres to cover up the obvious signs of heinous and merciless torture, which make us think of a possible internal power struggle between different apparatuses of the state in Egypt.  Today, we are calling on Egypt to demonstrate in practice its willingness to shed light on the death of Giulio Regeni, to punish those who are genuinely responsible and not those who are comfortable, to immediately stop the very serious violations of human rights and freedom of expression and opinion, because geopolitical and energy interests cannot justify unjustifiable terrorism, because extremist terrorism is not combated by state terror.  We call on the Eu ropean Union and the Member States to share all the information in their possession, because we cannot remain silent at any price. Today, ladies and gentlemen, it is not enough to commemorate Giulio's death: today we must act and demand that everyone do their part. We want truth and justice for Giuglio Regeni. Truth and justice.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: – Madam President, today we are here to condemn Giulio's death, but also to remember that many of those who admired activists in Egypt died as they died over the past five years. And to say that the future, international relations, respect for victims, are only built from the truth; a truth that is hidden from us, over and over again, in this case.  Giulio is not an isolated case; it is part of a long list of journalists, activists, lawyers or human rights defenders who have been arrested, and some killed or tortured, during recent years in Egypt.  And today we are here to say that his death was not in vain, that his tolerance inspires us. And it inspires us in such a way that today we say that, in the name of the fight against terrorism, we will no longer close our eyes, that the best struggle for stability in a strategic country like Egypt , which is – is respect for freedoms. And that must be said loud and clear to your authorities.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I strongly condemn the atrocious killing of Giulio Regeni and express my solidarity with the relatives of the victim. We need an independent, credible investigation into his death. Sadly the case of Giulio follows a long list, running into hundreds, of enforced disappearances that have occurred in Egypt since the military takeover. We demand justice for Giulio and his family; we also demand justice for the number of Egyptians who continue to suffer a similar fate on a daily basis. The security forces and the judiciary have failed to hold officers to account in cases where citizens have been tortured to death, or which involved excessive use of force.  The Egyptian authorities urgently need to repeal the repressive protest law and all other repressive legislations that are being used for internal repression under the pretext of security of the state. We need to take all the necessary steps to ensure the Egyptian Government does carry out these reforms in order to maintain peace and stability in Egypt.

name: Antonio Tajani (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Egypt is an important partner of the European Union, it is an important country for stability in the Mediterranean area. But we cannot trade our values for commercial interests or political interests. The dialogue with a country like Egypt is also based on the necessary and indispensable collaboration for respect for and protection of the rights of the individual. It is the European Union's duty to defend the dignity of the individual and human rights outside the Union's borders as well. I would have liked the High Representative to have taken stronger action, perhaps I would have liked to see it here today, as we would have liked to see it more active on the case of the two Italians murdered in Libya, just as we would have liked to see it more active on the issue of the two navy riflemen unjustly detained in India. Europe must make its voice heard in order to defend its values first and foremost.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe must stand shoulder to shoulder with Italy on the path that must lead to full light on the tragic death of Giulio Regeni in Egypt.  It is necessary to reaffirm, in the words of the Italian Foreign Minister, Paolo Gentiloni, that truths of convenience will not be accepted, truths such as those that the Egyptian Government is trying to propine in these hours. What happened in Egypt to Giulio Regeni requires us all to react decisively: Europe must strongly demand clarity on the death of the young researcher, and must also demand explanations of the human rights violations committed in that country.  Egypt, which is also an important partner of the European Union, must respect human rights and its obligations towards freedom of expression, religion and belief. Italy must have Europe at its side in order to arrive at the truth about the death of Giulio Regeni: we owe it to Giulio Regeni himself and to our dignity as European citizens.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, recently in this Chamber we have expressed strong concerns about the violation of human rights in Egypt. The murder in Egypt of Giulio Regeni, a citizen of the European Union, overflowed the glass. We condemn the murder of Giulio Regeni, express our condolences to his family and express our sympathy to the italian colleagues who took the floor a moment ago. The European Union must send a decisive signal to Egypt, which must respect human rights, and the Egyptian leadership must realise that the suppression of democratic freedoms and the Egyptian people is butter on the bread of the jihadists, who are lurking to get the rematch. It is a given that the European Union must in the most unequivocal way express its condemnation of the murder of Giulio Regeni .

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, first of all I share the deep sympathy for the family and the countrymen of Giulio Regeni.
