I subscribe to the fact that unconditionally this has to be independently investigated.  But I am concerned that this is ‘just’ one out of hundreds and thousands of cases. I really wonder what the authorities and institutions are shifting with Egypt. But what concerns me even more is that yesterday we spoke about the relevance of the partnership with Turkey, and despite what Erdoğan is doing, we will rushing into the liberalisation of visas and will be opening chapters.  A few minutes ago we discussed Kazakhstan. We have signed an agreement at a time when we know what kind of a regime we are dealing with. So, again, Egypt is a relevant partner and I subscribe to it, I understand that. But Commissioner, for once please leave your notes aside and give us a clue as to how we should refine and shape our policy towards Egypt so that we really contribute to a different situation in the future and a really strong partnership.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, ten years ago the women trade unionists in Mahala showed us Egypt calling for freedom, social justice and bread. Mubarak was the child pampered by the United States and Europe. Unfortunately, freedom, justice, or bread, but another coup d'am arrived, with a regime whose army the United States continues to pay more than 1 billion euros a year, or to which European Union countries continue to sell arms. The regime handed down 1,700 death sentences or arrested 3,000 people last year. The democratic union struggle continues, and that's what Giulio Regeni wanted to tell us. That's why he was terribly tortured and murdered. Egypt is a strategic partner of the European Union and the European Union should not let this go without anything happening. The thing is, I very much doubt that the European Union of insolidarity will act in this case, because it uses human rights only when it is interested.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I, in this case for such a serious matter, would like to stress that if Europe were indeed a united Europe, it should simply say to Egypt 'either you tell the truth about what happened to Giulio Regeni or we block any development and any economic and diplomatic relationship'.  This would simply be enough to make Egypt understand that neither Regeni's family nor Regeni's family, which is no longer there, nor an entire continent that expects answers while the Egyptian Government continues to give very different and conflicting versions, can be made fun of. That would be enough.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is clear that Europe's credibility is at stake. What is at stake is the credibility of giving truth, of protecting a path of deepening and investigation, which is not yet independent and an investigation that is not guaranteed. We are therefore here to urge that words be moved to deeds, that words should be given the condition of being able to give transparency to a death, to a tragedy of a young man, Giulio Regeni, who sought his identity belonging to a system that was different from the one he had lived.  Therefore, we strongly believe that High Representative Mogherini must guarantee this transparency, this truth. We believe that our Italian Government, first of all, must fulfill the condition of breaking off trade relations at this time, because verification and deepening of the truth is a priority over any other issue.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Madam President, as a British Member of the European Parliament I express our concern, with our Italian colleagues, over the case of Giulio Regeni and indeed for all victims of human rights abuse in Egypt and amongst the Egyptian people. In my speech I want to speak in favour of the paragraph which asked Mr Hahn and his European Commission colleagues to specifically regulate the European export of surveillance equipment used for repression in the light of the latest Privacy International Report, which suggests that such exports were made by Nokia Siemens from Germany and the Hacking Team based in Italy. The Egyptian Government has developed and maintained, within its own intelligence infrastructure, a secret unit with an extensive budget and mass surveillance capabilities, with no public scrutiny whatsoever. I believe the European companies involved in these exports are in breach of the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights and I ask for European action to ensure such complicity becomes illegal under European law.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the circumstances of giulio regeni's tragic and brutal death must be explored by an independent and impartial investigation, although unfortunately it is doubtful to me whether the full truth will ever be revealed. In any case, it seems clear that the young man was not the victim of a simple crime, but that his death had something to do with his political views and activities. This is unacceptable, even if it happened in a country whose social conditions and security situation are murky, even more disturbing, five years after the revolution than before the revolution. We must not let EU citizens end up like this with impunity, Europe must show solidarity with Italy and we must do everything we can to make sure that this situation never happens again.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, truth and justice for Giulio Regeni are a duty, a commitment, a necessary research for the European institutions all. We must be sure that no European economic reality is involved in surveillance, punishment and torture, which are unfortunately taking place in the country in question, Egypt. We have a situation of repeated violations of human rights, which our joint resolution reminds us, as our commitment to combating this situation with everything, all our strength, all our efforts.  I believe that a figure like Giulio Regeni's should lead us to reflect, to discuss, especially the youngest, the young people who engage in politics and who want to change the world. I think that Giulio himself has, with his research, with his studies, tried to change things. He can't have paid with his life for his quest for the truth.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I think we share the same view and we were all shocked at the discovery of Giulio Regeni’s dead body on 3 February in Cairo after he disappeared on 25 January. The torture and death of this young Italian PhD student in Cairo is not only a personal tragedy for all who knew him, but an unacceptable tragedy for the entire European Union, for the institutions and for the people. I think this has been expressed by all the speakers today.  Vice-President/High Representative Mogherini has personally raised Giulio Regeni’s murder twice with Egyptian Foreign Minister Shoukry and stressed the need to conduct a thorough independent and transparent investigation in close cooperation with the Italian authorities in order to shed full light on the circumstances and to bring the perpetrators to justice. The case was also raised by the EEAS and Commission officials in Cairo during bilateral talks with the Egyptian authorities in February. The High Representative and the External Action Service are following this case in close cooperation and consultation with the Italian Government.  The European Union attaches great importance to the protection and promotion of human rights in each and every country, Egypt included. To mention just one other recent example, we made a number of interventions over attempts to close down the El Nadim Centre which treats torture victims.  The protection and promotion of human rights, democracy and the rule of law are guiding principles of the Union’s external action and policies. In 2015 the European Union revived bilateral relations with Egypt in the framework of the Accession Agreement which had been on hold since 2010. The objective was to re-engage across key areas including democracy and human rights and to establish cooperation in fields of mutual interest. In November last year in Cairo we resumed the political and human rights dialogue with Egypt, the first such meeting for five years. The Commission and EEAS officials maintain regular contact with civil society organisations and human rights organisation and defenders, and Vice-President/High Representative Mogherini made the point of meeting these organisations in her visit to Cairo four months ago. We are also currently working with EU Member States on a statement on the human rights situation in Egypt to be delivered at the UN Human Rights Council on 15 March in Geneva. The European Union Special Representative is planning to visit the country in the coming months so as to continue engaging actively with Egypt on human rights matters. I can assure you that we will continue to do what we can, together with the Italian authorities, to ensure that the full truth comes out, and that those responsible for Giulio Regeni’s brutal torture and murder will face justice, but we are also working to prevent such unacceptable prejudice in the future. We will continue to call for and support a full implementation of the 2014 Constitution, reforms in the area of governance and rule of law and progress in the human rights situation in view of the aspirations of the Egyptian people for democracy and stability. May I add that we are, in the course of our cooperation and work with Egypt, ready to support civil society organisations, in particular addressing all these issues working for democracy in the country, and this is one of the targets of our policy in and with Egypt.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over.  The vote will take place today, Thursday, 10 March 2016. Declarations in Iras (Article 162)

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. Allow me first of all to express my closeness to the family of Giulio Regeni.  The murder of the young Italian researcher is an event that strikes us for its drama, an event on which we cannot afford to accept half-truths or convenient answers. The Egyptian authorities have a duty to work with Italian investigators to shed light on this sad affair, the latest case in a long list of abuses and violations repeatedly denounced by various NGOs active on Egyptian territory. Transparent and independent investigations must be able to guarantee justice for this unacceptable case of violence.  A peaceful stabilisation of Egypt's political reality cannot be achieved through practices that deny the core of human rights and fundamental freedoms. The prohibition of torture and the affirmation of the rule of law are among the values that best express the very essence of European reality. A prosperous and stable Egypt will only take place with a transition that embraces respect for fully democratic values. European action must therefore move strongly in this direction, and to this end I signed the motion on which we will be voting shortly.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. The murder of Giulio Regeni highlights all the flaws and dark sides of a country that claims to be democratic.  Egypt's 2014 Constitution, which enshrines fundamental rights and freedoms for its citizens, constantly clashes with the reality of arbitrary detentions (22,000 since July 2013), torture perpetrated against government opponents and threats against the center of El Nadim, a place of rehabilitation of victims of violence targeted with false arguments that would like to see it closed.  The case of Giulio Regeni is part of this framework of violations of fundamental human rights for which Egypt is responsible, in breach of Article 2 of the Association Agreement with the EU. I believe that the European Union, through the High Representative, must act urgently and firmly, in consultation with the Member States and the Egyptian authorities, so that clarity can be made as to when it happened to our young fellow countryman and what continues to happen in the country. I also believe that we must leave no unturned in order to intercept and punish those responsible for certain terrible events and urge the Egyptian Government to ensure that we can operate freely in the country, following the path mapped out by the agreements with the Union.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is a debate on seven motions for resolutions on cases of violations of human rights, democracy and the rule of law — Democratic Republic of congo.

name: Jordi Sebastià
text: Author. – Madam President, the deterioration of the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo is obvious and very serious.  President Kabila's maneuvers to perpetuate himself in power, even though the country's own Constitution is preventing it, are causing many protests by opposition parties and civil society in general. These protests are harshly suppressed, and we already know that there have been many fatalities.  This situation joins in the suffering of the absolutely unbearable poverty suffered by most of the people of the Democratic Republic of the Congo and also to violence, to this covert "low-intensity" war, but which is very harsh and that the populations of the north and northeast are suffering, and which also hits women much more.  I am therefore pleased that this Joint Resolution, signed by most groups in this House, is forceful to require President Kabila to respect human rights, to respect the legislation and to take steps to make it clear that it will not be perpetuated in power against the will of those who approved the Constitution, against the will of his people.  But I would also like this Resolution to include some reference to the issue of trade in minerals from conflict zones. This is not just a purely political issue of a character who does not want to respect the laws; behind it is quite an economic explanation, there is a whole blood trade with minerals that are generating this situation and from which the European Union takes advantage.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: Author. We are at a pivotal moment for the Democratic Republic of Congo. For months, opposition, NGOs, academics and even President Kabila's government partners have been crying out for change and respect for the constitution.  Actually, the president has no political future anymore. But he would like to add another unconstitutional term of office. In the meantime, the political climate and the human rights situation are deteriorating considerably. There is only one wisdom in congo, and that is that of silence. Human rights activists, journalists and opposition members have been hunted wild: persecuted, imprisoned, sometimes murdered. Even young people who protest peacefully are not spared.  I would particularly like to mention the names of 'Fred Bauma' and 'Yves Makwambala' who have been imprisoned for a year. We are now looking at the Congolese Government, but also at the Member States, the High Representative, the Council. They must play an active role in establishing an inclusive dialogue. Congo has everything to gain from a stable, democratic context and a rule of law where impunity is ending. These are the conditions for peace that the Congolese have long craved for so long.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the Democratic Republic of Congo we are facing a serious political crisis and a strong threat to democracy, represented by Attempts by President Kabila to delay the electoral process in order to extend his mandate. These dictatorial tendencies blatantly violate respect for the Constitution and the rights recognised in congo. We are talking about a country emblematic of the inconsistency in the European Union's external action.  At the same time, it is the country most aided by the European Union and the richest country in the world in terms of natural resources: just take a look at trade between Europe and the Democratic Republic of Congo. We must demand that the Constitution be respected and that the recommendations to the last electoral mission be followed, so that there are free elections without Kabila's feared third term.  We must also demand that the human rights defender, Christopher Ngoyi, who is unjustly detained, be released and given appropriate medical treatment, including outside congo, as he is seriously ill.

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: Author. Madam President, Commissioner, I am pleased that we have on the agenda an emergency resolution on the pre-election situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The next few months are crucial for the future of the DRC and for the Great Lakes region as a whole. I would like to emphasize three aspects covered by the common text. First, with regard to the electoral process itself, I stress the implementation of the recommendations of the 2011 election observation mission and the 2014 follow-up mission, which I had the honour of leading. It is more than necessary to put the president and the government before their responsibilities. An electoral calendar, a budget and, above all, a public commitment to respect the constitution without delay are necessary to avoid the country's fire. Secondly, in terms of security, I welcome the renewal of Monusco's mandate and support the extension of its powers to the protection of civilians. Thirdly, the regional dimension: the European Union and the African Union must do everything possible to maintain political dialogue with and between the countries of the region to avoid any escalation of tensions at the regional level.

name: Charles Goerens
text: Author. Madam President, the constitutional provisions of a state protect citizens from the arbitrariness of its leaders. This position of trust is broken when these leaders deviate from it. This is the case, in particular, in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Is it an internal matter for the Democratic Republic of Congo to want to postpone the elections on the grounds that it must amend the Constitution to allow the outgoing president to run for a third term or should it be a matter for the Democratic Republic of congo or should it be debated in plenary? It seems to me that this should be the case. What for? Let us remember that the European Union has been very closely involved in the transition process of the Democratic Republic of Congo since the beginning. It was the Union that helped to create the necessary conditions for the previous elections. It has, therefore, helped to consolidate the democracy to which the Congolese aspire. In doing so, the European Parliament merely reminds the leaders of the Democratic Republic of Congo of the roadmap for the democratisation of their country, to which they once adhered. The Congolese citizens will be grateful to us for continuing to refer to a process decided by mutual agreement.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: Author. – Madam President, I believe that we are facing a rather weak resolution and that it should delve into a few more aspects, which also constitute a violation of rights in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. I believe that this Parliament should adopt measures to put an end to the responsibility of multinationals in financing the armed conflict. In April 2015, the director of the United Nations Environment Programme said that 2% of the benefits of exploiting natural resources will feed armed groups. On the other hand, I think it would be important to put in place measures to review and repeal mining and forestry contracts, to restore sovereignty to the people to exploit, transform and market their raw materials. And finally, I have to mention the need to end land grabbing by multinationals as well.

name: Maria Arena
text: Author. Madam President, according to the Congolese constitution, elections must be held within 90 days, when President Kabila's term of office will expire. The latter's silence and the efforts of the government to maintain its position create real instability in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Since January 2015, a major wave of repression has been sweeping all opposition voices. In this text, we call on the Congolese authorities to put in place, as soon as possible, the conditions for a free and transparent election, respecting the constitution; the African Union to play its part in enforcing African constitutions; the European Union, to support a clear process and to consider targeted sanctions; and, finally, at the United Nations, to renew the mandate of Monusco.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – I would like to stress the need to hold legislative and presidential elections by the end of the year in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. That's what the Constitution says, and I think this line should be followed without any corrections. President Kabila has, in fact, before him, a choice between respecting the Constitution and limiting it to two terms, respectively, he has the possibility to cede the temptation to remain in power at all costs. As far as I am concerned, I hope that he will choose the first path, that of respectforing the Constitution, because otherwise I fear that we will see a repeat of the scenario in Burundi or other countries where this temptation to run to power by trampling on the constitutional provisions animates some of the political leaders.  (Applause)

name: Kashetu Kyenge
text: On behalf of the group, Madam President, in the DRC, presidential elections represent the greatest democratic challenge. The entire country will have to demonstrate that it can respect its constitution, including the alternating provisions that limit the number of presidential terms to two. The government must urgently establish and formalize an electoral calendar in strict compliance with constitutional provisions. In addition, we remind the DRC authorities of the need to respect the freedoms of the press, association and opinion. These are the minimum values of democracy. The end of President Joseph Kabila's term of office is fundamental to democracy in the DRC, and will have a strong impact on the future and stability of all of Central Africa.  Finally, I call for the immediate release of political prisoners guilty of defending the fundamental principles of their constitution, and I call on the African Union to accompany this process towards freedom and also respect for the Congolese constitution.

name: Javier Nart
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, talking about 'Democratic Republic of the Congo' is an irony because, first, it is not a republic, since it is not everyone's — it is armed groups and kleptocracy; it is not democratic because elections have always been a mockery; and, of course, as for "Congo", it is from a short minority of bakongos, because most are not even ethnically Bakongo. It is a rich country with a very large population, occupying the last place in the human development index. We have delivered almost 600 million euros of aid in recent years.  The Resolution calls for the clean-up of elections, an end to repression and impetus for civil society: all this is at odds with the very essence of kleptocracy and corruption in power. It is therefore necessary to invoke the application of Articles 8, 9 and 96 of the Cotonou Agreement and directly link the continuity of the European Union's aid to make Congo a republic and democratic.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The unstable political and humanitarian situation of the Democratic Republic of congo puts into question the peaceful and democratic conduct of the upcoming elections. There were no local elections last autumn. The November elections could mark the end of the 19-year rule of the Kabbal family. Meanwhile, the UN reports on the arrests of members of opposition parties, and peaceful demonstrations are being dispersed by police and security forces. The opposition also points to the current president's numerous efforts to delay elections and stay in power, while vast mineral resources, rather than being the driving force behind the economy, are becoming a source of corruption and human rights violations. It is important that the European Union, the UN and the African Union exert diplomatic pressure on the authorities of the country, and that the new electoral commission, which also consists of members of the opposition and civil society, be able to hold the November elections effectively and efficiently.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá Uachtarán Kabila i réim anois i bPoblacht Dhaonlathach an Chongó ó 2001 agus is cosúil go bhfuil fonn air fanacht ann ar feadh tamall fada eile agus tá sé ag úsáid gach cleas chun é sin a dhéanamh. Gan dabht ar bith, tá teannas polaitiúil sa tír. Tá easaontas agus foréigean ar siúl dá bharr sin. Caithfimid gach brú a chur air chun glacadh le bunreacht na tíre agus go mbeadh olltoghchán ann i Mí na Samhna na bliana sin. Mura dtarlaíonn sé sin, ní féidir “Poblacht Dhaonlathach” a ghlaoch ar an tír seo. Ba chóir go nglaoífí “Poblacht Mhídhaonlathach an Chongó” uirthi. Freisin, tá achmhainní saibhre sa tír agus níl aon dealramh go bhfuil na saoránaigh chomh bocht agus atá siad. Mar fhocal scoir, ba chóir ionadaí na Náisiún Aontaithe um Chearta an Duine a athbhunú sa tír seo chomh maith.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: Mr. President, I support this resolution because the situation in congo is very difficult indeed. Humanitarian organisations estimate that currently 7.5 million people are prevented from accessing drinking water and hospitals, and many children cannot and have nowhere to go to school. Due to conflicts and military operations, three million people have been displaced inside congo and 500,000 outside the state, mostly saved from wars in neighbouring countries. I believe the next presidential and parliamentary elections, scheduled for November this year, will mark the first democratic transition of power after decades of civil war and political instability in the African state. All of us together need to contribute to democratic processes in the Congo.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: Madam President, I believe that President Kabila should look around. Unfortunately, we have other examples in Africa of presidents who thought they were eternal and wanted to exempt themselves from their Constitution. Recently, this has been the case with Blaise Compaoré in Burkina Faso, with the consequences that we know. But in this case, it was the people who prevailed: the democratic process began. Congo's wealth - because there are, indeed - must be distributed by a democratic regime among the people, who are suffering today. The European Union must be a partner of Africa, because our interests are linked, but it must also exercise its right of vigilance with regard to respect for democracy in Africa.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission welcomes the opportunity to discuss the human rights situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) and it looks forward to the adoption of Parliament’s resolution which addresses the crucial political process towards elections and the worrying situation regarding human rights and fundamental freedoms in the DRC.  The DRC is a vast country of immense challenges, not least those of poverty and security, including gender-based violence. As Sakharov Prize Winner Dr Denis Mukwege has told this House, women’s bodies have become a true battlefield. It is true that the Democratic Republic of Congo has experienced a protracted humanitarian and security crisis. The fragile peace in Eastern DRC depends on what has become the largest UN peacekeeping operation ever. Monusco is still facing a highly volatile and insecure situation.  Since the constitution and elections of 2006 there has been some progress. The economy expanded, some armed groups in the east were defeated or restrained, and there was an effort with much work still ahead to build viable regional institutions, but the DRC is now approaching a critical milestone in its evolution. 2016 should be a presidential election year, but the opposition and civil society fear that the constitutional deadlines will not be respected. A political consensus is urgently needed on a focused set of steps to deliver inclusive and transparent elections within the framework of the constitution.  This does not mean that government and opposition have to agree on every policy challenge facing the country, but it does mean they should find a common understanding on a roadmap leading to the ballot box. Getting the right political climate for democracy to work is also important. Unfortunately, protests and peaceful dissent have been met with repression in some cases and fundamental freedoms seem to be at stake. State security services are accused of involvement in human rights abuses and in a number of cases the judiciary has been disproportionately severe.  The EU issued for this reason a statement in Kinshasa on 8 March reminding the government of the need to respect its obligation. The stakes are high, the economy has been hit by falling commodity prices and an inability to expand domestic revenue, and public services suffer. This recipe for public alienation and discontent deserves our full attention. The EU has invested heavily in security, humanitarian aid and development. We are committed to a long-term partnership with the DRC.  It is not only material help. We have deployed intense political and diplomatic activity in support of peace, stability and reconciliation in active partnership with African regional actors and with the rest of the international community. In our comprehensive approach we have placed human rights first and we recognise the crucial role of the UN as well.  Working closely with the United Nations Joint Human Rights Office in the DRC we monitor and support human rights defenders, we contribute to fighting impunity and we look to the longer term with support for security sector reform and conflict prevention, as well as human and social development. We also seek engagement with the authorities in political and policy dialogue. In conclusion, we believe that it will only be possible for the DRC to move from fragility to resilience in a political culture of constitutionalism, rule of law and respect for human rights. The DRC’s future belongs first and foremost to its citizens. Their voice must be heard in civic discourse and at the polls and the European Union will use the range of its instruments to make this happen. This resolution from Parliament is therefore timely and welcome, and I am grateful for the particular attention you paid to my speech.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: Seven motions for resolutions were sent to me to conclude the debate. The debate is over. The vote will take place today, Thursday, 10 March 2016. The vote is coming up. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Unfortunately, the political situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) is very disturbing. The country’s fragile young democracy is under serious threat. According to reports from various sources, authorities in the DRC are trying to break the constitution and to cancel the upcoming presidential elections in November 2016. In order to do so, Congolese security and intelligence officials have initiated a severe crackdown on peaceful activists, political leaders and ordinary civilians who oppose peacefully unconstitutional attempts of ruling by President Kabila, seeking to amend the constitution in order to stay beyond his constitutionally mandated two-term limit. As a leading democratic power and human rights champion, the EU should urge the Congolese authorities to respect their own constitution, to guarantee the holding of transparent, credible and inclusive elections, to promote and protect human rights and fundamental freedoms. At a deeper level, the EU should expand cooperation with the UN’s mission in the country (MONUSCO) to further protect civilians and consolidate peace. Undoubtedly, only stable democracy provides the natural environment for the protection of human rights and peace, and therefore we cannot allow ourselves to lose it in the DRC.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like again to raise the issue of the voting fraud by Ms Le Pen. This issue was raised at the October 2015 session and the Presidency kindly said it would launch an official investigation. Many of us are still wondering what the result of that investigation is after so many months. Mr Marcel de Graaff, co-Chair of the Group of European Nations and Freedom has been sanctioned for the voting fraud on the citizen’s initiative, but we have not heard anything on the vote by Mr Nicolas Bay on behalf of, from the poste of, and with the card of, Ms Le Pen, Secretary-General of the Front National, for voting on the emission schemes. I hope you have some news for us.

name: President. –
text: I have to inform you that I was tasked by the President to start with an announcement that I will make to you immediately, relating exactly to this matter, but Mrs Le Pen has asked for the floor, so first I will give her the floor.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Corazza Bildt seems to have developed a genuine obsession with me, and I thank her for that. In any case, I wanted to inform her that, contrary to the false allegations and defamations she developed against me, I was totally exonerated in this case.

name: President. –
text: Now, because I have announced this and it refers to the matter we are discussing, I will read the text which has been given to me to be presented to you on behalf of the President: ‘As you will certainly remember during the voting session at the plenary sitting of 28 October 2015, the President was asked by Mrs Corazza Bildt to verify the circumstances under which Mrs Le Pen’s voting machine was being used in her absence. On 17 December 2015, Parliament was informed of the President’s decision to impose a penalty on Mr de Graaff for his behaviour during the aforementioned voting session – that is for having used Mrs Le Pen’s voting machine. The penalty consisted in the forfeiture of his entitlement to the daily subsistence allowance for a period of five days. Moreover, after having heard various Members and Mr Bay twice, the President has decided to impose a penalty on Mr Bay for his behaviour during the same voting session – that is for having used Mrs Le Pen’s voting machine. It will consist in the forfeiture of his entitlement to the daily subsistence allowance for a period of five days. The Member has been notified of this decision’.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF).
text: Mr President, my intervention is based on Article 164 and Article 167 of Parliament's Regulation. I will, of course, appeal against this sanction decision, which has no legal basis, and is not supported by any evidence. President Schulz's decision is indicative of his totalitarian use of the institution and the office of President, as he has (Protests) as he showed last Tuesday before the representative of the United Nations. This decision is based on fanciful charges and testimony that I have not been able to access in flagrant violation of the basic rights of the defence and section 166 of the regulation. I remind you that, in this case, it is not for me to prove my innocence, but for my accusers, four out of five of whom are anonymous, to provide physical proof of my guilt. It has not escaped anyone's attention that Mr Schulz is now campaigning for a new half-term as President. This probably prompts him to give in to the whims of EPP Members. (Applause)

name: President. –
text: We have taken note of your decision to contest the decision, but now Mrs Corazza Bildt has asked for the floor.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, very quickly to say that this is proof of a public ‘mensonge’, a lie, because Mr Nicholas Bay said to me personally that he had voted on behalf of Mrs Le Pen in the car when we were going to the airport, and I have a witness, Mrs Frédérique Ries. It shows how the Front National think that they are above the rules of this Parliament.

name: President. –
text: The communique announcing the penalty for Mr Bay follows the establishment of the facts.

name: Preşedintele. –
text: The next item on the agenda is voting.

name: Françoise Grossetête
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I propose the postponement of the vote on the draft legislative resolution, in accordance with Article 61, paragraph 2, of the regulation, in order to proceed directly to inter-institutional negotiations on the basis of the mandate adopted.

name: President. –
text: That is adopted. So this matter is referred back to committee to allow the interinstitutional negotiations to begin.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I propose postponing the vote on the legislative resolution in accordance with the second paragraph of Article 61, so that we can proceed directly to interinstitutional negotiations on the basis of the mandate adopted.

name: President. –
text: That is adopted. So this matter is referred back to committee to allow the interinstitutional negotiations to begin.

name: Andrey Kovatchev (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like on behalf of the PPE to put an oral amendment to paragraph 3, first part, after the first sentence: ‘deplores external pressure attempts related to Montenegro’s integration into Euro-Atlantic organisations’.

name: Preşedintele. –
text: The vote is over.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted today against the additional duty-free import into the European Union of 35 000 tonnes of Tunisian olive oil, because this is a wrong choice that does not help Tunisian producers, increases the risk of fraud, to the detriment of European consumers and harms Italian producers, especially Apulian producers already penalised by the Xylella problem.  Today's parliament's sudden green light comes after Tunisian olive oil imports to Italy increased by 481% in 2015. The new concessionary quota will be added, among other things, to the current 56 700 tonnes at zero duty, already provided for in the EU-Tunisia Association Agreement, thus bringing the total number of facilitated arrivals above 90 000 tonnes.  The real risk is that this will only encourage the increase in fraud, deceiving consumers about the origin of the product and promoting unfair competition with quality producers. I do not question the European Union's support for the Tunisian economy but the way in which it is to be helped. The European Union must in every way accompany tunisia's democratisation process, but it cannot be our oil producers who suffer.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the On the one hand, there is great joy in the report that has been adopted, because the best development aid is, of course, mutual trade. Free trade relations generate economic development, and economic development creates jobs, jobs create income and prosperity – so far, so good.  On the other hand, we must pay attention to and refer to possible collateral damage in the internal market, particularly in the case of imports of agricultural products, because we have a latent oversupply in the European Union, particularly in the vegetable and fruit sector. An insensitive import can lead to a fall in prices for our European farmers.  I therefore ask the European Commission, firstly, to be aware of the problem and, secondly, to ensure appropriate compensatory measures for our European farmers.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, with respect to this trade agreement and cooperation with Tunisia, I said that it is very important that we support Tunisia and, above all, the development of its democracy. That is what they need strongly for that North Africa, as they do for the entire African continent, we know that. But perhaps enough of those means that I personally think that we should also now look after our own southern Europe and its olive production, the quality of olive oil, its origin and so on. In this respect, I also slightly sever the idea that the tariff-free quota for olive oil has been further increased. The existing agreements would have sufficed in this respect, but of course Tunisia needs help in this, and it can be said that Mr Caputo's speech in this regard was in line with what I think about it in quite a few respects.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Euro-Mediterranean Agreement regulates relations between the EU and Tunisia, establishing economic and financial cooperation while respecting human rights. However, the terrorist attack of 26 June 2015 near Sousse, Tunisia, urged Member States to take exceptional and temporary measures to support the Tunisian economy, which was badly damaged by these events. For these reasons, the import of 35 000 tonnes of duty-free Tunisian oil was authorised for the years 2016 and 2017, thus causing enormous damage to the Italian economy and agriculture. I therefore decided to vote against, considering that such a derogation from the import rules, for such a long period of time, seriously damages one of the excellences of the Italian economy, which has already been seriously affected by the economic crisis and xylella.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP supports the economic development of all countries, and trade preferences can be a part of this. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct any part of UK trade policy.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the introduction of autonomous emergency trade measures for Tunisia since the conviction that these measures are not to help Tunisian farmers and farmers, but are measures to reduce the cost of olives, which will harm small and medium-sized producers in southern European countries and also tunisia. Nor is there any guarantee that such oil will not enter the European Union below actual production costs or that organic or social dumping will not occur. For these reasons I voted against it.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 After the Arab Spring, Tunisia is the country model in the transition process to the Republic. As part of its effort to help the country at both political and economic level, the European Union has decided to import an additional 35 000 tonnes of olive oil tax-free, in addition to the 56 000 tonnes already imported under preferential arrangements. Unfortunately, measures that could secure Tunisia's financial support without jeopardising Greek and European olive oil production were not included. That is why I had to vote against the report as a whole.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The country is currently in serious economic difficulties in the face of the horrific terrorist attacks that struck Tunisia last year. Against this background, the Commission presented Parliament at first reading with a sensible proposal for a regulation on the introduction of urgent autonomous trade measures for Tunisia. For 2016 and 2017, the text introduces a duty-free quota of 35 000 tonnes of virgin olive oil, which has been produced entirely in Tunisia. Halfway through, however, the impact of this trade measure on the Union's olive oil market will also be evaluated. If it is found that the Union market is affected, the Commission may introduce corrective measures.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to help Tunisia emerge from its economic difficulties, while its political situation is very fragile. Unfortunately, clearing 35,000 tonnes of Tunisian olive oil can only exacerbate the difficulties of European olive oil producers and encourage fraud by making Tunisian oil look French or Italian, a practice that is already widespread. As a result, I voted against this text.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. It is essential to ensure Tunisia's economic and political stability. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution. The result of a long work by my colleague Marielle de Sarnez, this resolution will benefit the Tunisian economy and thus its long journey towards a peaceful democracy. We must support Tunisia in its efforts to consolidate democracy by contributing to the country's economic development.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the application of urgent autonomous trade measures to the Republic of Tunisia. On 18 March 2015 Tunisia and 26 June 2015 The terrorist attacks in Ssa have hit tunisia's economy hard. In this context, the European Union wishes to reaffirm its support for Tunisia and to take concrete steps to support Tunisia's economic development. It is proposed to introduce a unilateral temporary autonomous trade measure providing for a tariff quota for Tunisia, which allows it to export duty-free to the Union 35 000 tonnes of olive oil per year, that is to say a total of 70 000 tonnes, without increasing the total volume of imports. This quota shall be fixed for a period of two years from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017 and may apply from the date on which the tariff quota of 56 700 tonnes of zero tariff currently applicable as provided for in the Association Agreement between the Union and Tunisia is exhausted. This measure will be of great benefit to the Tunisian economy. Tunisia's olive-growing sector indirectly creates more than one million jobs, accounting for one fifth of the country's total agricultural sector jobs. In addition, olive oil is mainly exported tunisian agricultural product.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union could have helped Tunisia in many other ways without putting European olive growers in trouble. I voted against this text which, once again, ignores the difficulties faced by our own producers.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to help Tunisia economically and thus help to stabilise it in spite of the terrorist acts it faces.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. Olive oil is tunisia's main agricultural product exported to the European Union and a key sector for the country's economy.  The proposal for a regulation adopted today in Parliament aimed to introduce certain autonomous emergency trade measures to facilitate the entry of 70 000 tonnes of Tunisian oil, without increasing the overall volume of imports. I have chosen to vote against this measure, because I am convinced that these measures do not help producers in the Maghreb country.  While I am aware of the fragility of Tunisia's economic and social situation, I believe that the Union must help the country with a broader political commitment that can consolidate the democratic process initiated by Tunisia without putting consumers and citizens of the Union at risk. The import of Tunisian oil opens up the European market to a greater danger in terms of fraud, threatening to generate unfair competition that could harm quality producers.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against these extraordinary trade measures because we consider that, first of all, they do not respond to the original meaning of the Council's mandate, by not favouring the whole of the Tunisian economy and society, but with olive oil-producing companies with export capacity. Further note, the report does not provide for sufficiently guaranteed clearing mechanisms in the event of a fall in olive oil prices in Europe, which could adversely affect European oil producers, in particular Italians and Spaniards. Finally, these extraordinary measures seem to open the door to a permanent increase in the quota of imported Tunisian oil under the EU-Tunisia free trade agreement currently under negotiation.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on the introduction of autonomous emergency trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia, with which the EU wants to reaffirm its support in a concrete way for Tunisia's economic development. To this end, the Commission proposes to offer a duty-free, temporary and unilateral tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year for exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the Union in the form of autonomous trade measures and without increasing the total volume of imports.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I have taken a stand against this text on emergency trade measures in favour of Tunisia. If I consider that Tunisia should be a strategic partner, especially for France because of the historical ties between our two countries, and that I am aware of the destabilization of the Tunisian economy by the terrorist attacks, I do not believe that putting our European olive growers in competition with the Tunisian olive oil industry is the solution to Tunisia's economic problems. Tunisia must of course be helped to stabilise itself in order to avoid the risks of political and social upheavals which would also have a serious impact on Europeans, but the proposed aid would eliminate tariffs on an additional 35,000 tonnes of olive oil, even though our agricultural sector is experiencing one of the most serious crises in its history and the price of olive oil has tended to fall substantially over the past decade. Tunisia should have been provided with strategic support to reinvigorate the tourism sector, but this solution will, at best, have only short-term beneficial effects for Tunisians and certainly catastrophic effects for European olive growers, especially Italian, Spanish, but also French.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This measure is scandalous and will have devastating consequences for Italian oil producers and for Made in Italy. It represents yet another FOLLY of the EU, a decision that goes against our producers and consumers themselves: allowing 35 000 tonnes of Tunisian olive oil to enter at zero duty will mean the closure of thousands of Italian farms and an exponential increase in fraud linked to the olive oil trade. I voted against the adoption of this text.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the non-application of urgent autonomous trade measures to the Republic of Tunisia. On 18 March 2015 Tunisia and 26 June 2015 The terrorist attacks in Ssa have hit the Tunisian economy hard, but there have already been major economic difficulties in Tunisia before these events. Against this background, the European Union wishes to reaffirm its support for Tunisia and to take concrete steps to support Tunisia's economic development. The European Commission therefore proposes to introduce a unilateral temporary autonomous trade measure, which provides for a tariff quota for Tunisia, which allows this country to export duty-free to the Union 35 000 tonnes of olive oil per year, that is, a total of 70 000 tonnes, without increasing the total volume of imports. This quota shall be fixed for a period of two years from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017 and may apply from the date on which the tariff quota of 56 700 tonnes of zero tariff currently applicable as provided for in the Association Agreement between the Union and Tunisia is exhausted. This measure will be of great benefit to the Tunisian economy. Tunisia's olive-growing sector indirectly creates more than one million jobs, accounting for one fifth of the country's total agricultural sector jobs. In addition, olive oil is mainly exported tunisian agricultural product.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ by voting in favour of the amendments drafted by my negotiating colleagues in the European Parliament concerning the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the European Council imposing urgent autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia. We have thus pointed out that the extraordinary measures to help the Tunisian economy following two terrorist attacks last year are temporary in nature. The main export sector, olive oil production, has found itself in difficulty and will also benefit from measures to the greatest extent. In order to avoid fraud and to ensure that the envisaged autonomous trade measures will actually benefit the Tunisian economy, they should be conditional on compliance with the relevant Union rules on the origin of the products and the related procedures by Tunisia, as well as tunisia's effective administrative cooperation with the Union.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal to import seventy thousand additional tons of Tunisian oil into the EU, at zero duties, for the two-year period 2016-2017. Tunisia is a key player in stability in the North African area and it is in the common interest to promote its economic recovery and democratic transition. However, in order to offer concrete support, we need to act with appropriate means, capable of producing tangible benefits for the Tunisian population, and which are not counterproductive for European productions.  My vote today follows a path taken in recent weeks with representatives of the S&D Group, and in particular of the PD delegation, to improve the proposal. We have succeeded in passing the traceability obligation and the exclusion of extensions to the measure. I believe, however, that the text, without any other improvements that we had also made, remains highly problematic for honest European producers and, ultimately, for consumers, increasing the risk of fraud at the expense of the 'made in' guarantee.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that it is up to the European Union to support Tunisia's transition to democracy by all possible means.  I believe that the introduction of autonomous emergency trade measures in favour of Tunisia makes it possible to provide tangible support for the Tunisian economy and to make a change of regime, be it military or religious, less attractive to Tunisian citizens. Tunisia is the only country where the Arab Spring has achieved satisfactory results. It is in everyone's interest that the results achieved are not frustrated.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. Tunisia is undoubtedly a country whose democratic path must be supported and encouraged. However, I am opposed to this measure because this does not really help Tunisians, penalises our producers and certainly does not favour consumers.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Strongly voted against. This measure comes to life from a speech in person by High Representative Mogherini, with the aim of helping the Tunisian economy affected by the crisis in the tourism sector following the recent terrorist attacks. What the European Commission is proposing, therefore, is to allow a zero-tariff quota of 35,000 tonnes of Tunisian olive oil to enter the EU further. It is clear that the price of this "aid" would only be paid by certain Member States (Italy, Spain, Greece and partly France), while for the most part it would be a zero-impact measure. Moreover, this intervention would only favour the multinationals of the fake "made in Italy" that place on the Union market huge quantities of olive oil that looks Italian, but that is such – when it goes well – only in part.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. In the wake of the terrorist attacks in Sousse, Tunisia in September 2015, Tunisia's economy, which relies heavily on tourism, has been significantly impacted. With this in mind, the Commission has proposed the establishment, unilaterally and temporarily, of a zero-duty tariff quota of 35,000 tonnes per year for olive oil exports from Tunisia to the European Union for a period of two years.  At the February plenary session in Brussels, the European Parliament called for additional protection guarantee measures for European olive oil producers. The latter are mainly located in the southern regions of the Union, which are experiencing significant economic difficulties. It was therefore necessary to implement a measure that is both beneficial to Tunisia and does not endanger European olive oil producers.  I voted in favour of this text, which is a perfectly acceptable compromise.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP supports the economic development of all countries, and trade preferences can be a part of this. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct any part of UK trade policy.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the amendments to the proposal for a regulation on the introduction of emergency autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia relating to olive oil in the hope that they will help to resolve the difficult current economic situation in Tunisia. However, to remain cautious and ensure that EU producers of olive oil remain unaffected by this, the Commission should also conduct an assessment of this regulation and introduce corrective measures if necessary.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I confirmed my vote against the legislative resolution on special aid measures for Tunisia, because I believe that the zeroing of customs duties on imports of Tunisian olive oil can harm a sector already seriously affected by the consequences of the continuing economic crisis.  In the first vote in plenary on 25 February, Parliament succeeded in amending part of the proposal in order to limit the impact that the agreement would have on European production, particularly italian production. This was a clear and unequivocal position which had heartened the 'no' campaigners, giving hope that the conditions could be in place in the Council for a change of course.  There is no doubt that aid to third countries is one of the European Union's missions and measures to accompany the process of democratisation and stabilisation of the Mediterranean basin area must be undertaken, but the attempt to help a country in difficulty is in danger of damaging others. We expect a debate to be opened soon in order to give compensatory measures to those states most exposed to market share losses.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the implementation of exceptional autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Against the current background the European Commission proposes to offer a temporary, unilateral duty free tariff rate quota of 35 000 tonnes annually for Tunisia’s exports of olive oil to the Union, under the form of autonomous trade measure. Such quota will be made available for a period of two years, from 1 January 2016 until 31 December 2017. This additional volume will be opened once the existing duty-free tariff rate quota of 56 700 tonnes, enshrined in the Agreement, is exhausted. Olive oil is Tunisia’s main agricultural export to the EU, and the olive oil industry is an important part of the country’s economy, providing direct and indirect employment to more than one million people and representing one-fifth of the country’s total agricultural employment.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP supports the economic development of all countries, and trade preferences can be a part of this. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct any part of UK trade policy.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP supports the economic development of all countries, and trade preferences can be a part of this. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct any part of UK trade policy.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As before, I have underlined my opposition to the resolution establishing emergency measures in favour of Tunisia, which consist of the green light for the import of 70 thousand tonnes of Tunisian olive oil under tax exemption for two years, which will result in further damage to the situation of small oil producers in several European countries, in particular Italian ones.  We do not want to question the desire to help another country, which is also strategically important for Europe, but we cannot accept the fact that every time it is the small Italian producers and/or the countries of southern Europe who lose out. We must be able to find different solutions in order to show solidarity with third countries without creating disadvantages for the Member States.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the introduction of autonomous emergency trade measures for Tunisia since the conviction that these measures are not to help Tunisian farmers and farmers, but are measures to reduce the cost of olives, which will harm small and medium-sized producers in southern European countries and also tunisia. Nor is there any guarantee that such oil will not enter the European Union below actual production costs or that organic or social dumping will not occur. For these reasons I voted against it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted, for the second time and always firmly, against the abolition of duties on Tunisian oil.  I did so because I was struck by the comments of a number of Tunisian NGOs for which the measures are insufficient and unable to produce positive effects for the agricultural sector and, in general, for the economic situation. I did so also because I believe that the final resolution is a serious blow to small producers: the measure as it is structured risks helping only large industry by strengthening the industry's lobbies.  The failure to adopt important amendments has prevented the dispelling of all the doubts and uncertainties raised by the measure. The final resolution is hasty and unaly analytical, incapable of responding to the need for support from the Tunisian people and penalising part of our productive fabric. That is why, once again, I have chosen to vote against the measure.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following last year's terrorist attacks, the Tunisian economy has been greatly affected and the European Union has reaffirmed its support, acting specifically to support Tunisia's economic development. Thus, the Union will provide Tunisia, on a temporary basis, with a duty-free tariff quota made available for a period of two years, until 31 December 2017, of 70 000 tonnes in total, for exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the Union, in the form of an autonomous trade measure, without increasing the overall volume of imports. The measure will bring significant benefits to the olive oil sector, which indirectly employs more than one million people in Tunisia and accounts for a fifth of all agricultural jobs. By concretely engaging with Tunisians in supporting their economic development, the EU also contributes to the promotion of democracy in Tunisia.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The terrorist attack in June 2015 in Sous has sparked a debate in the EU on the need to continue to support Tunisia in its political and economic transition in a concrete and targeted way, through actions that can be effective in the short term.  The European Commission proposes a temporary unilateral duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year for exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the Union in the form of autonomous trade measures. Olive oil is Tunisia's main agricultural product exported to the EU, and the olive oil sector is an important part of the national economy, providing directly and indirectly employment for more than one million people, which together accounts for one fifth of employment in the entire agricultural sector. It should be noted that this concession should not prejudge the outcome of the negotiations on agriculture under the FTA, which began in October 2015. Given that the objective of these measures is to support the economy and thus to sustain the ongoing transition in Tunisia, I voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly believe that the European Union must support Tunisia since it is facing a politically and economically difficult period. Moreover we need a stable Tunisia also for the benefit of stability in the Mediterranean. The fact is, the economy of Tunisia was already facing serious difficulties and the terrorist attacks have led to further problems primarily in the economy. Stronger trade relations with the European Union would be beneficial for Tunisia to be able to revive its economy. With the Association Agreement, the European Union has already taken a positive step forward in assisting Tunisia. I am in favour of the autonomous trade measures proposed, as they are a concrete example of EU support and further promote democracy in Tunisia and for these reasons I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I opposed this exemption from tariffs for the export of tens of thousands of tons of Tunisian oil, voting against this text.  Our duty as parliamentarians is to protect our olive growers first. Especially since the latter are affected by the bacterium Xylella, especially in Corsica, Italy being even more seriously affected. Not to mention Spain, whose production has been weakened by drought since 2013.  Exonerating Tunisia is a shame when we know that it is already benefiting greatly from the recent rise in oil prices, which stems precisely from this context.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Aid to a non-EU state against its members who are already in difficulty, such as Greece and Italy, was negative. He doesn't take a second thought.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Olive oil is tunisia's main agricultural product exported to the EU. The oil sector is an important part of the country's economy, as well as some regions of certain Member States, especially the South. The Regulation provides for the granting of an annual duty-free tariff quota of 35,000 tonnes for tunisian olive oil exports to the EU in 2016 and 2017 (i.e. 70,000 tonnes in total). This quota will be opened after the depletion of the current 56 700 tonnes, also duty-free, enshrined in the EU-Tunisia Association Agreement. I agree that the Commission should carry out a mid-term assessment of the impact on the Union's oil market and that, if the European market is found to be affected, to propose corrective measures to restore the situation.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it: the European Union could have helped Tunisia in other ways without putting European olive growers in trouble.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the attacks of 26 February 2015, it is proposed to grant, for tunisian olive oil exports to the EU, a unilateral and temporary duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year in the form of an autonomous trade measure. This quota will be made available for a period of two years from 1 January 2016 until 31 December 2017. The philosophy of the measure is the same as in the past, which has explained identical measures, for example in relation to the import of textiles from Pakistan. For Portugal, as well as other Mediterranean-edge Member States, olive oil production is of significant economic and social importance and will be hampered by this measure.  It was possible to adopt other measures, genuinely and more effectively solidarity with the Tunisian people. This, however, is not the aim of this measure. Benefiting European importers (and some limited interests in Tunisia), this measure undermines them as always. The truth is that measures of this kind never harm the most powerful countries of the EU (so it was with the textiles of Pakistan, so it is now with tunisian olive oil). They are always the same to bear the costs of this false solidarity.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting totally against the report allowing Tunisian oil to enter Europe with negative consequences especially for Italian producers.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the introduction of exceptional autonomous trade measures for Tunisia, as aid to a non-EU state at the expense of its members already in difficulty, such as Greece and Italy, does not take a second thought.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Tunisia is an important partner for European cross-border trade. By strengthening the country's economic situation by promoting the olive oil sector, we are also making an important contribution to strengthening the economy.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP supports the economic development of all countries, and trade preferences can be a part of this. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct any part of UK trade policy.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against these extraordinary trade measures because we consider that, first of all, they do not respond to the original meaning of the Council's mandate, by not favouring the whole of the Tunisian economy and society, but with olive oil-producing companies with export capacity. Further note, the report does not provide for sufficiently guaranteed clearing mechanisms in the event of a fall in olive oil prices in Europe, which could adversely affect European oil producers, in particular Italians and Spaniards. Finally, these extraordinary measures seem to open the door to a permanent increase in the quota of imported Tunisian oil under the EU-Tunisia free trade agreement currently under negotiation.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. Struck by terrorist attacks since 2015, Tunisia has seen a significant drop in the number of visitors to its tourist sites, which are particularly important for its economy. The Union is responding with this resolution to its promise made last year to explore the possibility of taking exceptional and temporary measures vis-à-vis Tunisia.  That is why allowing the importation of 70,000 tonnes of duty-free olive oil within the Union seems to me to be a wise action. These trade measures are a good way for the Union to support the Tunisian economy, especially since they are subject to compliance with control rules. Finally, these measures are limited in time and resources are left to the Commission in the event of an imbalance in the European olive oil market.  This well-thought-out resolution will enable an excellent measure of aid to Tunisia to be put in place, without risking harm to the Union, and that is why I voted for it without hesitation.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. I support the autonomous trade measure. The measure marginally interferes with olive oil production within the EU Member States, but can have a great impact on stability and security in the region.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Regulation provides for an increase in imports of raw olive oil of 35,000 tonnes per year for the years 2016 and 2017. Tunisia's economy has been hit over the years by both instability and terrorist attacks. It is perhaps one of the few countries in the region where stability is currently observed and has not descended into the chaos that plagues other countries in the region, such as neighbouring Libya. However, the proposal to increase imports of olive oil raises problems and objections from the countries of the South in particular, which believe that their own economy will be affected if imports of cheap olive oil from Tunisia increase. Although in Cyprus we are not large producers, however this will affect Cypriot producers. That is why we consider this vote to be an appropriate stance.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to vote in favour of my colleague, Marielle de Sarnez’ report on introducing emergency autonomous trade measures for Tunisia. Tunisia has suffered severe damage to its economy and especially to its tourism sector. Given the long history of cooperation and trade between Tunisia and the European Union, the importation into the Union of untreated olive oil originating in Tunisia (Tunisia’s largest export) via an autonomous trade measure would be mutually beneficial for both parties to the agreement. It would boost economic ties to Tunisia and enhances its cooperation with the European Union. I also support the agreement clause which allows the Commission to suspend the measure should Tunisia fail to comply with any of its stipulations.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP supports the economic development of all countries, and trade preferences can be a part of this. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct any part of UK trade policy.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted according to the Commission’s proposal to Parliament and the Council. The Tunisian economy has been devastated following the terrorist attacks of 2015. It is crucial for the EU to support Tunisia through exceptional measures in order to boost its economy, and I fully support the quotas set by the Commission.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council to introduce urgent autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia, as I support efforts to help Tunisia's economy, which has been significantly weakened by terrorist attacks and political developments. In this context, I support the introduction of urgent autonomous trade measures, which is also the position of the ALDE Group. However, it is necessary to establish whether olive oil will be imported directly from Tunisia and that possible attempts at smuggling or origin fraud must be prevented. I therefore consider that the proposed measures should take into account the protection of European olive oil producers and prevent market distortions.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. To help Tunisia, whose economy is severely affected by terrorist attacks, the Commission is proposing an additional tariff-free quota of 35,000 tonnes of olive oil exports from Tunisia to the EU. The current quota is 56,700 tonnes. The measure will be in place from January 1, 2016 to December 31, 2017.  Tunisia is experiencing serious difficulties following numerous attacks that have shaken its tourism sector. Help is needed to prevent the regime from tipping over and this country so close to us from being destabilized. The proposed aid is to put zero tariffs on an additional 35,000 tonnes of olive oil.  The European Union could have helped Tunisia in other ways without putting European olive growers in trouble. The price of olive oil has tended to fall trendly over the past 10 years, affecting European producers, without the Commission's concern. So I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP supports the economic development of all countries, and trade preferences can be a part of this. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct any part of UK trade policy.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU must help Tunisia to succeed in the difficult transition the country has engaged in. This means we should support Tunisians in building a solid and credible democracy but also in developing their economy and creating jobs. The latter is the objective of this proposal, which is why I voted in favour. This measure allows for an additional 70 000 tonnes of its virgin olive oil to be imported duty free into the EU in 2016/17. The Tunisian olive sector indirectly provides employment to more than one million people, representing one-fifth of the total agricultural employment in the country. These temporary measures will have no impact on the total volume of Tunisian olive oil exported to the EU.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Marielle de Sarnez's report on the introduction of autonomous and urgent trade measures for Tunisia. The aim is to exempt from tariffs a quota of exports of Tunisian olive oil. These measures are temporary and exceptional and an impact assessment on European producers will take place mid-term. Olive oil is one of Tunisia's only sources of agricultural exports to the European Union, with more than one million people living in the sector. It is important to support Tunisia and thus its democratic process, which, while one of the most advanced in the region, is threatened by significant security challenges, making support for the stability of the Tunisian economy paramount. This text was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The proposal would put European olive oil producers at a disadvantage and would allow Tunisian competitors to flood the market with oil that is similar to their name, cheaper but less qualitatively verified. For these reasons, I am voting against this proposal.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ We were waiting for the Council opinion regarding the emergency trade measures on Tunisia. I regret the fact that the Council approved all the amendments and the final report without changing anything. This is why I voted against this report. I believe that exacerbating the economic situation of European oil-producers is not the solution to help Tunisia.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The introduction of emergency autonomous trade measures for Tunisia marks the beginning of a new era in relations between EU and Tunisia, a new approach in the Euro-Mediterranean political region. It has been clear that the Tunisian economy needs support in particular after last year’s terrorist attack which severely damaged the tourist industry (Tunisia’s main economic sector). Therefore, exceptional and temporary free access to the European market will really benefit the Tunisian economy. Last but not least, the introduction of emergency autonomous trade measures for Tunisia will facilitate negotiations between the Union and Tunisia on the establishment of a Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA).

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Today we have been called upon to vote on a report providing for aid to the Tunisian economy through EU emergency measures that will allow the import, for 20016 and 2017, of 70 000 tonnes of duty-free Tunisian extra virgin olive oil.  We have been working on this decision for many months, which is wrong for me, and I am opposed to the agreement. It should be pointed out, however, that thanks to our intervention, the text has been improved on the original text of the European Commission. I voted against because I believe that the EU must change its approach, because we cannot think of helping external countries by damaging our economy or part of it. Nor do I think there is any real help for Tunisia. I call on the European Commission to monitor the implementation of the agreement in order to avoid fraud and counterfeiting, and to proceed as soon as possible with the recognition of compensatory measures for our olive growers, such as the recognition of the PGI mark for Sicilian extra virgin olive oil.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
