text: In writing. To help the Tunisian economy, the Commission proposed to grant 35,000 tonnes of tariff-free import quotas for Tunisian olive oil for the years 2016 and 2017. However, these quotas have been strongly criticised by farmers in the south of the European Union. They have just suffered a sharp drop in production due to a bacterium attacking olive trees, and are worried that Tunisian olive oil will take the market share they have lost. Since these doubts have not received clear answers from the Commission and that the amendments I tabled, asking for safeguards for producers, are not taken up, I decided to abstain, because I also did not want to block a measure that could help the Tunisian economy. I note, however, that there are many other ways to help the Tunisian economy, starting with the revision of its debt or the conditions we put to our financial aid, rather than carrying out measures that threaten European producers and oppose them to Tunisians.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the introduction of autonomous and emergency trade measures in favour of Tunisia.  To help Tunisia, whose economy is severely affected by the terrorist attacks, the Commission is proposing an additional tariff-free quota of 35,000 tonnes of olive oil exports from Tunisia to the EU. The current quota is 56,700 tonnes. Help is needed to prevent the regime from tipping over and this country so close to us from being destabilized.  The European Union could have helped Tunisia in many other ways without putting French and European olive growers in trouble. The price of olive oil has tended to fall trendly over the past 10 years, affecting European producers. The Commission does not care about that.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it proposes to import 35,000 tonnes of Tunisian olive oil without tariffs. So this is going to put our olive growers in trouble. It is normal to help Tunisia, whose tourism is in free fall because of Islamist terrorism. But it should have been done differently!

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I have spoken out AGAINST this proposal. Tunisia is experiencing serious difficulties in recovering its economy after the terrorist attacks that hit it, and it is essential to help it stabilize, or risk seeing the country tip over before our eyes.  However, I think that the aid proposed by the European Commission, namely the exemption from tariffs on an additional 36,000 tonnes of olive oil, is inappropriate. Given that our own olive growers have been facing a trend decline in the price of olive oil over the past 10 years, the European Union should help its producers instead of enacting measures that lead them.  The text is therefore unsuitable for the European situation.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the introduction of autonomous emergency trade measures for Tunisia since the conviction that these measures are not to help Tunisian farmers and farmers, but are measures to reduce the cost of olives, which will harm small and medium-sized producers in southern European countries and also tunisia. Nor is there any guarantee that such oil will not enter the European Union below actual production costs or that organic or social dumping will not occur. For these reasons I voted against it.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. The proposal allows Tunisia to import 91,000 tonnes duty-free into the EU for two consecutive years instead of 56,000 tonnes of olive oil. It's a tiny partial release of business. I am in favour of duty-free trade because I believe that if we allow Tunisians to produce things at home and import them into the EU, they will find work at home and not try to flee to Europe. Free trade is good for both sides. I think that trade with Tunisia needs to be liberalised overall and it is undignified for Parliament to negotiate such a small change. By delaying this, I have allowed the proposal to pass, although I would like a more fundamental relaxation of trade with Tunisia.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing – The regulation responds to the terrorist attacks in Tunis of 2015, which also affected the country's economy and economic situation. In order to boost Tunis' economy, the EU is providing assistance to the Tunisian economy by setting a zero tariff for imports of olive oil into the EU for 2016-2017 of a maximum of 35 000 tonnes per year. Olive oil is Tunisia's most exported agricultural product. Its manufacturing sector employs a million people. With this measure, we will help to maintain employment, prevent the development of poverty in this African country and thus contribute to the fact that the people of this country do not have to run for a better life to such an extent.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the implementation of exceptional autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 24/2/2016. I would also point out that, while Greek olive growers have suffered enormous damage from last year's severe weather events that affected their production, at the same time comes the Decision of the European Union granting a duty-free import quota of seventy thousand tonnes of Tunisian oil for 2016 and 2017. This action by the Union will cause immeasurable damage to the poor Greek producers, who are already seeing this year's oil prices collapse.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Following the terrorist attack of 26 June 2015 in Sousse, Tunisia, the Council of the European Union, in its Conclusions of 20 July 2015, stated that the European Union, in consultation with its Member States, would explore the option of taking exceptional measures to support the Tunisian economy. Olive oil is Tunisia’s main agricultural export product to the EU and the olive oil industry is an important part of the country’s economy. I therefore see these measures as delivering on our promise.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Increasing the quota for oil imports from Tunisia is the worst way to help the North African country. Oil companies are trying, amid a thousand difficulties, to come out not only from the continuing economic crisis, but also from the xylella emergency. This measure will have devastating consequences for the whole sector and for these reasons I voted strongly against it.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. Tunisia is the cradle but also the symbol of the Arab Spring: it is the duty of the European Union to help it carry out the democratic transition it is able to achieve. On behalf of the Socialist Group, for which I am responsible on this issue, I have repeatedly argued for the need to help the Tunisian people concretely and sustainably in the face of the challenges they face.  The worrying events of the last few days in Ben Gardane only strengthen our resolve. While the unemployment rate is already at record highs, the terrorist threat has the effect of melting Tunisia's tourism revenues. In the face of this situation, both emergency economic assistance and sustainable political support are needed. I have therefore logically supported Sarnez's report, which lays the groundwork for urgent trade measures for Tunisia, in the form of an increase in quotas of zero-right imported olive oil in Europe. These measures should have an immediate positive effect for the one million Tunisians who work directly or indirectly in the sector, without having a negative impact on European producers (additional quotas represent 2.2% of the European market).

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of Tunisia's difficult economic situation and the terrorist attacks in spring 2015, which have further depressed the country's economy, the European Union is taking concrete steps to support Tunisia's economic development. The Regulation provides for a temporary, i.e. two-year duty-free export of 35 000 tonnes of olive oil to the EU. This measure is projected to benefit the Tunisian economy, as it indirectly creates more than one million jobs in the olive-growing sector. By committing itself to such action, the European Union supports tunisia's economic development while promoting tunisia's democratic process.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to promote democracy in Tunisia by boosting economic development.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report should help Tunisia to emerge from its economic difficulties, at a time when its political situation is very fragile. I would be involved in avoiding a state crisis if the way to help it was not entirely harmful to our olive growers. The aim is to clear 35,000 tonnes of Tunisian olive oil, which can only exacerbate the chronic problems of producers in this sector. As a result, I voted against this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to the report introducing emergency autonomous trade measures for Tunisia, my vote was to abstain. After the attacks in Tunisia, it is important that the European Union show solidarity with tunisia. However, I have many reservations when I see the European Union using trade policy as a bargaining chip in situations of this nature. In the present case, the olive oil sector of the countries of Southern Europe will suffer greatly. The olive oil sector is extremely important for Portugal. Portugal has promoted national production with support for investment and internationalization, having tripled production between 2007 and 2014.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it is important that the Union sends the message that we are ready to assist Tunisia’s economic recovery, tackle the level of unemployment in the country and support the political transition process.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – The terrorist attacks in Tunisia have severely damaged the country and its economy, which relies to a large extent on its tourism revenues. In order to ensure tunisia's further political and economic transition, it is essential that the European Union provides concrete and directly measurable support. The temporary trade measure for Tunisian olive oil exports to the EU will enable us to re-establish Tunisia's economic engine and to continue the economic and democratic transition, the success of which is vital for Tunisia and for Europe.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – Despite a series of political and economic reforms that have taken place in Tunisia since the coup in the Arab Spring and since the last elections in October 2014, the situation in the country is far from stabilised. The seriousness of the status quo was "contributed" by the terrorist attacks of March and June last year, which hit the economy hard. Tunisia is part of the European Neighbourhood Policy, crucial to the EU's foreign policy, and as such is part of programmes aimed at encouraging economic and political transitions that build on the principle of common interests and values such as democracy, the rule of law, respect for human rights or social cohesion. Security problems constantly plaguing the country are slowing down the process of economic development, to which poorly set government policies, low levels of investor certainty or high levels of unemployment are added. In this context, it is in our power to help the tunisian people with an effective instrument consisting in reviving trade between them, in particular by promoting exports from the country. The proposal on the table offers as one possible solution a temporary unilateral tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year at a zero rate for the period from 1 January 2007 to 31 December 2013. 1. 2016 until 31 December 2017 for exports of olive oil (the most exported Tunisian product and sector representing a fifth of agricultural jobs) to be opened after the existing duty-free quota of 56 7000 tonnes as enshrined in the Association Agreement has been exhausted. I express my support for the proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the introduction of emergency autonomous trade measures for Tunisia since the EU has long pledged support to Tunisia in its transition to democracy. Tunisia has been a success story in the region. However, its economy took a huge hit following the 2015 terrorist attacks. Recent months have seen rising levels of unemployment and resulting protests. Therefore it is essential that Tunisia’s economic and social development continues and therefore it is very important to support these temporary and exceptional measures.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the adoption of emergency trade measures for Tunisia. Following last year’s terrorist attacks the Tunisian economy is facing serious difficulties and is in dire need of further assistance. I welcome the Council’s decision to agree with the additional safeguards introduced by the EP in its plenary vote of 25 February 2016 such as the mid-term impact assessment. In this way a trilogue will be avoided and the measures will enter into force quickly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the establishment of autonomous emergency trade measures for Tunisia to help a country whose economy is disrupted by terrorist activities. The agreement would cover imports of olive oil without tariffs for the years 2016 and 2017. This measure will once again harm our olive growers when many options exist to help Tunisia. We voted against this report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Union, in consultation with its Member States, stated that it would carry out the analysis of exceptional and temporary measures to support the Tunisian economy. These support measures are key to supporting the economic and social development of this country, which has recently had enormous social upheavals and is going through a difficult period. I am voting in favour of this report, but I have saved the Portuguese products, in particular olive oil, to be protected. Olive oil is tunisia's main agricultural product exported to the European Union and the olive oil sector is an important part of the country's economy as well as some regions of certain Member States, and national production, which is important for the growth of our economic activity, must also be safeguarded.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The proposed aid is to put zero tariffs on an additional 35,000 tonnes of olive oil. The European Union could have helped Tunisia in many other ways without putting the olive growers of the Member States of the European Union in difficulty. That is why I voted against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which endorses the Commission's proposal to offer, from 1 January 2016 until the end of 2017, a one-sided tariff quota exempting tariffs of 35,000 tonnes for olive oil exports from Tunisia, in addition to the 56,700 tonnes existing under the EU-Tunisia Association Agreement.  The report rightly points out the exceptional and temporary nature of these measures. In addition, I am in favour of the mid-term impact analysis requested by the report, so that we can, if necessary, take corrective action.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I was not able, for medical reasons, to attend the plenary session from 7 to 10 March 2016. Nevertheless, I would like to express my support for the introduction of temporary trade measures granted to Tunisia.  As olive oil is the country's main agricultural export to the European Union, these measures should enable EU support for Tunisia's agricultural sector.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The brutal terrorist attacks in March and June last year came as a hit to Tunisia, which is already experiencing serious economic difficulties. Having faced a number of poignant incidents of this nature during 2015, it quickly became clear that we only have a chance to fight terrorist organisations if we join forces now. We must show solidarity with Tunisia, which is why I support the introduction of all extraordinary and temporary measures to boost the country's economy. I think it is great, for example, to implement the olive oil export programme, by which we have made it possible to create more than one million new jobs. I am confident that, despite what has happened, tunisian holiday resorts will once again be filled with enthusiastic holidaymakers and that the country is facing a strong tourist season.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Tunisian economy, already facing serious difficulties, suffered after the terrorist attacks of 18 March and 26 June 2015. I have voted for this report that has as its aim the temporary offering of a zero-duty tariff for exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the EU.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because I believe that, in the interests and support of southern European olive producers, this proposal must be rejected in principle. Tunisia's further rapprochement with the European Union does not respect the will of the majority of European citizens.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Tunisia's economy is in difficulty and the EU should support Tunisia's political and economic transition with measures that help them.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The EU-Tunisia agreement on the duty-free import into the EU of 75,000 tonnes of olive oil for the years 2016 - 2017 is another painful blow by the EU to Greece's poor olive growers. The agreement comes as the CFP has taken a crushing hit on small and medium-sized farmers and the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government along with the EU and IMF is seeking a free shot with barbaric unpopular measures. It coincides with the attempt to strike the fair fight of the poor peasant, because it fights the roadblocks for survival. The lies that the agreement is being made to "confront terrorism" and "promote the democratisation" of Tunisia do not mislead anyone. The main objective is to bring down the producer price to olive oil, so that middlemen and large traders can continue to buy cheaply and sell expensively. Workers will buy oil very expensively, while poor producers will be captive to the farm. The agreement serves exclusively the profits of large business groups in the chain of transport, export-import, disposal and marketing. Poor farming can draw its own conclusions from this. Her path is to fight in alliance with the working class and the other poor grass roots against their monopolies and power, their imperialist associations that serve them.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP supports the economic development of all countries, and trade preferences can be a part of this. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct any part of UK trade policy.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. In view of the need for the EU to help revive the Tunisian economy at an undoubtedly difficult time, it seems to me to be a timely decision, but it must be borne in mind that the Union's solidarity is a solidarity at the expense of the southern European farmers who are currently that part of the market that has been fragile for some time.  The introduction of 35 000 tonnes of olive oil from Tunisia duty-free, if it does not greatly help the Tunisian economy, certainly damages the Italian economy, with a fall in prices as well as an increase in fraud and damage to consumers. The Mezzogiorno and its regions will therefore pay the highest price.  That is why, as an MEP, but above all as an Italian citizen, I am voting against this report so that a better solution can be found, such as direct financial support, rather than penalising the entire olive industry.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Since 2011 Tunisia has been а country in successful transition towards democracy. EU support during the period when the region is still very unstable, and the strengthening of democratic reforms in Tunisia are key. A lack of jobs and opportunities was one of the main reasons for massive popular demonstrations in 2011 and many of the problems are present still today. Economic growth will be embedded in rules through a trade agreement, which should enforce incentives for further economic and institutional reforms. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ To express solidarity with Tunisia and support the democratic regime, the European Commission has proposed the introduction of temporary unilateral duty-free quotas of 35 000 tonnes per year for Tunisian olive oil exports to the European Union, with an already existing quota of 57 000 tonnes. Such a quota would be available for a period of two years, from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. I assess this EU measure as partial and express concern that it will have a bad impact on European farmers.  Tunisia, as a country with still fragile democracy, needs to be provided with assistance, including through economic measures. However, European support for Tunisia should not have negative consequences for European farmers, as was the case with the Russian embargo. Decisions by politicians are suffered by farmers who have not contributed to these decisions and then the damage caused by market distortions is settled from the EU budget. According to experts' estimates in 2014, the EU is at risk of losing $6.7 billion and more than 130,000 jobs due to the Russian embargo in the agriculture sector. I am therefore of the view that experience with the Russian embargo invites us to find a balance between the help to be provided to Tunisia and the protection of our agricultural production.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the unfortunate attacks of 26 June 2015, a unilateral and temporary duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year in the form of an autonomous trade measure is proposed for exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the European Union. A quota to be made available for a period of two years, starting on 1 January 2016. Olive oil production has significant economic and social relevance, not only for Portugal but also for other Mediterranean Member States.  We believe that there is a need to assist Tunisia, particularly in the wake of the criminal attacks. We do not accept, however, that the same countries systematically bear the costs of this solidarity, burdening countries such as Portugal, which have their economies depressed by the austerity policies imposed by the Troika, in this case by means of solidarity that directly collides with their national production interests. The European Union must activate other solidarity mechanisms to provide proper support to Tunisia. From the express, we voted against it.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission proposes the introduction of a duty-free quota of 35 000 tonnes per year for Tunisian olive oil exports to the Union for two years.  I understand the EU's willingness to help revive the Tunisian economy at a difficult time for our allies, but I believe that EU solidarity should not materialise at the expense of farmers in southern Europe, in the specific case of olive oil producers. The latter have already been hit hard, during 2015, by some diseases that have affected their crops.  Solidarity with Tunisia could be demonstrated through funding for law enforcement or investment in youth culture and training. Instead, once again, it will be the farmers of the South who will lose out. I voted against the introduction of these autonomous emergency trade measures and I will continue to work to ensure that Europe no longer makes mistakes of this kind in the future.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the provision of this measure to support the Tunisian economy. This country in North Africa is perhaps the only example that has mastered the Arab Spring. But it pays hard when it is repeatedly attacked by Islamist terrorists. Tunisia therefore deserves all our support, and that is why this proposal has my support.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted to introduce emergency trade measures in favour of Tunisia. This country, a victim of terrorism, is seeing its tourism sector fall. At the same time, the olive oil sector is important for Tunisia, with olive oil being its main agricultural export.  Granting a one-sided tariff-free quota of 35,000 tonnes for Tunisia's olive oil exports is therefore a way for Europe to show its support for the country on a temporary basis (2 years).  Above all, no disruption of the European olive oil market is to be expected, especially in France where Tunisian olive oil does not compete with French oils, protected by geographical indications. Trade can be a weapon, but it can also be a shield.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP supports the economic development of all countries, and trade preferences can be a part of this. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct any part of UK trade policy.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report intends that, for the calendar years 2016 and 2017, an annual import tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes will be opened for imports into the Union of untreated olive oil originating in Tunisia, codes CN 1509 10 10 and 1509 10 90, if that untreated olive oil has been fully produced in Tunisia and transported directly from Tunisia to the Union. Following the entry into force of this Regulation, the Commission shall carry out a mid-term evaluation of the impact of this Regulation on the Union oil market and shall present the conclusions of that assessment to the European Parliament and the Council. Where the Union's oil market is found to be affected by the provisions of this Regulation, the Commission shall be empowered to adopt an implementing act which provides for corrective measures to restore the situation on that market. This Regulation, which I voted in favour of only on humanitarian grounds and because it is clearly limited in time, despite recognising its impact on the European olive oil sector, is directly applicable in all Member States and enters into force on the day following its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union and shall apply until 31 December 2017.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Thanks to this vote, 70,000 tonnes of olive oil, Tunisia's first agricultural export, will be able to be imported into the EU over the next two years with zero customs fees. Tunisia is an important partner in the region, a neighbour of Europe and a member of Euromed, but democratic and economic reforms are still fragile. This encouragement of the olive industry, which indirectly employs more than one million people, is all the more significant given that a slow growth of just 0.5%, now leaves more than 15% of Tunisians at the door of the labour market. The measures approved today should not unbalance the European market, as olive oil stocks are currently lower than in recent years. More than economic support, this afternoon's vote is also a real encouragement of Tunisia's democratic process.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The terrorist attacks of 18 March 2015 in Tunis and 26 June in Sousse have hit a severe blow to the Tunisian economy, which was already facing serious difficulties. In this difficult context, the EU reiterates its support through concrete measures aimed at promoting Tunisia's economic development. It is in this line of thinking that the European Commission proposes to grant, with regard to exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the Union, a unilateral and temporary tariff quota, duty-free, of 35 000 tonnes per year, i.e. 70 000 tonnes in total, in the form of an autonomous trade measure and without increasing the overall volume of imports. The olive oil sector indirectly provides employment to more than one million people and accounts for one fifth of the country's total agricultural employment. Olive oil is Tunisia's main agricultural export.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament, meeting in a plenary session in Strasbourg on Thursday 10 March, adopted the emergency trade measures for Tunisia already approved on its merits at the last plenary session on 25 February 2016.  At the time, Parliament supported the adoption of an additional duty-free import quota of 35,000 tonnes per year of Tunisian olive oil over two years, but did not formally conclude the first reading of the text.  Meanwhile, for the Council, the Committee of Permanent Representatives on Wednesday (March 9th) approved the amendments voted by Parliament, giving MEPs the opportunity to adopt them formally and definitively.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On March 18, 2015 Tunisia and 26 June The terrorist attacks in Ssa have hit tunisia's economy hard, and has already suffered many structural shocks. I am convinced that the EU must help this neighbour to maintain its economy, thus avoiding another source of potential turbulence. I believe that the unilateral decision to provisionally apply the autonomous trade measure establishing a tariff quota for Tunisia for duty-free exports to the Union of an additional 35 000 tonnes in 2016 and 2017. tonnes of olive oil per year is a small but effective aid for Tunisia, which indirectly employs around one million people in the olive sector, or one fifth of the country's total agricultural workforce, where the unemployment rate has long exceeded 30%.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the legislative resolution which allows the first reading to be concluded and the emergency autonomous trade measures for Tunisia to enter into force very soon, since an agreement with the Council has been reached.  As a reminder, the aim is to grant Tunisia a quota of 35,000 tonnes of non-tariffed olive oil for a period of two years. This measure will provide support to Tunisia in order to participate in the recovery of its economy, which has been severely destabilized by the terrorist attacks on the country. The agreement reached with the Council endorses Parliament's position that it stresses the importance that there can be no abuse or circumvention of this additional quota and that it benefits all Tunisian producers, including small producers. It is also setting up a mid-term review of the effects of this regulation in order to take corrective measures to restore the situation in the European market should it be destabilised. I welcome the adoption of this agreement, which shows the Union's support for Tunisia in the pursuit of its democratic transition.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against these extraordinary trade measures because we consider that, first of all, they do not respond to the original meaning of the Council's mandate, by not favouring the whole of the Tunisian economy and society, but with olive oil-producing companies with export capacity. Further note, the report does not provide for sufficiently guaranteed clearing mechanisms in the event of a fall in olive oil prices in Europe, which could adversely affect European oil producers, in particular Italians and Spaniards. Finally, these extraordinary measures seem to open the door to a permanent increase in the quota of imported Tunisian oil under the EU-Tunisia free trade agreement currently under negotiation.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. Tunisia is in an economically difficult situation. We need to get the country back on track. The Regulation ensures that a certain quantity of olive oil in the calendar year 2016-17 can be imported duty-free from Tunisia into the European Union. That is good for the economy, which is why I support the agreement.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the introduction of autonomous emergency trade measures for Tunisia since the conviction that these measures are not to help Tunisian farmers and farmers, but are measures to reduce the cost of olives, which will harm small and medium-sized producers in southern European countries and also tunisia. Nor is there any guarantee that such oil will not enter the European Union below actual production costs or that organic or social dumping will not occur. For these reasons I voted against it.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I reiterated my vote against duty-free imports of 35,000 tons of olive oil for two years from Tunisia. This decision will force our producers to face unfair competition because Tunisian oil will be placed on the market at lower prices than Italian quality oil. This is certainly a serious mistake which, unfortunately, is likely to have a serious impact on the entire European and Italian olive sector.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tunisia is going through a period of strong turmoil and is a country deserving of European solidarity. The additional quota granted for the export of olive oil to the European Union is part of this solidarity approach. As for Tunisia, the olive oil sector is relevant to the European agricultural economy and it is up to its resilience. As with any bilateral trade relationship with the EU, appropriate precautions should be taken to ensure stability in the internal sector market as well as import quality requirements. I therefore believe that appropriate bodies should have mechanisms to warn of potential imbalances in the functioning of the EU oil market, which involves regular monitoring of imported quantities. I also believe that this measure should be implemented without setting any precedent in relation to the eu-Tunisia negotiation process on the establishment of a free trade area.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP supports the economic development of all countries, and trade preferences can be a part of this. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct any part of UK trade policy.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. An annual duty-free import quota of 35 000 tonnes shall be opened for the calendar years 2016 and 2017 for imports of unprepared olive oil originating in Tunisia. The resolution therefore represents an expression of EU support in Tunisia in a concrete way aimed at reviving economic and democratic development in the country.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the emergency measure we have taken in favour of Tunisia is intended to help its economy, which has been exposed to a difficult situation in recent months. Tunisia was hit in 2015 by two major terrorist attacks that had an adverse impact on the development of its economy. I therefore agree with the Commission's proposal, by which the EU expresses its support for Tunisia and, in concrete steps, seeks to contribute to the recovery of its economy. To this end, Tunisia is offered a temporary unilateral tariff quota at a zero rate of 35 000 tonnes per year for the export of olive oil to the Union. Tunisia will be able to benefit from this additional quota for a period of two years from January 2016, starting only after the current tariff quota, which is set at 56 700 tonnes in the Association Agreement between the Union and Tunisia, is exhausted. As the Tunisian olive oil sector accounts for a large share of the entire economy and indirectly provides work to more than a million people, representing a fifth of all agricultural jobs, I believe that this measure will have a positive impact on Tunisia's development. Tourism has been hit hard in this country and it will take some time to restore its confidence. Therefore, even with such a measure, the EU can support not only economic development, but also other democratisation changes in the country.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Last year's terrorist attacks in Tunis and in Sousse had a very negative impact on the Tunisian economy, which had previously been in serious trouble. The European Union wants to assist Tunisia in its political and economic transition. The European Commission has therefore proposed to introduce a temporary unilateral duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year for a period of two years – i.e. a total of 70 000 tonnes – for exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the Union, in the form of autonomous trade measures and without increasing the total volume of imports. In these difficult circumstances, the European Union supports Tunisian economic development and thus also contributes to the Tunisian democratic process. This measure will support a large part of the Tunisian economy, as the Tunisian olive sector collectively provides jobs to more than one million people; one fifth of all jobs in Tunisian agriculture. Olive oil is also the main agricultural product that Tunisia exports. I believe that the SWIFT and concrete actions of the EU represent a strong political signal of support for Tunisia; this promotes the path of democracy. As a result of this, I supported the report in plenary.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure authorising duty-free imports of an additional share of oil from Tunisia for the next two years, as it is a solidarity measure that makes a concrete contribution to the Tunisian economy, which was seriously weakened after the 2015 terrorist attacks. Tunisia is the only country permanently on the road to democracy since the 2011 revolutions, which the economic crisis risks weakening under the looming threat of radical propaganda and terrorist infiltration. Thanks to the work done, the measure has been significantly improved with safeguards that meet the concerns expressed by operators in the sector to protect European olive growing: the traceability of the imported product (the oil will have to come entirely from Tunisia, to ensure that the measure actually serves to help the Tunisian economy and to avoid fraud) and the evaluation of the measure after the first year , to check its impact on the European market and to take any corrective measures to safeguard our producers. It is not by denying concrete aid to a fragile economy such as Tunisia that the interests of European farmers are being done, but by making a real commitment on other fronts such as the valorisation of typical products, the protection of quality, traceability and the fight against counterfeiting.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Following the terrorist attack on 26 June 2015 in Sousse, Tunisia, the Council of the European Union stated in its Conclusions of 20 July 2015 that the Union, after consulting its Member States, would explore the possibility of taking extraordinary and temporary measures to support the Tunisian economy.  Olive oil is Tunisia's main agricultural product for export to the Union, and the olive oil industry is an important part of the country's economy, as well as those of some Member States. Therefore, for the year 2016, a duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes is opened for imports into the Union of virgin olive oil classified in CN code 1509 10 10 and 1509 10 90 which is fully produced in Tunisia and brought directly from Tunisia to the Union.  Those measures should be limited in time and shall be without question the negotiations between the Union and Tunisia on the establishment of a deepened and comprehensive free trade area (DCFTA), and I therefore supported the report.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council imposing urgent autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia. Free trade creates economic development, and economic development creates jobs. I support the European Commission's proposal to introduce a temporary unilateral duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year, i.e. a total of 70 000 tonnes, for exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the Union, in the form of autonomous trade measures and without increasing the total volume of imports. This will benefit a large part of the Tunisian economy, because olive oil is the main agricultural product that Tunisia exports and provides direct and indirect employment to more than one million people.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Regulation provides for an increase in imports of raw olive oil of 35,000 tonnes per year for the years 2016 and 2017. Tunisia needs it and its economy has been hit over the years by both instability and terrorist attacks. It is perhaps one of the few countries in the region where stability is currently observed and which has not been in the chaos that plagues other countries in the region, such as neighbouring Libya. However, the proposal to increase imports of olive oil raises problems and objections from the countries of the South in particular, which consider it justified that their own economy will be affected if imports of cheap olive oil from Tunisia increase. Although in Cyprus we are not large producers, however this will affect Cypriot producers. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to ensure that the European Union imports a total of 70 000 tonnes of Tunisian olives at 0% tariffs over two years as a unilateral trade measure, following the current tariff-free quota. I have taken into mind that Tunisia is an important Mediterranean partner of the EU, whose promising democratisation efforts have been shattered by the serious terrorist attacks of March and June 2015 and the political uncertainty that followed, which has not been without impact on the country's already fragile economy.  Given the key role of olive production and exports in the country's economy and labour market, this unilateral trade discount can be used to help the Tunisian economy strengthen without appreciable damage to the interests of EU producers or to ongoing EU-Tunisian trade negotiations. I am convinced that, with this trade decision on the PART of the EU, we are also giving political support to tunisia's democratic development.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I said no to the European Commission's proposal to allow 35 000 tonnes of Tunisian oil per year to enter the EU duty-free for two years. Tunisia must be helped in its transition process, but certainly not at the expense of Italian and European olive oil producers. They, which are already suffering from a series of crises, will suffer further serious damage because, according to the Commission's analysis, this oil imported from Tunisia is likely to replace the current inward processing traffic, i.e. the temporary importation of goods to be exported after processing. This means that it will remain in the EU and drive down the price of oil, damaging producers in Mediterranean countries, who are already suffering from EU austerity policies. I am surprised that Italy and the other EU Mediterranean countries did not oppose it and did not renegotiate the measure in the Council. During the February plenary session, I voted in favour of a number of amendments that made it necessary to renegotiate the agreement in the EU Council. We hope that at the next elections, both nationally and at the next elections to the European Parliament, olive growers in Italy and Mediterranean Europe will certainly remember the names of ministers and MEPs who have damaged their interests.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the text. It is necessary for the Union to contribute to the recovery of the country's economy in a difficult period while stressing respect for labour rights and human rights.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Tunisia represents a case of hope in a region marked by instability and poverty. However, the additional burden put on the Tunisian economy following the terrorist attacks pose a serious threat to the success of the path to democracy Tunisia has courageously taken. This is why I voted in favour of the introduction of emergency autonomous trade measures for Tunisia. The idea is to offer a temporary, zero-duty tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year for exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the EU, in the form of an autonomous trade measure, and to do this without increasing the overall volume of imports. I expect that this concrete action will provide some relief to the Tunisian people. The olive oil sector indirectly employs more than a million people, accounting for one-fifth of jobs in the country’s agricultural industry, and is Tunisia’s main agricultural export.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the introduction of urgent autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia, as I think their introduction will be beneficial for both sides, both Tunisia and the European Union. Tunisia is facing a difficult economic situation due to terrorist attacks and the state will benefit greatly from duty-free tariff quotas of 35,000 tonnes per year for olive oil exports to the European Union.  However, I would like to point out once again that an impact assessment will be carried out on the olive oil market in the European Union and corrective measures will be adopted if the provisions are established to affect the Union market.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council introducing the necessary autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia, as the EU, through the latter regulation, allows Tunisia to strengthen its economy at a time when it is also facing a difficult and unstable economic situation as a result of last year's terrorist attacks. I believe that, precisely because of targeted measures, the regulation can have a direct, relatively rapid and positive impact on Tunisia's economic development, since the Tunisian olive sector accounts for a fifth of all agricultural jobs and is, among other things, the country's central agricultural export product. While it is a temporary provision, which I believe will not have a negative impact on the agriculture of EU countries, it will be a solid step forward towards Tunisia's political and economic transition and an even greater incentive for the country's democratic process.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against these extraordinary trade measures because we consider that, first of all, they do not respond to the original meaning of the Council's mandate, by not favouring the whole of the Tunisian economy and society, but with olive oil-producing companies with export capacity. Further note, the report does not provide for sufficiently guaranteed clearing mechanisms in the event of a fall in olive oil prices in Europe, which could adversely affect European oil producers, in particular Italians and Spaniards. Finally, these extraordinary measures seem to open the door to a permanent increase in the quota of imported Tunisian oil under the EU-Tunisia free trade agreement currently under negotiation.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. To help Tunisia, whose economy is severely affected by terrorist attacks, the Commission is proposing an additional tariff-free quota of 35,000 tonnes of olive oil exports from Tunisia to the EU. The current quota is 56,700 tonnes. The measure will be in place from January 1, 2016 to December 31, 2017. Tunisia is experiencing serious difficulties following numerous attacks that have shaken its tourism sector. Help is needed to prevent the regime from tipping over and this country so close to us from being destabilized. The proposed aid is to put zero tariffs on an additional 35,000 tonnes of olive oil. The European Union could have helped Tunisia in other ways without putting European olive growers in trouble. The price of olive oil has tended to fall trendly over the past 10 years, affecting European producers. So I voted against it.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The terrorist attacks in Tunisia and the instability involved have prompted the EU's response to the need to continue to support Tunisia in a concrete and specific way in its political and economic transition. The emergency trade measures are aimed at improving the difficult economic situation facing Tunisia as a result of the terrorist attacks. It is important that those measures are applied for a limited period and are without prejudice to the negotiations between the Union and Tunisia with regard to the establishment of a deep and comprehensive free trade area. The European Commission proposes to offer Tunisia, unilaterally and temporarily, a duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes annually, from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017, for exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the Union. Olive oil is the main agricultural product exported by Tunisia. This quota will enter into force as soon as the current zero-duty tariff quota of 56,700 tonnes under the EU-Tunisia Association Agreement is exhausted. I support the EU's involvement in supporting the economic development of Tunisia, which also contributes to the promotion of democracy in that country.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The terrorist attacks in Tunis on 18 March 2015 and Soussa on 26 June 2015 dealt a serious blow to the already struggling Tunisian economy. In this difficult situation, the European Union would like to stress its continued active support for Tunisia, in particular its economic development. This measure will have a positive impact on much of the Tunisian economy. The Tunisian olive oil sector indirectly employs more than one million people, which represents one fifth of the total tunisian agriculture. With this specific commitment, in addition to tunisia's economic development, the European Union is also supporting the country's process of democratisation. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against these extraordinary trade measures because we consider that, first of all, they do not respond to the original meaning of the Council's mandate, by not favouring the whole of the Tunisian economy and society, but with olive oil-producing companies with export capacity. Further note, the report does not provide for sufficiently guaranteed clearing mechanisms in the event of a fall in olive oil prices in Europe, which could adversely affect European oil producers, in particular Italians and Spaniards. Finally, these extraordinary measures seem to open the door to a permanent increase in the quota of imported Tunisian oil under the EU-Tunisia free trade agreement currently under negotiation.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this file as Tunisia is the only Arab Spring country on the right path to democracy, but the country is struggling with huge numbers of refugees from its unstable neighbours, terrorist attacks destroying its tourism industry and growing social unrest aggravated by an economic downturn. We have to provide rapid economic help in order to give a clear political signal that the country is supported on its way of democracy.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on emergency autonomous trade measures for Tunisia, which involve importing 70 000 tonnes of its virgin olive oil duty free during 2016 and 2017 without increasing total export volumes. The resolution entails a mid-term evaluation of the effects of the measures, changing them if they turn out to be harmful, and ensuring that the imports are traced through their entire route. These measures will help the Tunisian economy, hit strongly by the terrorist attacks, and are not likely to destabilize in any way the European market, in particular European olive oil producers.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Other avenues other than trade measures would be more effective in resolving situations such as tunisia today. In any event, I consider it necessary to vote in favour of these measures as long as the quota concessions are temporary and do not cause distortions in the market.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'The European Union must help Tunisia and the Tunisians to make the difficult transition period in which the country finds itself a success. This means supporting them, on the one hand, in building a solid and credible democracy and, on the other hand, in the development of their economy.  The latter objective is the subject of this proposal. This measure will provide a boost to the olive oil sector in Tunisia. This sector indirectly accounts for 1/5th of total employment in the country's agricultural sector. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report aims to temporarily increase quotas for the importation of Tunisian olive oil into the European Union. Tunisia's economy is depleted after the fall in tourism that followed the attacks. This quota is a drop in the bucket (35,000 tonnes per year) compared to European production (over one million tonnes), but it is a breath of fresh air for the Tunisian economy. These new quotas are also highly time-framed (maximum 2 years) and are accompanied by a mid-term assessment (with an update if their consequences prove harmful) as well as a "follow-up clause" (the obligation to ensure that all olive oil is produced entirely in the country and transported directly from Tunisia). These measures are therefore not likely to destabilise the European market and will not solve anything of the problems of farmers in southern Europe (Italy and Spain) linked to olive tree diseases and the practices of the European agri-food industry.  On the other hand, they are vital to help the success of Tunisia's democratic transition.  I voted for it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the terrorist attack of 26 June 2015 in Sousse, Tunisia, the Council of the European Union, in its conclusions of 20 July 2015, stated that the Union, in consultation with its Member States, would explore the possibility of taking exceptional and temporary measures in support of the Tunisian economy. However, what we have seen is that the cost of these measures will once again fall on the same as always, that is, on the countries and workers of the countries of southern Europe.  If the eu's major powers want to continue their aggressive policies of interference that foment terrorism, we do not think that they should use trade rules to clear their conscience. There are certainly many other possibilities to help the Tunisian economy without disgraceing the lives of Portuguese, Spanish and Italian olive growers.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the introduction of urgent autonomous trade measures for the Tunisian Republic. I welcome the consideration of temporary special measures to support the Tunisian economy, in so far as it provides for trade facilitation. I regret that, with regard to olive oil, the interests of producers within the EU are to be protected to the detriment of consumers.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The EU-Tunisia agreement on the duty-free import into the EU of 75,000 tonnes of olive oil for the years 2016 - 2017 is another painful blow by the EU to Greece's poor olive growers. The agreement comes as the CFP has taken a crushing hit on small and medium-sized farmers and the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government along with the EU and IMF is seeking a free shot with barbaric unpopular measures. It coincides with the attempt to strike the fair fight of the poor peasant, because it fights the roadblocks for survival. The lies that the agreement is being made to "confront terrorism" and "promote the democratisation" of Tunisia do not mislead anyone. The main objective is to bring down the producer price to olive oil, so that middlemen and large traders can continue to buy cheaply and sell expensively. Workers will buy oil very expensively, while poor producers will be captive to the farm. The agreement serves exclusively the profits of large business groups in the chain of transport, export-import, disposal and marketing. Poor farming can draw its own conclusions from this. Her path is to fight in alliance with the working class and the other poor grass roots against their monopolies and power, their imperialist associations that serve them.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ just as I supported the various parts of this report and the Commission's proposal at the February mini-sitting in Brussels, I also supported Mrs De Sarnez's report in the final vote at the March plenary session in Strasbourg. I think that, given that olive oil is Tunisia's basic export commodity to the European Union, by supporting the temporary derogation, the new duty-free quota, we will help Tunisia overcome the economic problems it is currently facing as a result of the terrorist attack in Sousse in June 2015. Such a temporary measure is also significant because Tunisia is the only country in the Middle East and North Africa region that has managed to successfully manage the democratic and political transition under the so-called 'Green Paper'. The Arab Spring, and I hope that it will continue to serve as a positive example in the region, thanks to the rapid assistance of the European Union.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. In order to help Tunisia, which is in a serious economic situation, the European Commission has proposed to offer important support to the olive oil sector as recovery aid. This is a commercial measure which provides for duty-free imports of 70 000 tonnes of product over two years. Olive oil is tunisia's main agricultural product to the EU: imports from Tunisia increased by 600 % in 2015 and fraud in the oil sector quadrupled in the same year. The seizures and investigations of the judiciary throughout Italy show that there is a correlation between increased imports and counterfeiting.  The Union's solidarity is once again a solidarity at the expense of farmers in southern Europe. Olive oil is an important factor in economic and social sustenance in the producing areas, including Italy. Europe is thus on the side of the multinationals which are interested in marketing cheap oil. This undermines the survival of many small Italian farmers and landowners who will now suffer the collapse in their oil prices. The 5 Star Movement fights alongside Italian farmers: I could only vote in favour of the total rejection of the proposal.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the introduction of urgent autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia because I believe that they will contribute to Tunisia's economic development and maintain stability and peace in the region.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr This proposal marks another effort by the European Union to further develop Community legislation on animals living next to us, because in principle veterinary medicines are often used not to treat or improve animal health, but also to guarantee the health of us humans, therefore, consumers of animal products. The main objective that this draft legislative resolution seeks to address is to improve access to the necessary medicinal products and to reduce the administrative burden in the area concerned, to promote innovation, competitiveness and to ensure the effective functioning of the veterinary medicinal product market within the Community, as well as to combat antibiotic resistance. The last issue, by the way, was already discussed at the plenary session on Monday. This is a very important document, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Agriculture is facing up to its responsibilities. There are two things that we need to bear in mind when using veterinary medicines. Firstly, the use must be appropriate.  The use must be based on animal welfare. Secondly, we must, of course, also pay attention to possible side effects in the human field. Keywords: reserve antibiotics and antibiotic resistance. Of course, agriculture is only part of the problem. But even if you are only part of the problem, you must of course also solve this sub-area. I think we are in the process of finding good compromises with this report: we want to ban the internet trade in antibiotics, we want to minimise the use of antibiotics, and we have introduced a quasi-double authorisation procedure, particularly in the use of reserve antibiotics, which really limits these particularly important medicines in use.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that reform will improve the efficiency and availability of medicines in Europe. Also because it contributes to the protection of human health and the environment and addresses the responsible use of antibiotics to treat sick animals in order to avoid possible negative consequences for human health, such as antimicrobial resistance. As established by the European Medicines Agency (EMA), its use for prophylactic purposes should be limited to very exceptional assumptions. I would like to highlight the difficulty in finding medicines for certain animal species and minor uses and I am pleased that the included waterfall procedure has improved the European Commission's proposal. In addition, research and innovation are committed among other proposals with the increase in time by the patent generator. Finally, the report includes a cross-reference with the new veterinary medicines legislation and the role of the EMA in the authorisation and supervision of veterinary products through a centralised procedure.

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We in UKIP believe that a responsible use of all veterinary medicines in British livestock farming is vital to maintaining our high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare. We believe that all veterinary medicines should be used responsibly, under veterinary care and according to licensing conditions. With regard to economic incentives provided by pharmaceutical companies, whilst recognising the issues surrounding commercial practice and the specific use of incentives in the human and veterinary healthcare sectors, UKIP is concerned about a negative impact on the provision of cost benefit analyses and other health economic data and studies by neutral and independent academic research institutions. This is an area where the UK and USA institutions are world leaders and thus unnecessary EU interference has the potential to adversely affect their investigative work and its applications. UKIP believes that the EU should have no jurisdiction in what is a global arena for drug development and cannot enforce the removal of products from the market in this manner – this would penalise leading drug development companies including world-leading UK corporations.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We in UKIP believe that a responsible use of all veterinary medicines in British livestock farming is vital to maintaining our high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare. We believe that all veterinary medicines including antibiotics should be used responsibly, under veterinary care and according to licensing conditions. We believe that the British Parliament should be able to legislate on this issue without being overruled by the unelected EU Commission.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that, although I disagree on important points, it is an improvement in legislation in this area at a time of current need. The report includes very positive references to the exclusive role that veterinarians should play in prescribing such medicinal products; the report also refers positively to the need to assess the environmental impact of medicines on the environment, the inclusion of small and medium-sized enterprises, the prevention of unnecessary suffering on animals, etc. This Regulation is very necessary in the face of the crises that the livestock sector is experiencing, with elements such as the extension of tuberculosis among other diseases that need the availability of such veterinary medicinal products. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report on veterinary medicinal products. Whilst a shorter length of patent protection would have been preferable to allow more affordable generics to enter the market sooner, overall this report is a positive step forward in the field of veterinary medicines. One of the key issues for both human and animal health addressed in this report is antimicrobial resistance, with a proposal for a strict limit on prophylactic use where antibiotics are applied to healthy animals – a process with worrying implications for antibiotic resistance, especially for vital antimicrobial medicines uses for humans. With the WHO warning that the world is on the cusp of entering a post-antibiotic era with grave implications for human health, it is essential that we act now and take measures to effectively tackle the very dangerous risks we face if we do not face up to the threat of antibiotic resistance.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The report on veterinary medicinal products includes the harmonisation of the requirements of the veterinary prescription and the recognition of prescriptions in all Member States, always in line with the relevant national legislation. It also includes stimulating innovation and the development of new veterinary medicinal products, as well as harmonising the protection periods for new data packages related to antimicrobial veterinary medicinal products (patents).  The report refers to the action to reduce the use of antibiotics and sets out the requirements for packaging labelling. It also simplifies application requirements for limited markets, facilitates the movement of veterinary medicinal products across the EU with clear rules on online sales and includes addressing public health risk in germ resistance. I voted in favour of the report, with a view to a regulation providing better access to veterinary medicinal products, taking measures to combat antimicrobial resistance, reducing administrative burdens, and promoting innovation and competitiveness in the sector.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. In view of the fact that, according to the WHO, 25,000 people die each year in the EU because antibiotics lose their effectiveness, it is necessary to take the fight against antibiotic resistance seriously. That is why it is so important to start with veterinary medicine, because antibiotic-resistant germs can also develop in animals, which can spread to humans. Specifically, the revision of the regulation provides for the restriction of the use of existing antimicrobials and the advancement of the development of new active substances. For these reasons, I welcome this text.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report plans to centralise veterinary drug approvals to a European agency as much as possible. If certain proposals amend the proposal in the right way, it will still allow Member States to take away their own prerogatives and expertise through this transfer of competence. I voted against it.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. This proposed regulation is intended to govern the authorisation, manufacture, marketing, distribution and use of veterinary drugs.  I voted in favour of this deliberation because it differentiates the market for veterinary medicines from that of human medicines, which respond to very different logics. In addition, the text will improve product availability and administrative simplification, without sacrificing public health and environmental concerns.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that reform will improve the efficiency and availability of medicines in Europe. Also because it contributes to the protection of human health and the environment and addresses the responsible use of antibiotics to treat sick animals in order to avoid possible negative consequences for human health, such as antimicrobial resistance. As established by the European Medicines Agency (EMA), its use should be limited for prophylactic purposes to very exceptional assumptions, as well as a list of antibiotics reserved for human use. Medicinal products for human use should only be used as a last resort in the treatment of animals. Finally, the report includes a cross-reference with the new veterinary medicines legislation and the role of the EMA in the authorisation and supervision of veterinary products through a centralised procedure.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on veterinary medicinal products aimed at reducing the use of antibiotics in animal husbandry. Bacteria are becoming more resistant, so the use of antibiotics in animal husbandry needs to be restricted and a new type of medication needs to be developed. The new proposal promotes research into innovative medicines and limits the preventive use of antibiotics in animals. It aims to regulate the authorisation, manufacture, marketing, distribution and use of veterinary medicinal products for veterinary medicinal products throughout their lifetime, as well as the pharmacovigilance process applicable to them. The European Commission proposes to improve access to and availability of medicinal products, especially for non-essential species, to reduce the administrative burden, in particular as regards the pharmacovigilance process, to stimulate innovation in the sector and its competitiveness, to ensure the good functioning of the internal market for veterinary medicinal products and to combat antibiotic resistance. I support the proposals that the provisions on combating antimicrobial resistance should be more ambitious and should include clear definitions of different therapies, and that the prophylactic use of antibacterial agents should be banned. It is also necessary to strengthen incentives to support innovation.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The text aims to regulate the marketing and circulation of veterinary drugs. The main concerns that underpinned the proposals are the fight against antibiotic resistance and the assurance of the best possible availability of medicines. However, under this objective lies in a liberalisation of the sale of medicines, especially through online sales sites, thus subtracting this source of income from veterinarians, who are better able to deliver the products in question.  Although this report is more restrictive than the Commission's proposal, it does not respect the interests of our vets who carry out a real work of health sentries. It also authorizes the prescribing of certain drugs by non-veterinarians, which is unacceptable for public health reasons. So I voted against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on a proposed directive which aims to put in place an updated body of legislation, adapted to the specifics of the veterinary sector, while preserving public health, animal health, food safety and the environment. The rapporteur shares the Commission's objectives and her desire to differentiate the market for veterinary medicines from that of human medicines, which responds to a very different logic. Similarly, the Commission has chosen to focus on product availability and administrative simplification, without sacrificing public health and environmental protection imperatives. However, the Commission has not gone far enough on some points. The draft report thus specifies the conditions under which veterinary health professionals are allowed to prescribe and sell antibiotics or stresses that antibiotics and medicines cannot be sold over the internet.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Grossetête report on the proposal for a regulation on veterinary medicinal products.  Medicinal products reserved for animals are important tools that require particularly complex processing due to the multiplicity of existing species. Legislative action in this area must take into account two aspects, on the one hand the need to simplify legislation as much as possible and, on the other, to address the serious issue of increasing resistance to antimicrobial drugs. The development of resistant bacteria must involve not only a restriction on the use of antimicrobial drugs, but above all an investment in innovation that will enable research in this area to be strengthened.  The WHO has already denounced the health and life risks of millions of people, which could result from the rise of a post-antibiotic era. Europe must play its part by blocking mass treatment and ensuring limited prophylactic use of antibiotics for cases where it really seems justified.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In favour of this report, we voted in favour of this report as it points to greater control of both the sales cycle of antibiotics and their use. It limits the online sale of medicines that should be sold with a prescription, is limited and controls use preventively and relates to other issues that concern animal welfare criteria.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I congratulate the rapporteur on her excellent work on this proposal for a Regulation on veterinary medicinal products, which I have supported. In the same way, I voted that those genetically modified medicinal products should not be used, as I have done on previous occasions with regard to genetically modified organisms.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I have not been able to support this report, which, while it has laudable objectives, actually carries a risk of harm to the interests of our veterinarians and to our health and even food security. Of course, the text highlights just concerns such as the fight against antibiotic resistance or the need for better availability of medicines. However, behind these just causes lie an attempt to liberalize the sale of medicines, through online sales sites in particular, which will not only lead to a precariousness of our veterinarians but could also endanger our health safety, by allowing the prescription of certain medicines by non-veterinarians. Finally, although it is more restrictive than the Commission's proposal, it is regrettable that this report does not contain some essential provisions such as: banning animals in the food chain if they have participated in clinical trials or banning the online sale of prescription medicines, particularly for food-producing animals.

name: J
text: Osé Blanco López (S&D), in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on veterinary medicinal products. Veterinary medicinal products are regulated in Directive 2001/82/EC and Regulation (EC) No 726/2004. In 2004, the Commission proposed to unite the two acts, with objectives such as improving access to veterinary medicinal products, reducing the bureaucratic burden, analyzing antibiotic resistance and promoting innovation.  The issue of veterinary medicinal products, as well as the need to establish a comprehensive approach to their use, makes it mandatory to review veterinary pharmaceutical legislation. The Socialist Group therefore calls for the inclusion of more ambitious objectives, such as banning the use of prophylactics in antibiotics or clarifying the conditions under which veterinarians prescribe and sell antibiotics, as well as the online sale of antibiotics. The framework of human medicinal products should be tightened for use with animals and a number of preventive measures should be established before resorting to antimicrobial treatments of entire groups of animals intended for food production.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which aims to adopt a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on veterinary medicinal products. The purpose of this draft Regulation is to regulate the authorisation, manufacture, marketing, distribution and use of veterinary medicinal products for veterinary medicinal products throughout their lifetime, as well as the pharmacovigilance process applicable to them. It was concluded that a specific regulatory framework should be established adapted to the specificities of the veterinary sector. The current legal framework has raised problems, such as the lack of veterinary medicinal products (especially in small markets), regulatory burdens, the functioning of the internal market and, of course, the phenomenon of antibiotic resistance. The Commission would like to draw up a list of very important antibiotics for the treatment of humans only. The European Parliament supports this idea if only this list is based on sound scientific criteria. The European Medicines Agency has made excellent recommendations in this regard to be followed. Finally, contrary to what the Commission proposes, the online sale of antibiotics (and veterinary products subject to prescription in general) should be banned as it poses a serious risk to public health. The Commission also proposes to simplify the use of medicines for human use without a marketing authorisation for the treatment of animals. The text leaves responsibility to veterinarians to decide on such use. Parliament does not question the responsibility of veterinarians, but calls for a better definition of this possibility by clarifying that the use of medicinal products for human use can only be taken as a last resort when there are no better alternatives.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the report voted on today, which marks an important step forward in the fight against antibiotic resistance, through a more limited and responsible use of existing antimicrobial drugs and the development of new medicines.
