The text aims to update European legislation on veterinary medicinal products, excluding antibiotic treatment practices for purely preventive or collective purposes, while encouraging research into and the creation of new quality medicines. Reducing the use of antibiotic medicines without specific authorisation does not, however, mean dismantling our equipment of veterinary medicines; the new regulation aims, on the contrary, to facilitate access to these medicines within the Union, creating more favourable conditions for their circulation thanks also to better authorisation procedures, more effective pharmacovigilance and lower administrative burdens.  This encourages a more thoughtful and regulated use of medicines, which cannot under any circumstances replace good farming practices and should only be administered after a careful assessment by the veterinarian, thereby strengthening protections in favour of animal, human and environmental health.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ This regulation regulates relations in the distribution and use of veterinary medicines, but my main focus has been on those parts dealing with combating antimicrobial resistance. It is important that the regulation contains a provision prohibiting certain antibiotics in veterinary order to preserve them for human use. But for this to make sense it must be retroactive, therefore include the obligation to withdraw from the market those reserved antibiotics already on sale.  Furthermore, binding the distribution of antibiotics with a prescription issued by the responsible person is essential. Likewise, to prevent possible abuses in the interest of public health is to ban the online sale of antibiotics. In conclusion, I believe that the proposal for regulation coming out of Parliament is well designed and will contribute to better protection of animal and human health.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This provision is useful for improving access to medical and health products, particularly in the veterinary sector where there is a shortage of medicines in many market areas.  The main objectives of the provision can be summed up in the desire to improve access to and availability of medicines, in particular for species improperly known as 'minor'; to reduce the administrative burden, in particular with regard to the pharmacovigilance process; to stimulate innovation and the competitiveness of the sector; to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market for veterinary medicines; in addition to combating antibiotic resistance, which is an element of danger, both for human and animal health, of increasing importance.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The livestock sector accounts for 41 % of total investment in agriculture, with a total of more than EUR 142 billion in livestock. Harmonisation of conditions for veterinary prescriptions, recognition at Member State level and authorisation of other qualified persons to issue certain prescriptions contribute significantly to the reduction of red tape and the rational use of veterinary medicinal products. Also, taking into account technological developments, the use of electronic prescriptions facilitates the work of farmers. We consider that antimicrobial resistance is a major risk factor on animal health and welfare, and the effects are directly felt on human health. Prohibition of the use of antibiotics in prophylactic treatments contributes significantly to reducing the volume of medicines administered to animals. I believe that prevention is often more effective and the costs lower, the amount of medicines used in preventive treatment being much lower compared to that used in metaphytolactic treatments. The proposal for a regulation on veterinary medicinal products should be adapted to the realities on the ground, should aim at reducing administrative burdens, taking into account the needs of farmers and meet the needs of consumers. I am of the opinion that the vote in the ENVI Commission was the necessary guarantee for this report to enter into interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. With this new regulation, the rules for the authorisation and placing on the market of veterinary medicinal products are separated from those for human use. This undoubtedly brings greater clarity. However, on the substance, the final vote cannot be favourable for these essential reasons: the release into the food chain of animals on which clinical trials have been carried out is not entirely averted; medicinal products containing GMOs are permitted (Em. 297 and 131 tend to prohibit them); other persons other than veterinarians are also subject to veterinary prescription; the sale of prescription medicines is also allowed online; measures to combat AMR (although improved by the amendments).

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The impact of veterinary medicinal products on both animal and human health is a very worrying one. The use of medicinal products is closely linked to the antimicrobial resistance developed in animals and, by eating dairy products or meat originating in those animals, the resistance is also transferred to humans. The main cause is the prophylactic administration of antimicrobial drugs in animals, sometimes used to improve performance or compensate for their inappropriate development. With this report, we want to limit the prophylactic use of antibiotics only in situations justified by the veterinarian by the presence of clear clinical symptoms. Combating antimicrobial resistance is a priority for the EU, as it aims to improve patient safety, and Mrs Grossetête's report underlines the Union's role in creating a single action plan to combat antimicrobial resistance. On the other hand, this report seeks to create a framework to stimulate and support innovation in veterinary medicinal products, so as not to reduce the therapeutic arsenal of veterinarians. The industry needs encouragement to create new medicines and place them on the market for veterinary medicinal products, as it is relatively small and fragmented.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that reform will improve the efficiency and availability of medicines in Europe. Also because it contributes to the protection of human health and the environment and addresses the responsible use of antibiotics to treat sick animals in order to avoid possible negative consequences for human health, such as antimicrobial resistance. As established by the European Medicines Agency (EMA), its use should be limited for prophylactic purposes to very exceptional assumptions, as well as a list of antibiotics reserved for human use. Medicinal products for human use should only be used as a last resort in the treatment of animals. Finally, the report includes a cross-reference with the new veterinary medicines legislation and the role of the EMA in the authorisation and supervision of veterinary products through a centralised procedure.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to simplify veterinary drug legislation by merging the Eu veterinary medicines code with the regulation that establishes Community procedures for authorising and monitoring medicines for human and veterinary use.  This new text will help to combat the abuse of antibiotic use in livestock. The sale and prescribing of veterinary antibiotics will be greatly reduced and more supervised. Legislation is needed to adapt to the new phenomenon of antibiotic resistance. Indeed, the amount of antibiotics we consume through our diet causes a certain habituation that makes these antibiotics less effective to treat us when we are sick.  I voted for this text, which is the european Parliament's position for negotiations with the Member States.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this proposal for a regulation, which sets out a regulatory framework specifically designed for the characteristics of the veterinary sector. The legal framework in force has given rise to problems in its application, in particular with regard to the shortage of veterinary medicinal products, the functioning of the internal market, the phenomenon of antibiotic resistance, the lack of incentives to support innovation, and the administrative burdens imposed. The proposal adopted today remedys all these shortcomings. The issue of antibiotic resistance is saying something increasingly worrying: every year an average meat consumer ingests almost 9 grams of antibiotics without his knowledge (the equivalent of four treatments).  The responsible use of antibiotics that are important for human medicine, such as 'fluoroquinolones' and 'cephalosporins', must therefore be promoted more responsibly in veterinary medicines. The widespread use of these two substances in breeding to counteract common infections contributes to the spread of antimicrobial resistance. I believe that, where no disease has been diagnosed, the administration of antimicrobials for preventive or prophylactic purposes should be prohibited.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report sets out a new legal framework for veterinary medicines for authorisation, manufacturing, drug safety and their use. The aim of the report is to strengthen the Commission proposal. This report calls for the ban on prophylactic use of veterinary medicines which contain antimicrobials (albeit with some exceptions) which is an important move forward in combatting antimicrobial resistance. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe that a responsible use of all veterinary medicines in British livestock farming is vital to maintaining our high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare. We believe that all veterinary medicines should be used responsibly, under veterinary care and according to licensing conditions. With regard to economic incentives provided by pharmaceutical companies, whilst recognising the issues surrounding commercial practice and the specific use of incentives in the human and veterinary healthcare sectors, UKIP is concerned about a negative impact on the provision of cost benefit analyses and other health economic data and studies by neutral and independent academic research institutions. This is an area where the UK and USA institutions are world leaders and thus unnecessary EU interference has the potential to adversely affect their investigative work and its applications. UKIP believes that the EU should have no jurisdiction in what is a global arena for drug development and cannot enforce the removal of products from the market in this manner – this would penalise leading drug development companies including world-leading UK corporations.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a very good report that includes excellent amendments to Directive 2001/82/EC, for example in relation to access to medicinal products, innovation and environmental protection. However, I believe that this report is not yet mature for agreement and I agree with the need to postpone the final vote in order to fine-tune the details.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 While the industry's fundamental objective is to achieve a single market for veterinary medicines, the main objective of the M5S Europe is the protection of animal welfare, the increase in the availability of veterinary medicines throughout Europe and above all the transition from a culture of mass care of animals to a culture in which animals are given individual care as well as humans. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome today’s vote in the European Parliament to usher in tighter controls and restrictions on the administration of antibiotics to farm animals. We cannot allow cost-cutting business as usual to carry on in large-scale, industrial farming. Increased resistance to the most common antibiotics could bring us back to the dark ages of medicine, when we were at the mercy of infectious diseases and the chances of surviving surgery were scant. This is not an overstatement. The World Health Organisation has been compiling alarming data on the development of multi-drug resistant superbugs that pose severe public health risks on a global scale. I am glad we managed to bring a majority of MEPs on board to make progress on this critical issue. We cannot afford to allow the indiscriminate use of antibiotics, which are often sold online and end up on our plates. These heightened threats to human health and life make the use of medication to make up for shoddy animal husbandry absolutely unacceptable. We certainly need to establish classes of antimicrobials which are critical for human treatment and must be off-limits for other purposes. I very much hope that the Member States’ governments will be similarly minded, and refrain from diluting the agreement we reached today.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report on the licensing, manufacture, marketing, distribution, safety of medicines and the use of veterinary medicinal products.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote because it will help prevent the misuse and overuse of antibiotics on animals which could then potentially enter the human supply chain. The report covers, amongst other things: routine prophylactic use of antimicrobials being banned and metaphylactic use restricted; and the data protection period of technical documentation for new antibiotics set at 14 years with the possibility of prolongation however limited. Online sale of antimicrobials, psychotropics and vaccines is not allowed. It will also result in harmonisation of the requirement for a veterinary prescription and recognition of prescriptions across Member States.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe that a responsible use of all veterinary medicines in British livestock farming is vital to maintaining our high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare. We believe that all veterinary medicines should be used responsibly, under veterinary care and according to licensing conditions. With regard to economic incentives provided by pharmaceutical companies, whilst recognising the issues surrounding commercial practice and the specific use of incentives in the human and veterinary healthcare sectors, UKIP is concerned about a negative impact on the provision of cost benefit analyses and other health economic data and studies by neutral and independent academic research institutions. This is an area where the UK and USA institutions are world leaders and thus unnecessary EU interference has the potential to adversely affect their investigative work and its applications. UKIP believes that the EU should have no jurisdiction in what is a global arena for drug development and cannot enforce the removal of products from the market in this manner – this would penalise leading drug development companies including world-leading UK corporations.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has submitted the proposal for a Regulation on veterinary medicinal products incorporating a complete recast of the legislation on veterinary medicinal products, paragraphs here of Directive 2001/82/EC and Regulation (EC) No 726/2004, with the aim of regulating the authorisation, manufacture, marketing, distribution and use of veterinary medicinal products throughout their life cycle, as well as the applicable pharmacovigilance process. I support the Grossetête Report, considering that a specific regulatory framework was required, adapted to the characteristics of the veterinary sector, first in view of the problems that arose with the implementation of the existing legal framework, namely the lack of availability of veterinary medicinal products, the administrative burden imposed by the regulations, the functioning of the internal market and, of course, the increasingly worrying phenomenon of antibiotic resistance.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support the idea that the market for veterinary medicinal products should be clearly separated from the market for medicinal products for human use. I welcome the facilitating the access and availability of medicines, as well as the promotion of the internal market for veterinary medicinal products. This requires better cooperation within the 28 EU Member States, which will also ensure better cross-border consumer protection. I also support the rapporteur's more ambitious approach, according to which there should no longer be a preventive use of antibiotics in animal rearing. This is urgently needed if we are to be able to combat antibiotic resistance.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We in UKIP believe that a responsible use of all veterinary medicines in British livestock farming is vital to maintaining our high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare. We believe that all veterinary medicines should be used responsibly, under veterinary care and according to licensing conditions. With regard to economic incentives provided by pharmaceutical companies, whilst recognising the issues surrounding commercial practice and the specific use of incentives in the human and veterinary healthcare sectors, UKIP is concerned about a negative impact on the provision of cost benefit analyses and other health economic data and studies by neutral and independent academic research institutions. This is an area where the UK and USA institutions are world leaders and thus unnecessary EU interference has the potential to adversely affect their investigative work and its applications. UKIP believes that the EU should have no jurisdiction in what is a global arena for drug development and cannot enforce the removal of products from the market in this manner – this would penalise leading drug development companies including world-leading UK corporations.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The legal framework of the veterinary sector has always been a source of problems in its application, in particular with regard to the shortage of veterinary medicines (especially for smaller markets), the administrative burden imposed, the functioning of the internal market and, of course, the phenomenon of antibiotic resistance.  For these reasons, the Commission's proposal lays the foundations for a complete recast of the legislation on veterinary medicinal products, currently based on Directive 2001/82/EC and Regulation (EC) No 726/2004, and is intended to regulate the authorisation, manufacture, placing on the market, distribution and use of veterinary medicinal products throughout their life cycle, as well as the related pharmacovigilance process. I believe that it is fundamentally a step in the right direction, both in its objectives and in its desire to make a clear distinction between the market for veterinary medicinal products and that of medicinal products for human use. I agree with the rapporteur's comments and amendments, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ There is a need for new legislation which should increase the scope for research into and development and monitoring of veterinary medicinal products and which will increase production and profitability on the internal market. There is also a growing need for new and better medicines for use in livestock farming, in view of climate change and the worldwide trend towards greater movement. From the farmers’ point of view, it is of decisive importance that effective and accessible medicines should be available at a reasonable price when they are needed.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission has requested the establishment of rules on veterinary medicinal products, from the moment of manufacture to placing on the market, including the time of import, export and control, in order to pursue the objective of improving the functioning of the internal market, reducing administrative burdens, stimulating competitiveness and innovation and increasing the availability of veterinary medicinal products.  The European regulatory framework for veterinary medicinal products must be adapted to scientific progress and must protect the animal, seeking to minimise the suffering of veterinary medicinal products and ensuring their well-being. As many of our demands have been accepted and I consider this issue to be of major importance, I am in favour of it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that, although I disagree on important points, it is an improvement in legislation in this area at a time of current need. The report includes very positive references to the exclusive role that veterinarians should play in prescribing such medicinal products; the report also refers positively to the need to assess the environmental impact of medicines on the environment, the inclusion of small and medium-sized enterprises, the prevention of unnecessary suffering on animals, etc. This Regulation is very necessary in the face of the crises that the livestock sector is experiencing, with elements such as the extension of tuberculosis among other diseases that need the availability of such veterinary medicinal products. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Regulation aims to regulate the authorisation, manufacture, marketing, distribution and use of veterinary medicinal products throughout their life cycle, as well as the related pharmacovigilance process. This legislation is more ambitious with regard to the provisions related to combating antibiotic resistance, comes in particular with clear definitions of different forms of treatment (curative treatment, control treatment and preventive treatment) and prohibits the prophylactic use of antibacterial drugs. Close consistency between the Regulation on medicated feedingstuffs and the Regulation on veterinary medicinal products is therefore essential. The creation of a list of important antibiotics reserved for human medicine, which the Commission wishes to achieve, should be made only on condition that it is based on sound scientific criteria. Furthermore, the sale on the internet of antibiotics (and, more generally, the sale of veterinary medicinal products for which a prescription is required) should be prohibited as it poses a serious risk to public health.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In September 2014, The Commission has published a new draft regulation on veterinary medicinal products. This proposal completely restructures the existing provisions relating to veterinary medicinal products. It is intended to regulate the authorisation, manufacture, placing on the market, distribution, pharmacovigilance and use of veterinary medicinal products.  A number of tools and actions have been developed, m.in. collection by Member States of data on the use of antimicrobials, a list of antimicrobials to be reserved for the treatment of certain infections in humans, with a view to preserving the efficacy of certain active substances in humans, the prohibition of routine use of antimicrobials in prevention and strict conditions for ad hoc prevention and metaphylaxis, and minimum veterinary prescription requirements , as well as the introduction of a number of categories of veterinary medicinal products (anabolic, anti-inflammatory, anti-indemntive (other than against worms), anti-cancer, hormonal or psychotropic products or containing such substances, to which only a veterinarian may issue a prescription. I voted in favour of this document.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation on veterinary medicinal products that will govern the authorisation, manufacturing, marketing, distribution, drug safety and use of veterinary medicinal products over their lifetime. This regulation aims to improve access to medicinal products and make them widely available, to reduce the administrative burden, to promote innovation and competitiveness within the sector, to ensure that the internal market for veterinary medicinal products functions properly, and to tackle antibiotic resistance.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the creation of a more streamlined system of regulation of veterinary medicines allowing for improvements in the treatment of animal diseases. This reduction of bureaucracy in the industry is an important tool in assisting the development and production of medicines and treatment and safeguarding animals.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report aims to revise veterinary drug legislation dating back to 2004. The text covers the authorisation, production, sale, distribution and use of veterinary medicines during their lifetime.  Its objectives include improving access to medical products for professionals and encouraging innovation. The harmonisation of veterinary prescribing conditions and mutual recognition between Member States will create a level playing field between countries and a minimum level of health security. The text also provides for facilitating the circulation of veterinary medicines throughout the EU, while reducing the use of antibiotics in livestock.  Considering that this report facilitates the safe access of veterinary medicines via online purchase for breeders and their prescription by veterinarians, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In September 2014, the Commission published the new proposal for a regulation on veterinary medicinal products. The latter lays the foundations for a complete recast of legislation on veterinary medicinal products and is intended to regulate their authorization, manufacture, placing on the market, distribution and use throughout their life cycle.  Among the objectives identified by the Commission, emphasis should be placed on combating antibiotic resistance and promoting innovation and the competitiveness of the sector. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important to make a clear distinction between the market for veterinary medicinal products and the market for medicinal products for human use, guaranteeing the availability of products and promoting administrative simplification, without renouncing the essential objectives of public health and environmental protection.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. Antibiotic resistance is now a real scourge of public health, which is rooted in the abuse of antibiotics on farms. That is why I voted in favour of this regulation, which aims to completely revise the legislative framework for veterinary drugs. Thus, the text enacts a number of provisions to regulate the use of these substances in veterinary medicine, in order to reduce the number of antibiotics that end up on the consumer's plate.  Through this vote, we aim to encourage and protect innovation, reduce bureaucracy and relax certain marketing procedures.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. 'Increasing resistance to human and animal antibiotics is a towering public health problem. By 2050, it is estimated that 10 million people worldwide would die every year from the effects of resistant bacteria due to excessive and misuse of antibiotics. The warnings from both the World Health Organisation and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) are well known. If we want to prevent antibiotics from becoming unusable, action at different levels is necessary. The update of the legislation on veterinary medicinal products approved by the European Parliament today sends a strong signal that the N-VA delegation supports: in order to drastically reduce antimicrobial resistance, the preventive use of antibiotics in animals must be curbed. At the same time, innovation, research and competitiveness must be fully promoted in order to increase the availability of medicines and administrative burdens should be reduced.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which aims to combat the increasing resistance of bacteria to current antibiotics. The vote comes on the occasion of the draft update of EU legislation on veterinary medicines.  We advocate limited use of existing antimicrobials (including banning collective and preventive antibiotic treatment of animals; veterinary medicines should not be used to improve livestock performance or compensate for non-compliance with good breeding practices) and call for the development of new products that are less harmful to human health.  As such, I would like to see special attention paid to the online sale of antibiotics, vaccines and psychotropic products. It is essential to put an end to this uncontrolled purchase option.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report because I believe that limiting the use of antibiotics in agriculture is imperative. Measures need to be taken because citizens' health is at the forefront for me. This, of course, should be done gradually, and it can not be completely prohibited, and suddenly, because the spread of diseases in this area can also be threatened.  The use of antimicrobial drugs is a wonderful alternative and their manufacturers and researchers need to be stimulated. I am pleased that this report provides such incentives as an extension of the protection period for the technical documentation of new medicines.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Positively, if the majority of the Greens' amendments pass or if the PPE amendments do not pass, because it is a text that is very important for public health. Negatively, only if the Greens' amendments do not pass and pass the PPE.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft regulation on veterinary medicinal products completely recasts the legislation in force, which has so far been applied under Directive 2001/82/EC and Regulation (EC) No 726/2004. The aim of the new proposal is to regulate the authorisation, manufacture, placing on the market, distribution and use of veterinary medicinal products throughout the life of medicinal products. The text approved by the Committee on the Environment prioritises the problem of the availability of veterinary medicinal products, which can be tackled by strengthening innovation. The market for veterinary medicinal products is small and highly fragmented, so industry players have little motivation to innovate and introduce new products to the market. Compared to the current legislation, the draft contains a number of important advances for hungary. Taking into account the characteristics of the veterinary sector, the new legislation encourages the extension of preparations already authorised to other animal species. New antimicrobials and preparations for so-called less important animal species will enjoy enhanced data protection. The report prioritises drugs authorised for bees, giving them a 20-year privacy period. The changes can help the emergence of new antibiotics in veterinary medicine and improve the availability of preparations in sectors of particular importance in Hungary, such as beekeeping. Although there is room for improvement in the draft in order to take full account of the interests of the sectors covered by the regulation, the report provides an excellent basis for dialogue with the Council. It's a good step in the right direction.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The proposal aims to improve the availability of veterinary medicinal products, reduce administrative burdens, stimulate innovation in the sector and combat antibiotic resistance. Antimicrobial veterinary medicinal products should under no circumstances be used to improve production levels or to compensate for non-compliance with good animal husbandry practices. The fight against antibiotic resistance should begin at breeding sites. The aim of the proposal is, in particular, to ban the purely preventive use of antibiotics, to restrict mass treatments to very specific cases, to ban the veterinary use of antibiotics of critical importance for human medicine and to end the sale via the Internet of antimicrobial medicinal products.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it: although this report is more restrictive than the Commission's proposal, it does not respect the interests of our vets who carry out a real health sentry job.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report contains positive aspects. Ensuring the production of safe, effective and affordable veterinary medicines is an important objective for our producers. The introduction of the issue of generic medicines, antimicrobial resistances or small markets are important elements that go in the right direction. However, the pressure exerted by multinational companies on the EU institutions is clear, with the aim of extending their privileges and benefits to the fullest. It was necessary to go further in safeguarding the interests of smaller countries in order to prevent multinationals from making their products available only in the most profitable markets. The European Commission's proposal defends the interest of pharmaceutical multinationals by proposing the extension of periods of protection of documentation for antibiotics (18 years instead of 14) and the inclusion of main species in the marketing authorisation (two additional years instead of one). It also provides for the possibility of establishing a 5-year (non-cumulative) protection period for certain new post-authorisation studies or trials. We have tabled amendments to lower these document protection periods so that generic companies and small and medium-sized enterprises can access and enter the market.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the European Union has long maintained high standards of public health and environmental protection. I welcome the European Commission's proposal because it monitors the thorough separation of veterinary medicines from human medicines. With this Regulation, the European Commission is monitoring in particular the improvement of access to and availability of medicines for different animal species, the reduction of administrative burdens, but also the improvement of the functioning of the internal market in veterinary medicinal products. According to several experts and MEPs, the European Commission could adopt an even more ambitious regulation and should in future close a number of shortcomings, such as combating resistance to antimicrobial medicines or protecting the environment by introducing a single decentralised evaluation.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on veterinary medicinal products. In any event, for public health reasons, the new Regulation should enable Member States to maintain or adopt more far-reaching rules on the use and prescription of antimicrobial medicines. For health and environmental safety, authorised veterinary medicinal products should be used as a matter of priority. The use of medicinal products intended for human use must be subject to strict conditions.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to endorse the proposal and to welcome the alignment with the Lisbon Treaty. I support the decoupling of marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products from those for human medicinal products, to take account of the specific needs of the veterinary sector. It is important to harmonise the requirements for a veterinary prescription and recognition of prescriptions across Member States; to stimulate innovation and the development of new veterinary medicines; and to harmonise the periods of protection (and potential prolongation) of new data packages related to antimicrobial veterinary medicinal products. I believe the regulation will provide better access to veterinary medicines, take measures to fight antimicrobial resistance, reduce the administrative burden, and promote innovation and competitiveness within the sector. Finally I support action to reduce the use of antibiotics, which may not be sold via the internet.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that reform will improve the efficiency and availability of medicines in Europe. Also because it contributes to the protection of human health and the environment and addresses the responsible use of antibiotics to treat sick animals in order to avoid possible negative consequences for human health, such as antimicrobial resistance. As established by the European Medicines Agency (EMA), its use for prophylactic purposes should be limited to very exceptional assumptions, as well as a list of antibiotics reserved for human use. Medicinal products for human use should only be used as a last resort in the treatment of animals. Finally, the report includes a cross-reference with the new veterinary medicines legislation and the role of the EMA in the authorisation and supervision of veterinary products through a centralised procedure.

text: Writing. There is a great need for new legislation in the veterinary sector. An amendment tabled by myself and some colleagues helps to avoid unnecessary bureaucracy. Natural products and thus classic alternatives to the use of antibiotics could be excluded from the regulation.

text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe that a responsible use of all veterinary medicines in British livestock farming is vital to maintaining our high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare. We believe that the British Parliament should be able to legislate on this issue without being overruled by the unelected EU Commission.

text: in writing. In favour of this report, we voted in favour of this report as it points to greater control of both the sales cycle of antibiotics and their use. It limits the online sale of medicines that should be sold with a prescription, is limited and controls use preventively and relates to other issues that concern animal welfare criteria.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. There is a need to ensure the availability of safe, effective and affordable veterinary medicinal products in the EU while guaranteeing their responsible use.

text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Over time it has become clear that the needs of the veterinary sector differ significantly from those of the human sector in relation to medicines. For example, price-setting mechanisms in the veterinary field follow a completely different logic. Therefore, prices for veterinary medicinal products are usually significantly lower than for medicinal products intended for human use. We voted in favour of the report, since it proposes measures to address such problems as (a) the lack of availability of veterinary medicinal products, (b) administrative burdens, (c) a reduction in competitiveness and innovation and (d) the risk to public health of antimicrobial resistance (AMR).

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the regulation after having worked on the file over a number of months. Firstly, I believe it will bring more certainty to the EU regulatory environment for veterinary medicines compared to the current situation where legislation is fragmented across different areas. This regulation will also help increase the availability of veterinary medicinal products by removing red tape and allowing for the harmonisation of the summaries of product characteristics. This will benefit originator and generic manufacturers which will hopefully lead to greater availability and more competitive prices. I supported reducing the Commission’s proposal for the protection of technical documentation for the first marketing authorisation by originator drug companies from 18 years to 14 years. In addition to that, I was very happy to note that the regulation clearly aims at combating anti-microbial resistance which is of particular concern to health professionals. I was also very happy that salmon will be contained within the scope of the regulation. Finally, I was happy to support the amendments which called for the continuity of the use of homeopathy in animals. This contributes to the reduction of the use of antibiotics and allows for consumers to continue using these practices.

text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report since there must be a regulation that sets more efficient and effective access to veterinary medicines. Moreover, such a regulation will also promote competitiveness within the sector, while reducing the administrative burden.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on veterinary medicinal products, on the view that I believe it is necessary to ensure the availability of safe, efficient and affordable products across the Union by encouraging their responsible use. Of particular importance is the fight against growing antimicrobial resistance, and further attention is focused on improving the regulatory framework related to the reasonable use of antimicrobials for the treatment of animals. It is also necessary to reduce the administrative burden for all actors involved, which represents the position of the ALDE Group, and therefore I support this report.

text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Françoise Grossetête's report on the european Parliament and the Council's proposed regulation on veterinary medicines. The aim of this report is to combat antibiotic resistance and thus limit the use of antimicrobials. The European Parliament is calling for a ban on collective and preventive antibiotic treatments and wants new alternatives to be developed. I therefore agree with this report which aims to combat antibiotic resistance and the presence of antibiotics on the plates of Europeans while encouraging innovation in research. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. In my opinion, it was the right decision to postpone the vote and to start negotiations directly in the trialogue. While the rapporteur can conclusively state that the proposed Commission regulation could, with the amendments made by the rapporteur, contribute to the achievement of the objectives, the large number of amendments would have affected a clear vote and would ultimately lead to an unfinished regulation.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal as it provides better access to veterinary medicines, takes measures to fight antimicrobial resistance, reduces the administrative burden, and promotes innovation and competitiveness within the sector.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because it represents an important step in the fight against antibiotic resistance: animal health needs a secure supply of high-quality medicines and proper use in practice. This is the only way to protect public health and combat the irresponsible use of antibiotics.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The plenary has today dismissed an important text, and I would like to thank Mr Söderman for his excellent report. Grossetête for the excellent work done in recent months.  One of its main objectives is the protection of animal health and, consequently, of human health. It aims to combat antibiotic resistance, while at the same time increasing the competitiveness of our farms and veterinary medicine industries. An important space is allocated to the role of the veterinarian, whose importance of work and professionalism are stressed, without a reduction in the therapeutic arsenal at his disposal. On the other hand, provision is made for a reduction in out-of-authorization medicinal products, which continue to be placed on the market.  The foundations are also being laid for a new pharmacovigilance system which will be more flexible, more effective and less bureaucratic.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported my colleague Françoise GROSSET-EE's report on veterinary medicines to completely amend existing legislation by reserving certain substances for human medicine, framing their prescription and banning the online sale of antibiotics and their routine use.  These measures should benefit consumers, who will find fewer antibiotics on their plates, and breeders, who benefit from clear and applicable rules without reducing the therapeutic arsenal of veterinarians.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the veterinary drug report. The main concerns that underpinned the proposals are the fight against antibiotic resistance and the assurance of the best possible availability of medicines. Underneath this objective lies in a liberalisation of the sale of medicines, especially through online sales sites, subtracting this source of income from veterinarians, more able to deliver the products.  Although this report is more restrictive than the Commission's proposal, it does not respect the interests of our vets who carry out a real health sentry job. It also allows the prescription of certain medicines by non-veterinarians because of England, which is unacceptable for public health reasons.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to regulate the marketing and circulation of veterinary drugs. The measures put to the vote respond to the general desire to combat antibiotic resistance and to ensure optimal availability of medicines. However, the adoption of such regulations will facilitate the liberalisation of medicines and benefit online sales sites or, in particular, allow non-veterinarians to prescribe certain medicines, which is a violation of the interests of our veterinarians.  The Commission not only over-liberalizes a public health issue, but also endangers an essential profession. So I voted AGAINST this text.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that reform will improve the efficiency and availability of medicines in Europe. Also because it contributes to the protection of human health and the environment and addresses the responsible use of antibiotics to treat sick animals in order to avoid possible negative consequences for human health, such as antimicrobial resistance. As established by the European Medicines Agency (EMA), its use for prophylactic purposes should be limited to very exceptional assumptions, as well as a list of antibiotics reserved for human use. Medicinal products for human use should only be used as a last resort in the treatment of animals. Finally, the report includes a cross-reference with the new veterinary medicines legislation and the role of the EMA in the authorisation and supervision of veterinary products through a centralised procedure.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that reform will improve the efficiency and availability of medicines in Europe. Also because it contributes to the protection of human health and the environment and addresses the responsible use of antibiotics to treat sick animals in order to avoid possible negative consequences for human health, such as antimicrobial resistance. As established by the European Medicines Agency (EMA), its use for prophylactic purposes should be limited to very exceptional assumptions, as well as a list of antibiotics reserved for human use. Medicinal products for human use should only be used as a last resort in the treatment of animals. Finally, the report includes a cross-reference with the new veterinary medicines legislation and the role of the EMA in the authorisation and supervision of veterinary products through a centralised procedure.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that, although I disagree on important points, it is an improvement in legislation in this area at a time of current need. The report includes very positive references to the exclusive role that veterinarians should play in prescribing such medicinal products; the report also refers positively to the need to assess the environmental impact of medicines on the environment, the inclusion of small and medium-sized enterprises, the prevention of unnecessary suffering on animals, etc. This Regulation is very necessary in the face of the crises that the livestock sector is experiencing, with elements such as the extension of tuberculosis among other diseases that need the availability of such veterinary medicinal products. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The report we are dealing with comes from a new draft Regulation of the European Commission to recast all existing legislation so far on veterinary medicinal products. In my view, this report must be supported, on the one hand, because it aims to unify the authorisation, manufacture, marketing and distribution of veterinary medicinal products and, on the other hand, because it guarantees access to them and reduces administrative burdens, thus stimulating innovation and competitiveness of the sector and ensuring the proper functioning of the internal market. Due to the specific characteristics of this sector, the report's priority is a clear differentiation with the human medicines market. I also show my support for some of its ambitions, such as the incorporation of a ban on the online sale of these antibiotics and the extension of measures to promote innovation in this sector, increasing periods of data protection, studies and new trials.  For all this I vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Directive 2001/82/EC and Regulation (EC) No. 726/2004 define procedures for authorization and supervision of medical devices for humans and animals. The aim of this Report is to consolidate instruments for veterinary products. All the conditions in which veterinary products can be used are defined, how and when antibiotics for animals are used. This Report introduces harmonisation of the system for the use of veterinary products, stimulates the development of veterinary medicine and takes special care to reduce the negative impact on the environment, so I supported it.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of postponing the vote on the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on veterinary medicinal products in accordance with the rapporteur's proposal.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This draft report aims to regulate the marketing and circulation of veterinary drugs. The main concerns that underpinned the proposals are the fight against antibiotic resistance and the assurance of the best possible availability of medicines. Underneath this objective lies in a liberalisation of the sale of medicines, especially through online sales sites, subtracting this source of income from veterinarians, more able to deliver the products.  Although this report is more restrictive than the Commission's proposal, it does not respect the interests of our vets who carry out a real health sentry job. It also allows the prescription of certain medicines by non-veterinarians because of England, which is unacceptable for public health reasons (e.g. "mad cow").

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on veterinary medicinal products. The existence of these effective and accessible medicines at a reasonable price is essential for broadening the scope of research and development, increasing the production of veterinary medicinal products and their profitability in the internal market.  We therefore need legislation that is explicit and as simple as possible in order to improve access to medicines, reduce administrative burdens, stimulate competitiveness and innovation, so as to make available new and better medicines for the treatment and prevention of animal diseases, while avoiding harming the environment.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the Commission’s draft regulation, I believe that it is a move in the right direction and fully agree with the Commission’s objectives and its view that the veterinary medicines market should be separated from the human medicines market, which works very differently. The Commission is right to stress the importance of product availability and simpler administrative procedures without sacrificing the principles of public health and the protection of the environment.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Antibiotic resistance poses a real threat to our health, especially with regard to animals that feed on meat. That is why I am pleased that this report calls for detailed data collection at Member State level, which must be at the forefront of solving these problems.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour over the years that, for the years, it has become clear that, for medicinal products, the issues and needs of the veterinary sector and the human sector were different, as the existence of multiple species implies greater investment, for example, in extending authorisations for existing medicinal products of one species to the other. Pricing must also follow its own logic, but it is a pity that several increased difficulties in the availability of medicines for smaller market sectors such as bees are created.  A distinct legal framework for veterinary medicinal products is therefore essential.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The new Regulation on veterinary medicinal products, which I vote in favour, will better regulate the authorisation, manufacture, marketing, distribution and use of these products, as well as surveillance. From this Parliament we have made some improvements to the text proposed by the Commission, and I am sure that the final text will improve access to and availability of medicines, especially with regard to so-called minor species, reduce administrative burdens, in particular as regards the pharmacovigilance procedure, stimulate innovation and competitiveness in the sector , ensure the proper functioning of the internal market for veterinary medicinal products and combat antibiotic resistance.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The Commission's recent proposal to introduce a new regulation on veterinary medicinal products completely revises existing legislation (Directive 2001/82/EC and EC 726/2004). The new Regulation will regulate in its entirety the procedure for the manufacture, authorisation, promotion, distribution and use of veterinary medicinal products by interested parties. The need for a modern regulatory field reflecting the specific needs of the veterinary sector at European and national level has prompted me to vote in favour of this initiative. From the purposes of the proposal from the Commission, I consider it desirable and necessary to improve access to veterinary medicinal products even for smaller markets, which must be taken into account in particular and will help to increase the overall availability of these products by reducing the administrative burdens on their disposal. At the same time, it aims to promote and enhance the competitiveness and innovation of the veterinary medicinal products market by providing incentives for new ideas and improving the quality of existing medicines. Particular attention should be paid to the issue of antibiotics, in particular the definition of the terms and conditions for their administration and the prohibition of their distribution via the internet. Environmental protection remains, after all, a guiding tool in the whole effort.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on the EC proposal for a regulation on veterinary medicinal products. The purpose of this legislation is to regulate the authorisation, manufacture, marketing, distribution and use of veterinary medicinal products for veterinary medicinal products and to facilitate the use of medicinal products for human use without a marketing authorisation for the treatment of animals.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that aims to ban preventative use of antibiotics and restrictions of their use in the treatment of animals, while also supporting innovation in this sector.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft report aims to regulate the marketing of veterinary drugs. Behind the laudable desire for better availability of medicines and a fight against antibiotic resistance is liberalism. It must be said that pharmaceutical groups have been involved in the liberalization of drug sales.  I recognize that this report is more mature than that of the Commission, but the prescription it authorizes for non-veterinary persons is unreasonable in terms of public health. More fundamentally, it goes against the interests of veterinarians who remain by their work health guarantors. So I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. New legislation is extremely important to extend the scope for research, development and monitoring of veterinary medicinal products.  Farmers need to have effective, affordable and reasonably priced medicines at their disposal. It is important to know more about antimicrobial resistance, which poses a serious threat to humans and animals. That is why i voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on veterinary medicinal products.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution as it builds upon the work done by the Commission to separate the veterinary medicinal market from the human medicinal market as well reducing the red tape, maintaining the principles of public health and protecting the environment. I also supported the proposed measures to curb antimicrobial resistance.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Anti-antibiotic resistance is increasingly present around the world and poses a serious threat to public health. In the years to come, the resistance of bacteria to antibiotics will therefore pose a real health challenge. Closely linked to the administration of antibiotics to farm animals, the problem of antibiotic resistance must be addressed at the source. The European legislator must therefore adopt provisions on veterinary medicines as soon as possible. As such, I welcome Parliament's adoption of its position on the legislative proposal for veterinary medicines. The use of antibiotics on farms must be strictly supervised in order to limit it to what is strictly necessary and to avoid any misuse, undifferentiated or systematic use of antibiotics on animals destined for the food chain.  In addition to framing the use of antibiotics, the focus should be on finding alternatives to these drugs. Innovation must be encouraged to ensure that antibiotics are used as narrowly as possible and thus perpetuate their effects. This is an urgent issue that we must make every effort to address. It's about all of us.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – The new regulation would constitute a separate legislation on veterinary medicinal products, separate from the regulation regulating human medicinal products. It responds to changes in veterinary medicine and pharmacy, which should naturally be taken into account by current legislation. The Regulation aims to regulate the process of authorisation of veterinary medicinal products, their manufacture, distribution, sale, pharmacokinetics and use throughout their lifetime. I consider it important that the regulation will address questions about how to improve access to veterinary medicines and ensure their wider availability, how to respond to problems related to the trend of increasing antibiotic resistance of animals, to encourage innovation or to protect the environment. The new Regulation should take into account the proposals made in the submitted report concerning a total ban on the prescription of antibacterial agents for preventive purposes, the determination of a data protection period of 14 years, with the possibility of extension, the issue of the recognition of prescriptions in individual Member States, requirements for the labelling of veterinary medicinal products, the improvement and simplification of the authorisation and marketing process for veterinary medicinal products, etc. I am therefore voting in favour of the proposal tabled.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the veterinary medicinal products in order to have a regulation that provides better access to veterinary medicines, takes measures to fight antimicrobial resistance, reduces the administrative burden, and promotes innovation and competitiveness within the sector.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The draft report aims to regulate the marketing and circulation of veterinary drugs, with the main concerns being the fight against antibiotic resistance and the possible best availability of these drugs. This report undermines the interests of our veterinary medicine, in particular because it proposes to allow the prescribing of medicines by non-veterinarians, which also presents a real health risk. We are voting against this report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Veterinary medicinal products are, to date, regulated by Directive 2001/82/EC and Regulation (EC) No 726/2004. I believe that there is a need for new legislation with the aim of extending the scope for research, development and monitoring of veterinary medicinal products and increasing production and profitability in the internal market. Some shortcomings have been found in the current legal framework, such as the lack of availability of veterinary medicinal products, the administrative burden imposed by regulation, the functioning of the internal market and antibiotic resistance. It is important to highlight the complexity of the production of veterinary medicinal products, in some cases more intricate than the production of medicinal products for human use, due to market fragmentation. I believe that the laws and regulations relating to the development of veterinary medicinal products should be clear, explicit and simple. I believe it is essential that measures to promote innovation be expanded and that public health and environmental protection are always safeguarded.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Although this report is more restrictive than the Commission's proposal, it does not respect the interests of our veterinarians who carry out a real health sentinel work. It also allows the prescription of certain medicines by non-veterinarians because of England, which is unacceptable for public health reasons (e.g. mad cow). If it had not been postponed, I would have voted against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I support this report. In particular, I voted in favour of all the provisions that limit the misuse of antibiotics on farms, including by prohibiting their online sale and routine use.  Systematically finding certain molecules in meat consumed by humans can eventually create resistance that will no longer cure certain diseases. There was therefore an urgent need to reform veterinary drug legislation.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I was not able, for medical reasons, to attend the plenary session from 7 to 10 March 2016. Nevertheless, I would like to express my support for the report on veterinary and human medicines.  This report, in particular, aims to improve access to medicines, innovation and respect for the environment. It also contains important clarifications regarding the attribution of veterinary doctors in the prescribing and sale of antibiotics.  I know the importance of the work of doctors and veterinarians. I am therefore largely in favour of this report as prepared by Mrs Grossetête.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the new draft regulation on veterinary medicinal products drawn up by the Commission with the aim of regulating procedures for veterinary medicinal products. The report aims to introduce a new regulatory framework aimed at boosting innovation and competition in the sector, improving the availability of medicines and substantially reducing administrative burdens. I particularly welcome the proposals to differentiate the market for veterinary medicinal products from the market for medicinal products for human use.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission published its new draft regulation on veterinary medicinal products in September 2014. I have voted for this report that will improve the existing rules on medicinal products for veterinary use set out in Directive 2001/82/EC and Regulation EC 726/2004.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on veterinary medicinal products, which improves existing legislation and creates the conditions for improving veterinary care. I consider the fight against antibacterial resistance, which is plaguing more and more farmers and breeders, to be an important element. I consider it right that the condition for issuing a prescription for a veterinary product is the establishment of a veterinary diagnosis on the basis of a clinical examination of an animal and that its continuous health monitoring is not sufficient.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that a revision of the EU law on veterinary medicinal products is necessary. I am also in favour of promoting research into new medicines in this area. The rapporteur has presented the situation in a coherent way so that the objectives mentioned can be achieved as desired.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The existence of relevant rules and rules and the widest possible simplicity of the relevant rules and rules are essential for the development of veterinary medicinal products. At the same time, more attention should be paid to the fight against ANTIMICROBIAL RESISTANCE. This is an area that needs more attention, as it also directly affects people.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU must have a common legal framework that adequately protects public health, animal health and the environment and ensures food safety. The new legal regulation must be proportionate, adapted to the specificities of the veterinary sector. It should be noted that the needs of the veterinary and human medical sectors in relation to medicines vary considerably. A different regulatory mechanism should therefore be applied.  In view of the spread of antimicrobial resistance, it is necessary to address as soon as possible the public health risks of antimicrobial resistance. Incentives must be created for the treatment and prevention of new animal diseases.  The EU needs to create an efficient single market for veterinary medicinal products that increases the availability of veterinary medicinal products, promotes competitiveness and innovation and reduces administrative burdens.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe that a responsible use of all veterinary medicines in British livestock farming is vital to maintaining our high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare. We believe that all veterinary medicines should be used responsibly, under veterinary care and according to licensing conditions. With regard to economic incentives provided by pharmaceutical companies, whilst recognising the issues surrounding commercial practice and the specific use of incentives in the human and veterinary healthcare sectors, UKIP is concerned about a negative impact on the provision of cost benefit analyses and other health economic data and studies by neutral and independent academic research institutions. This is an area where the UK and USA institutions are world leaders and thus unnecessary EU interference has the potential to adversely affect their investigative work and its applications. UKIP believes that the EU should have no jurisdiction in what is a global arena for drug development and cannot enforce the removal of products from the market in this manner – this would penalise leading drug development companies including world-leading UK corporations.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the rapporteur's proposal as it represents an important step towards greater supervision in the field of veterinary medical products. This will make it easier to control the area of authorisation, manufacture, marketing and life span of medicines. We aim to ensure the conditions for better access to medicines, to increase the number of innovations, particularly in the area of eliminating antibiotic resistance, and to protecting the environment. At the same time, I also support this proposal because of the need to define the circumstances of when a veterinarian can prescribe and sell an antibiotic medicine, in order to reduce the overuse of antibiotics in animal husbandry, which leads to increasing resistance of bacteria to medicines.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. I supported the postponement of the vote and the start of negotiations on this report with the Council and the Commission. The decision that the use of prophyromatic antimicrobial veterinary medicines should be allowed for use only in the case of individual animals and when veterinarians decide to do so for duly justified reasons and in exceptional cases I assess it as good. The use of metaphylactic antimicrobial veterinary drugs will be limited to use in clinically ill animals and individual cases, when there is a risk of the spread of the disease. I am committed to tightening the criteria when talking about veterinary medicines because it is about the health of all of us who consume meat and meat products.  I pay particular attention to online sales, where the rules become stricter, i.e. antimicrobials, biological and immunological veterinary medicinal products must not be offered for sale online. I also recall the importance of protecting animal health and the possible consequences by which they would be exposed to irresponsible use of medicines.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The legal framework for veterinary medicinal products should be adapted to scientific progress, current market conditions and economic reality by respecting animals, nature and their interaction with man.  Animals may become ill with a wide range of diseases that must be prevented or treated with veterinary medicinal products to ensure their health, and our role is to ensure that pharmaceutical substances or veterinary medicinal products manufactured or placed on the market do not have a detrimental effect on human or animal health or any unacceptable environmental impact.  For this reason, I support this Veterinary Medicinal Products Regulation, which provides better access to veterinary medicines, takes action to combat antimicrobial resistance, reduces the burden of administrative procedures and barriers, and encourages research, innovation and competitiveness in the sector.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have identified positive elements in the report. Ensuring the production of safe, effective and affordable veterinary medicinal products is relevant to our producers. Equally important and correct is the introduction of the issue of generic medicines, antimicrobial resistances or small markets. The pressure exerted by large pharmaceutical multinationals on the EU institutions is great and clear, seeking to extend their privileges and benefits to the fullest. In this sense, it falls short of safeguarding the interests of smaller countries in order to prevent multinationals from making their products available only in the most profitable markets. The European Commission's proposal defends the interest of pharmaceutical multinationals by proposing the extension of periods of protection of documentation for antibiotics (18 years instead of 14) and the inclusion of main species in the marketing authorisation (two additional years instead of one). It also provides for the possibility of establishing a 5-year (non-cumulative) protection period for certain new post-authorisation studies or trials. We have tabled amendments to lower these document protection periods so that generic companies and small and medium-sized enterprises can access and enter the market.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. – I support my colleague Grossetete's report. Given that the needs and characteristics of the veterinary sector differ from that of humane and both medicines markets work differently, I consider it necessary to establish a new regulatory framework for veterinary medicines. After all, the production itself dictates that.  The production of veterinary medicinal products is considered more demanding and financially generous due to the market inaliety caused by the vehicular of different animal species. It is necessary to attract more investors even though the price of the drugs itself is lower than those for human consumption. It is impossible to apply the model of the market of drugs for human consumption on drugs for animals. In addition, this regulation would achieve the objective of making veterinary medicinal products more accessible to populations engaged in livestock farming, for example. In accordance with the animal species, various diseases may occur and it is necessary that this Regulation ensures a high standard of animal health. It is achieved by enhancing veterinary medicinal products in the form of quality, safety and efficacy.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I have supported this report, which aims to update EU veterinary medicine legislation. Because it was dangerous, collective and preventive antibiotic treatment of animals had to be banned. Quite simply, one of the objectives is to prevent too many antibiotics from getting on the consumer's plate.  Nevertheless, the therapeutic means of veterinarians should not be called into question and it is thereby necessary to encourage the search for new medicines.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe that a responsible use of all veterinary medicines in British livestock farming is vital to maintaining our high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare. We believe that all veterinary medicines including antibiotics should be used responsibly, under veterinary care and according to licensing conditions. We believe that the British Parliament should be able to legislate on this issue without being overruled by the unelected EU Commission.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report addresses the commission's proposal for a regulation on veterinary medicinal products, which incorporates a complete recast of legislation and intends to regulate the authorisation, manufacture, marketing, distribution and use of veterinary medicinal products throughout their life cycle, as well as the applicable pharmacovigilance process. I voted in favour of this report because I agree with the necessary differentiation between the market for veterinary medicinal products and the human medicines market, which should only be applied as a last resort and in the absence of a better alternative. In line with the above in this report, I support the need to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market in relation to veterinary medicinal products, the strengthening of measures to encourage innovation, as well as the creation of a system based on the regular submission of pharmacovigilance reports during the first years of the product's life and, subsequently, on risk analysis and signal deployment. In view of the foregoing, and also because the report contains the need for special attention to environmental protection, I voted in favour of it.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. At noon, MEPs adopted the draft update of EU legislation on veterinary medicines. An important vote in a worrying context of antibiotic resistance. In this regard, the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) recently warned that bacteria in humans and animals continue to show resistance to the most commonly used antimicrobials. Resistance to ciprofloxacin, an extremely important antimicrobial for the treatment of infections in humans, is particularly problematic. Agreement was reached on the main points, first of all the principle ban on the prophylactic use of antibiotics. This means authorizing only the preventive administration of medicines to animals on an individual basis and only when justified by a veterinarian. The latter remains at the heart of the system, it is essential, and will be able to continue to prescribe and deliver the drugs.  Other limits have been set by the European Parliament, such as a ban on the veterinary use of antibiotics critical to human medicine or the desire to end the sale of prescription antibiotics and vaccines on the internet. An agreement is now within reach with the Council at first reading.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal on veterinary medicinal products has been voted in favour. Its purpose is to regulate the authorisation, manufacture, marketing, distribution and use of veterinary medicinal products throughout their life cycle, as well as the applicable pharmacovigilance process. The Commission's proposal has as main objectives: to improve access to medicines and their availability; reduce administrative burdens, in particular with regard to the pharmacovigilance process; stimulate innovation and competitiveness of the sector; ensure the proper functioning of the internal market in relation to veterinary medicinal products and also to combat antibiotic resistance. The proposal also aims to clearly differentiate the market for veterinary medicinal products from the human medicines market. I disagreed only with the extension of periods of protection of the technical documentation of veterinary medicinal products, which I consider to be an unnecessary obstacle to market access for generic medicines, allowing them to increase the availability of medicinal products, financial access (price control) to them and to promote their own competitiveness.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on veterinary medicinal products Veterinary medicinal products are regulated in Directive 2001/82/EC and Regulation (EC) No 726/2004.
