In 2004, the Commission proposed to unite the two acts, with objectives such as improving access to veterinary medicinal products, reducing the bureaucratic burden, analyzing antibiotic resistance and promoting competitiveness innovation.  The issue of veterinary medicinal products, as well as the need to establish a comprehensive approach to their use, makes it mandatory to review veterinary pharmaceutical legislation. The Socialist Group therefore calls for the inclusion of more ambitious objectives, such as banning the use of prophylactics in antibiotics or clarifying the conditions under which veterinarians prescribe and sell antibiotics, as well as the online sale of antibiotics. The framework of human medicinal products should be tightened for use with animals and a number of preventive measures should be established before resorting to antimicrobial treatments of entire groups of animals intended for food production.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament adopted amendments to the European Commission's initial proposal on veterinary medicines in plenary on Thursday 10 March. But it was decided to postpone the vote on the draft legislative resolution "to proceed directly to inter-institutional negotiations on the basis of the mandate adopted".  The amended text aims to better combat antibiotic resistance on farms, including by prohibiting pure preventive use (prophylaxis) and by conditioning metaphylactic use (treatment of an entire herd when a single animal is sick).  Personally, I also supported an amendment that seeks to add, to the grounds that may justify a refusal to market authorization, the fact that the drug contains GMOs (knowing that currently 19 vaccines containing GMOs are already on the market).

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the content point of view of the really well-designed proposal. The issue of safe and sheltered veterinary products is important for the eu sector as a whole.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which aims to combat the increasing resistance of bacteria to current antibiotics. Thus, the use of existing antimicrobials should be limited and new products should be developed. The fight against antibiotic resistance must begin on farms and to do so we must ensure that the only preventive use of antibiotics is prohibited, that mass treatments are reduced to specific cases, or that the online sale of antibiotics, vaccines or psychotropic products is prohibited. With these measures, the amount of antibiotics will be reduced. At the same time, it is important to develop incentives to encourage the search for new antimicrobials.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In favour of this report, we voted in favour of this report as it points to greater control of both the sales cycle of antibiotics and their use. It limits the online sale of medicines that should be sold with a prescription, is limited and controls use preventively and relates to other issues that concern animal welfare criteria.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report. The measures contained in it, especially those concerning prophylactic and metaphylactic use of antibiotics and restrictions on internet sales, should help in the struggle against antimicrobial resistance. At the same time, the distribution of essential veterinary medicines throughout the EU should be increased and the administrative burden reduced.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. We in the European Parliament agree that the use of antibiotics in animals should be restricted. Our bid for new veterinary legislation is a good step forward and shows how seriously we are taking the problem. We open up the possibility of reserving certain types of antibiotics for human health so that they are not used in agriculture and for animals in general. In 20 years' time, Europe must also be able to treat a simple pneumonia, and this proposal will help to ensure that. From the Danish and Nordic eyes, the rules should have gone even further. But this is, after all, a step in the right direction. That is why I support the agreement.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the draft report on veterinary medicinal products, as I think it is a good proposal to dedicate a separate regulation to veterinary medicinal products and to leave medicinal products for human use in the previous Directive 726/2004. The report deals with improving access to medicines and increasing the incentive to promote innovation, tackle antibiotic resistance and protect the environment. I find it relevant that the general reduction in the use of antibiotics and the harmonisation of the requirements for veterinary prescription and recognition of prescriptions are relevant. There was a need for discussion on the 14-year data protection period for technical documentation on new antibiotics, as problems could arise for generic manufacturers. However, we reached a compromise.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that, although I disagree on important points, it is an improvement in legislation in this area at a time of current need. The report positively refers to the need to assess the environmental impact of medicines on the environment, the inclusion of small and medium-sized enterprises, the prevention of unnecessary suffering on animals, etc. This Regulation is much needed in the face of crises in the livestock sector, with elements such as the spread of tuberculosis among other diseases. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation voted on today, which lays the foundations for a revision of existing legislation on veterinary medicinal products.  The objectives set out in the report concern access to these medicines and their availability, innovation and development of new generation medicines, the proper functioning of the internal market for veterinary medicines, the reduction of administrative burdens and antibiotic resistance. On this last point, I think it is important to emphasise that the proposal regulates the limited use of antimicrobial drugs: the prophylactic use of antibiotics as a preventive measure should only be implemented if fully justified by a veterinarian, and therefore not to improve performance or compensate for inappropriate farming practices.  Indeed, the figure released by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control that bacteria in humans, food and animals continue to show resistance to the most common antimicrobials is worrying, with the result that bacteria such as salmonella continue to proliferate throughout Europe. I believe it is essential that we invest better and more in research and innovation in the development of new medicines.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe that a responsible use of all veterinary medicines in British livestock farming is vital to maintaining our high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare. We believe that all veterinary medicines including antibiotics should be used responsibly, under veterinary care and according to licensing conditions. We believe that the British Parliament should be able to legislate on this issue without being overruled by the unelected EU Commission.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is clear that we need to have a regulation that provides better access to veterinary medicines, so I voted in favour of this because I believe that measures need to be taken to fight against antimicrobial resistance due to the routine use of prophylactic antibiotics, as well as aiming to reduce the administrative burden. We need to see an environment where this sector can innovate and develop the best medicinal products possible.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I am in favour of reducing the consumption of antibiotics in veterinary medicine. It is therefore necessary to take action against the excessive, ill-considered and unjustified use of antibiotics in this area as well, which is why I voted in favour of adopting this resolution.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this proposal for a Regulation as it has the potential to simplify the regulatory environment and reduce administrative burdens in the issuance and management of veterinary medicinal products. The proposal will stimulate the development of new veterinary medicines and encourage their Internet sales throughout the European Union. This Regulation raises the criteria of good breeding and management practices to enhance animal welfare. Veterinary prescriptions in the future will require a complete clinical examination of animals, not just evidence of constant health checks. Better information is also needed on how, when, where and why antimicrobials are used. Member States therefore undertake to analyse and publish data on the volume of sales of antimicrobials. Antimicrobial production also has an impact on the environment, but this Regulation unfortunately did not oblige manufacturers to report data on these impacts. Great success has been achieved in approving the use of homeopathic remedies intended for humans, for use in all animals, including those used for food production.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ due to the fact that the manufacture of veterinary medicinal products is much more complex than the manufacture of medicinal products for human use, the market for veterinary medicinal products is too fragmented. That is why the Commission came up with a proposal in September 2014 with a proposal for measures to support the development and distribution of veterinary medicinal products. The European Parliament has tabled a number of amendments to this proposal for a regulation, as some issues have not been sufficiently addressed. After more than a year and a half of negotiations, it seems that the current form of the legislative text could contain all the necessary measures, which is why I supported the amendments. The Regulation should in future concern the regulation of the authorisation, manufacture, placing on the market, distribution and use during their lifetime, as well as pharmacokinetics. The Commission intends to improve access to medicines, reduce administrative burdens, promote innovation, ensure the good functioning of the market, but also combat antibiotic resistance. It is the issue of antibiotics that is essential for public health. The Commission's wish to draw up a key list of antibiotics reserved for human medicine must be based on sound scientific criteria. At the same time, the online sale of antibiotics as well as all prescription veterinary medicinal products should be prohibited, as such practice poses a serious risk to public health. In addition to trying to improve the market for veterinary medicinal products, it is also necessary to think about the impact on human health and the protection of the environment.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation on veterinary medicinal products, which updates the Relevant European Framework, in order to protect animal and human health at the same time as protecting the environment.  With regard to the Commission's proposal, which focuses on the availability of veterinary medicines and administrative simplification, while respecting public health and environmental protection, the text voted on today adds another important aspect, the fight against antibiotic resistance. Indeed, as a Parliament, we call for the preventive use of antibiotics for farm animals to be restrictd, that is to say, to avoid using antibiotics as a preventive measure and in the absence of clinical signs of infection, or even as a means of improving livestock performance.  As recently reported by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), bacteria in humans, food and animals continue to show resistance to the most common antimicrobials, thus reducing options for the effective treatment of serious infections. It is therefore necessary for humans and animals to have a clear overview of the use of all antimicrobial medicines as soon as possible, so that we can act without delay to reduce their misuse and put an end to abuse.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ the area of veterinary medicinal products also needs to be adapted to scientific progress, market requirements and the economic situation. It is precisely in order to strengthen the protection of public health that there should be a framework in the Union to improve animal welfare and easy access to effective veterinary medicinal products. The introduction of good breeding and management practices will significantly reduce the risk of a negative impact on public health.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒In light of the lessons learned and following the Commission's assessment of the functioning of the veterinary medicinal products market, the legal framework for veterinary medicinal products needs to be adapted to scientific progress, current market conditions and economic reality. Animals can get a whole range of preventable or treatable diseases. The impact of animal diseases and the measures necessary to combat them can be devastating for individual animals, animal populations, animal keepers and the economy.  Diseases of animals that are transmittable to humans can also have a significant impact on public health. Therefore, sufficient effective veterinary medicinal products must be available in the Union to ensure high standards of animal health and public health and the development of the agriculture and aquaculture sectors.  A pharmacovigilance database at Union level should also be established to record and unify information on adverse events for all veterinary medicinal products authorised in the Union. The database should improve the detection of adverse events and enable and facilitate pharmacovigilance surveillance and division of work between competent authorities, and I therefore supported the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs support a ban on routine prophylactic use of antibiotics in farming to help fight antimicrobial resistance.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Veterinary medicinal products should be paid attention in equal measure and even higher, as well as for medical devices for human use. In animal husbandry, it is particularly important that newer and better medicines are available, as it is essential that veterinary medicinal products are available at reasonable prices for livestock herders. Adequate laws and regulations in this area are so useful and the European Parliament must simplify and clarify the Commission's proposal. At the same time, checks on new products, monitoring of their side effects and impacts on animal health and impacts on public health and the environment must in no way be reduced. I supported the postponement and resumption of negotiations at the interinstitutional level.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on veterinary medicinal products. I support the approach that the market in veterinary medicinal products should be separated from the market for medicinal products for human use, which operates very differently. I also welcome the fact that the Commission wants to increase the availability of medicines and simplify administrative procedures without sacrificing the principles of public health and environmental protection. I support the amendment to establish strict control mechanisms, in particular for the control of cross-border veterinary prescriptions, which, in the event of illegal activity or non-compliance with the code of professional conduct, may allow for dissuasive penalties or prosecution. This requires better cooperation between all 28 Member States.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report on new veterinary medicines legislation, which will stimulate innovation and provide new solutions to tackling animal diseases.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report clearly sets out the conditions under which prescriptions may be given and antibiotics sold. We voted in favour of the report, as the market for veterinary medicinal products must be separated from the market for medicinal products for human use, but at the same time the health of the animals themselves must also be guaranteed by the use of medicines and antibiotics, without the use of Genetically Modified Organisms. It is important that the rules on medicinal products for human use and the rules on medicinal products for veterinary use agree on this point.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft regulation on veterinary medicinal products completely recasts the legislation in force, which has so far been applied under Directive 2001/82/EC and Regulation (EC) No 726/2004. The aim of the new proposal is to regulate the authorisation, manufacture, placing on the market, distribution and use of veterinary medicinal products throughout the life of medicinal products. Compared to the current legislation, the draft contains a number of important advances for hungary. Taking into account the characteristics of the veterinary sector, the new legislation encourages the extension of preparations already authorised to other animal species. New antimicrobials and preparations for so-called less important animal species will enjoy enhanced data protection. The report prioritises drugs authorised for bees, giving them a 20-year privacy period. The changes can help the emergence of new antibiotics in veterinary medicine and improve the availability of preparations in sectors of particular importance in Hungary, such as beekeeping. Although there is room for improvement in the draft in order to take full account of the interests of the sectors covered by the regulation, the report provides an excellent basis for dialogue with the Council. It's a good step in the right direction.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft regulation on which the report, supported by my vote, is based, aims to regulate the authorisation, manufacture, placing on the market, distribution and use of veterinary medicinal products throughout the life of medicinal products and to regulate the applicable pharmacovigilance procedure. Problems have arisen in the application of the existing legal framework, including the lack of availability of veterinary medicinal products, the administrative burden, the functioning of the internal market and, of course, the phenomenon of antibiotic resistance. It was therefore necessary to develop a new regulatory framework. With regard to internet distribution, it is to be welcomed that the proposal confirms that, where a product cannot be formulated in a Member State, its distribution is prohibited online. Nevertheless, the report calls on the European Commission to draw up a guide in this regard, which I believe is heading in the right direction. I agree with the report that there should be much more ambitious provisions on the fight against antimicrobials, which can be achieved, inter alia, by inserting the definition of different types of treatment (healing treatment, mass treatment and preventive treatment), by prohibiting the prophylactic use of antibacterial agents and by using alternative non-antibiotic drugs.  I consider it important and I support the need to strengthen incentives to support innovation. The market for veterinary medicinal products is highly fragmented and industry players are thus less motivated to innovate and introduce new products to the market.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The world is slowly moving towards a post-antibiotic era. Firstly, the problem of antibiotic resistance (AMR) in animal husbandry needs to be addressed. Prophylactic use of antibiotics should be discontinued and critical antibiotics should be banned in animals.  The report is designed to highlight the role of veterinarians and other veterinary staff as specialists in this field by facilitating their work rather than imposing additional burdens and regulations on the profession. It is also necessary to improve the quality of treatment and to limit the use of antibiotics that have not been allowed for sale, as well as to ensure the availability of medicines.  The reform of the veterinary law on medicinal products is extremely important in order to strengthen the single market in this sector, which is why I decided to support the report presented.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it represents a step forward, particularly with regard to antibiotic resistance, animal welfare and cutting red tape. In many countries, antibiotics are still used preventively without a confirmed disease, which is not right.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, albeit from a particular perspective: although the report focuses mainly on the creation of the single market for veterinary medicines, there are other components that I agree with: the protection of animal welfare, the increase in the availability of veterinary medicines throughout Europe, the transition from a culture of mass care of animals to one in which animals are given individual care as well as humans. I particularly welcome the elimination of the administration of antibiotics to farm animals for prophylactic or metaphylactic purposes. Antibiotics do not replace decent living conditions for animals, although all too often farmers use them precisely in order to save on the costs of running and increasing yields. The massive and routine administration of antibiotics to farm animals is linked to the increasing appearance of antibiotic-resistant strains of bacteria, which has serious consequences for human health. Antibiotics have saved people's lives at least a couple of times: it would be foolish to make them increasingly ineffective in exchange for some cheap steak.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. On most points of the file, I agree with Ms. Grossetête. With regard to pharmacovigilance, the European Commission's new approach based on risk detection is progress, provided it does not compromise on public health. A system based both on the regular submission of periodic reports of pharmacovigilance in the very first years of the product's life, and only then on risk analysis and signal detection, appears to be more appropriate. The Commission proposes to make it easier to use human medicines to treat animals outside AMM. The text leaves it up to veterinarians to decide on this use. Without questioning the responsibility of the latter, the rapporteur calls for this possibility to be better supervised, stating that the use of human medicines can only be done as a last resort and if no better alternative exists.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Healthy animals are an essential prerequisite for Europe’s agriculture, public health and environment. However, veterinary products have been difficult to access in small markets, their use plagued by heavy and sometimes unnecessary administration and there has been worrying resistance to antibiotics. In addition, medicine for animals and humans has been put into the same category, which is very confusing. I believe that the Commission’s proposal is an important step forward to remedy to this, which is why I voted in favour of it. It provides a good balance between consumer needs by improving access to medicinal products, simplifying administration while simultaneously providing incentives for the veterinary industry to encourage innovation, which is needed in this small and quite fragmented market. It will also work on ensuring a functioning internal market. More importantly, it will tackle the growing antibiotic resistance by limiting the use of antibiotics, but also by allowing the use of homeopathic alternatives, and by defining who is entitled to prescribe veterinary medicine.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, I supported this report, because changes have been expected on this issue for a long time. The European Commission's draft on veterinary medicinal products amends the provisions on these medicinal products. The purpose of this document is to regulate the authorisation, manufacture, marketing, distribution and use of veterinary medicinal products for veterinary medicinal products throughout their lifetime, as well as the pharmacovigilance process applicable to them. And the safety of medicines is paramount, because the final consumer of agricultural products is always a person. This must be remembered every time the law changes. Everything points to the fact that the new provisions will improve access to veterinary medicinal products and reduce administrative burdens, especially with regard to pharmacovigilance.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ In light of the lessons learned and following the Commission's assessment of the functioning of the veterinary medicinal products market, the legal framework for veterinary medicinal products needs to be adapted to scientific progress, current market conditions and economic reality, which is why I supported this report.  The impact of animal diseases can be devastating for individual animals, animal populations, animal keepers and the economy. Therefore, sufficient effective veterinary medicinal products must be available in the Union to ensure high standards of animal health and public health. In addition, this report is also essential to combat antimicrobial resistance and therefore a number of measures need to be taken. The rules on the advertising of veterinary antimicrobials should be tightened and authorisation requirements must sufficiently cover the risks and benefits of antimicrobial veterinary medicinal products. Although I voted positively, I believe that the sale of all veterinary medicinal products online should not be completely prohibited, but additional surveillance measures should be put in place to prevent the sale of counterfeit and insufficient quality medicines.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on veterinary medicinal products, as I believe that new legislation is urgently needed to increase the scope of research, development and monitoring in the field of medicines. In view of the increasing resistance of bacteria to antibiotics, it is necessary to limit the use of existing antimicrobials. Negotiations on this legislation must therefore begin as soon as possible.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In favour of this report, we voted in favour of this report as it points to greater control of both the sales cycle of antibiotics and their use. It limits the online sale of medicines that should be sold with a prescription, is limited and controls use preventively and relates to other issues that concern animal welfare criteria.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is normal that technology advances over time and new drugs appear and existing legislation has to be updated and adapted to the new economic situation and the current market conditions. I support this proposal in order to improve the situation of farm animals and improve as well the protection of public health and the environment.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The draft report aims to regulate the marketing and circulation of veterinary drugs. The main concerns that underpinned the proposals are the fight against antibiotic resistance and the assurance of the best possible availability of medicines.  Underneath this objective lies in a liberalisation of the sale of medicines, especially through online sales sites, subtracting this source of income from veterinarians, more able to deliver the products.  Although this report is more restrictive than the Commission's proposal, it does not respect the interests of our vets who carry out a real health sentry job. It also allows the prescription of certain medicines by non-veterinarians because of England, which is unacceptable for public health reasons (e.g. mad cow). So I voted AGAINST this report.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Antimicrobial resistance in both humans and animals is an increasingly serious health problem in the European Union and around the world. It is essential for both humans and animals to establish a clear picture of how antimicrobial medicines are used, in order to be able to significantly reduce their use and stop all abuses. Responsible use of antimicrobials in the treatment of diseases of bacterial origin contributes to the control of diseases affecting the livestock sector. Their misuse and excessive use in animal farms stimulates resistance, which can spread to humans in many ways, including through food. Diseases can be prevented by implementing good practices of biosecurity, nutrition, hygiene and animal comfort. Under no circumstances should the prescription of an antibacterial medicinal product be allowed without a clear diagnosis of the disease. It is necessary to ensure that the leaflet of veterinary antimicrobials contains appropriate warnings and instructions, in particular clear definitions of different forms of treatment (curative treatment, control treatment and preventive treatment) and to prohibit the prophylactic use of antibacterial medicinal products.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In favour of this report, we voted in favour of this report as it points to greater control of both the sales cycle of antibiotics and their use. It limits the online sale of medicines that should be sold with a prescription, is limited and controls use preventively and relates to other issues that concern animal welfare criteria.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it successfully strengthens the requirements for antimicrobials, in particular with regard to prophylaxis, metaphylaxis and data collection per farm.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – The legal framework governing veterinary medicinal products should be updated to take account of the results of scientific progress, current market conditions and economic reality, taking into account animals, nature and their interaction with humans.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The vote on the report on the proposal for a regulation on veterinary medicinal products was actually a vote on the request that this report be referred back to its competent committee. I voted in favour of the referral back to committee, which would allow some controversial issues to be hopefully clarified.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The report sets out the limitation of the use of antibiotics while encouraging the development of new products to combat the increasing resistance of bacteria to antimicrobial drugs, prohibiting collective and preventive treatment of animals and supporting the momentum of research into new medicines. We are talking about a document which has been the subject of extensive debate and has needed a very broad consensus, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Regulation contains positive aspects. Ensuring the production of safe, effective and affordable veterinary medicines is an important objective for our producers. Introducing the issue of generic medicines, antimicrobial resistances or small markets is an important element that goes in the right direction. We thought, however, that it could go further, were it not for the pressure of multinational companies that want to extend their privileges to the fullest, capturing monopolistic incomes if possible until eternity. It could have gone further in a greater generalisation of the centralised method, in our view the only one that safeguards the interest of smaller countries and prevents multinationals from making their products available only in the most profitable markets. Let us be clear, however. The great concern with the safety and good application of veterinary medicinal products is not only solved by this regulation: it is solved by attacking the problem at the root, which lies in an essentially productivist CAP that promotes intensive monoculture and destroys small and medium-sized European family farming.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The rapporteur can be conclusive in her inmind that the proposed Commission regulation, with the amendments requested by the rapporteur, can contribute to the achievement of these objectives. I therefore support this report.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ already in 2014, the European Commission made a commitment to completely overhaul veterinary medicines legislation. Various problems have ariseed in the application of the legal framework in force. One of the most serious that directly affects a person is the issue of antibiotic resistance.  This proposal by the European Commission is a step in the right direction. I appreciate the Commission's willingness to distinguish the market for veterinary medicinal products from that of medicinal products for human use. I also think it is right that emphasis is placed on the availability of medicines and the simplification of administration. At the same time, the principles of public health and environmental protection are respected. I therefore supported this proposal and am also grateful to my colleague, Mrs Grossetête, for her comprehensive report on the veterinary medicines regulation.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I think the content of this report is very interesting, as it seems to me to be very much in line with the objectives of the European Union for unifying laws and markets between Member States.  In this case, what is being pursued is a harmonisation of laws on animal medicines, which will have a clear impact in the EU, as we are talking about a relatively large market.  Thanks to the proposed initiatives, veterinary products will be unified, so that they are equally accessible in all States, with the same characteristics, which will speed up and make their trade more effective. I therefore support the report and am confident that it will contribute to improving the EU cohesion process.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Grossetête report, which seeks to ban the routine of using antibiotics in healthy animals to help combat antimicrobial resistance. The widespread use of antimicrobial antibiotics in Europe not only raises serious animal welfare concerns, but also poses a real threat to human and animal health. Europe now has one of the highest rates of antimicrobial resistance in the world.  Among the measures supported by the Socialist group in this area, I would like to present the proposal for the creation of a harmonised digital prescription system across Europe. The issue and control of revenue shall take place at national level, at least until the establishment of a Union system enabling cross-border revenue control.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of a legislative proposal aimed, inter alia, at improving access to veterinary medicines, increasing incentives for innovation and research, legald regulation of the problem of increasing antibiotic resistance and taking into account environmental protection. I believe that it is a good thing that the procedures in the Union concerning the obtaining of a veterinary prescription should be harmonised and that the recognition of prescriptions between Member States should be allowed.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this legislation relates to the previous point. It concerns veterinary medicinal products in general. What I see in these materials is that we are trying to adapt the subject, which has already been regulated in the directives, better and more perfectly. I think it's a good course of action going forward. Not to extend the permanent competence of the European Union and not to regulate new and new areas, but rather to adapt those that have already been adapted better and better. And that, in my view, is the main philosophy of this regulation, which is why I supported it, and because it is a matter that is to the benefit of animals, I am doubly pleased that I feel that this material has a great deal of support in Parliament.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr The fact is to be welcomed on how to specify the possible source of funding for the European Medicines Agency in this document. I also share the rapporteur's view that the role of the Agency in the registration and supervision of veterinary medicinal products should be clearly defined with the maximum centralised procedure. That's very good, it's a big step forward. At present, let us say, each Member State has its own system and a common de ass. is needed. I would also like to welcome the changes brought in, which to some extent reduced the Commission's role: the codecision procedure will be used, not implementing acts, as was the case so far. In addition, I would like to congratulate the idea of publishing reports once every five years, which would analyse in detail the experience that was cumulated during the implementation of the provisions of the Regulation. So I voted in favour.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In addition to the last report, I would like to add here that, in principle, we can only vote in favour of this report. I would like to point this out and I am pleased that the agricultural sector is very transparent. We have a very high detection density when using antibiotics. We are also facing up to the new authorisation procedures. I have only one request: that we also transfer these realities, which we have now established in the agricultural sector, in the veterinary sector, to the human sector, because there it is unfortunately still the case that, in some cases, as far as the flow of information in terms of the density of use is concerned, many things are still rather unclear and that a lot of data cannot be obtained at all or can only be statistically recorded via detours via the health insurance funds. Even the field of veterinary medicine can be an example for human medicine.  I repeat: the use of antibiotics is a major problem. It affects all areas of social life, and all areas must help to solve the problem here, including the veterinary sector and the human sector together.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí áthas orm tacaíocht a thabhairt don tuarascáil seo agus áthas orm freisin gur glacadh leis. I must say, having been involved with the veterinary profession for many years, I have great admiration for them. I think they are a sector of society that do not get enough praise for their good work and, particularly here in Europe where we have a very good name, as Mr Jahr pointed out, of traceability of our food products from farm to fork. It is the veterinary profession that are the guardians of that particular great image which we have and want to preserve. For that reason, the proposals before us today are very apt; we want to ensure that there is full compliance with the rules and, again as Mr Jahr pointed out, the one danger is that the sale over the internet might not be always what we would like it to be, and that needs to be looked at very carefully to preserve the good name of the products, but also of the profession which , as I said, is exemplary.

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We in UKIP believe that a responsible use of all veterinary medicines in British livestock farming is vital to maintaining our high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare. We believe that all veterinary medicines including antibiotics should be used responsibly, under veterinary care and according to licensing conditions. We believe that the British Parliament should be able to legislate on this issue without being overruled by the unelected EU Commission.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We in UKIP believe that a responsible use of all veterinary medicines in British livestock farming is vital to maintaining our high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare. We believe that all veterinary medicines including antibiotics should be used responsibly, under veterinary care and according to licensing conditions. We believe that the British Parliament should be able to legislate on this issue without being overruled by the unelected EU Commission.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a proposal for change in the Regulation on the European Medicines Agency with a view to developing a more effective European framework to provide a faster and more efficient response at European level. In the present context of economic and trade integration of the European Union, an improvement is needed to reduce disparities in access to certain health technologies. The report also includes provisions on the human and financial resources necessary for the European Medicines Agency to perform its functions effectively, as well as those relating to the control and supervision of its activity. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report, which I voted in favour of, lays down Community procedures for amending the Regulation on the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products intended for human and veterinary use. This is necessary in order to disconnect the centralised marketing authorisation of products intended for humans and animals, so that the new Regulation on veterinary medicinal products covers the entire marketing authorisation procedure for veterinary medicinal products at central and national level. The Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats is seeking the European Parliament to be involved as co-legislator in determining the structure and level of fees to be paid to industry by the European Medicines Agency.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The current regulatory framework in the EU for the authorisation and distribution of medicinal products applies to both human and veterinary medicinal products. However, in order to meet the specific needs of the veterinary sector, it is important to separate the two sectors, which I am very much in favour of.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to regulate the marketing of veterinary drugs. Behind the desire for better availability of medicines and a fight against antibiotic resistance, pharmaceutical groups are involved in the liberalisation of drug sales.  This report is more acceptable than the one proposed by the Commission, but the prescription it authorizes for non-veterinary people is risky in terms of public health. It goes against the interests of veterinarians who remain by their work health guarantors. So I voted against it.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this regulation because it aims to completely revise the legislative framework for veterinary drugs. It differentiates the market for veterinary medicines from that of human medicines, which responds to a very different logic. In addition, the text aims to encourage innovation, reduce bureaucracy and relax certain marketing procedures.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal repealing Directive 2001/82/EC on veterinary medicinal products and amending Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 laying down Community procedures for the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products for human and veterinary use and establishing a European Medicines Agency to take account of the centralised separation of the marketing authorisation procedure for veterinary medicinal products from similar medicinal products for human use.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. As part of the review of the Veterinary Medicine Regulations, there are plans to centralise authorisations to a single European agency as much as possible. This report therefore amends the Commission's proposal for the separation of veterinary and human activities from the European Medicines Agency.  Some of the rapporteur's proposals are moving in the right direction, but the aim remains the same: to centralise as much as possible and to take power and expertise away from the Member States through a transfer of powers. Unacceptable.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have approved this report which will allow the new regulation to govern all procedures for granting authorisations for the marketing of veterinary medicines in the EU, which will be separate from those for medicines for human use.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Union regulatory framework for the manufacture, authorisation and distribution of veterinary medicinal products is currently set up by Directive 2001/82/EC and subsequent Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 establishing the European Medicines Agency (EMA).  In September 2014, the Commission presented a draft to bring together legislation in the field of veterinary medicines, repealing the 2001 directive and amending the 2004 regulation. The Tănăsescu report, which I supported with my vote, welcomed the Commission's proposal, but correctly highlighted the need to involve Parliament in the procedure for setting the EMA's tariffs. It is essential that full codecision is used in this area in accordance with the provisions on pharmacovigilance.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of authorising and supervising medicines, as well as the establishment of a European Medicines Agency. While there were discrepancies in funding it, we believe that regardless of how funding is managed, the Agency should exist.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on the Regulation establishing Community procedures for the authorisation and control of medicinal products for human and veterinary use and establishing the European Medicines Agency. A 2001 Directive and a 2004 Regulation constitute the EU regulatory framework for the manufacture, authorisation and distribution of medicinal products for veterinary use. This report improves these regulatory standards and reinforces the Commission's commitment to ensure that the new measures take into account the specificities of the veterinary sector and that fees are maintained at an affordable level for the veterinary industry in order to promote the development and availability of new medicines in the EU.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I refused to vote in favour of this report which, as part of the revision of the Regulation on Veterinary Medicines, provides for the maximum centralisation of authorisations for medicines for human and veterinary use with a single agency, the European Medicines Agency. Certainly, the rapporteur has made some common-sense proposals, such as better parliamentary control over these activities. However, we see once again the attempt across all areas to withdraw member states from competence again and again in favour of centralisation towards Brussels. As the European institutions have largely demonstrated their inability to lift the European peoples out of the multiple crises they are going through, this new step towards the federalisation of the Union could not have received my approval.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although I welcome the Commission's efforts to clarify the legislation governing medicinal products, distinguishing those for veterinary use from those for human use, I do not agree with the excessive extension of the powers of the European Medicines Agency. That is why I did not support the text with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 constitutes the EU regulatory framework for the manufacture, authorisation and distribution of medicinal products for veterinary use. Its treatment is of paramount importance, as it can seriously affect public health. Legislation is needed with a view to harmonization between different Member States. The European Commission intends to remove from that regulation the provision for the granting and maintenance of marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products, which are transferred to the new regulation.  The European Parliament's proposal seeks to get itself within the scope of the EMA, through a centralised procedure in which it will maintain its role in the authorisation and control of veterinary medicinal products, ensuring its services with the configuration of a reserve fund. Parliament must participate fully in the setting of agency fees through that decision-making process. A cross-reference with the new Veterinary Medicines Regulation and the role of the EMA in the authorisation and control of veterinary medicinal products is also necessary. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with the procedures for the dispensing and supervision of medicinal products for human and veterinary use. In September 2014, following an assessment of the functioning of the internal market in this sector, The Commission has published a proposal that the rules applicable to veterinary medicinal products should be merged into a single Regulation on veterinary medicinal products repealing and replacing the provisions of Directive 2001/82/EC on the Community code relating to veterinary medicinal products and amending the provisions of Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 in order to delete any references to veterinary medicinal products and thus to completely distinguish between the provisions on veterinary medicinal products and the provisions on medicinal products for human use. The European Parliament broadly supports this proposal and welcomes the aim of bringing the provisions of the Regulation into line with those of the Treaty of Lisbon. Parliament welcomes the proposal to distinguish between marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products and marketing authorisations for medicinal products for human use in order to take account of the specific needs of the veterinary sector. However, some aspects of this proposal still need to be improved and a cross-reference to the new Veterinary Medicines Regulation needs to be made and a clear indication of the role of the European Medicines Agency in the issue and supervision of veterinary medicinal products through the centralised procedure.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. In the context of the granting of marketing authorisations and the supervision of veterinary medicinal products, I supported the amendments drawn up by the European Parliament, in line with the position of the EPP. Harmonisation of the laws of the Member States and the facilitated placing on the market of new medicinal products is an essential purpose of this Directive. When granting licences, a centralised procedure should be carried out, taking decisions on the basis of objective scientific criteria of quality, safety and efficacy.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text adopted today, accompanying the new regulation on veterinary medicinal products, aims to improve the procedure for placing veterinary medicinal products on the Union market, separating it from that on medicinal products for human beings.  I particularly welcome the fact that, as also requested by the ENVI Committee, the report provides for the full participation of the European Parliament in the activities of the European Medicines Agency, preserving its role as co-decision-leader in defining the level and structure of the Agency's tariffs, which continues to be responsible for the evaluation, surveillance and pharmacovigilance of medicinal products for human use and veterinary use.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ In order for the regulation of medical veterinary medicines to work, the acts regulating the functioning of the EMA need to be amended. I believe that the proposal is well designed and will contribute to better protection of animal and human health.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In September 2014, following an assessment of the functioning of the internal market in this area, the Commission published a proposal to bring together the rules on veterinary medicinal products in a single regulation on veterinary medicinal products, repealing and replacing Directive 2001/82/EC on veterinary medicinal products and amending Regulation (EC) No 726/2004.  This action is useful with a view to removing all references to veterinary medicinal products and, therefore, completely separating the provisions governing veterinary medicinal products from those relating to medicinal products for human use. It is to be hoped that the Union's work will move towards increasing the competitiveness of pharmaceutical companies with the consequent beneficial effects on prices and availability of access to medicines.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products for human and veterinary use aims to separate marketing authorisations for medicinal products for human use from those for veterinary medicinal products, precisely in order to take account of the specific needs of the veterinary and human sectors. This initiative proposes that the new measures be customized to the veterinary sector, as well as the human sector, and that the related fees be accessible to the veterinary industry, with the aim of promoting the development and availability of new types of medicines at European Union level. I voted in favour of the report because I believe that the needs of the veterinary sector differ significantly from those of the human sector, which is why it is necessary to treat these two areas separately, depending on the specificities of the sectors. The market for medicinal products in the veterinary sector is a fragmented market, given the multitude of animal species; therefore, veterinary medicinal products should be addressed separately from those for human use.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. The Commission has proposed to completely separate the provisions governing veterinary medicinal products from those relating to medicinal products for human use. This separation is welcome, as it contributes to greater clarity in the legislative framework. In this case, the Commission has simply proposed repealing all regulatory references to veterinary medicinal products, which are transferred to a new ad hoc regulation (see Grossetête report). Unfortunately, the ENVI Committee took the opportunity to 'communitise' the definition of the fees due to the EMA, including the methods of collection, by replacing implementing acts with an ordinary legislative procedure (Em. 31).  In addition to being impractical, this appears to be a sneaky extension of the EMA's powers. In addition, the amendments aim to centralise the authorisation process for veterinary medicinal products at EU level a great deal, creating a special division within the EMA.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal to amend Regulation No 17/2002 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 December 2002 amending Regulation (EC) No 14 726/2004 is closely related to the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on veterinary medicinal products. Following the Commission's evaluation studies in 2014 it was found that all rules on veterinary medicinal products should be brought together in a single regulation in order to meet the specific needs of this sector. The market and the needs of the veterinary sector are essentially different from those of the human sector, because we are dealing firstwith with a multitude of animal species, which determine a fragmented market. It is important to emphasise the role of the European Medicines Agency (EMA) in the process of authorising and supervising veterinary products through the centralised procedure, as its tasks must apply to both medicinal products for human and veterinary use. The objectives of the two regulations voted on must therefore be interconnected, so that the end result will lead to boosting competitiveness and innovation while aiming to reduce red tape and ultimately aim at the availability of new veterinary medical products to combat the public health risks posed by antimicrobial resistance.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this proposal for a regulation to protect public health in the European Union and to ensure that the centralised marketing authorisation for veterinary medicinal products is separated from that for medicinal products intended for human use. I would stress that, in the interests of public health, authorisation decisions taken under the centralised procedure should be taken on the basis of the objective scientific criteria of quality, safety and effectiveness laid down in Directives 2001/83/EC and 2001/82/EC. In the case of medicinal products authorised by the Union, provision should be made for an assessment of the risk/benefit ratio of all medicinal products to take place both at the time of their placing on the market and at the time of renewal of the authorisation and at any other time deemed appropriate by the competent authority. In order to improve knowledge and understanding of antimicrobial resistance, the European Medicines Agency (EMA) should publish annually, in cooperation with the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), a report on the use of antimicrobials in human and veterinary medicine, as well as on the current situation of antimicrobial resistance in the European Union.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report was concerned amongst other things with whether the European Parliament agrees with veterinary authorisation fees (which go to the EMA agency) being decided by co-decision or by implementing acts. I am in favour of co-decision where the European Parliament has a say and can block decisions which have been decided behind closed doors between the Council and the Commission, with no transparency or democratic accountability. On a separate but related point, the democratic deficit which permeates the EU is a matter that urgently needs to be addressed. The lack of transparency and accountability in the legislative process has led to citizens losing trust, faith and confidence in the EU. Moreover, it is difficult to disagree with the contention that Ireland and indeed all national parliaments have been reduced to a situation where national parliaments act largely as a rubber stamp for measures implementing laws signed up to by government ministers in Brussels. The entire legislative framework within the EU is in urgent need of radical reform.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe that a responsible use of all veterinary medicines in British livestock farming is vital to maintaining our high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare. We believe that all veterinary medicines including antibiotics should be used responsibly, under veterinary care and according to licensing conditions. We believe that the British Parliament should be able to legislate on this issue without being overruled by the unelected EU Commission.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to postpone the final vote on this report following the postponement of the final vote on the previous report on veterinary medicinal products, which needs slight changes. Both reports should be voted on at the same time as they are interlinked.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The rapporteur, Mrs Tănăsescu, has proposed improvements that we can support, in particular, on the structure and level of the fees payable to the European Medicines Agency and on the fact that the remuneration allocated to the competent national authorities should not be fixed by means of a mere implementing act. In the light of the above, I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report establishing Community procedures for the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products intended for human and veterinary use and on the establishment of a European Medicines Agency representing the regulatory framework of the European Union for the manufacture, licensing and distribution of veterinary medicinal products.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote because following the proposal which will repeal and replace the directive on veterinary medicinal products, the regulation on the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products for human and veterinary use and establishing a European Medicines Agency must be amended to take account of the fact that centralised marketing authorisation for veterinary products is being decoupled from that for medicines for humans. This proposal, within the package, is not meant to be a thorough review of the rules. It is only meant to delete every reference to veterinary medicines from the old, all-inclusive regulation and to ‘Lisbonise’ it (compulsory).

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe that a responsible use of all veterinary medicines in British livestock farming is vital to maintaining our high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare. We believe that all veterinary medicines including antibiotics should be used responsibly, under veterinary care and according to licensing conditions. We believe that the British Parliament should be able to legislate on this issue without being overruled by the unelected EU Commission.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 726/2004, establishing Community procedures for the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products for human and veterinary use and establishing a European Medicines Agency, should be amended to take account of the fact that the centralised marketing authorisation procedure for veterinary medicinal products will be dissociated from the procedure for medicinal products for human use. I support the Tanasescu report, as It considers positive the decoupling of marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products and human medicinal products, thus taking into account the specific needs of the veterinary sector.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We in UKIP believe that a responsible use of all veterinary medicines in British livestock farming is vital to maintaining our high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare. We believe that all veterinary medicines including antibiotics should be used responsibly, under veterinary care and according to licensing conditions. We believe that the British Parliament should be able to legislate on this issue without being overruled by the unelected EU Commission.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Union regulatory framework for the manufacture, authorisation and distribution of veterinary medicinal products was composed of Directive 2001/82/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council on a Community code on veterinary medicinal products and Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing Community procedures for the authorisation and surveillance of medicinal products for human and veterinary use.  The Commission proposes that the rules on veterinary medicinal products should be brought into a single regulation on veterinary medicinal products, repealing and replacing Directive 2001/82/EC on veterinary medicinal products. I voted in favour, because this reform will lead to a separation between the provisions governing veterinary medicinal products and those relating to medicinal products for human use and will therefore lead to simplification and coherence.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the resolution is to amend Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 establishing Community procedures for the authorisation and surveillance of medicinal products for human and veterinary use.   In 2014, the Commission published a proposal to bring together all the rules on veterinary medicinal products into a single regulation, with the aim of completely separating the provisions governing veterinary medicinal products from those relating to medicinal products for human use. The proposal therefore aims to remove from Regulation No 726/2004 the provisions on the granting and maintenance of marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products, to establish certain principles applicable to the remuneration due to the European Medicines Agency and to align the implementing powers conferred on the Commission under the 2004 Regulation.  I welcome this proposal because I agree with the improvements that will be made in the field of medicinal products for human and veterinary use in the resolution before us.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a proposal for change in the Regulation on the European Medicines Agency with a view to developing a more effective European framework to provide a faster and more efficient response at European level. In the present context of economic and trade integration of the European Union, an improvement is needed to reduce disparities in access to certain health technologies. The report also includes provisions on the human and financial resources necessary for the European Medicines Agency to perform its functions effectively, as well as those relating to the control and supervision of its activity. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Veterinary Medicinal Products Directive and the Regulation laying down Community procedures for the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products for human and veterinary use and establishing a European Medicines Agency are the European Union regulatory framework for the manufacture, authorisation and distribution of veterinary medicinal products. It is important to provide for the application of the quality, safety and efficiency criteria laid down by European legislation to medicinal products authorised by the Union, as well as the possibility of assessing the ratio of benefits and risks to all medicinal products when they are placed on the market at the time of renewal of the authorisation and at any other time which the competent authority considers appropriate. At the same time, the European Medicines Agency must have access to other sources of funding to support its work on public health projects, such as the Innovative Medicines Initiative.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This report is closely linked to the report on veterinary medicinal products. The Commission has decided to bring together the provisions on veterinary medicinal products in a single Regulation on veterinary medicinal products, repealing and replacing the Veterinary Medicinal Products Directive and amending Regulation (EC) No 726/2004. This report is necessary in order to remove all references to veterinary medicinal products and thereby completely separate the provisions on veterinary medicinal products from those relating to medicinal products for human use. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it takes account of the specific needs of the veterinary sector and aims to decouple the marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products from those for human medicinal products. Furthermore, it clarifies and updates the principles applicable to fees payable to the Agency and ensures that the fees remain affordable for the veterinary industry in order to promote the development and availability of new medicines in the EU.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The purpose of this legislative report is to revise existing rules on the authorisation and supervision of veterinary and human medicines to take into account the fact that marketing authorizations for veterinary drugs are now governed by specific and specific rules.  This technical report makes the necessary status changes. The report also proposes to allocate the determination of the costs to be paid to the European Medicines Agency. Considering that this report is balanced, I voted for it.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft regulation on veterinary medicinal products completely recasts the legislation in force, which has so far been applied under Directive 2001/82/EC and Regulation (EC) No 726/2004. The aim of the new proposal is to regulate the authorisation, manufacture, placing on the market, distribution and use of veterinary medicinal products throughout the life of medicinal products. The text approved by the Committee on the Environment prioritises the problem of the availability of veterinary medicinal products, which can be tackled by strengthening innovation. The market for veterinary medicinal products is small and highly fragmented, so industry players have little motivation to innovate and introduce new products to the market. Compared to the current legislation, the draft contains a number of important advances for hungary. Taking into account the characteristics of the veterinary sector, the new legislation encourages the extension of preparations already authorised to other animal species. New antimicrobials and preparations for so-called less important animal species will enjoy enhanced data protection. The report prioritises drugs authorised for bees, giving them a 20-year privacy period. The changes can help the emergence of new antibiotics in veterinary medicine and improve the availability of preparations in sectors of particular importance in Hungary, such as beekeeping. Although there is room for improvement in the draft in order to take full account of the interests of the sectors covered by the regulation, the report provides an excellent basis for dialogue with the Council. It's a good step in the right direction.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the authorisation and control of medicinal products for human and veterinary use is closely linked to the report on veterinary medicinal products, which I supported. In this case, we are talking about technical details due to the Commission's decision to bring the rules on veterinary medicinal products under one Regulation, replacing the existing Directive. This requires the separation of medicines for animals and those for people under different laws and leads to the vote on this report, which I supported. Again, I can stress that citizens' health is always at the forefront of choosing my position.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We vote in favour. The report concerns provisions relating to the movement of veterinary medicinal products in particular. All the improvements it proposes are in the right direction, especially those which prevent the Over-concentration of powers in the Commission and enable the European Parliament to monitor its actions.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission has published a proposal to bring together the rules on veterinary medicinal products in a regulation to fully decouple the provisions governing veterinary medicinal products from those governing human medicinal products. I therefore endorse this proposal in line with the Treaty of Lisbon, even though it can be improved, in particular in terms of the fees charged by the Agency.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In September 2014, the European Commission published a proposal to bring together the rules on veterinary medicinal products into a single regulation, completely differenting the provisions governing veterinary medicinal products from those governing human medicinal products. This new Regulation repeals and replaces Directive 2001/82/EC on veterinary medicinal products and amends Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 in order to remove any references to veterinary medicinal products, and decoupling authorisations to place veterinary medicinal products on the market from medicinal products for human use in order to take account of the specific needs of the veterinary sector. In addition, a European Medicines Agency is established, clearly indicating its role in authorising and supervising products for veterinary use through the centralised procedure. Current Regulation No 297/95 on the general regime of fees charged by the European Medicines Agency and Regulation (EU) No 658/2014 on pharmacovigilic rates shall remain as a legal basis until the adoption and entry into force of the revision of Regulation (EC) No 297/95 or any other fee provisions. We voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 This particular proposal aims to align existing regulations and regulatory framework with the provisions of the Treaty of Lisbon. I welcome this activity by the European Commission and its efforts to separate the market for veterinary medicinal products from the market for medicinal products for human use. In future, the European Commission must actively work to ensure that the new measures take account of the specific features of the veterinary sector and that the fees for the sector remain real, thus supporting the development of new medicines and their availability in the European Union.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining because, despite some positive passage, an attempt is being made to over-centralise the process of authorising veterinary medicines.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the establishment of Community authorisation and surveillance procedures for medicinal products intended for human and veterinary use and for the establishment of a European Medicines Agency. The report is in the right direction, especially those amendments which prevent the Commission from over-concentrating powers and enable the European Parliament to monitor its actions.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal accompanies the new regulation on veterinary medicine products that will repeal and replace Directive 2001/82 /EC, and amend Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 laying down Community procedures for the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products for human and veterinary use and establishing a European Medicines Agency. It must be amended to take account of the fact that centralised marketing authorisation for human and veterinary products is being decoupled so that the new regulation on veterinary medicinal products (COM(2014)0558) will cover all routes granting marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products in the Union – both at centralised and national level. In addition, it seeks to align provisions to the Lisbon Treaty and to introduce implementing acts to set the fee provisions – previously set by co-decision. I voted in favour of the report, especially since I believe the European Parliament must be involved as co-legislator in setting the structure and level of fees payable by the industry to the European Medicines Agency.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft regulation on veterinary medicinal products completely recasts the legislation in force, which has so far been applied under Directive 2001/82/EC and Regulation (EC) No 726/2004. The aim of the new proposal is to regulate the authorisation, manufacture, placing on the market, distribution and use of veterinary medicinal products throughout the life of medicinal products. The text approved by the Committee on the Environment prioritises the problem of the availability of veterinary medicinal products, which can be tackled by strengthening innovation. The market for veterinary medicinal products is small and highly fragmented, so industry players have little motivation to innovate and introduce new products to the market. Compared to the current legislation, the draft contains a number of important advances for hungary. Taking into account the characteristics of the veterinary sector, the new legislation encourages the extension of preparations already authorised to other animal species. New antimicrobials and preparations for so-called less important animal species will enjoy enhanced data protection. The report prioritises drugs authorised for bees, giving them a 20-year privacy period. The changes can help the emergence of new antibiotics in veterinary medicine and improve the availability of preparations in sectors of particular importance in Hungary, such as beekeeping. Although there is room for improvement in the draft in order to take full account of the interests of the sectors covered by the regulation, the report provides an excellent basis for dialogue with the Council. It's a good step in the right direction.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote is a first step towards changing the process by which medicines are approved at European level and in particular towards a drastic reduction in the time between the authorisation of the marketing of a new drug and the decisions of individual countries on their reimbursement.  The current procedure, in fact, creates very marked differences in the timing of access to new medicines, because the same drug is evaluated for its effectiveness 28 times, once for each Member State, while always relying on the same data. In some cases it has taken up to ten years for innovative and life-saving medicines, even those deemed essential by the World Health Organisation, to be truly used and reimbursed. I therefore very much hope that this first step will show us a new way of overcoming these difficulties.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The new Veterinary Medicines Regulation will unite the provisions in a uniform manner and are strictly separate from those for medicinal products for human use. The Regulation contributes to the development and availability of new medicinal products, taking into account the specificities of the veterinary sector.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe that a responsible use of all veterinary medicines in British livestock farming is vital to maintaining our high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare. We believe that all veterinary medicines including antibiotics should be used responsibly, under veterinary care and according to licensing conditions.
