We believe that the British Parliament should be able to legislate on this issue without being overruled by the unelected EU Commission.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of authorising and supervising medicines, as well as the establishment of a European Medicines Agency. While there were discrepancies in funding it, we believe that regardless of how funding is managed, the Agency should exist.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. Having been rapporteur of this draft text in Parliament myself, I voted in favour of the new regulation, which aims to completely revise the legislative framework for veterinary medicines.  Its main objective was in particular to better combat antibiotic resistance, a real scourge of public health that is rooted in the abuse of antibiotics on farms. The text thus enacts a number of provisions aimed at regulating the use of these substances in veterinary medicine, in order to reduce the number of antibiotics that end up on the consumer's plate!  The text also aims to encourage and protect innovation, reduce bureaucracy and relax certain marketing procedures, so that epidemics can be prevented and stopped.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. It is important to update the regulatory framework governing human and veterinary medicines at EU level. The European Parliament makes use of this technical amending regulation to empower the EMA to fulfil its growing tasks and to ensure that the rules on fees payable to the agency are subject to a democratic decision-making process.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support, along with my ALDE colleagues, the amendments to this file. It was important to amend this regulation considering the proposal by the Commission on veterinary medicinal products which now consolidates the regulation on veterinary medicines into one regulation rather than being fragmented across a number. The new regulation will thus cover all routes granting marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products in the Union. The reason for this modification, and why I supported it, was because the needs of the veterinary sector differ substantially from those of the human sector in relation to medicines. In the veterinary sector there are many different animal species, which creates both a fragmented market and the need for major investments in order to extend the authorisation of medicines existing for one animal species to another. Within the text, I was happy that the level and structure of the fees payable to the European Medicines Agency will not be set via implementing acts as the Commission intended but through co-decision, which will allow the Parliament to have clear oversight into the budgetary expenses of the EMA. In addition, I was happy that there will be annual assessments of antimicrobial resistance in the EU.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This regulation sets procedures for the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products for human and veterinary use. The European Medicines Agency (EMA) is a long-needed institution. It is paramount that the European Parliament, as co-legislator, takes part in establishing a structure and level of fees payable by the industry to the EMA.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council amending the Regulation establishing the procedures for authorising the use and procedures for monitoring the use of medicinal products used in human and veterinary medicine, and the establishment of a European Medicines Agency, as I believe it is necessary to improve the legislative framework governing human and veterinary medicine at European level. I support Parliament's intention to strengthen the European Medicines Agency so that it can fulfil its tasks and ensure that the fees paid to the Agency are subject to a democratic decision-making process. Also, the European Parliament should be more involved in decision-making dynamics in the area concerned, and I therefore support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. As part of the review of the regulations on veterinary medicines, it is planned to centralise authorisations with a single European agency as much as possible. This report therefore amends the Commission's proposal for the separation of veterinary and human activities from the European Medicines Agency.  Some of the rapporteur's proposals are moving in the right direction, including stricter oversight by Parliament, but the aim remains the same: to centralise as much as possible and to remove power and expertise from the Member States through a transfer of powers. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We in UKIP believe that a responsible use of all veterinary medicines in British livestock farming is vital to maintaining our high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare. We believe that all veterinary medicines including antibiotics should be used responsibly, under veterinary care and according to licensing conditions. We believe that the British Parliament should be able to legislate on this issue without being overruled by the unelected EU Commission.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Claudiu Ciprian T-nsescu on the authorisation and supervision of veterinary medicines. The aim of this text is to improve the procedure for authorising veterinary medicines to be marketed. A European Medicines Agency will also be set up for greater security for EUROPEAN citizens. I agree with this text, which separates this procedure from that which concerns medicines for human use. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The vote on this report has been postponed. The rapporteur welcomes the separation of marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products and medicinal products for human use in order to meet the specific needs of the veterinary sector. The report also calls for Parliament to be fully involved in the definition of agency fees and monitoring. For these reasons, I am in favour of the report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission is decoupling legislation on human and animal medicines and adopting a specific regulation on veterinary medicines. Therefore, I supported this proposal as it simply amends the Regulation to remove references to veterinary medicines and adapts it to the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ It is essential to update and improve veterinary medicinal products legislation, since it exists since 1965. The aim of this report is to address the characteristics and specificities of the veterinary sector and to tackle some problems of the sector (administrative burdens, reduced competitiveness, innovation). I voted in favour of this report since it will change positively the veterinary medicinal field.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The new regulation on veterinary medicinal products regulates all procedures for the issue of marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products in the Union, both at centralised and national level.  The new measures will clearly take account of the specific characteristics of the veterinary sector. This proposed amendment is, in fact, to be connected with the needs of the veterinary sector which, with regard to medicines, are substantially different from those of the human sector. I supported the text because it took balanced account of the different needs to be protected in this sensitive area.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the authorisation and supervision of veterinary drugs. As part of the review of the regulations on veterinary medicines, it is planned to centralise authorisations with a single European agency as much as possible. This report therefore amends the Commission's proposal for the separation of veterinary and human activities from the European Medicines Agency.  Some of the rapporteur's proposals are moving in the right direction, including stricter oversight by Parliament, but the aim remains the same: to centralise as much as possible and to remove power and expertise from the Member States through a transfer of powers.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a proposal for change in the Regulation on the European Medicines Agency with a view to developing a more effective European framework to provide a faster and more efficient response at European level. In the present context of economic and trade integration of the European Union, an improvement is needed to reduce disparities in access to certain health technologies. The report also includes provisions on the human and financial resources necessary for the European Medicines Agency to perform its functions effectively, as well as those relating to the control and supervision of its activity. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In September 2014. The Commission has published a proposal to consolidate the rules on veterinary medicine into a single Regulation on veterinary medicinal products. It is proposed to establish certain principles that would apply to fees payable and to adapt the Regulation to the Lisbon Treaty. I supported this Report, which calls for two significant changes: The first contains a legal tool for deciding on compensation to be paid to the European Medical Agency (EMA), and the second relates to the duration of the Commission's delegating procedure, which is limited to a period of 5 years.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. In the case of medicinal products intended for human and veterinary use and for the establishment of a European Medicines Agency, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 9/3/2016, and because this report is complete and substantiated.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I broadly endorse the proposal and welcome the alignment to the Lisbon Treaty. I welcome the decoupling of marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products from those for human medicinal products, to take account of the specific needs of the veterinary sector.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. In direct connection with the previous vote, it is planned, as part of the revision of the regulations on veterinary medicines, to centralise as much as possible the authorisations with a single European agency. This report therefore amends the Commission's proposal for the separation of veterinary and human activities from the European Medicines Agency.  Some of the rapporteur's proposals are moving in the right direction, including stricter oversight by Parliament, but the aim remains the same: to centralise as much as possible and to remove power and expertise from the Member States through a transfer of powers. We cannot accept that.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I believe that this report includes concerns about animal welfare, provides for widespread access to new technologies in order to reduce disparities, is based on a scientific-based authorisation system and includes an obligation to report annually on the use of antimicrobials.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the report on the proposal for a new Regulation establishing Community procedures for the authorisation and control of medicinal products for human and veterinary use and establishing the European Medicines Agency. It is positive that we have agreed that marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products should be dissociated from those relating to medicinal products for human use, in order to take account of the specific needs of the veterinary sector. In addition, we believe that the use of existing veterinary antibiotics should be limited, while encouraging the development of new products, to combat the increasing resistance of bacteria to antimicrobial medicines, according to Parliament.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Commission's proposal to amend the existing legislation, which lays down Community procedures for the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products for human and veterinary use. I support the Commission's proposal that the rules applicable to veterinary medicinal products be merged into a single Veterinary Medicinal Product Regulation and a complete separation of provisions on veterinary medicinal products and the provisions on medicinal products for human use.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that improves the marketing authorisation procedure for veterinary medicinal products, decoupling it from medicines for humans.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. It is planned to centralise veterinary drug approvals with a European agency as much as possible. If certain proposals amend the Commission's proposal in the right way, I note that the result will be the same, taking away from the Member States their power and expertise by this transfer of supranational competence. As a result, I have spoken out against this text.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it concerns amending the regulation on the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products to reflect the separation of veterinary medicinal products from human medicinal products.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. In parallel with the adoption of Mrs Grossetête's report on veterinary medicines, Parliament also voted on the proposed regulation amending the existing provisions on the authorisation and supervision of medicines for human and veterinary use.  The aim here is to separate the marketing authorizations from these two types of drugs. Bringing together the provisions for veterinary medicines in a separate regulation will allow full account of the specifics of the veterinary sector.  I also commend the desire to clearly delineate the role played by the European Medicines Agency on veterinary medicines, in particular their authorisation and monitoring.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – The legislative proposal tabled does not generally contain numerous changes in content (the purpose is to exempt the provisions on veterinary medicinal products that will be governed by the specific Regulation on veterinary medicinal products). The basic content change to this legislation is to adapt it to the changes that occurred in the field of medicines following the adoption of the Treaty of Lisbon and to propose a new way of financing the European Medicines Agency. I support the solution for this funding to be adjusted by means of a legislative act (instead of an implementing act), while the European Parliament should be fully involved in deciding on the setting of fees for the Agency. In setting them, account should be taken of the specificities of small and medium-sized enterprises so that the charges do not present an excessive financial and administrative burden. It is also necessary to specify the precise competences of the Agency in the field of authorisation of medicinal products for veterinary use as well as in carrying out appropriate supervision. I agree with and support the proposal as it stands.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal that accompanies the new regulation on veterinary medicine products that will repeal and replace Directive 2001/82 /EC, and amend Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 laying down Community procedures for the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products for human and veterinary use and establishing a European Medicines Agency. It must be amended to take account of the fact that centralised marketing authorisation for human and veterinary products is being decoupled so that the new Regulation on veterinary medicinal products (COM(2014)0558) will cover all routes granting marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products in the Union – both at centralised and national level. In addition, it seeks to align provisions to the Lisbon Treaty and to introduce implementing acts to set the fee provisions – previously set by co-decision. I strongly believe that the EP must be involved as co-legislator in setting the structure and level of fees payable by industry to the EMA.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This is an amendment to a 2004 European regulation which aims to centralise authorisations as much as possible with a single European agency. We therefore oppose this revision, which still removes sovereignty from states through a transfer of powers.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the Commission's view, with its proposal to repeal Directive 2001/82/EC on veterinary medicinal products, there should be an amendment to Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 establishing Community procedures for the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products for human and veterinary use and establishing a European Medicines Agency. I advocate harmonisation of legislation at Member State level on the manufacture, authorisation and distribution of veterinary medicinal products in order to ensure clarity, simplicity and legal certainty, but above all the protection of public and environmental health. I endorse the rapporteur's position, which considers that the proposal should be improved in some respects, in particular as regards the structure and level of fees charged by the Agency. I also argue, like the rapporteur, that Parliament should be involved in setting the fees charged by the Agency, as is the case in the legislation on pharmacovigilance. In this way, codecision in this area would be ensured.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Some of the rapporteur's proposals are moving in the right direction, including stricter oversight by Parliament, but the aim remains the same: to centralise as much as possible and to remove power and expertise from the Member States through a transfer of powers. If it had not been postponed, I would have voted against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text. This is a technical report to take the necessary legal steps to separate regulations on human and veterinary medicines. In particular, I support the five-year limit on the duration of the delegation of powers granted to the European Commission for authorisation and surveillance for medicines for human and veterinary use.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. In view of the proposal on veterinary drugs, regulations on the authorisation and supervision of veterinary drugs need to be changed. This report is therefore a continuation of the work done on the regulation of veterinary drugs. Although I am not in the plenary session for medical reasons, I am, however, largely in favour of this report as well as its corollary.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Following an assessment of the functioning of the internal market in this sector, the Commission published a proposal to bring together the rules on veterinary medicines under one regulation on veterinary medicinal products in September 2014. I voted for this report that will, among other things, align the regulation to the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have voted in favour of this report, as the rapporteur proposes to separate the marketing authorisation of veterinary medicinal products and medicinal products for human use in order to better meet the specific needs of the veterinary sector. It also does not consider it right, as the Commission proposes, to determine, by means of an implementing act, the structure and level of fees to be paid to the Agency and remuneration to the competent national authority. As was the case with the pharmacovigilance act, Parliament should be fully involved in the definition of agency fees. The rapporteur proposes a complete codecision procedure in this respect.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim is to untie the provisions on veterinary medicinal products and human medicinal products.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report.  In order to ensure a high level of protection of public health and to ensure the effective functioning of the internal market, the effective functioning of the European Medicines Agency must be promoted. Medicinal products must be placed on the market only after the marketing authorisation has been granted by the competent authorities. Consumers must only receive safe and effective medicines.  In view of the specific needs of the veterinary sector, it is necessary to distinguish clearly between marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products and marketing authorisations for medicinal products for human use. In order to increase transparency and accountability, the role of the European Parliament must be strengthened and its full involvement in the establishment of the Agency's fees must be ensured.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe that a responsible use of all veterinary medicines in British livestock farming is vital to maintaining our high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare. We believe that all veterinary medicines including antibiotics should be used responsibly, under veterinary care and according to licensing conditions. We believe that the British Parliament should be able to legislate on this issue without being overruled by the unelected EU Commission.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report, despite some shortcomings, as it contains some good proposals for the marketing and control of veterinary medicinal products. These certainly include compliance with the Treaty of Lisbon and the separation of marketing authorisations for veterinary and human medicinal products, with a view to taking account of the specific needs of the veterinary sector. I agree with the rapporteur that Parliament should be fully involved in setting the Agency's fees, and I therefore support the application of the codecision procedure, and to ensure that the Agency also has the right to other sources of funding, which would support its work in the field of public health projects, such as the Innovative Medicines Initiative or the 7th Framework Programme for Research and Development.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I welcome the changes that go towards separating the outlets of veterinary and human medical devices.  The report clearly defines the conditions under which veterinary product professionals can prescribe and sell antibiotics. This is undoubtedly a step forward in terms of clear guidelines and eliminating any manipulation of misinterpretation of regulations. I support defining a list of critical antibiotics intended solely and strictly for human consumption. Scientific recommendations from the competent institutions should be included, in this case the European Medicines Agency.  Banning the internet sale of medicines is a good decision in terms of preventing potential dangers to public health. Innovation in the veterinary medicines market is welcome, primarily because it is a small and heavily fragmented market with little incentive for manufacturers to create new market products.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Directive 2001/82 of the European Parliament and the Council on Veterinary Medicines and Regulation 726/2004 of the European Parliament and the Council lay down Community procedures for the authorisation and control of medicinal products for human and veterinary use and the establishment of the European Medicines Agency, and these directives establish a regulatory framework for the manufacture, approval and distribution of veterinary medicinal products. I welcome the Commission's proposal, based on an assessment of the functioning of the internal market in the sector, to bring the rules on veterinary medicines together and to abolish and replace existing directives, in order to completely separate the provisions on veterinary medicines from those governing human medicines. I would also set out the establishment of principles applicable to the fees paid to the European Medicines Agency, and would further emphasise that any such initiative must involve the European Parliament and respect it as one of the legislators when setting the structure and level of fees paid to the Agency.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In September 2014, the Commission proposed to bring together the rules on veterinary medicinal products into a single regulation, completely differenting the provisions governing veterinary medicinal products from those governing human medicinal products. This new Regulation repealed and replaced Directive 2001/82/EC on veterinary medicinal products by amending Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 to delete any references to veterinary medicinal products. On the other hand, it distinguishes and distinguishes and distinguishes authorisations for the marketing of veterinary medicinal products from those of medicinal products for human use in order to take account of the specific needs of the veterinary sector. It has set up a European Medicines Agency, with a clear role in authorising and supervising products for veterinary use through the centralised procedure. Current Regulation No 297/95 on the general regime of fees charged by the European Medicines Agency and Regulation (EU) No 658/2014 on pharmacovigilic rates shall remain as a legal basis until the adoption and entry into force of the revision of Regulation (EC) No 297/95 or any other fee provisions. We voted for it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. – I support colleague Tanasescu's report. I agree with the proposal for a regulation that will lay down procedures for the granting of licences, supervision and pharmacovigilance of medicinal products for human use, I am also of the opinion that the separation of the registration of veterinary medicinal products from human human products is necessary. The needs and requirements of the veterinary sector are higher.  The European Union carries out an assessment and supervision of medicinal products and medical devices on its market and applies specific rules to them. Before these products are on the open market, the European Medicines Agency or national agencies have a duty under a centralised or decentralised procedure to approve pharmaceutical products for human use.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. This text, which is essentially technical, aims to improve the marketing authorisation procedure for veterinary medicines, which will now be separated from that for medicines for humans.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe that a responsible use of all veterinary medicines in British livestock farming is vital to maintaining our high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare. We believe that all veterinary medicines including antibiotics should be used responsibly, under veterinary care and according to licensing conditions. We believe that the British Parliament should be able to legislate on this issue without being overruled by the unelected EU Commission.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which an opinion is issued on the Commission's proposal to bring together the rules on veterinary medicinal products which aim to fully decouple the provisions governing veterinary medicinal products from those governing human medicinal products in order to take account of the specific needs of the veterinary sector. Like the rapporteur, I welcome the alignment of the proposal with the Treaty of Lisbon. However, I agree that this should continue to be the subject of improvements in some respects. To this end, I believe that the European Parliament should be fully involved in the definition of the fees charged by the European Medicines Agency and that a comprehensive codecision procedure should be established in this regard. Furthermore, I agree that changes are needed to clarify and update the principles applicable to the fees charged by the Agency, as well as the possibility of the Agency having access to other sources of funding to support its work in public health projects. Finally, I voted in favour of this report because it reinforces the Commission's commitment to ensure that the new measures take into account the specificities of the veterinary sector and that fees remain bearable by the veterinary industry.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 constitutes the EU regulatory framework for the manufacture, authorisation and distribution of medicinal products for veterinary use. Its treatment is of paramount importance, as it can seriously affect public health. Legislation is needed with a view to harmonization between different Member States. The European Commission intends to remove from that regulation the provision for the granting and maintenance of marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products, which are transferred to the new regulation.  The European Parliament's proposal seeks to get itself within the scope of the EMA, through a centralised procedure in which it will maintain its role in the authorisation and control of veterinary medicinal products, ensuring its services with the configuration of a reserve fund. Parliament must participate fully in the setting of agency fees through that decision-making process. A cross-reference with the new Veterinary Medicines Regulation and the role of the EMA in the authorisation and control of veterinary medicinal products is also necessary. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament and Veterinary Medicines Council Directive 2001/82/EC and Regulation (EC) 726/2004 of the European Parliament and the Council establishing EU procedures for authorisation and surveillance for medicines for human and veterinary use, and establishing a European Medicines Agency, constitute the EU's regulatory framework governing the manufacture, authorisation and distribution of veterinary medicines.  In September 2014, following an assessment of the functioning of the internal market in this sector, the Commission published a proposal to bring together the rules for veterinary medicines in a single regulation on veterinary medicines, repealing and replacing the 2001/82/EC Veterinary Medicines Directive and amending Regulation (EC) 726/2004 with a view to removing all references to veterinary medicines and, therefore, completely decoupling the provisions governing veterinary medicines from those governing medicines for human use.  While I supported this text, I also supported the commitment made by the EU executive to ensure that the new measures take into account the specifics of the veterinary sector and that royalties remain affordable for the veterinary sector in order to promote the development and availability of new medicines in the Union.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this legislative proposal on procedures for the dispensing and supervision of medicinal products for human and veterinary use. In September 2014, following an assessment of the functioning of the internal market in this sector, the Commission duly proposed merging the different rules applicable to veterinary medicinal products into a single Veterinary Medicinal Product Regulation. It repeals and replaces the provisions of Directive 2001/82/EC on the Community code relating to veterinary medicinal products and amends the provisions of Regulation (EC) No 726/2004, removing any references to veterinary medicinal products, thereby completely separating the regulation of veterinary medicinal products and medicinal products for human use.  The only comment that can be made is that the new legislation lacks a definition of the role of the European Medicines Agency in the issue and supervision of veterinary medicinal products.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which is part of the recall of the Veterinary Medicines Directive. This regulation on Community procedures for the authorisation and monitoring of medicines for human and veterinary use needs to be amended. The aim is to separate EU marketing authorisations from those for medicinal products for veterinary use.  It is a technical text to better clarify European legislation that directly affects citizens.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The role of Parliament and the European institutions in monitoring what we eat is primary.  The European institutions have always guaranteed high food standards, and this report aims to reduce the amount of antibiotics we eat by eating meat from medically treated animals as well as combating antibiotic resistance. The report's contribution to a new regulation laying down procedures for the authorisation, supervision and distribution of medicines used in the veterinary sector suggests, for example, eliminating the online sale of antibiotics for veterinary use and restricting preventive care, while supporting the exchange of best practices and research and innovation in this field.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of authorising and supervising medicines, as well as the establishment of a European Medicines Agency. While there were discrepancies in funding it, we believe that regardless of how funding is managed, the Agency should exist.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal from the Commission intends to align the legislation with the Lisbon Treaty, which provides for improved democratic oversight and transparency through the increased role of the European Parliament in the legislative process. I welcome this report, and especially the emphasis it places on parliamentary scrutiny of the structure and level of fees payable to the European Medicines Agency.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. It is important that the European Parliament should be involved as a co-legislator when determining the structure and amount of the fees to be paid by industry to the EMA. That is why I support the agreement.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it amends certain rules relating to the authorisation and surveillance of medicinal products for human and veterinary use, in order to completely separate the two areas of discipline.  It is clear that the needs of the veterinary sector are substantially different from those of the human sector in relation to medicines. Thanks to this proposal, therefore, Directive 2001/82/EC will be repealed and Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 amended with a view to removing all references relating to the issue and maintenance of authorisations for veterinary medicinal products and taking into account the specific needs of each sector. The new regulation on veterinary medicinal products will therefore regulate all procedures for granting marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products in the Union, both at centralised and national level.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe that a responsible use of all veterinary medicines in British livestock farming is vital to maintaining our high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare. We believe that all veterinary medicines including antibiotics should be used responsibly, under veterinary care and according to licensing conditions. We believe that the British Parliament should be able to legislate on this issue without being overruled by the unelected EU Commission.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament, in my view, has to be involved as the co-legislator, not just as a matter of principle, but also that by establishing a European Medicines Agency, Parliament ought to be involved in the setting up the structure and level of fees payable by industry to the European Medicines Agency.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I voted in favour of adopting this resolution, which regulates the legislation on the granting of marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products. At a time when, unfortunately, we need to combat antibiotic resistance, I consider it necessary to establish differences in the authorisation of medicines for animals and medicinal products for humans, even if they contain the same active substance.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ Placing new medical devices on the market requires strict but prudent regulation, notably so that quality, safety and effectiveness measures are implemented on time and by the competent authorities. I therefore supported this Regulation as it takes into account technical and health progress and facilitates the placing of new human and veterinary medical devices on the European market. The new Regulation covers all ways of obtaining authorisation for new medical devices for humans and animals to enter the EU market – those centralised as well as those at national level. The establishment of the European Medicines Agency is a major step in strengthening the Union's ability to register medicines entering Member States' markets and it is necessary to carefully define the criteria for selecting future members of the committee to lead the Agency itself. A robust analysis of the amount of funding to be allocated to the Agency is also required, depending on the scope of its activities and technical requirements for the registration of medical devices.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I support the Commission's proposal to modify the regulation on procedures for the authorisation of medicinal products for human and veterinary use, as well as to regulate the functioning of the European Medicines Agency, as it is mainly about aligning the regulatory framework with the Treaty of Lisbon. This proposal builds on the Commission's efforts to take into account the specificities of the veterinary sector and to adapt legislation to the needs of the development of the veterinary medicinal products market. It is possible to evaluate positively in the proposal the separation of marketing authorisations for medicinal products for veterinary use from authorisations for medicinal products for human use. There is also an adjustment within the organisation of the European Medicines Agency, which, on the one hand, clearly defines the different types of revenue that make up the Agency's budget, while defining the Agency's competence in the authorisation of medicinal products for veterinary use. I believe that the reservations expressed in its opinion by the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development can be incorporated into the final proposal, which would further clarify the final form of the legislative text. When the scope and responsibilities of the Agency are clarified, undesirable duplication can be avoided. Overall, however, I welcome the Commission's proposal because, once clarified by the proposals of the EP committees, it can contribute to supporting the development of new medicines and their availability on the EU market.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report amending the proposal for a regulation on veterinary medicinal products (GLP) at first reading. The proposed Regulation replaces the existing Union arrangements for veterinary medicinal products contained in Directive No 2001/82/EC and Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 and responds to criticism of the existing arrangements by the pharmaceutical industry, farmers and veterinarians. Union regulation of this issue is needed to ensure a high level of protection of human and animal health and the environment, as well as for the functioning of the internal market. The proposed Regulation contains a new regulation on the marketing authorisation of medicinal products, with the aim of reducing the administrative burden associated with the marketing authorisation. Furthermore, the Regulation focuses on a fundamental and topical issue, namely the effort to reduce increasing antimicrobial resistance. It is precisely the control of antibiotic use in the veterinary field that is very important, because the overuse of antibiotics also negatively affects their effectiveness in treating people. The new regulation supports research into new products, for example by extending the deadline for the protection of technical documentation, which makes investment in the development of GLP more worthwhile. The scope of the Regulation also includes a modification of the rules for the production and distribution of VLP, rules for regulatory authorities, as well as an overhaul of the regulation of so-called pharmacovigilance – i.e. post-authorisation monitoring of VLP – to serve, for example, a single database for all registered GLP in the EU.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: writing \ u2012 Significant progress has been made in the area of alternative testing in recent years, which requires the establishment of an effective regulatory framework. Here, too, the issue of public health plays the most important role. Decisions in the field of authorisation of medicinal products should therefore be implemented on the basis of objective scientific criteria.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Directive 2001/82/EC of the European Parliament and the Council and Regulation (EC) No 2001/82/EC 726/2004 Of the European Parliament and the Council constituted a Union regulatory framework for the manufacture, authorisation and distribution of veterinary medicinal products.  As a result of the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the powers granted to the Commission under Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013 726/2004 should be compatible with Articles 290 and 291. treaty on the functioning of the European Union. In order to complement or amend certain elements of Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013, 726/2004 which are not essential, the Commission should be delegated the power to adopt acts in accordance with Article 290 TSC. treaties to amend the Annex on technical and scientific progress in order to facilitate the marketing of new medical devices, establishing the circumstances in which performance studies may be required after the authorisation, the establishment of provisions and requirements for marketing authorisations subject to certain specific obligations, the establishment of procedures for examining requests for changes to the conditions of marketing authorisation and for examining requests for the transfer of marketing authorisations, and the establishment of infringement investigation procedures and the imposition of a fine or periodic fine on marketing authorisation holders granted under this Regulation.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which has the aim of decoupling legislation on human and animal medicines and adopting a specific regulation on veterinary medicines. This Regulation is therefore being amended to remove references to veterinary medicines.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Veterinary medicinal products should be paid attention in equal measure and even higher, as well as for medical devices for human use. In animal husbandry, it is particularly important that newer and better medicines are available, as it is essential that veterinary medicinal products are available at reasonable prices for livestock herders. Adequate laws and regulations in this area are so useful and the European Parliament must simplify and clarify the Commission's proposal. At the same time, checks on new products, monitoring of their side effects and impacts on animal health and impacts on public health and the environment must in no way be reduced. Furthermore, orphan medicines are one of the most important reasons for the revision of veterinary-pharmaceutical laws. I support the report on the establishment of authorisation procedures and supervision procedures for the use of medicines used in medicine and the establishment of a European Medicines Agency, as I believe that applications for registration of veterinary medicinal products within the EU should be assessed in a quality way, including the distribution of power between the EU and the Member States, as well as the scope and scale of obligations of the European Medicines Agency, the activities of which must be justified in the budget proposals. Therefore, a detailed analysis of clearly defined legal frameworks is required.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Regulation on Community procedures for the authorisation of the marketing and control of medicinal products for human and veterinary use and establishing a European Medicines Agency. I welcome the European Commission's proposal to merge the rules on veterinary medicinal products in a single regulation on veterinary medicinal products. This would completely separate the provisions on medicinal products for human use. I support the amendment that licences will be issued according to a centralised procedure based on objective scientific criteria of quality, safety and efficacy.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that there are many advantages to separating veterinary medicinal products from marketing authorisations for medicinal products for human use. Significant progress has been made in the development of the report, for example, it is gratifying that significant compromises have been reached between the factions in both the licensing and supervision of generic medicines. The report proposes amendments to the Commission's proposal on a number of points, such as the composition and level of the fees payable or the fact that remuneration paid to the competent national authorities is not recorded through implementing acts. I agree that the European Parliament should be fully involved in the setting of agency fees, as is the case with the legislation on pharmacovigilance activities. The fight against and monitoring of antimicrobial resistance also plays an important role in the report, which has already been given great attention in part to medicated feedstuffs, myself as a shadow reportter. Finally, I think it is important that the new measures take into account the specificities of the veterinary sector and that premiums remain affordable for the veterinary industry. This is important in order to promote the development and availability of new medicines in the EU.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I agree with the proposal as a whole and am satisfied with the compliance with the Lisbon Treaty. It is to be welcomed that marketing authorizations for veterinary drugs are decoupled from those of medicines for human use in order to take into account the specific needs of the veterinary sector.  However, I believe that the proposal should be further improved in some respects. The structure and level of royalties due to the Agency, as well as the remuneration of national competent authorities, should not be determined by an act of execution, contrary to what the Commission proposes. Parliament should be fully involved in setting royalties due to the Agency, as in the case of pharmacovigilance legislation. That is why we suggest that this issue be addressed in a full-fledged codecision procedure.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of amending the regulation on the European Medicine Agency (EMA), to make sure that it is capable of effectively implementing new regulations and ensuring that all medicines available on the EU market are safe, effective and of high quality.  While the authorisation for veterinary medicinal products is now part of a new regulation, this amendment clarifies that the EMA is still responsible for the central authorisation procedure for human and the veterinary products, that it is line with the new financial regulations, and that it has a role to play in increasing access to medicine. Increasing cooperation and exchange of scientific information with the Agency for Health Technology Assessment bodies will be useful for the latter. I particularly agree with the idea that EMA should be also able to provide Member States with a comparative evaluation of medicinal products for humans, which can then be taken into consideration on a voluntary basis.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒Since the Commission has decided to consolidate the rules on veterinary medicines under one common veterinary medicinal products regulation, which abolishes and replaces the Veterinary Medicines Directive and amendments to the rules, this report is necessary to completely separate the provisions on veterinary medicines from those provisions governing the rules on medicinal products used by man. It is for this reason that I supported this report. However, there is one controversial provision on the structure and level of fees for the European Medicines Agency. Although the rapporteur has changed the Commission's proposal setting out that those provisions should be adopted by an implementing act allowing Member States a final decision, I do not support his opinion but I remain in my view that this should remain within the competence of the Commission and the regulatory authorities of the Member States.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1049/2001 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of the general public I supported the regulation as it makes some necessary changes in the production, distribution, marketing and control of medicinal products for human and veterinary use in the EU, in particular as a result of the proposal to repeal Directive 2001/82/EC on veterinary medicinal products which it has submitted at the same time. The needs for medicines in the human medicine sector are certainly different from those in the veterinary sector, as the latter involves many different animal species. That is why I particularly welcome the separation of marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products from human medicine and the alignment of the regulation with the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of authorising and supervising medicines, as well as the establishment of a European Medicines Agency. While there were discrepancies in funding it, we believe that regardless of how funding is managed, the Agency should exist.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. As part of the review of the Veterinary Medicine Regulations, there are plans to centralise authorisations to a single European agency as much as possible. This report therefore amends the Commission's proposal for the separation of veterinary and human activities from the European Medicines Agency.  Some of the rapporteur's proposals are moving in the right direction, including stricter oversight by Parliament, but the aim remains the same: to centralise as much as possible and to remove power and expertise from the Member States through a transfer of powers.  So I voted against it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of authorising and supervising medicines, as well as the establishment of a European Medicines Agency. While there were discrepancies in funding it, we believe that regardless of how funding is managed, the Agency should exist.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of postponing the vote on the legislative resolution so as to enter into negotiations with the Council for a possible first reading agreement.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I support the fact that medicines for rare diseases and rare species (now newly defined as medicines for small markets) are one of the main reasons for the revision of veterinary legislation. It is therefore necessary to ensure that the budgetary requirements of the European Medicines Agency, which have been included in the Regulation, are maintained.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The vote on the report on the proposal for a regulation concerning the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products for human and veterinary use was actually a vote on the request that the vote in Plenary itself be postponed to a later part-session. I voted in favour of the postponement of the vote on this particular report.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In relation to the previous report, we found this proposal which aims to update legislation to improve the marketing authorisation of veterinary medicinal products and separate it from that of medicines for humans. We are talking about a document which has also had broad consensus in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this proposal because it will first and foremost give us better access to veterinary medicinal products. Secondly, it will reduce the administrative burden and ensure that measures are taken to combat increasing resistance to human and animal antibiotics. And finally, it stimulates further innovation in the sector.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report expresses Parliament's position on the European Commission's new draft regulation on veterinary medicines, aimed at implementing administrative simplifications. The European Parliament calls for combating the increasing resistance of bacteria to current antibiotics and banning collective and preventive antibiotic treatment of animals, as well as improving the differentiation in the veterinary drug market from that of human medicines, including the establishment of a list of critically important antibiotics reserved for human use. However, this report could have gone further.  Our group has tabled amendments to reduce patent monopoly time and facilitate access to generic drugs with more affordable prices, but they have been rejected.  We have supported and obtained strong protection of the environment and animals as criteria for impact assessment and ban on online sales for antibiotic products, vaccines and psychotropic drugs.  It should be noted that Member States are free to go further if they wish.  I voted in favour of this report and curiously noted that the National Front had rejected the administrative simplifications brought about by this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In September 2014, the Commission published a proposal to bring together the rules on veterinary medicinal products in a regulation, completely differenting the provisions governing veterinary medicinal products from those governing human medicinal products. This new Regulation repeals and replaces Directive 2001/82/EC and amends Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 in order to delete any references to veterinary medicinal products and decoupling marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products from medicinal products for human use in order to take account of the specific needs of the veterinary sector.  A European Medicines Agency is also established, clearly indicating its role in authorising and supervising products for veterinary use through the centralised procedure.  Current Regulation No 297/95 on the general regime of fees charged by the European Medicines Agency and Regulation (EU) No 658/2014 on pharmacovigilance rates shall remain as a legal basis until the adoption and entry into force of the revision of Regulation (EC) No 297/95 or any other fee provisions.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The rapporteur welcomes the separation of marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products from those for medicinal products for human use in order to meet the specific needs of the veterinary sector.  It does not consider it right, as the Commission proposes, that the structure and level of fees to be paid to the Agency and the remuneration paid to the competent national authority should be determined by means of an implementing act. As was the case with the pharmacovigilance act, Parliament should be fully involved in the definition of agency fees. The rapporteur therefore proposes a complete codecision procedure in this respect. This is to be welcomed and, in this respect, I support this report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 establishing Community procedures for the authorisation and monitoring of medicinal products for human and veterinary use and the establishment of a European Medicines Agency. I am opposed to the establishment of further EU authorities, for whatever purpose.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ the 2001 Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on veterinary medicinal products and the 2004 Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council constitute the Union regulatory framework for the manufacture, authorisation and distribution of medicinal products for veterinary use. I welcome the effort to bring this regulatory framework into line with the Treaty of Lisbon. I think that the proposal adopted in the European Parliament has improved the original text presented by the Commission in some areas. The granting of marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products should be separate from the authorisations for medicinal products intended for human beings. The needs of the veterinary sector differ significantly from those of the humane sector in the area of pharmaceutical policy and the market for medicinal products, which is why I supported the proposal.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Tanasescu report which supports the reform of the veterinary medicines law and strengthens the single market in this sector, not only by extending the centralisation of authorisation and surveillance procedures, but also by establishing a database of all authorised veterinary medicinal products in the European Union. This reform seeks to improve the efficiency and availability of veterinary medicines in the EU, while also safeguarding human health and environmental impact. These objectives include restricting the overuse of antibiotics in agricultural practices, seeking to avoid antimicrobial resistance, as well as traceability of antibiotics in the EU whose active pharmaceutical substances pose major environmental risks.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I fully support the resolution towards a data-centred economy, and, in particular, the references to digital skills. If we are to enable our citizens to truly grasp the possibilities of the digital world, we need to coordinate action across Member States. The need to provide digital education and training opportunities – whether it is in school, college, university, at the work place or in pensioners’ clubs – has never been so important. If we do not have digital skills, we cannot access the potential of the digital single market to create jobs and support the European economy. We need digital skills to be at the heart of all that we do. As the Swedish Prime Minister offered to hold a special summit on social Europe yesterday, I would like to see also a digital skills summit organised and prioritised so that no EU citizen is left behind in this digital revolution.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr By 2020, the total data will reach 16 zetabaitus, gigabyte trillions, which means 236% this is a big annual increase. Other predictions, among others, about 40 and 44 zetabates, in the case of 40 zetabaitu, mean a whole gigabyte of 5,200 data per planet.. In other words, the potential for economic development is enormous, it must be exploited.  I support this document and, given the perspectives of consumers, businesses, education management systems and other areas, further efforts are clearly needed, I would say, to inform and promote citizens, which must be made imperative by the European Union, the European Commission, and the same applies to innovation and investment, not only at the transnational level of the European Union, but also in all others.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – In Uachtaráin, bhí know suimiúil sa tuarascáil seo nach raibh aon ghlaoch rolla againn sna vótaí go léir a bhí againn. Taobh amuigh from cheann amháin to bhí agatsa nó nach raibh a fhios agat an raibh daoine and bhfabhar nó i gcoinne vóta leasú 2, high 26. Dá bhrí sin, is dóigh liom nach bhfuil sé sin ceart i slí amháin. Ba chóir go mbeadh fianaise againn ag deireadh an lae conas a vótáil feisirí and ngach aon tuarascáil, go háirithe an méid a vótáil agus an raibh siad i bhfabhar nó i gcoinne na tuarascála, agus ba chóir dúinn féachaint air sin amach anseo. Taobh amuigh de sin, is ábhar an-tábhachtach é seo. Bhí mise i mo rapóirtéir ar an DPR. I know sin críochnaithe againn anois agus tá súil agam gur féidir linn bualadh ar aghaidh agus an Margadh Aonair Digiteach a chur ar bun, go háirithe chun mórshonraí agus mar sinn de a chur chun cinn.

name: President. –
text: I should tell you that some Groups are asking for a roll call vote and some are not, so I am just implementing what has come from others.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, sorry, I am making no criticism of you, none whatsoever. But I think this is something that we should look at from the point of view of the record, for those who want to see how we voted.

name: President. –
text: I see your point. There are indeed amendments which are worth being checked like this. That is the point.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The "big data" market is expanding at an unstoppable rate. It is estimated that more than 50 billion turnover and a data flow of 16 billion terabytes by 2020. The resolution indicates that a data-driven economy can be harmonised and properly integrated with privacy-oriented data management.  Finally, the network, data and the Internet can be used in harmony in order to foster open, transparent and inclusive governance. In addition, initiatives that include programming and data processing related subjects in national educational programmes are encouraged, highlighting the multiple benefits of free software in education. In order to promote the digital economy and the digitisation of European states, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We in UKIP oppose the EU Commission proposal ‘towards a thriving data-driven economy’. We oppose new EU prescriptive legislation. We believe that Europe can achieve competitiveness by creating incentives and removing obstacles. It can achieve it by setting free the entrepreneurial spirit of business and industry.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this proposal because I believe that technological development should be at the service of the European people, not the other way around. We are concerned that the text will support the Commission in its strategy of liberalisation and privatization of digital infrastructure and services, including public data banks. Mentions of security and privacy are vague, which will also negatively reverse the fundamental freedoms of Europeans.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this resolution as it was unbalanced, with a strong focus on public—private enterprise, and not enough emphasis was placed on data protection or privacy protection. The fact that the resolution is 9 pages long with 45 paragraphs and has only 5 fleeting references to data protection means that it is completely big—business oriented. The few references to data protection in the resolution are taken completely from the point of view of businesses rather than the point of view of the user or consumer, saying that data protection is in the interest of big data companies as creating trust can foster growth. The report talks about having default privacy models built in to operating systems for the benefit of fast development of companies rather than for users. The report also assures businesses that data protection and opportunities for the integrated use of data ‘are not mutually exclusive’. This clearly is not written in favour of users. It was for these reasons that we voted against this resolution.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, as it seeks to define broadband infrastructure investment, consumer protection, opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises, smooth and effective innovation processes and data protection as priorities in a thriving data-based economy. This resolution is the answer, noting the shortcomings and expectations in the strategy announced in July 2014 by the Commission on the transition to a data-based economy.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Some positive aspects, of course, but the project is inspired by an ultraliberal ideology and a desire to achieve an integrated market. The approach is purely commercial and service-oriented rather than industry-oriented. This common data market tends towards regulatory standardization and the removal of barriers to data exchange, to the detriment of states, of course. I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. The UK is leading the world in capturing the possibilities of big data and the benefits it could bring to businesses in every sector. It is the new kid on the block and has the potential to change how data is collected and analysed for the considerable future. However, with it come dangers, more and more personal data is being collected on each of us and already allows targeted advertising. It is important to have regulations in place that lay out what data can be collected and how to ensure the public know that their data is being collected and how that data can then be used. The UK already has a framework in place for the security, control, ownership, the portability and reusability of this intellectual capital. I do not support this report as I do not believe that it is in the best interests of the UK for the EU to be deciding how UK businesses are allowed to use this resource. We should not allow the EU to be a barrier to innovation or the revolution of technology that will only benefit the UK economy.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a thriving data-driven economy. The volume of data is increasing faster than ever before, with 16 trillion tonnes in 2020. gigabytes of data. Knowledge-based solutions based on big data can contribute to a significant increase in productivity and competitiveness, while the benefits of a data-driven economy will increase GDP by an additional 1.9% by 2020. The development of the big data sector is an integral part of the new digital market and it is therefore necessary to ensure that innovative and competitive business models are developed in line with the requirements of the EU data protection framework through the development of this sector. I agree with the need to establish a regulatory framework to address the economic, technological, social and cultural problems of the data-based economy, such as access to data, in particular public data, control and ownership. Big data can help to increase economic productivity and improve the services provided to consumers and public authorities.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved the resolution that arose from the oral question, because there is a need for a framework that allows both growth, job creation and competitiveness to make the most of the benefits of the data economy while ensuring strong privacy protection through the protection of personal data.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Big data is one of the great opportunities of the 21st century; an opportunity that according to the most recent estimates should generate, by 2017, a market of 50 billion euros with the potential to create jobs for 3.75 million people.  The resumption of growth, innovation and investment can only be achieved through a digital single market strategy based on the development of a strong economy capable of exploiting the huge amount of information produced on a daily basis. My vote in favour of the resolution tabled in Parliament today stems from the deep conviction that big data is a huge opportunity still to be exploited.  From industry 4.0 to mHealth, from the theme of Smart Cities to that of e-government, the new technological frontier requires the development of advanced skills capable of promoting employment growth. The issue of the intelligent exploitation of opportunities is also linked to that of data protection. In an increasingly connected world, the protection of privacy is a priority to be guaranteed and it is therefore essential to develop an appropriate and uniform European legal framework in this area.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We share the resolution's view that the digital economy can serve as a lever for economic growth. We also share some recommendations on privacy and data protection. Therefore, these guarantees must go further and ensure that the flow of data cannot serve as a tool for the control of the population by governments or companies. The Resolution also seems to us to be too optimistic about the growth possibilities offered by the digital economy. That's why we abstain.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this motion for a Resolution on the ITRE Commission's 'Towards a Thriving Data Economy' initiative. It discusses the role of the data economy in the Digital Union's strategy and investing in a data economy, both in infrastructure and R&D, as well as creating a data economy in the Union market, promoting start-ups and SMEs and incentiving society. It is a weighty resolution that we voted on and approved today.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I rejected this resolution on the digital economy and in particular the future framework for digital data. Certainly, it is vital to support this sector, which happens to be a real driver of growth and which faces American competition, as the United States is at the forefront in this area. However, this is a resolution based on an ultra-liberal philosophy, which is in line with the risk of monopolistic appropriation of this data by certain multinationals such as Google or Facebook. Of course, I recognize the need to support infrastructure, to have a real legal framework and to encourage research and development in this area that is crucial to our competitiveness. However, I reject the underpinned logic that leads us to this digital single market which will deprive Member States of their capacity to act and therefore of this industry of the future in favour of a European Commission friendly to multinationals. Finally, as a full member of the Committee on Culture, I will remain attentive to the issue of copyright protection for digital content - access for all and instantaneously not to lead to the precariousness of creation and creators - as well as to the issue of respect for private data.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is acceptable and does not present any particular critical issues, so I voted in favour.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Data production is growing at an exorbitant rate. Studies indicate that the volume of data increases at an annual rate of 236% and this trend will increase with millions of devices exchanging information with each other. Europe cannot be left out of the big data revolution, a revolution that is already affecting every economic sector and every area of our lives.  It is therefore urgent that the European Union take a step forward by creating a framework conducive to the exploitation of the opportunities that this new reality brings to economic development and job creation.  As this Resolution points out, which I have supported, it is necessary to promote and support investment in R&D, enable public and private financing avenues, invest in broadband networks, promote digital adaptation of SMEs and train and train workers in this area, but it is certainly crucial to ensure data protection and network security , as well as shielding respect for intellectual property rights.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because a future prosperous, data-driven economy can become an opportunity for growth and employment, including by enabling new business models and services and improving productivity. In order to create the right framework for economic growth, a good balance needs to be struck in order to maintain confidence and to ensure and uphold consumer rights through effective monitoring, evaluation and appropriate response, where necessary through legislative measures. Parliament hopes that the benefits of a data-driven economy at national and European level will have an impact on society and all types of value chain companies. The creation of a data-driven economy is considered to be at the heart of the Digital Single Market strategy and welcomes the opportunities it offers to help europe restore the competitiveness of advanced sectors and accelerate the recovery of the European economy, investment in growth and innovation in all sectors. This can only be achieved if an appropriate business environment is created and measures are put in place to promote the digital transformation, and if these technologies comply with the EU legal framework for data protection in order to take into account the risks and challenges associated with fundamental rights, in particular privacy and data protection.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, it is important that the EU and its Member States make greater, coordinated efforts in schools and educational establishments to make information and communication technologies an attractive professional area. I believe that these efforts should also include measures aimed at enhancing entrepreneurship and facilitating the start-up of businesses in the area of big data by starting new start-ups. I would like to recall the importance of a multidisciplinary approach to training and team building for professionals. We need initiatives and funding models to encourage lifelong learning.  I support initiatives aimed at programming and inging data management subjects in national curricula. I also agree with the proposal that the EU and its Member States should step up their efforts to prevent highly skilled and qualified professionals from migrating to other regions outside Europe. With this in mind, I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Union's Big Data Strategy aims to support and accelerate the transition to a digital single market in Europe and, ultimately, towards a More Effective and Fully Regulated European Digital Union.  The potential benefits of an increasingly digitised economy, based on a growing stimulus to innovation and investment in R&D, are manifold and affect businesses, public administrations and private citizens, thus bringing significant benefits to society as a whole.  However, the challenge posed by this important transition also presents more sensitive problems, which deserve to be treated with due care, as highlighted in the resolution voted on today. The development of a data-based economy cannot ignore the provision and maintenance of the highest protections for their content, the guarantee of confidentiality of the most sensitive information and the certainty, as well as transparency, about its processing.  The use of data must therefore be regulated on time, according to precise and shared standards, which, moreover, allow fair opportunities for companies to use them, particularly with regard to SMEs. Data protection and opportunities arising from the integrated use of data must therefore not be excluded, but complement each other.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I am convinced that the role that big data will play in the near future will be fundamental for the growth of the continent's economies and that they have considerable potential in terms of economic growth. It is up to the Eu ropean Union and the Member States to ensure that this opportunity is not missed.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The data-driven economy has a number of benefits both economically and socially. The successful, data-driven economy can generate growth and foster employment through various economic incentives. The data-driven economy is perceived as a success given the growth rate of the market for large volumes of data, which by 2017 will be six times faster than in the global ICT market, reaching a total global value of EUR 50 billion. There is also an unprecedented increase, so that by 2020 there will be 16 trillion gigabytes of data, indicating an annual increase of 236% in data generation. At the same time, the benefits associated with a data-driven economy will lead to additional GDP growth of 1.9% by 2020. I was in favour of this resolution because I believe that the data-driven economy has the potential to boost competitiveness at Union level and accelerate Europe's economic recovery, as well as to boost investment and innovation growth in various key sectors.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. Apology for the progressive virtues of big data, where of course the benefits (competitiveness, productivity, employment, economic growth...), the beneficial effects of which will be multiplied by the future Digital Union expertly governed by the Commission, are much more relevant than risks (privacy, democratic control, ethics, fundamental freedoms...)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
