text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reflection and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution 'Towards a thriving data-based economy' because, as the author of numerous questions, speeches and statements on the development of the Internet and the strengthening of big data to modernise the economy and public health, I consider the Internet to be the real challenge of universal services, in order to guarantee public utility services with ever greater standards.  It should be stressed, in any case, that we need more protection on personal data, greater respect for the Charter of Fundamental Rights, because only defined rules generate a positive social and cultural impact and create the digital single market, with equal conditions for businesses and security for citizens.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution as it was unbalanced, with a strong focus on public—private enterprise, and not enough emphasis was placed on data protection or privacy protection. The fact that the resolution is 9 pages long with 45 paragraphs and has only 5 fleeting references to data protection means that it is completely big—business oriented. The few references to data protection in the resolution are taken completely from the point of view of businesses rather than the point of view of the user or consumer, saying that data protection is in the interest of big data companies as creating trust can foster growth. The report talks about having default privacy models built in to operating systems for the benefit of fast development of companies rather than for users. The report also assures businesses that data protection and opportunities for the integrated use of data ‘are not mutually exclusive’. This clearly is not written in favour of users. It was for these reasons that I voted against this resolution.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This is an important motion for a resolution as it covers a topic which is relevant across different policy areas. The current technological advances change our world constantly and it is crucial that we adapt our policies to them and use them to our benefit as much as possible.  Among other benefits, they impact and create opportunities for innovation, science, labour markets and, of course, our private lives. It is crucial that we come up with cohesive policies on related matters such as data protection, and I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution, which states that a thriving economy should be harmonised and properly integrated with privacy-oriented data management.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that a strong European role in the data-driven economy will be vital to our economic growth in the future. While we must always support the right to privacy by default, there are real opportunities for Europe if we are active in the development of big data, cloud computing, connected vehicles, and the internet of things. A data-driven economy can make our cities cleaner, help bring smart solutions to real problems and create new jobs. In short, a connected world will be an important part of making life better and easier for our citizens and I hope we will not let this chance slip by.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and expect that the benefits of a data-based economy at national and European level will have an impact on society and on every type of business at all levels of the value chain.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ A thriving data-driven economy will contribute to the well-being of citizens as well as to socio-economic progress through new business opportunities and through more innovative public services. It will flourish in a European Digital Single Market governed by modern and innovative rules. The envisaged actions, once implemented, will result in accelerated innovation, productivity growth and increased competitiveness in data across the whole economy as well as on the global market with Europe as a key player.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We in UKIP oppose the EU Commission proposal ‘towards a thriving data-driven economy’. We oppose new EU prescriptive legislation. We believe that Europe can achieve competitiveness by creating incentives and removing obstacles. It can achieve it by setting free the entrepreneurial spirit of business and industry.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 A thriving data-driven economy can be an opportunity for growth and employment, making new business models or new services possible, as well as increasing productivity.  Based on the fact that the growth rate of the big data market up to 2017 is estimated for a total total of 50 billion euros and according to the forecasts of the International Data Corporation (IDC) for the period 2013-2017 related to the global market for big data technology and related services, this sector could create 3.75 million new jobs by 2017 according to the public-private partnership with Big data value; For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The opportunity for unleashing the potential of cloud computing is an important one for Europe. It will not only provide economic growth and jobs, but will also bring about socio-economic progress through the use of big data in research. This does not, however, come about without risks and challenges such as those in the area of privacy and data protection, which also need to be addressed. While tapping into this opportunity, Member States will also need to address the current skills mismatch and ensure that education fosters a more entrepreneurial mindset.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this proposal because I believe that technological development should be at the service of the European people, not the other way around. We are concerned that the text will support the Commission in its strategy of liberalisation and privatization of digital infrastructure and services, including public data banks. Mentions of security and privacy are vague, which will also negatively reverse the fundamental freedoms of Europeans.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The volume of data is growing at an unprecedented rate and it is estimated that by 2020 there will be 16 000 billion gigabytes of data.  This growth in the big data market will have positive effects in terms of productivity and competitiveness and will create new possibilities for consumers, businesses, administration, science and medicine. The European Parliament resolution promotes this type of data-driven economy and places it at the heart of the European Digital Single Market Strategy.  By voting in favour, I wanted to support all kinds of measures to promote a data-driven economy because I think it can help Europe regain competitiveness in advanced sectors and accelerate investment in growth and innovation; However, I believe that it will be very important to develop a harmonised regulatory framework that guarantees access to data in accordance with data protection principles.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The development of large volumes of data is an integral part of a new digital market and should ensure the development of innovative and competitive business models, respecting the EU data protection framework. However, large amounts of data can entail significant risks and challenges, in particular for fundamental rights (including the protection of privacy and data). There is a need to develop a strong database of service providers to promote the benefits and assets of integrated data use for the economy and society and to promote confidence in technologies related to large volumes of data among SMEs. The widespread application of high-volume data services should be supported in order to improve efficiency in different economic sectors and to support new service providers. At the same time, it is important to create a one-stop shop to help SMEs make better use of their own and public data, adhering to EU data protection legislation.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Database marketing is a fundamental segment of modern market trading, in which different marketing companies try to gain as much information about customers as possible, thereby bringing them into different categories based on their earnings, purchasing habits and interests. On this basis, they intend to base their business campaigns on the information extracted from the data in order to make a product more successful for customers.  The European Parliament considers that it is of the utmost importance that, in today's world, where increased activity of 'phishing' is increasingly expected as IT and mass services come to the fore, it is important to protect the rights of European citizens as much as possible so that their data does not fall into the wrong hands.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The aim of the resolution is to highlight the importance of big data (datasets that are so large or complex that traditional data processing applications are inadequate) for the Digital Single Market and the European Economy. The resolution covers the following key areas related to big data: data protection, broadband and data processing infrastructure, cloud computing, brain drain, electronic services, etc. I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this overview of the challenges in the new, data-driven economy. We have to ensure that the framework we create at EU level is legally sound, gives priority to broadband infrastructure investment, consumer protection and new opportunities for SMEs. In all, data-driven economy has a great potential to stimulate R&D&I on data while leading to more business opportunities and an increased availability of knowledge and capital, in particular for SMEs across Europe.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Big data is an essential part of the transformation process underway towards a digital single market. An innovative sector that could revive the European economy, whose benefits are estimated at an overall GDP growth of 1.9 % by 2020, in the creation of new jobs and in innovative services for citizens. In particular, as the resolution I voted on today suggests, the Union will have to define and develop an e-government strategy that will make it possible to make effective use of big data and open data, so that public administrations can tailor and qualify their services aimed at citizens, and improve the provision of essential information by business sector and SMEs.  In the process of defining a competitive and forward-looking regulatory environment capable of promoting technological progress and innovation, particularly in public administrations, the Union must be firm in ensuring an adequate level of data protection and dissemination. This will be the key to making full use of the invaluable potential of big data, without derogating from compliance with one of our fundamental principles, namely the protection of the privacy of our citizens.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution examines the economic and social potential of the information and communication technology revolution. It mainly concerns big data and is part of the digital union carried out by the Juncker Commission. This resolution reacts to the Commission's July 2014 communication on the same subject and addresses the issue of innovation and the creation of a market for big data.  In addition to the development of appropriate infrastructure (optical fibre, high-performance IT infrastructure), we call for increased support for SMEs investing in big data. Considering that this text also proposes to improve the computer and digital skills of professionals and young people, I voted in favour.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The data-driven economy is one of the main lines of the Digital Union strategy for the economic future of the European Union. In particular, the current report builds on the so-called Big Data market. In the near future, businesses based on this will create more jobs, increase competitiveness and make a major contribution to economic growth. However, particular attention should be paid to the potential hazards, in the event of potential. Citizens' data protection should therefore be included in the report. For this complex plan to be successful, infrastructure development must be a priority.  It should also be remembered that these developments also create new conditions in the labour market, which may be accompanied by a new knowledgeable, well-skilled workforce. These can be used primarily by SMEs as potential Big Data market players. Digital market developments clearly require transparency of available data and disclosure by various public bodies. In the long term, this could contribute to the development of e-government and electronic democracy. These guidelines lay the basis for the Digital Union and are therefore extremely important for the future of Europe.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this initiative because I agree that the Commission must address these problems because of the importance of 'big data' in our society today.  We need to push for greater clarity and transparency when it comes to pushing through sensitive key areas, such as those described in the text. Especially with the latest proposals from the European Commission, there are more developments that can be expected. It is imperative that we be able to work on a solid basis to avoid ineffective legislation. We must therefore carefully assess all the issues at issue in order to find the right solutions.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The development of technology is a means in the hands of man to improve his life and develop entrepreneurship and work. But it can also be used for criminal purposes such as invasion of personal data and privacy, terrorism, etc.  The European Union must educate and help its citizens to use the data but also protect them from malicious acts by individuals, organisations and states.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The growth rate of the large data market by 2017 will be six times higher than that of the global ICT market and will reach an overall total of EUR 50 billion, which could generate 3.75 million new jobs by this year. Data volume is growing at an unprecedented rate, so by 2020 there will be more than 16 billion gigabytes of data, equivalent to an annual growth rate of 236% in terms of data generation. I would like to point out from this proposal the social and economic benefits associated with the integrated use of data in all sectors of the European economy and in all areas of European research, as well as the right of people to access up-to-date and relevant data and data processing information.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour: the resolution encourages the European public to raise awareness of the importance of massive data, especially categories of people who do not have access to or are unfamiliar with technology, which is always an important element when we know the issues of digital divides that we see even in France.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution on the theme "Towards a thriving data economy" is associated with the Digital Single Market Strategy, where the "development of market-oriented standards", the "public-private partnerships in the field of big data" and the "new business models" are just some of the orderly words of the dominant neoliberal agenda. "Job creation", "growth of SMEs" and "data protection" are references that emerge here as mere adornment to a document that is daily contradicted by the unrelenting reality, in which thousands of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises emerge and disappear by bankruptcy always with the promise of a prosperous horizon, a mirage for the overwhelming majority. Unemployment remains at very high levels in the EU, and particularly in Portugal. This resolution sets out a number of unacceptable proposals at various levels. Examples are proposals in the field of data protection, with unacceptable concessions to multinationals and limitations to state action.  For the rest, we are faced with the challenge of the tedious and repetitive neoliberal argumentative argument, which serves as the basis for the majority of reports and resolutions on the digital single market. Nothing new. It addresses a relevant theme from a totally wrong perspective. We voted against it.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Differences in digitisation, insufficient investment, as well as lack of technical standardisation and timeless data protection legislation could lead Europe to become technologically and economically behind in the development of a data-driven economy. The European Union must simplify grant award procedures and increase funding for research and innovation on integrated data use, digital innovation and market development in areas that should bring added value to citizens, society and the economy, as well as effectively support the market entry of innovative products and services. Key technological obstacles to the development of the data-driven economy include a lack of interoperability and a lack of a framework for a common interface to facilitate data communication between sensors and machines and communication between virtual and real worlds, a lack of availability of open data and a lack of market conditions enabling entrepreneurs to in upgrade and grow. In order for all this to be possible, individual Member States need to work towards the inclusion of ICT in their national training programmes to a greater extent.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The development of technology is a means in the hands of man to improve his life and develop entrepreneurship and work. But it can also be used for criminal purposes such as invasion of personal data and privacy, terrorism, etc.  The European Union must educate and help its citizens to use the data but also protect them from malicious acts by individuals, organisations and states. For these reasons, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the data—driven economy, which will stimulate research and innovation on data while leading to more business opportunities and an increased availability of knowledge and capital, in particular for SMEs, across Europe. The development of the digital world, beyond connectivity, needs common standards, interoperability, accessible platforms, high-speed networks and high—performance computing infrastructure. I therefore support the call on the Commission to clarify its plan on how to support the development of broadband infrastructure, cloud computing, innovations in standards and a stable legal framework. I believe the Commission must ensure that the framework for a data-driven economy is legally sound, respecting data protection standards, yet flexible enough to adapt to the changing environment of digital markets. Finally, I would like to understand how the Commission will encourage and support the Member States in implementing training initiatives related to data handling and the development of the necessary skills.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on 'Towards a thriving data-driven economy' because I consider the issue of big data to be fundamental in the future of the EU and in the digital single market. The data-driven economy can be key to putting Europe's technological know-how to good use, recovering lost competitiveness, creating jobs and digitising the younger generation. In order to have these effects, however, I believe it is essential that the legislation strikes the right balance with regard to the issues of the processing of personal data, transparency in their use and the protection of privacy. I agree with Parliament's call for Europe to equip itself with the network infrastructure, such as broadband, necessary to develop a data-driven economy, and I consider the instrument of public-private partnerships to be very important. I believe, in fact, that the data economy also requires the development of entrepreneurship, and it is therefore essential to involve SMEs, start-ups and the world of research in order to innovate more and more the technologies and services offered. Finally, I welcome the reference to the issue of raising the awareness and involvement of society and the public with regard to the issues of new technologies, the shared economy and the digital market.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP oppose the EU Commission proposal ‘towards a thriving data-driven economy’. We oppose new EU prescriptive legislation. We believe that Europe can achieve competitiveness by creating incentives and removing obstacles. It can achieve it by setting free the entrepreneurial spirit of business and industry.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We share the resolution's view that the digital economy can serve as a lever for economic growth. We also share some recommendations on privacy and data protection. Therefore, these guarantees must go further and ensure that the flow of data cannot serve as a tool for the control of the population by governments or companies. The Resolution also seems to us to be too optimistic about the growth possibilities offered by the digital economy. That's why we abstain.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The text is positive towards the innovative potential of big data; not only does it welcome the free flow of data initiative, but also highlights the importance of open data and open source, privacy and security by design, modern and future-proof regulatory framework to ensure the right conditions are set for growth and innovation in a data-driven economy.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report because of the emphasis placed on the need to strengthen society's participation in the digital economy. In particular, the report proposes actions aimed at raising public awareness and encouraging public debate in the Member States as well as at European and international level on the benefits of digital technologies and their value (especially among those groups that do not yet have access to or become familiar with digital technologies). Initiatives are also needed to enable citizens to make use of their data, in particular with regard to the development of new innovative services, and to increase public awareness of the benefits and value of mass data to society.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution ‘towards a thriving data-driven economy’. The Commission’s 2014 strategy on big data supports the transition towards a data-driven economy in Europe, which will be core to the Digital Single Market, and aims to stimulate research and innovation on data, leading to more business opportunities and an increased availability of knowledge and capital – in particular for SMEs – across Europe. The big data market has huge potential with an expected growth rate up to 2017 that is six times faster than in the overall ICT market, possibly 3.75 million new jobs by 2017 and 1.9 % in additional GDP growth by 2020. This rapidly growing sector will need advanced, digitally skilled workers, an area in which the EU workforce is currently lacking. Education and training will therefore be crucial. Also hugely important will be improved investment in broadband services, particularly in rural areas, so that all EU regions and citizens can benefit from this burgeoning sector. That is why I supported the amendment calling for improved support and incentives for cooperative and municipal investments in broadband infrastructure, which will also facilitate broadband coverage in rural areas.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution, which is accompanied by five oral questions, highlights the importance of big data and specific areas linked to it, such as data protection, broadband infrastructure and e-services. As a strong supporter of the data-driven economy, and in light of the importance of these topics for the successful implementation of the Digital Single Market, my vote was positive. In addition, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP oppose the EU Commission proposal ‘towards a thriving data-driven economy’. We oppose new EU prescriptive legislation. We believe that Europe can achieve competitiveness by creating incentives and removing obstacles. It can achieve it by setting free the entrepreneurial spirit of business and industry.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on communication "Towards a growing data-driven economy" as it strengthens the European Digital Single Market and boosts the Union's competitiveness and technological progress. Great emphasis has been placed on information and communication technologies, which are becoming increasingly important for all sectors of society, and the launch of the economy. In this regard, barriers preventing such development and growth should be reduced. However, it is necessary to ensure effective data protection and prevent any kind of misuse of free data flow. Accordingly, the legislative framework should be adapted to the new conditions requiring certain changes and adjustments.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite some good ideas, the project is being fished by ultraliberalism and a European desire to achieve an integrated market. The approach is mercantile and service-oriented rather than industry-oriented. This common data market is part of a Europeanised framework that is moving towards regulatory standardisation and the removal of barriers to data exchange. This is done at the expense of the States, and strengthens the Commission. As a result, I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We in UKIP oppose the EU Commission proposal ‘towards a thriving data-driven economy’. We oppose new EU prescriptive legislation. We believe that Europe can achieve competitiveness by creating incentives and removing obstacles. It can achieve it by setting free the entrepreneurial spirit of business and industry.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Jerzy Buzek's resolution on a prosperous data economy. The European Parliament wants to examine the economic potential of this digital revolution while protecting the data of EU citizens. This revolution calls for the development of new infrastructure. However, SMEs are very active in the big data sector and I am in favour of encouraging them because they promote European growth. However, the data economy will lead to very significant changes in the labour market. That is why I support this resolution, which highlights in many sectors the potential, but also the risks, generated by these new developments in the European landscape. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The excellent resolution on big data is, on the one hand, a balanced inventory, according to which Europe has a great deal of catching up to do in order to be a global standard setter again in this field, and on the other hand, it contains some forward-looking proposals on how to achieve the objectives. I am therefore voting in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament resolution on moving towards a prosperous, data-based economy. This resolution goes hand in hand with the EU's move towards a single digital market, which is being implemented in order to open up more opportunities for economic development.  The data-based economy, or digital economy, where information technologies are widely used in all social, economic, cultural and educational areas, offers enormous opportunities for development. However, investment in research, infrastructure and technical development is necessary for these opportunities to be exploited, and this resolution accordingly stresses the need for the EU to establish a single, modern and future-appropriate legal framework that stimulates and develops investment in both network infrastructure and research. I believe that the data-based economy using information technology has enormous potential to boost the economic growth of the European Union.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution calling to support and accelerate the transition towards a data-driven economy in Europe. It will stimulate research and innovation on data while leading to more business opportunities and an increased availability of knowledge and capital, in particular for SMEs, across Europe.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ We are currently living in a time of the fourth industrial revolution. The fourth industrial revolution has been characterised by the advance of technology and availability of vast amounts of data. Looking from this perspective, it is obvious why the EU should support and accelerate the transition towards a data-driven economy in Europe. Availability of information and knowledge will definitely stimulate research and innovation and will create many opportunities for businesses across Europe. Furthermore, the data—driven economy will improve competitiveness and make citizens’ lives better. In this context, it can be argued that the data—driven economy will bring productivity growth to the EU. That is another reason why we should support it and facilitate it.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission had presented its communication on data-driven economy and it was up to Parliament to give its opinion. I think that privacy and data protection are indispensable and cannot be compromised. A data-driven economy should be built on anonymous data. I am concerned about the use of data for corporate and governmental surveillance. This is why I voted abstention.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. – According to forecasts by the International Data Corporation (IDC), for the period 2013-2017, relating to the global market for big data technology and related services, the growth rate of the big data market, until 2017, will be six times faster than in the global ICT market.  The development of Big Data is an integral part of a new digital market and will ensure the development of innovative and competitive business models. I have chosen to vote in favour of this resolution because a data-driven economy is a unique opportunity for growth and employment. With regard to companies, it is possible to say that data is a valuable resource, increasing its value through the development of innovative and intelligent methods, obviously in compliance with the legislation on the protection of privacy.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution "towards a prosperous data economy". This is a very interesting text that contains some good ideas. However, it does not address the issue of the independence of European countries from foreign network and data providers and managers.  The strategic aspect of technological mastery of data management and storage, as well as its impact on the political and economic sovereignty of Member States and on the freedom of citizens, is completely evaded from the report, in favour of a liberal vision.  Finally, it is part of a Europeanist framework by calling for regulatory harmonisation and an end to barriers to data exchange, which translates into new Brussels legislation and a strengthening of the European Commission.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it is overtly ultra-liberal.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this proposal because I believe that technological development should be at the service of the European people, not the other way around. We are concerned that the text will support the Commission in its strategy of liberalisation and privatization of digital infrastructure and services, including public data banks. Mentions of security and privacy are vague, which will also negatively reverse the fundamental freedoms of Europeans.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The proposal is a pack of regulatory and subsidy ideas, such as encouraging Member States "to support broadband infrastructure through existing programmes such as the CONNECTING Europe Facility, the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and the Cohesion Fund." The infrastructure for fast internet has long been being developed by private companies, and eu and government intervention is out of place. Investment is best supported by a healthy competitive environment without regulation and subsidies.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the motion for a resolution on the transition to a prosperous data-based economy, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/3/2016 and because this motion for a resolution is not complete.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the resolution entitled 'Towards a successful data-driven economy' because it is necessary to create, as soon as possible, a legislative framework for the Digital Single Market, which will have a decisive impact on the future of SMEs. In the technology and innovation economy, SMEs will use large volumes of data to compete as global leaders in a data-driven economy. The EU urgently needs to prepare legislation on the value of data and how to use it to develop new investment models and encourage economic growth. The European Commission must speed up the process of stimulating the emergence of new business and service models that can create many jobs in the coming years. In order to achieve this, the Commission and the Member States must implement the necessary regulations to ensure increased investment in network infrastructure. Without a high-performance network infrastructure that guarantees adequate data capacity and speeds, the digital economy will not be able to get started.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution, which stresses that the processing of certain kinds of data, in particular personal data, falls under the scope of EU data protection law and urges, in this connection, the swift adoption of the Data Protection Package.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text. Big Data (or massive or megadata data) is a more or less structured set of data that becomes so large that it is difficult to work with traditional database management tools.  The issue of the collection, capture, storage, research, sharing, analysis, commercial and non-commercial use of this data will impact all areas of everyday life (health, trade, agriculture, public services, e-commerce, marketing, logistics, telecoms, connected objects, public security, transparency of public action and democracy, meteorology, automotive industry, social services, traffic management and transport , applications and services, cybersecurity, etc.). Despite some negative points, one element of the resolution nevertheless encourages the European public to become aware of the importance of massive data, particularly categories of people who do not have access to or are not familiar with technology, which is still an important element when we know the issues of digital divides that we see even in France.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the increase in investment in a data-driven economy, while ensuring that the benefits reach everyone, men and women. At the same time, we must take into account the safety of our citizens. I am convinced that Europe is ready to face these challenges, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. "U2012 My support for the motion for a Resolution on the "Towards a Prosperous Data Economy" initiative. The data economy plays a very important role in the Digital Union's strategy and we must work to take advantage of its advantages. We must therefore invest in infrastructure and R&D, as well as promote start-ups and SMEs in the data economy, while involving society.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's report on building a prosperous, data-driven economy. I agree with the report's stated that an e-data-driven economy can become an opportunity for growth and employment, and that new business models and services improve productivity. I therefore believe that due attention should be paid to investment in infrastructure, research, development and incentives for start-ups and SMEs.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which deals with big data and encourages new research and development, whilst also encouraging closing the skills gap.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite some good ideas, the project is being fished by ultraliberalism and a European desire to achieve an integrated market. The approach is mercantile and service-oriented rather than industry-oriented. This common data market is part of a Europeanised framework that is moving towards regulatory standardisation and the removal of barriers to data exchange. This is done at the expense of the States, and strengthens the Commission. As a result I voted against it.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, as it highlights the fact that the creation of a data-driven economy is essential for the success of the Digital Market Strategy. The resolution also demonstrates that the shift towards a data driven economy must happen at every level and is not something that should happen only in the industries commonly associated with the digital sphere, but is something that should occur across the board. It also stresses the importance of data protection and consumer privacy.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The digitization of society is becoming more widespread. It affects our entire society and today generates a fourth revolution. By launching the single digital market, the European Union aims to seize this opportunity for growth and jobs. It aims to return to competitiveness in order to revive its economy.  But, as the report points out, this revolution needs to be framed, especially on the importance of privacy. Data protection is a prerequisite for the sustainable development of our digital economy.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – A data-driven economy at national and European level has undeniable benefits for our society and economic development. It is a cornerstone for the creation of a functioning digital union and is of great importance for horizontal aspects of the economy such as research and development, the creation of a data market, the promotion of a knowledge society with relevant digital technology skills, the promotion of start-ups, investment, growth, employment, the development of small and medium-sized enterprises, increasing competitiveness, social cohesion, etc. In a data-driven society and virtual information exchange, it is essential to find a middle way between the 'big data' market and the protection of personal data. A sufficiently clear and strict definition of the authorities and persons authorised to access and dispose of personal data is a sensitive subject and forms the basis for transparent relations based on trust between citizens and consumers, on the one hand, and public authorities and firms, on the other. The digital economy undoubtedly has the potential to create a number of new jobs, as well as to facilitate the cross-border exchange of information, but another aspect that must be guaranteed in this regard is the protection of intellectual property rights and patent rights, which is a key precondition for a functioning system of governance and democracy based on information technology and data. This proposal takes account of the above, so I express my support for it.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the resolution ‘towards a thriving data-driven economy’ in order to define broadband infrastructure investment, consumer protection, SMEs’ opportunities, smooth and efficient innovation processes and data protection as priorities in this new data—driven economy.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. According to International Data Corporation's forecasts, by 2017 the growth rate of the large data market will be six times higher than that of the global ICT market and will reach an overall total of €50 billion, which could generate 3.75 million new jobs. The unprecedented exponential increase in data volume means that by 2020 there will be more than 16 billion gigabytes of data, equivalent to an annual growth rate of 236% in terms of data generation. I advocate the creation of a data economy on the basis of the Digital Single Market Strategy, enabling Europe to regain competitiveness in advanced sectors and accelerate its economic recovery, investment in growth and innovation in all sectors. To do this, we must have a favourable business environment, with a modern regulatory framework prepared for the future, stimulate and promote investment in network infrastructure necessary to the demands of the digital economy. I stress the importance of policy-making that removes the excess of obstacles in innovative sectors that encourage investment in research and development and European standardisation.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution is based on erroneous factual elements, which could skew the analysis. Moreover, it endorses an ultraliberal vision of the economy, subservient to free-trade dogmas.  That is why I voted against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which deals mainly with big data. The problem of collecting and processing the growing mass of digital data offers new economic, social and technological innovation perspectives that need to be exploited.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. The resolution "Towards a prosperous data economy" highlights the economic potential that the information and communication technology revolution can enser about society as a whole. Metadata, in particular, has great economic and social opportunities. Although I am not from the plenary session for medical reasons, I support the resolution presented.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution, which expects the benefits of a data-driven economy at national and European level to have an impact on society and on all types of enterprise in the value chain. At the core of the Digital Single Market strategy is the creation of a data-driven economy.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation of a data-driven economy is at the heart of the Digital Single Market strategy and has the potential to help Europe regain competitiveness in advanced sectors and accelerate Europe's economic recovery. The Commission and the European data industry have committed to invest EUR 2.5 billion in a PPP to strengthen the data sector and put Europe ahead of the global data race by maximising the potential of the digital economy. Access to open data portals and electronic research infrastructures is a possible way to reduce the disadvantages that researchers and SMEs in peripheral regions could face. We call on the Commission to adopt policies that remove excessive barriers in innovative sectors and stimulate investment in research and development activities and European standardisation. We also call for the creation of a viable regulatory environment in the future that reflects the changing nature of the market, is technology neutral, stimulates the creation of new businesses and the entry into the market of new operators, ensuring a level playing field and a level playing field, while avoiding the burden of excessive regulation and ensuring full compliance with data protection rules and privacy. We welcome the Commission's intention to review the Electronic Privacy Directive.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the context of this resolution, I find it alarming that only 1.7% of businesses make full use of advanced digital technologies, despite the benefits that digital tools can have in all economic sectors. It is therefore urgent that the Commission and the Member States put in place a digital technology strategy aimed at business entities. European digital economy centres should also be set up to address the use of big data and other data technologies by entrepreneurs, SMEs and innovative companies, as well as to include researchers and the wider economy. The establishment of innovation spaces and clusters should be promoted in order to help develop skills and create a competitive advantage in the field of intellectual capital and to better understand the perspectives and limitations of big data technology.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In order for the EU to remain competitive, it is necessary to further develop the digital sector, invest in a data-driven economy, encourage start-ups and SMEs and increase the involvement of society.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution.  The European Union needs to develop a data-driven economy. This is a source of economic productivity.  In order to ensure the unhindered development of a data-driven economy, an appropriate legal framework and strategies and measures for the protection of personal data and information security need to be ensured. Research and development in technical, social and economic sciences needs to be supported. Particular attention must be paid to promoting investment in a data-driven economy. It is necessary to facilitate SMEs and to promote greater public participation.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP oppose the EU Commission proposal ‘towards a thriving data-driven economy’. We oppose new EU prescriptive legislation. We believe that Europe can achieve competitiveness by creating incentives and removing obstacles. It can achieve it by setting free the entrepreneurial spirit of business and industry.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The data-driven economy requires advanced skills and is expected to create a significant number of jobs in Europe in the coming years. The growth rate of the big data market up to 2017 will be six times faster than in the global ICT market and will reach a total of €50 billion. The development of this market is therefore an integral part of a new digital market and should therefore ensure the development of innovative and competitive business models, while having to comply with the EU data protection framework. For these reasons, I would have voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The data-driven economy will stimulate research and innovation on data while leading to more business opportunities and an increased availability of knowledge and capital, in particular for SMEs, across Europe. Social and economic benefits associated with the integrated use of data in all sectors of the European economy and all fields of European research could be enormous. Big data is an integral part of the new digital market, which I have been continuously supporting with my work as MEP. That is why I am in favour of the resolution.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. The amendments adopted are a sign that the Commission has recognised the potential and significance of this report concerning a growing data-driven economy. With the development of supporting infrastructure such as broadband, highly efficient computing infrastructure, future internet development, IPv6 development and secure storage, we contribute to the growth of the economy and we need to go this way. We see market demands changing; focusing in particular on professionals with skills such as 'data management' and coding, and based on this, I consider this resolution to be aligned with the needs of consistency and objectives towards a growing economy.  Government databases are a tool that should serve everyone's benefit and I sincerely hope that this will be achieved thanks to this resolution. Data protection is a very important issue today for every citizen of the European Union, but also for the world. Europe must be a leader in the protection of personal data in order to create new standards globally for others to follow.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The development of big data systems is an integral part of the new digital market and should ensure the development of innovative and competitive business models. Data volumes are estimated to be growing at an unprecedented rate and by 2020 there will be 16 trillion gigabytes of data, an annual growth rate of 236% in data creation. Decisions taken thanks to knowledge derived from big data systems can result in a noticeable increase in productivity and competitiveness, and the benefits of these systems will contribute to additional annual GDP growth of 1.9% by 2020. According to IDC (International Data Corporation), the growth rate in the big data market could result in 3.75 million new jobs being created by 2017, which is extremely important given the economic climate that rules Europe.  For this reason, I support the Resolution towards a growing data-driven economy given its positive impact on society and all types of businesses at national and European level. A data-driven economy will boost research and innovation, leading to greater business opportunities and increased availability of knowledge and capital, especially for SMEs across the EU.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution is intrinsically associated with the Digital Single Market Strategy, which touts some of the verbiage that is flourishing with the dominant neoliberal strategy, such as the "development of market-oriented standards", the "public-private partnerships in the domain of big data" and the "new business models". "Job creation", "Growth of SMEs" and "data protection" are references that mask reality, in which thousands of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises emerge and disappear by bankruptcy always with the promise of a prosperous horizon, a mirage for the overwhelming majority. Unemployment remains at very high levels in the EU, particularly in Portugal. The resolution advances a number of proposals which we consider unacceptable. Examples are unacceptable concessions to multinationals in the field of data protection and limitations to state action. We voted against it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. – I support representative Buzek's motion for a resolution and fully support it. I believe that a data-driven economy is one of the key factors for the future economic development of the Union and can make a significant contribution to job creation, but it is previously necessary to create good legal frameworks. I consider commendable proposals concerning the free movement of data and legal initiatives aimed at removing barriers to achieving the Single Market.  I would like to recall that the development of a data-driven economy remains a number of obstacles both at European and Member State level. Existing legal frameworks do not favour the development of a data-driven economy, and the lack of interoperability and unnecessary administrative barriers, according to the report, have led to many good business opportunities either being lost or realised outside Europe.  I therefore hope that this resolution will also contribute to changing existing legal frameworks as fast as possible and creating a suitable climate for the development of a data-driven economy.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the data-driven economy, as data, which is an integral part of our lives, can bring new opportunities for growth and jobs. I also supported the report because of the benefits of data for consumers, government, medicine and the fight against crime. I am aware that the use of data entails considerable risks, so building a digital single market cannot do without adequate data protection. This should be ensured by a single legal framework. A data-driven economy can lead to greater prosperity, economic growth, research, and innovation. However, it is equally necessary for both the European Commission and the Member States to think that it is the promotion of research and innovation that is essential to build a data-based economy. I therefore voted in favour of using European and national funding to strengthen European research and innovation in this area.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Every minute the world generates data for 1.7 million bytes, or 360,000 DV, more than 6 megabytes per capita every day. As a result, the data sector grows by 40 % a year, seven times faster than the general information and communication market.  The creation of a data-driven economy should be at the heart of the digital single market strategy and could create a significant number of jobs in Europe in the coming years. I voted in favour of this proposal and I hope that the Commission and the Member States will be able to invest more in network infrastructure through an ad hoc regulatory framework and by continuing to support broadband infrastructure through existing programmes such as the Connecting Europe Mechanism, the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and the Cohesion Fund.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Committee on Regional Development, I am in favour of increasing employment with all possible instruments. In the context of the European Commission's current work programme, the Digital Single Market is a key objective for a future thriving data-driven economy that can present opportunities for jobs and growth, inter alia, by enabling the emergence of new business models and services. On our common path to a thriving economy, a data-driven economy represents a future that requires common standards, high-speed networks, as well as powerful computer infrastructure in addition to connectivity. I am in favour of the Member States of the European Union using more large-scale data and of being financially supported by the Union, as well as for the Council to support the creation of uniform electronic identification rules. I think that decisions based on big data can contribute to an increase in productivity and competitiveness, which will ultimately contribute to the increase in GDP in the Member States of the European Union.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the IMCO committee currently dealing with the broad issue of the digital market, I welcome the European Parliament's attention to the issue of the data-driven economy. The EU will best support this kind of economy if it sets the ground rules, but it does not seek to interfere with everything and regulate every detail. If we really want to help, let us add support for education, which will prepare citizens well to participate fully in the 'data' economy.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution because it is part of a process of adapting our economies to meet the challenges of the 21st century.  Indeed, the text stresses the importance of a data-based economy in the strategy for a digital union and the need to invest in infrastructure, research and development. Support for innovative start-ups must also be recalled, with particular attention to the involvement of citizens in the use of these new tools.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP oppose the EU Commission proposal ‘towards a thriving data-driven economy’. We oppose new EU prescriptive legislation. We believe that Europe can achieve competitiveness by creating incentives and removing obstacles. It can achieve it by setting free the entrepreneurial spirit of business and industry.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on 'Towards a thriving data economy' because I believe that creating a data economy based on the Digital Single Market Strategy will enable Europe to regain competitiveness in advanced sectors and accelerate its economic recovery, investment in growth and innovation. I agree that a data economy requires advanced skills and will therefore contribute to the creation of a significant number of jobs in Europe in the coming years. I therefore welcome this report for recognising the social and economic benefits associated with the integrated use of data in all sectors and fields of the European economy and research. However, I stress the importance of adopting a data protection package, which falls within the scope of EU data protection legislation.  I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, also because I consider investment by the private sector to be important, as well as the promotion of start-ups and SMEs in the data economy.  I therefore recognise the importance of promoting public initiatives and debates in the Member States on the benefits and value of digital technologies in order to involve society.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. Due to the exponential growth of the big data market (an estimated 236% annual growth rate for data production by 2020) and its growing place in the daily lives of citizens and consumers, this motion for a resolution aims to set the European framework for thinking about the challenges and challenges of a data-based economy.  The latter represents a major gain in productivity and competitiveness, with positive impacts on growth (estimated at 1.9% additional GDP growth by 2020) and employment (creation of 3.75 million new jobs by 2017).  In the face of these promising prospects, Parliament's strategy to develop the data-based economy in the best possible way focuses on continuing efforts to establish a digital single market in Europe, encouraging investment in infrastructure and research and development, and supporting SMEs and innovative start-ups.  The role of the Union is also being recalled: promoting innovative and competitive business models, ensuring healthy competition, and protecting the fundamental rights of citizens and consumers (protection of privacy and data). For these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. A new revolution is underway, crossing our European societies and marking them with its imprint: that of digital, opening up new opportunities especially on the economic front. We must take this to ensure that the European Union is at the forefront of this issue in the world.  But this revolution also raises new questions, particularly in terms of security and trust of citizens and consumers, data and big data. Founding a "prosperous data economy" requires finding this balance between the need to create a framework that allows innovative business and industrial ideas and models to express themselves in their full potential and thus develop new avenues of growth and employment in Europe on the one hand, and the need to establish an adequate framework for protecting the data of citizens and consumers on the other.  This text provides some interesting answers in this regard, and that is why I have supported it.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The growth rate of the large data market by 2017 will be six times higher than that of the global ICT market and will reach an overall total of €50 billion, which could generate 3.75 million new jobs by 2017. The benefits of a data economy at national and European level are expected to have an impact on society and all types of companies in the value chain, recognising its potential to enable Europe to regain competitiveness in advanced sectors and accelerate its economic recovery, investment in growth and innovation in all sectors. However, this will only be possible in the presence of a business environment conducive and if there are ways to trigger digital transformation, and only if these technologies comply with the European Union's legal framework on data protection in order to overcome the risks and associated challenges, in particular with regard to fundamental rights.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Data production is growing at an exorbitant rate. Studies indicate that the volume of data increases at an annual rate of 236% and this trend will increase with millions of devices exchanging information with each other. Europe cannot be left out of the big data revolution, a revolution that is already affecting every economic sector and every area of our lives.  It is therefore urgent that the European Union take a step forward by creating a framework conducive to the exploitation of the opportunities that this new reality brings to economic development and job creation.  As this Resolution points out, which I have supported, it is necessary to promote and support investment in R&D, enable public and private financing avenues, invest in broadband networks, promote digital adaptation of SMEs and train and train workers in this area, but it is certainly crucial to ensure data protection and network security , as well as shielding respect for intellectual property rights.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which deals with the economic potential of the current phase of the new technology revolution in Europe and whose major points are: the need, for a new digital recovery in Europe, to achieve synergies between big data, data protection, data security and open data; the establishment of appropriate infrastructure, such as fibre-optic broadband networks, high-performance IT infrastructure, the future development of the Internet of Things, the deployment of the IPv6 protocol and secure storage, linked to the development of cloud computing in Europe; Recognition of SME initiatives that promote growth and make it the leading player in big data; recognition of patents as key instruments to encourage investment in research and development.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully supported this resolution on a data-driven economy. The future belongs to a data-driven economy, and it is in which we need to develop new business models and services, thereby improving productivity.  At the same time, appropriate consumer protection measures need to be developed. I hope that a data-driven economy at national and European level will have an impact on society and all types of value chain companies. Building a data-driven economy is at the heart of the new Digital Single Market strategy. I therefore welcome its potential to help restore the competitiveness of advanced sectors in Europe and accelerate the recovery of the European economy, investment in growth and innovation in all sectors.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The oral question followed by the resolution voted on today is an integral part of the completion of the digital single market, one of the priorities of the Commission's current work programme.  In particular, the text adopted emphasises the need to develop broadband infrastructure, cloud computing, better adapted legislation for new technologies and at the same time more stable in order to promote investment. The digital economy offers many opportunities for growth, especially for SMEs, and job creation, but these require new 'data and digital skills'. At the same time, we must not forget data protection, network security and privacy legislation.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We share the resolution's view that the digital economy can serve as a lever for economic growth. We also share some recommendations on privacy and data protection. Therefore, these guarantees must go further and ensure that the flow of data cannot serve as a tool for the control of the population by governments or companies. The Resolution also seems to us to be too optimistic about the growth possibilities offered by the digital economy. That's why we abstain.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution on the road to a thriving data economy is, from my point of view, a balanced contribution to big data issues that have the potential to increase economic productivity and improve consumer and public administration services. Already, with big data, consumers can use some services that increase convenience, efficiency, and savings, such as transportation. I consider it important that the resolution recognises the potential opportunities for the development of a data-driven economy, but at the same time points out that the development of these opportunities must be conditional on maintaining trust and setting up and effectively promoting consumer rights. I therefore supported the resolution.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The world market for big data technology, i.e. large amounts of data of different types produced at high speed from many types of sources, represents the future of our economy.  Nowadays, human activities, industrial processes and research generate an unprecedented level of data collection and processing, which favor the appearance of new products, services and business processes. The analysis of digital data, in fact, contributes substantially to the improvement of economic results, the birth of new ideas and the prediction of future events. This trend represents enormous potential for the European Union in terms of growth and employment; I therefore hope that the Member States and the EU will be dedicated to developing appropriate infrastructure and technologies, such as broadband and cloud computing, in the context of a stable legal framework that meets data protection and security standards and privacy rules.  I believe that a thriving data-driven economy will contribute to the well-being of citizens and socio-economic progress by creating new business opportunities and making public services more innovative. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP oppose the EU Commission proposal ‘towards a thriving data-driven economy’. We oppose new EU prescriptive legislation. We believe that Europe can achieve competitiveness by creating incentives and removing obstacles. It can achieve it by setting free the entrepreneurial spirit of business and industry.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Back in 2014, the Commission drew up a new strategy on ‘big data’ which sought to support and accelerate the transition towards a data-driven economy. I will support initiatives which seek to positively assist in the development of the digital revolution.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing \ u2012 Only 1.7% of companies make full use of modern digital technologies, despite the benefits that digital tools can bring. That is why, with this resolution, I also voted in favour of the Commission and the Member States in adopting a digital entrepreneurship strategy and supporting start-ups and SMEs in a data-driven economy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: writing \ u2012 According to the forecasts of big data and services companies, the growth rate of the big data market will be six times faster by 2017 than for the IT market and should reach a total of up to EUR 50 billion. At present, data volumes are growing at an unprecedented rate, with big data-based decisions also having a significant impact on productivity and competitiveness. It is therefore understandable that the development of big data forms an integral part of the new digital market. On the other hand, it is unmistakable that big data can bring with it certain problems with regard to fundamental rights such as privacy. In view of both the risks and the benefits, I supported the European Parliament resolution calling for the data-driven economy to be incorporated into the basis of the Digital Single Market Strategy. In the future, we can expect that data will be a valuable resource for the company and the ability to process it effectively will benefit not only the business environment, but also the functioning of the public administration. A data-driven economy will also require specific skills, which should lead to the creation of a large number of jobs. It is therefore still necessary to increase confidence in these technologies, to encourage investment in network infrastructure, as well as to facilitate access to research and innovation grants.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution on the development of a European data-driven economy, for which I was shadow rapporteur on behalf of the Social Democratic Group. Data-driven economics means the collection, analysis and subsequent interpretation of huge information databases. This is an advanced and rapidly developing sector, in which the EU still plays a limited role, while representing an opportunity for strategic growth for our continent.  Europe, with its 500 million citizens, internet penetration of more than 80 % and world-class universities, could be one of the largest digital markets in the world. To step out of the role of viewers/users of services and become protagonists in the development of the data-driven economy, it is necessary to create a competitive environment, supporting the creation and standardization of open data, especially with regard to data developed by the public sector, and also encouraging private companies to open their databases whenever possible in compliance with privacy. By investing in infrastructure capacity, the creation of specialised skills, the promotion of entrepreneurship, in a certain but flexible regulatory environment, the conditions can be created for the common and coordinated European development of the data economy, so that the EU can compete globally.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: writing \u2012 The data-based economy represents an opportunity for economic growth and employment. At the same time, big data also presents a wide range of opportunities for consumers, businesses and public administration. However, in addition to the benefits offered by such a market, it is necessary to think about the protection of personal data, because big data can also entail certain risks.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ International Data Corporation (IDC) predicted in its forecast for big data technologies and services that from 2013 to 2017 the growth rate in the big data market will be six times higher than in the entire ICT market and will total €50 billion, which, according to the Big Data Value public-private partnership, could result in the creation of 3.75 million new jobs by 2017.  The development of big data systems is an integral part of the new digital market and should ensure the development of innovative and competitive business models in line with the EU data protection framework, as big data can carry big risks and challenges, especially when it comes to fundamental rights (including privacy and data protection), and can also cause unfair discrimination due to distorted conclusions drawn on the basis of correlation , not causation.  As big data systems open up new opportunities for consumers (in terms of benefits, efficiency and savings), businesses (industry 4.0) and administration (e-administration), including when it comes to housing (smart cities), science, medicine (mHealth), disaster response and crime suppression, I supported the report.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The main element of the Digital Single Market strategy is the creation of a data-driven economy that has great potential and contribute to the development of Europe's competitiveness in technologically advanced sectors as well as rapid economic recovery. Likewise, a data-driven economy will have a positive impact on growth and innovation in all sectors that are possible only if there are adequate resources to initiate the digital transformation. Furthermore, we must not allow underinvestment and technical standardisation and data protection legislation to adversely affect Europe's technological and economic progress when it comes to the development of a data-driven economy. I support the proposals for communication resolutions "Towards a growing data-driven economy" because I think that a data-driven economy is of great importance and will create many jobs in the future that will requires advanced skills. Likewise, such a form of economy can have a positive impact on society and all types of companies in the value chain at state and European level.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Commission communication 'Towards a successful data-led economy'. I support ensuring that information and communication technologies are closer to pupils and students, especially women and girls, in schools and educational institutions. I also support these efforts to include measures to promote a more entrepreneurial spirit and to facilitate entry into big data entrepreneurship through the financing of new start-ups in this area and the consequent creation of employment opportunities.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The exploitation of new digital data must have the primary objective of prosperity and enhancing people's quality of life. Unfortunately, with the objectives set out in the report, there is a risk that the potential of technology will only serve the interests of multinationals and large capital to increase competitiveness and business profits. We are certainly not against technological development, but we need to redefine the objectives and focus on putting the needs and interests of society at the heart.   The aim should be to promote research, innovation and development, create new quality jobs, ensure free and free access to the internet, protect personal data and strengthen consumer rights. It is equally important to support SMEs so that they can use technology to strengthen their market position and facilitate their access to finance.  Only if these objectives are achieved will we be able to talk about a thriving economy. That is why we abstained on the report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Commission communication on the road to a prosperous, data-driven economy, which raises a number of well-founded questions about the 'Big Data' strategy drawn up by the Commission, such as common standards, interoperability, high-speed networks, high-performance computing infrastructure, consumer protection and data protection.  I agree with the view that the data-driven economy requires advanced skills and could create a significant number of jobs in Europe in the coming years. For this to happen, it is essential to strengthen partnerships between businesses and higher education institutions and research centres, as the report rightly pointed out. This will in any way encourage innovation in big data technology. Furthermore, I welcome the fact that the issue of data protection has also been given priority. A number of amendments have made clear the expectation that innovative and competitive business models should be developed in accordance with the EU legal framework on data protection. Respect for fundamental rights, in particular privacy, must not be jeopardised.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The emergence of a data economy is one of the main elements of the Digital Single Market Strategy, which will give Europe the opportunity to regain competitiveness in high-tech sectors, which will also accelerate economic recovery, investment for growth and innovation in all sectors. The benefits of a data economy at national and European level will have a huge impact on citizens and businesses. They are estimated to generate additional GDP growth of 1.9% by 2020. Moreover, building an ecosystem conducive to the development of ICT, through investments in broadband, cloud computing and the Internet of Things, will also make it necessary to educate skilled workers with advanced skills, which will lead to the creation of a significant number of jobs in Europe in the coming years. In addition, big data technology itself creates new opportunities for consumers (e.g. in terms of convenience, efficiency and savings), businesses (industry 4.0) and administration (e-government), as well as housing (smart cities), science, medicine (mHealth), disaster response and the fight against crime. Given the crucial importance of developing a data economy for the creation of the Digital Single Market, I have decided to support the proposed resolution.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The unprecedented development of new information technologies has led to a real revolution in the way we are designing human society today. New devices have become part of our lives as indispensable tools through which we communicate, work and spend our free time. At the same time, however, these technologies can also contribute substantially to the development of the economies of our countries and the European Union as a whole. They can stimulate research and innovation, create new business opportunities, increase the availability of knowledge and capital, especially help the development of SMEs and give concrete expression to the so-called 'data-driven successful economy'. In July 2014, the European Commission outlined a new it database strategy to accelerate the transition to the computerised economy on the European continent. The resolution proposed by the European Parliament on this subject highlights the lingering gaps in common standards, interoperability, high-speed networks, IT infrastructure and consumer and data protection. This is why investments in broadband infrastructure, consumer protection, sME opportunity development, efficient innovation are needed. The current resolution is a commendable initiative and deserves to be supported.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. I believe it is essential to develop a regulatory framework to address the economic, technological, social and cultural challenges of a data-based economy, such as access to data or control and ownership of data, including public data.  Data security and protection are essential conditions for the growth of the data sector.
