It is fundamental for a new digital start in Europe to find synergies between big data, data protection, data security and open data. We also call for the following challenges: ownership, possession, management, security, interoperability, limitation and storage of data, and access to data, restrictions on data use and reuse in Europe, barriers to innovation in the field of human capital, accessibility and infrastructure, transparency of data transfer rules, cross-border mechanisms and, where appropriate, creation of data , dissemination, availability of open data and access to it for governments and service providers.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Big data represents an immense opportunity to both our businesses and our societies, which is why I voted in favour of this resolution. By making use of the economy of scale, big data will be able to significantly improve productivity and encourage new and innovative business models and services. Big data and the economy of scale will be particularly beneficial for SMEs, who will be more apt to compete with big businesses. I am also hopeful that this will create a significant number of new jobs in Europe in the coming years, as the use of big data requires many new advanced skills. In that sense, raising awareness and providing widespread training to deal with big data and new technologies is crucial. Moreover, big data can also be a big step for improving the way we live (smart cities), the quality of our science and medicine (Mhealth), and for preventing disasters and fighting crime more effectively. Moreover, it will bring new opportunities for consumers in terms of convenience, efficiency and savings, and can allow government administrations to work more efficiently and closer to citizens through e-government.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We share the resolution's view that the digital economy can serve as a lever for economic growth. We also share some recommendations on privacy and data protection. Therefore, these guarantees must go further and ensure that the flow of data cannot serve as a tool for the control of the population by governments or companies. The Resolution also seems to us to be too optimistic about the growth possibilities offered by the digital economy. That's why we abstain.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the successful data-led economy, as I believe that we need to adapt this area to a modern information society, where the growth in data volumes is unprecedented. The development of big data is an integral part of the modern digital market, and the data-led economy represents a fundamental step for growth and employment, based on new business models and services.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The digital world has a huge volume of data and this is expected to increase significantly in the coming years. I support this proposal to have a safe and orderly management of all these documents on the network, but this does not have to put a brake on productivity and competitiveness in the European digital market.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The benefits of a data-driven economy at national and European level will have an impact on society and on all types of businesses in the value chain. The creation of a data-driven economy is at the heart of the Digital Single Market Strategy, which will help Europe regain its competitiveness in advanced sectors and accelerate Europe's economic recovery, investment in growth and innovation across all sectors.  These can only be achieved if there is an appropriate business environment and the tools needed to activate the digital transformation exist and if these technologies comply with the EU legal framework on data protection in order to address the risks and challenges they face, in particular fundamental rights, privacy and data protection. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We share the resolution's view that the digital economy can serve as a lever for economic growth. We also share some recommendations on privacy and data protection. Therefore, these guarantees must go further and ensure that the flow of data cannot serve as a tool for the control of the population by governments or companies. The Resolution also seems to us to be too optimistic about the growth possibilities offered by the digital economy. That's why we abstain.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which tackles the data-driven economy. The report stresses the importance of the outstanding growth of data volume, which leads towards a data-driven economy embodying an opportunity for growth and employment. Such an economy would have an impact on the whole of society and all enterprises and represents the core of the Digital Single Market strategy. While there are significant social and economic benefits associated with the integrated use of data in all sectors of the European economy, the report expresses concern regarding the digital divide, insufficient investments and a lack of technical standardisation and data protection legislation, which could leave Europe lagging behind in future technological and economic developments. The report also calls for more investments in data infrastructure in order to be able to benefit fully from a data-driven economy.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This Resolution deals with big data along with innovation and research; all this related to the Digital Union, which currently has great economic and social potential for the EU. The proposal focuses on the economic potential of the current phase of ICT development, establishing the need to seek synergies between big data, data protection and security, the development of appropriate band infrastructures for the development of everything related to the cloud in Europe, as well as the importance of patents or governments in regulating and developing eGovernment. In short, we are talking about a resolution that seeks to boost a sector that can help create jobs and economic growth in Europe. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this resolution calling for an acceleration of the transition to a data economy in Europe. This resolution stimulates research and innovation in this area, but at the same time creates more opportunities for SMEs in Europe because of the better availability of capital and knowledge.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The growth rate of the large data market by 2017 will be six times higher than that of the global ICT market and will reach an overall total of EUR 50 billion according to International Data Corporation's forecasts on global big data technologies and services for 2013-2017, which could generate , according to the report, 3.75 million new jobs by 2017, according to the public-private partnership in the field of big data. The benefits of a data economy at national and European level should have an impact on society and all types of value chain companies in the context of creating a data economy under the Digital Single Market Strategy. It follows that the report does not say a word about the need for public control over this market, and continues to believe that the market will be in charge of solving all problems. It thus demonstrates that nothing has been learned from the past.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The issues raised concern: access, control, ownership, portability, cross-purpose utilisation, spectrum, and availability of technologies. The resolution clearly points out that the data-driven economy and the digitisation of industry are one of the few digital business areas in which Europe still has a global market and innovation advantage over the US, which should be promoted in terms of economic importance. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution on 'Towards a thriving data-driven economy'.  The report contains a number of dubious claims. The call for 'the EU and the Member States to coordinate their efforts in schools and educational institutions even better', 'so that ICT can become an attractive profession, especially for women and girls', is enough to do so. It is not a matter for the EU to coordinate schools and educational institutions in the Member States. It is certainly not the EU's job to demand the privilege of women and girls instead of equality. And it is not the EU's job to make certain sectors attractive.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ ICT technologies are indeed central to our future, and big data holds an enormous potential. I would like to give special emphasis to some elements included in this report: big data technologies must not breach or limit the fundamental rights to privacy or freedom of expression. Initiatives must be taken to ensure that the big data economy is inclusive of marginalised groups and advances gender equality.  Investing in education for ICT literacy starting from an early age all the way up to higher education, and including life-long learning, is among the most important steps towards an ICT—driven economy. This must specifically target vulnerable and marginalised or disadvantaged groups, and particularly women and girls. Entrepreneurship education should include ICT subjects and big data technologies in order to promote the growth of the sectors, including SMEs, start-ups and alternative business models such as cooperatives. Greater public debate of the potential impact of emerging technologies should be promoted in order for citizens to be able to make democratic decisions on what an ICT— and big-data—driven future might look like.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the resolution on the data economy. We need to look very carefully at the economic potential of this sector: it will move around EUR 50 billion, according to forecasts by the International Data Corporation (IDC) for the period 2013-2017, which could lead to the creation of 3.75 million new jobs by 2017.  In particular, I welcome the fact that the employment and educational implications of the data economy have been taken into account. Firstly, there is an incentive to raise awareness among SMEs on this issue, for example by creating a one-stop shop to help them make more effective use of both their data and public data, while strictly complying with EU data protection rules; secondly, support will be given to initiatives which include programming and data processing related subjects in national educational programmes.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this resolution because it is the future thriving data-driven economy that can be an opportunity for economic growth and higher employment in the Union, as well as increasing its competitiveness externally. At the same time, I agree that all the principles set out in European Union data protection legislation, such as honesty and legality, limitation of purpose, legal basis of processing, must be respected in this area when processing personal data. I also support the initiative mentioned in the resolution on the call for the Commission and the Member States to set up European digital economy centres to deal with the use of big data by entrepreneurs, SMEs. The development of a data-driven economy must also necessarily be accompanied by a better way of ICT education, not only in schools, but also in lifelong learning.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the resolution on the road to a thriving data-driven economy. I believe that different aspects of the data-driven economy need to be addressed, especially as the volume of data is growing at an immense rate and the development of these so-called big data forms an integral part of the digital market. Among other things, the development of this type of economy can lead to growth and the creation of new jobs. On the other hand, however, we must take particular care that the protection of fundamental rights in the European Union, particularly as regards the protection of personal data and privacy, does not suffer with the development and support of the data-driven economy. The resolution touches on all these problems, as well as on investment and the removal of barriers to innovation. That is why I supported it in the final vote.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The digital revolution and universal access to the internet are changing the shape of the global economy, where data plays an important role today. Europe is not a leader today in new technologies or innovation in the digital economy, but we have many advantages that make us a serious player. In order to fully develop the potential at our disposal, we need to close the development gaps that still exist between the different regions in the EU more effectively and quickly. Investment in the construction of broadband internet should be one of the priorities in all spending strategies for European funds. We need to give young people from all Member States the opportunity to acquire qualifications and develop their talents, which will pay off in the future in the form of patents and new business models. The data economy is also a huge opportunity for SMEs, which can use digital technology to reach new customers, raise funds for investments or exchange experiences with partners from all over the world. Of course, by taking all necessary measures, we cannot abandon the highest standards in the field of data protection, especially personal and financial data. Managing huge collections of information is a task that requires expertise and a lot of responsibility; we should work together to achieve high standards in both areas. I believe that this report and the solutions it offers will help.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the initiative on creating effective conditions for the development of a thriving data economy, which confirms the strategic role of the European Parliament in the development of the Digital Agenda. I highlight the need to ensure transparency and fairness in access to data, promote open access to relevant data with respect for legal protection, foster the development of new business areas that generate wealth and employment, opening opportunities not only for large companies but also for small and medium-sized enterprises, new entrepreneurs and start-ups. I also point out that it is essential to ensure the stability of the legal framework, to support the development of infrastructure and to focus on research and training in a context of promoting digital inclusion.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this resolution, which speaks to the situation in Eritrea. The situation is truly extremely tragic. One of the poorest countries in the world with a totalitarian regime that considers its citizens more or less prisoners. He abuses them, sends them on military service that is time-bound.  It is worth remembering that this is one of the basic countries from which a large number of refugees come to Europe, mostly after Syria, without there being a civil war in the country itself. This is a consequence of the totalitarian regime of the president there, and it is good that we have adopted a resolution condemning this regime and calling on the president and the government there to make amends. The question is how much this will affect the behavior of the country's totalitarian chunts, but I think it is a good idea to point it out at least in this way, although I am afraid that this will probably do nothing about the behavior of the President and his government.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Eritrea today is an extremely bad situation with respect for human rights, with freedom of expression and the press, access to basic resources. In fact, there is no independent judicial system, it simply does not function, not to mention the compulsory military service for all Erythroses aged between eighteen and fifty years old. The conditions in the service are the most difficult and there is a huge annual number of refugees, including to the European Union. Those who call Eritrea An African North Korea are certainly somewhat right for these people, because that says a lot in itself. But it is a pity that there is still no real lever to influence the situation in Eritrea, there are no instruments of influence on Asmara's actions, and it is also regrettable that the current Eritrean regime has absolutely no matter what we say here, and at the same time it has a bad relationship with its closest and future neighbours. But there is hope that the resolution will help improve the situation.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, once again I was fully supportive of this motion of resolution submitted by my own Group, the European People’s Party, in relation to the current situation in Eritrea, the calls on the Eritrean authorities to release all political prisoners, reform and shorten national service obligations, stop all forced evictions and demolitions, and expand the provision of social housing. I would like to stress the need for Eritrea to respect and implement the right to education without question, the inobservance of which is causing so many young Eritreans to flee. Sustainable peace, development and prosperity cannot exist without respect for human rights. In conjunction with my Party, I would like to emphasise a deep concern at the lack of freedom of expression and the continued existence of political prisoners held in violation of the principles of the rule of law. I fully support the demand stipulating the immediate release of Swedish/Eritrean journalist, Dawit Isaak, as a matter of urgency, who has been imprisoned under harsh conditions and without trial since September 2001.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The humanitarian crisis in Eritrea has reached enormous proportions. Drought, lack of freedom of the press, low human development index are just a few factors indicating a serious situation in the Eritrean State. The European Parliament resolution aims to commit the Commission to verifying that the funds used contribute directly to the well-being of Eritrean citizens by minimising unnecessary intermediates. However, the main concern is the continuing violation of human rights in the country, and the Government of Eritrea is therefore urged to end the system of permanent national service by demobilisation of conscripts who have completed the 18 months of compulsory service; In addition, the Eritree authorities are once again being asked to proceed with the immediate and unconditional release of parliamentarians, journalists of political prisoners and prisoners of conscience. In order to protect human rights and citizens, I voted positively

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report. We do not recognise the authority of the European Union or the European Parliament to take decisions or positions on foreign policy issues. In particular, the humanitarian crisis has led to Eritrea becoming one of the biggest source countries for migrants in the ongoing crisis. On balance, we abstained.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report. We do not recognise the authority of the European Union or the European Parliament to take decisions or positions on foreign policy issues. In particular, the humanitarian crisis has led to Eritrea becoming one of the biggest source countries for migrants in the ongoing crisis. On balance, we abstained.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. "U2012 While I share concern about the human rights situation in Eritrea, a country over which the United Nations Commission of Inquiry has concluded that violations in the areas of extrajudicial executions, torture, forced labour and the policy of shooting to kill at the border can constitute crimes against humanity and from which , according to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, more than 400 000 Eritreans have fled, I have not been able to vote in favour of the European Parliament's resolution since the position of this Eurochamber is that the European Union does not grant funding from the European Development Fund. Eritrea is going through a food crisis that has reduced crops in the region by between 50 and 90 per cent; Parliament's position to cancel development aid to the country has to do with its willingness to promote regime change in the country, at the cost of sanctioning the Eritrean population by denating this development aid to a country with one of the lowest human development index indicators in the world.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union, as usual, would like to impose its interference in the affairs of Eritrea. But "right-of-hommist" compassion does not give legitimacy to interfere in cases that do not concern it. The latest Western interventions in Africa and the Middle East have been catastrophic enough not to repeat these ideological recklessness. I obviously voted against this text.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. The motion in question describes the situation in Eritrea with the realism and rawness due to a country which, as stated in the recent report by the UN Special Envoy, displays one of the worst human rights records in the world. The motion is all the more relevant as European citizens are very little aware of the situation of Eritreans, although 7% of refugees arriving at the EU's external borders come from that country. I consider it particularly important to call on the Eritrean government to put an end to the system of unterm-defined military service which is one of the main reasons behind the exodus of 9% of the population since the 1990s. I also welcome the call for the EC to ensure that funds allocated in 2016 to Eritrea under the National Indicative Programme are effectively used for the benefit of Eritrea, as well as criticism of the fact that the EC and the Council ignored the EP's recommendation for this programme to be better considered, given the regime's notorious lack of credibility as a partner for cooperation and development.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the situation in Eritrea. Eritrean civilians are arbitrarily detained or arrested for various unjustified reasons, including government criticism or opposition, journalistic activities, the practice of informal religion, the avoidance or desertion of compulsory military service, cooperation with foreign entities or attempts to flee the country. Fear and oppression make up a large number of Eritreans (5 000 people flee every month) and make up the third largest group of refugees entering Europe. I support the calls for the Eritrean Government to end the detention of opposition representatives and innocent civilians and to ensure a fair trial of the defendants. The Eritrean Government must start implementing urgent reforms, such as abolishing the one-party system and renewing the national assembly and elections. The Eritrean Government must take into account the calls of the international community and release unjustly imprisoned persons.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. "Interference, still interference, always interference" Well no, especially in view of the calamitous results of a so-called "European diplomacy" subservient to interests that are not those of the peoples of the Old Continent.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have obviously supported this joint resolution which underlines the appalling human rights situation in Eritrea, which is leading to a mass exodus of Eritreans in search of a better life and international protection.  The European Union and the international community must do all they can to ensure that the Eritrean people can enjoy fundamental rights and thus get out of the terror regime they have been under for far too long.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. I proposed to make a Resolution on the situation in Eritrea within the ALDE Group. I am particularly pleased with the work carried out in this resolution by the clear and forceful message that MEPs from all European political groups send to the Commission. Eritrea is in a desperate situation; thousands of young people leave the country every month fleeing one of the worst dictatorships on the planet. Clearly we have to help the people of the country, but we cannot finance through development aid to their government. MEPs need to have assurances that this money is really going to help the Eritrean people.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Eritrea proclaimed its independence from Ethiopia in 1993. Twenty-three years since that historic event have seen the country's government fail to deliver on its democratic promises, with strict control over society as a whole. The country has not been able to attend free elections and has been negatively distinguished by the very strong repression of the opposition, which has manifested itself in constant violations of human rights.  The 2015 UN report confirmed the tragic situation, placing the African country in 186th place, out of the 188 countries considered, with regard to the human development index. The serious situation in Eritrea requires a commitment on the part of the entire international community, which is why I supported the joint motion for a resolution on this subject today. The country's main problems linked to violations of economic, social and cultural rights are accompanied by the persistence of a genuine trafficking in human beings. This is an intolerable situation. The Eritrean Government must take a serious path towards democracy, restoring the rule of law and the protection of human rights. Europe now has the task of exerting all possible pressure to fulfil the dream of peace and stability of the Eritrean citizens.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution because we consider it essential to condemn the Eritrean regime and call on the EU to end its growing complicity with this regime for geostrategic and migration flow control reasons.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the negotiators of this Resolution on the situation in Eritrea for their work so that today we could vote on this resolution, which I supported. It notes with concern that the deplorable human rights situation persists and the total absence of the rule of law and freedom of the media in Eritrea, beyond the humanitarian situation and unaccompanied minors.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union, which rolls out the red carpet and gives in to Erdogan's blackmail, wants to once again, through this resolution, dress the school teacher's clothes giving moral and human rights lessons to the rest of the world.  It is rather funny, if not sad, that the European Union allows itself in this text to make a big eye to Eritrea on respect for human rights: should we remember that Brussels is ready to integrate into the Union countries like Turkey or Kosovo, little known for their ethics in this area?  In terms of diplomacy, for European parliamentarians, it is therefore 'do what I say, not what I do', especially since this text once again seeks to grant itself the regal prerogatives of the Member States in matters of foreign policy, and this, in order to practice an indecent interference in Eritrean affairs. So I voted against this resolution.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution regularly analyses the dramatic situation that this country is experiencing. Given that Eritrea is one of the states from which the greatest number of migrants to the EU start, I believe that EU intervention would be necessary especially given the repercussions that the current situation has on Europe itself. That is why I voted in favour of the text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Eritrea is a country that, after thirty years of war, gained its independence in 1993. Its further development continues to be linked to border conflicts with its neighbours, especially Ethiopia. The EU-Eritrea cooperation framework is contained in the Cotonou Agreement, which includes cooperation in areas ranging from trade to the fight against poverty, to the protection of human rights and good governance. Despite all the efforts, the human rights situation has been progressively deteriorating, according to the United Nations. Free elections have never taken place in Eritrea, and the separation of powers from the state is unclear. Citizens do not enjoy freedom of expression and arbitrary detentions for undetermined periods, ill-treatment and torture are frequent practices.  This report demands immediate improvements in these areas from the Eritrean authorities to promote peace, development and sustainable prosperity through unwavering respect for human rights, which is why I cast my vote in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which deals with the situation in Eritrea. Eritrean civilians are arbitrarily detained or arrested for an indefinite period for various unjustifiable reasons, including government criticism or opposition, journalistic activities, the practice of informal religion, the avoidance or desertion of compulsory military service, cooperation with foreign entities, attempts to flee or have a relative fleeing the country, or without providing a clear justification. Detainees are denied medical care because children are detained and detained under the same inhumane conditions as adults. In addition, women detained are often supervised by male security guards, increasing the risk of sexual violence and gender-based violence. The European Parliament calls on the Eritrean Government to honour its obligations under the United Nations and other international agreements to which Eritrea is a party, including obligations under the Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment. Calls, in this regard, for greater transparency and cooperation with United Nations inspectors and international observers so that they can carry out detention facilities in a targeted and uninterfering way in accordance with the requirements of the Convention.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the situation in Eritrea is extremely serious and that it is the EU's task to urge the Eritrean Government to put an end to the continuing and repeated violations of human rights and to hold democratic and pluralist elections and to begin a real transition to democracy.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The seriousness of the situation in Eritrea, where the regime systematically violates the most basic human rights, where torture and rape for the purposes of political intimidation are practices commonly adopted by regime apparatuses, where the totalitarian grip of the regime is such that it extends its totalitarian grip to the Eritrean diaspora, extorting funds from its expatriates by means of a 2 % tax on their income , spying on them and targeting members of their families who have remained in Eritrea in the event of behaviour perceived as improper.  That is why, since 2 000 years, more than 300 000 Eritreans have fled, out of an estimated population of 6.3 million, and more than 30 000 have been killed in an attempt to prevent them from fleeing or in suppressing demonstrations of dissent. That is why the European Union cannot continue to cooperate with the Eritrean regime and must take action in all international for a to restore freedom and democracy in that region.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation in Eritrea is characterised by serious violations of human rights and freedoms, amplified by an authoritarian regime based on fear of indefinite military mobilization, arbitrary detention, torture and other human rights violations. According to a UN report on the human rights situation in Eritrea, there are three issues that need to be remedied in order to ensure compliance with the main rights and freedoms, namely: smuggling and trafficking, the increasing number of unaccompanied minors who are among the 5,000 people who abandon this country each month, and the exercise of economic, social and cultural rights , including the right to adequate housing. Threats to the right to adequate housing have resulted in forced evacuations, which have been intensifying since the beginning of 2015. I was in favour of this report because I believe that the principles and values of the European Union must be reflected in joint actions and efforts on respect for human rights in the context of development cooperation. Restoring the rule of law and promoting democratic governance in Eritrea must be on the European agenda, as the EU is founded on a strong commitment to the defence of human rights and democracy.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Shareable resolution. The situation in the country is dramatic and is one of the countries with the highest number of refugees to the EU. There are child soldiers, women and girls subjected to genital mutilation, famine, corruption. The resolution is based on real and acceptable problems and calls for a remedy to be made to a situation whose negative profiles spill over directly into Europe.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Eritrea because many of the refugees arriving in Europe come from Eritrea. According to the UN and Human Right Watch, the current exodus is fuelled by the violation of human rights in the country, there is talk of summary executions without trial, disappearances, torture and mandatory conscription.  The country is in a very difficult situation, according to a UN report, the government would also use tensions with neighbouring countries as a pretext for ignoring respect for human rights and for subjecting every aspect of people's daily lives to military control. The European Union must also restart a dialogue with Asmara in order to try to resolve the root issue of migratory flows, but at the same time it must make economic aid conditional on a significant increase in fundamental freedoms in the country.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this motion for a resolution because the ongoing human rights violations in Eritrea are worrying and should be put to a halt. Likewise, lack of elections, the authoritarian and repressive rule and the non-existent freedom of press are major issues faced by the Eritreans. They should be addressed by the government with the help of the international community. In the meantime, I support the allocation of funds to the Eritrean people to meet at least some of their needs.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Eritrea, one of the countries from which a large number of asylum seekers arrive in Europe, is deteriorating the rule of law and human rights.  I voted in favour of the text approved by the European Parliament calling on the Eritrean Government to make progress on the reform path, starting with respect for human rights. I also think it is right to emphasise that I am in favour of full and strong support for the Eritrean people, especially in order to combat poverty, which is one of the main causes of emigration, but I believe that the EU cannot afford to uncritically support the government, because to do so would be to condemn the Eritrean people.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report which stresses that priority must be given to addressing the justice deficit, democratic governance and restoring the rule of law, ending the authoritarian power exercised for fear of indefinite conscription, arbitrary detention in isolation, torture and other human rights violations. Respect for human rights is a key value of the EU's foreign policy and the EU's overall approach to the Horn of Africa and should therefore be regularly included in the dialogue with Eritrea.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EPP Group has repeatedly emphasised that democratic governance, the building of transparent and inclusive institutions and the protection of human rights should be the basis of an eventual National Indicative Programme (NIP) under the 11th European Development Fund (EDF) for Eritrea. The European Commission did not take this into account when proposing the NIP for Eritrea as the programme focuses on energy and public administration efficiency in the energy sector.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report. We do not recognise the authority of the European Union or the European Parliament to take decisions or positions on foreign policy issues. In particular, the humanitarian crisis has led to Eritrea becoming one of the biggest source countries for migrants in the ongoing crisis. On balance, we abstained.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation in Eritrea is dramatic. The latest UN report on this describes the Afewerki regime as harsh and oppressive. Fundamental freedoms are not guaranteed and even less respected.  No citizen under the age of 60 can have a passport, because up to that age they are all called upon to do military service. Prisons are full of political, religious or opposition prisoners who are subjected to torture. In addition, Eritrea has dramatic levels of malnutrition and malnutrition described as worrying by the FAO. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution of the European Parliament because it insists on an end to this situation and respect for democratic principles, fundamental freedoms and the rule of law.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. "U2012 While I share concern about the human rights situation in Eritrea, a country over which the United Nations Commission of Inquiry has concluded that violations in the areas of extrajudicial executions, torture, forced labour and the policy of shooting to kill at the border can constitute crimes against humanity and from which , according to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, more than 400 000 Eritreans have fled, I have not been able to vote in favour of the European Parliament's resolution since the position of this Eurochamber is that the European Union does not grant funding from the European Development Fund. Eritrea is going through a food crisis that has reduced crops in the region by between 50 and 90 per cent; Parliament's position to cancel development aid to the country has to do with its willingness to promote regime change in the country, at the cost of sanctioning the Eritrean population by denating this development aid to a country with one of the lowest human development index indicators in the world.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The degradation of living conditions in Eritrea by the restriction of human rights and freedoms has caused the departure of more than 9% of the population. Every year, 5,000 people risk their lives in an attempt to leave the country. The government's intentions to reduce legal and illegal immigration through shoot-to-kill policies and the diaspora tax are inhumane and contrary to freedom of movement. This is a simple example, which indicates the extent and seriousness of the violation of human rights and freedoms and the poor concern of the Eritrean government for the well-being of citizens. For this reason, I regret that the concerns expressed by the European Parliament have not been taken into account by the Commission, I denounce the resumption of aid amounting to EUR 200 million by signing the PIN for Eritrea and I call on the Commission to fully monitor its implementation. I therefore strongly support the return of Eritrea to a state of political normality, the establishment of a true separation of powers in the state, the development of democracy and the rule of law. I condemn the policies of European companies, which take advantage of the inequalities of the system, thus having an indirect involvement in the use of forced labour. Last but not least, I believe that respect for human rights and freedoms, access to education and the abolition of torture are essential elements of the healthy development of the state.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Eritrea gained independence in 1991 and in 1997 a new constitution was approved and ratified to ensure full respect for human rights , but so far it has not entered into force. The two-and-a-half-year border conflict with Ethiopia, which erupted in 1998, was averted under the aegis of the UN in December 2000. Isajas Afwerki is the only president of Eritrea to date since 1993; his rule, especially since 2001, has been highly autocratic and repressive. They have led to a significant militarisation of society by introducing an unpopular programme of compulsory appointment to military service, sometimes for an indefinite period. The period of military service, officially 16 months, can be extended during the "national crisis". In addition, tens of thousands of Eritreans are still being held in more than 300 locations across the country without being charged or trialed in life-threatening conditions. Torture is routinely pracised in these places. Many priests, pastors and other church figures are either under house arrest or in prison. With this in mind, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Human rights is a fundamental basis of the European Union, and we must ensure that we use all the tools available to help those in need, in countries like Eritrea. The European Union must seek to take an important role in addressing such situations of human rights breaching. We need to tackle the reality before us, Eritrean refugees are one of the largest groups of asylum seekers arriving in Europe. In Eritrea, civilians are being regularly detained or arrested for a number of unjustifiable reasons. I voted in favour of this resolution, as it highlights how the EU aid and resources can be best focused to address this situation and bring changes to situations like the one faced by Mr Dawit Isaak, a political prisoner who has been imprisoned without trial in Eritrea.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. In this resolution, the European Parliament expresses its deep concern at the deteriorating political situation in Eritrea, where the rule of law and respect for human rights are increasingly hampered. As a result of this growing instability, Eritrean refugees are among the largest number of asylum seekers in Europe.  The European Parliament resolution also points to the case of political prisoners, some of whom have been held without charge in Eritrea for more than a decade. Supporting the objectives of this resolution, I voted in favour.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The continued violation of human rights, the complete lack of the rule of law and freedom of the press, institutionalised violence, the detention and torture of innocent people (including a European journalist) have forced an estimated 5 000 Eritreans to flee their home countries every month, including to the European Union. In its resolution, the European Parliament expresses its concern, condemns the authoritarian actions of the Eritrean Government and urges the restoration of the protection of human rights. In its motion, the European Parliament appeals to the European Commission, on the one hand, to obtain assurances on the implementation of democratic reforms in Eritrea and, on the other hand, to encourage the international community and its Eritrean development partners to put the autocratic government under pressure.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament resolution on the situation in Eritrea, as what is happening in the country is very worrying. Since declaring its independence in 1993, the country has been ruled by a single president, Isaias Afewerki, who has led an extremely authoritarian and repressive government for the past 15 years. One of the main criticisms of the country is that the constitution, which was adopted and ratified in 1997, violates human rights, has many cases of torture and representatives of all religions are persecuted. The situation in Eritrea is steadily deteriorating, causing many people to flee and leave the country, an argument for which there are 450,000 asylum seekers in neighboring countries.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Negative, because when the EU intervenes in states that are at war or generally unstable, it only manages to create more problems and migrants to Europe.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The continued violation of human rights, the complete lack of the rule of law and freedom of the press, institutionalised violence, the detention and torture of innocent people (including a European journalist) have forced an estimated 5 000 Eritreans to flee their home countries every month, including to the European Union. In its resolution, the European Parliament expresses its concern, condemns the authoritarian actions of the Eritrean Government and urges the restoration of the protection of human rights. In its motion, the European Parliament appeals to the European Commission, on the one hand, to obtain assurances on the implementation of democratic reforms in Eritrea and, on the other hand, to encourage the international community and its Eritrean development partners to put the autocratic government under pressure.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The EU has been supporting Eritrea since its independence from Ethiopia in 1993, but the initial promise to establish democracy and the rule of law after the country's independence was ensnareed by the Eritrean government on the pretext of national defence and national service. The truth is that several electoral processes have not taken place and expectations in building a country that respects human rights and without repression have been soured. Eritrea has one of the worst human rights records in the world. Every day human rights violations occur and there has been no improvement in recent years. I therefore express deep concern at the perpetuation of the catastrophic human rights situation, and I consider it imperative to give priority to combating the justice deficit, democratic governance and restoring the rule of law.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution on the situation in Eritrea is another example of the European Union's policy of interference, aligned with the interests of the imperialist powers it represents. Since the economic and social situation in Eritrea is difficult, it has causes and responsible. The imperialist powers continue to look at certain regions, and particularly africa, as colonies and not as independent and sovereign states.  If governments serve their interests of preying on the riches of countries and exploitation of peoples, they are supported, if the opposite happens, the wrath of the imperialists falls upon them. We believe that the problems that exist must be solved by the action and struggle of the Eritrean people and not by any intervention or external interference. The Horn of Africa region has been affected by constant destabilization. Somalia and Uganda are an example of this. This is a region that, by its positioning and its riches, could free itself from dependence if there was peace in the region, something that the imperialist powers do not desire. It is in the face of instability, how often instigated, that they best defend their interests.  This resolution also seeks to hide what is happening nearby in Yemen.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the European Union and its Member States must ensure that, in cooperation with the Government of Eritrea, they always place emphasis on full respect for human rights, in particular as regards the management of migration flows, since on 28 January 2016 Eritrea and the European Union signed a ground-breaking agreement on future development cooperation that promotes renewable energy sources and good governance, and subsequently the European Union announced providing the country with €200 million in long-term support. The root causes of the Eritrean refugee crisis are the lack of the rule of law, democracy and respect for human rights, and the repression of the citizens of Eritrea, and unless these root causes are addressed, the refugee crisis cannot be stopped and it is highly questionable whether the Government of Eritrea is a responsible partner for the European Union. I therefore do not consider it a good step that the European Union is going to allocate EUR 200 million from the European Development Fund to energy and governance projects in Eritrea, given the dire human rights situation in this country, because it is very questionable how the local government will use this financial injection.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the reports on the situation in Eritrea as a whole, because the EU, when intervening in states that are at war or generally unstable, only manages to create more problems and migrants to Europe.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union decided to resume its development assistance to Eritrea notably via a National Indicative Programme (NIP) for Eritrea of EUR 200 million. Scrutiny Working Group A of the Committee on Development of the European Parliament, which I chair, called on the EDF Committee on 11 November 2015 not to adopt the draft NIP pending further discussion. This is explained by the human rights situation in Eritrea, that has long been deteriorating – civilians are regularly arbitrarily detained or arrested for a number of unjustifiable reasons – criticising or opposing the government, practising journalism, practising an unofficial religion, evading or deserting mandatory national service, trying to flee the country. Eritreans fleeing the country now constitute the third largest group of refugees making the perilous journey to Europe. However, our call upon the Commission was not taken into consideration. I ask the European Commission to review its scrutiny arrangements with the European Parliament and to seriously consider how EU aid and resources can be best focused to address the situation and help bring about change.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it refers to the current situation in Eritrea, its political context and human rights violations, which are seriously hampering the country's economic and human development.  In the resolution, we reiterate the importance of making better use of the European Development Fund (EDF), which must contribute to the reduction of poverty and the socio-economic development of Eritrea and contribute to eritrea's openness by enabling progress in democracy, human rights, governance and security. The national indicative programme, including its governance component, should enable Eritrea to move forward in the voice of democratization and to promote the country's openness and stability.  We also recall in this resolution that the European Parliament must be given control powers over the EDF, which still operates today outside the European Union budget.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Due to the continued violation of human rights, the complete lack of the rule of law and freedom of the press, institutionalised violence, the detention and torture of innocent people (including a European journalist), an estimated 5 000 Eritreans are forced to flee their home countries every month, including to the European Union. In its resolution, the European Parliament expresses its concern, condemns the authoritarian actions of the Eritrean Government and urges the restoration of the protection of human rights. In its motion, the European Parliament appeals to the European Commission, on the one hand, to obtain assurances on the implementation of democratic reforms in Eritrea and, on the other hand, to encourage the international community and its Eritrean development partners to put the autocratic government under pressure.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Due to the continued violation of human rights, the complete lack of the rule of law and freedom of the press, institutionalised violence, the detention and torture of innocent people (including a European journalist), an estimated 5 000 Eritreans are forced to flee their home countries every month, including to the European Union. In its resolution, the European Parliament expresses its concern, condemns the authoritarian actions of the Eritrean Government and urges the restoration of the protection of human rights. In its motion, the European Parliament appeals to the European Commission, on the one hand, to obtain assurances on the implementation of democratic reforms in Eritrea and, on the other hand, to encourage the international community and its Eritrean development partners to put the autocratic government under pressure.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. We should continue to work to build Eritrea as a country with human rights, a functioning rule of law and political structures. The country has one of the worst human rights records in the world.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report. We do not recognise the authority of the European Union or the European Parliament to take decisions or positions on foreign policy issues. In particular, the humanitarian crisis has led to Eritrea becoming one of the biggest source countries for migrants in the ongoing crisis. On balance, we abstained.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution because we consider it essential to condemn the Eritrean regime and call on the EU to end its growing complicity with this regime for geostrategic and migration flow control reasons.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution. The EP notes with great concern the continuing deplorable human rights situation and the complete absence of rule of law and media freedom in Eritrea. Therefore, it stresses that addressing the justice deficit, democratic governance and restoration of the rule of law must be prioritised by ending authoritarian rule by fear of torture and of other human rights violations, some of which may amount to crimes against humanity.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The continued violation of human rights, the complete lack of the rule of law and freedom of the press, institutionalised violence, the detention and torture of innocent people (including a European journalist) have forced an estimated 5 000 Eritreans to flee their home countries every month, including to the European Union. In its resolution, the European Parliament expresses its concern, condemns the authoritarian actions of the Eritrean Government and urges the restoration of the protection of human rights. In its motion, the European Parliament appeals to the European Commission, on the one hand, to obtain assurances for the implementation of democratic reforms in Eritrea and, on the other hand, to encourage the international community and Eritrea's development partners to put the autocratic government under pressure.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the resolution on Eritrea since it contains important provisions aimed at safeguarding and protecting human rights in the country. In particular, the country is requested to sign, ratify and implement immediately the United Nations Convention against Torture and Other Forms of Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment, as well as to comply fully with its obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the African Charter of Human and Peoples' Rights, both of which prohibit torture. It is also called for an end to all arbitrary arrests, violent disappearances and indefinite imprisonment without charges or trial. It is also recommended that the practice of indefinite military service be terminated and that service be limited to 18 months for all current and future clergy over the age of 18, and that provision be made for conscientious objectors. There is also great concern about the extremely high number of Eritrean refugees attempting to cross the Mediterranean to Europe and considers that eritrea's undemocratic and totalitarian regime is the main cause of this situation.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The humanitarian situation in Eritrea has become a growing concern for the European Union. The EU has a vested interest in a stabilised Eritrea and does not wish to see the population of the region suffer any further. A sizeable proportion of the Eritrean population has fled as a result of actions of the Eritrean Government in its active disregard for human rights or due to the lack of protection it has provided to its citizens. It is imperative that the Eritrean Government implement as many measures as possible to guarantee the basic human rights of its citizens. Particularly worrying are reports which claim that the government commits widespread extrajudicial killing, torture, arbitrary detention and discrimination. With all this in mind, and considering the vast protection provided by several international human rights instruments such as the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, I support the European Parliament’s motion for a resolution on the situation in Eritrea.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution. People are fleeing Eritrea due to its oppressive regime. The EU must support the Eritrean people.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Eritrea has had only one president since its independence in 1993 – a president who, under a highly autocratic and militarized rule, has made conscription mandatory. Though the official length of enlistment is 16 months, it is often extended, thus making the average service last 6.5 years. This leads many young people to flee from the country, and it has been estimated that there are over 440 000 refugees and asylum seekers in neighbouring countries. Moreover, all religions are persecuted in Eritrea and tens of thousands of citizens are detained without charge or trial. Given the worrying situation of human rights in Eritrea and my commitment to this cause, I have supported this report. In addition, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The continued violation of human rights, the complete lack of rule of law and freedom of the press, institutionalised violence, the detention and torture of innocent people (including a European journalist) have forced an estimated 5 000 Eritreans to flee their home countries every month. In its resolution, the European Parliament expresses its concern, condemns the authoritarian actions of the Eritrean Government and urges the restoration of the protection of human rights. In its motion, the European Parliament appeals to the European Commission, on the one hand, to obtain assurances on the implementation of democratic reforms in Eritrea and, on the other hand, to encourage the international community and its Eritrean development partners to put the autocratic government under pressure.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report. We do not recognise the authority of the European Union or the European Parliament to take decisions or positions on foreign policy issues. In particular, the humanitarian crisis has led to Eritrea becoming one of the biggest source countries for migrants in the ongoing crisis. On balance, we abstained.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Eritrean authorities have been lashing down hard on their citizens. This situation, where basic human rights are violated through harsh conditions imposed by the government, must stop. The use of the ‘Diaspora tax’ is deplorable, as is the lack of freedom and the arbitrary arrests. As a matter of urgency, Eritrea should ratify and enact the UN Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on the situation in Eritrea, given that this is a country with major problems: according to the UNDP human development report for 2014, Eritrea is 182nd out of 187 countries according to the 2014 Human Development Index, according to the World Bank's last poverty assessment of 2003, 65% of the population lives below the poverty line, human rights are violated daily and no progress has been recorded in recent years. , Eritrea is one of the countries from which the most refugees come and third in the world (after Syria and Afghanistan) in terms of the number of people embarking on a dangerous journey to Europe. In this regard, particular attention should be paid to unaccompanied children who are victims of trafficking in human beings. EUR 200 million needs to be allocated over the next six years from 11 October 2014. European Development Fund for the National Indicative Agenda to encourage poverty reduction and socio-economic development and tackle the economic and political causes of migration, but with clear transparency and good governance in terms of public finances, and to ensure democratic reforms and respect for human rights. The Council should ensure that the allocated funds will not be used incorrectly by the Eritrean government but used for the needs of Eritrean citizens.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The affable European Union would like to impose its interference in the affairs of Eritrea. I do not believe that his "right-of-hommist" compassion has the legitimacy to interfere in matters that do not concern him.  If only the European Union had an in-depth understanding of the situation, these words would have some interest. But it seems to me that the last Western interventions were catastrophic enough not to repeat these ideological recklessness. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report. We do not recognise the authority of the European Union or the European Parliament to take decisions or positions on foreign policy issues. In particular, the humanitarian crisis has led to Eritrea becoming one of the biggest source countries for migrants in the ongoing crisis. On balance, we abstained.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Eritrea. It is becoming very problematic in terms of human rights violations. The rule of law and freedom of the media are almost non-existent. However, the European Union, through the European Development Fund, allocates large sums of money to Eritrea. That is why Parliament should have control over the EDF. In addition, the Commission must now commit to enstaining that the money of European citizens will benefit the people and not an oppressive government. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of the resolution. In view of Eritrea's deteriorating situation, this resolution sets out the right measures and priorities and highlights the most pressing issues that need to be addressed to the world community.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ According to a report by the UN Special Rapporteur, Eritrea has one of the worst human rights records in the world, with no improvement in sight. Eritreans fleeing the country now constitute the third largest group of refugees making the perilous journey to Europe. Therefore, I supported the resolution as its purpose is not only to highlight and call for improvements to the appalling human rights situation, but to consider how EU aid and resources can be best focused to address the situation and help bring about change.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Due to the continued violation of human rights, the complete lack of the rule of law and freedom of the press, institutionalised violence, the detention and torture of innocent people (including a European journalist), an estimated 5 000 Eritreans are forced to flee their home countries every month, including to the European Union. In its resolution, the European Parliament expresses its concern, condemns the authoritarian actions of the Eritrean Government and urges the restoration of the protection of human rights. In its motion, the European Parliament appeals to the European Commission, on the one hand, to obtain assurances on the implementation of democratic reforms in Eritrea and, on the other hand, to encourage the international community and its Eritrean development partners to put the autocratic government under pressure.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Eritrea is one of the top refugee—producing countries in the world. This is not a coincidence. The country is a notorious human rights violator. One of the main reasons for the endless migration from the country is the fact that Eritrea conscripts all men and unmarried women into the so-called ‘national service’. Although Eritrean law limits national service to 18 months, most conscripts serve for much of their working lives. Working conditions are usually very harsh: people do not get paid or they get very small amount of money; brutal torture and beating are used as a way to force soldiers to do their jobs. Therefore, I call on the Eritrean authorities to respect human rights and, most importantly, immediately to end mandatory military conscription, including forced labour and rampant rights abuses, and to allow freedom of worship, freedom of the media and freedom of expression.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. This motion for a resolution, on which I have chosen to vote in favour, outlines the difficult situation of the people of Eritrea.  We find it unacceptable that the governing authority should continue to systematically violate human rights. This is a country which is totally suppressing freedom of expression, together with serious violations of freedom of religion and belief. Current reality shows that tens of thousands of Eritreans continue to be detained without charge. This state of affairs is the main cause of the extremely large number of Eritrean refugees attempting to cross the Mediterranean to reach Europe.  Another factor behind the exodus is the difficult conditions that the government imposes on the population. Because of the above, the European Parliament therefore calls on Eritrea to sign, ratify and implement immediately the United Nations Convention against Torture and to recognise the existence of human rights violations. Eritrea is also strongly called upon to put an end to arbitrary arrests, enforced disappearances and indefinite detention without charge or trial.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the situation in Eritrea. This is a new case of interference in the internal affairs of a third country, interference under the pretext of the defence of human rights. Furthermore, the text endorses the diplomatic role that the European Union should play when the Member States are perfectly capable of playing this role. The European Union does not provide any value for foreign affairs.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it is an interference in Eritrean internal affairs.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. "U2012 While I share concern about the human rights situation in Eritrea, a country over which the United Nations Commission of Inquiry has concluded that violations in the areas of extrajudicial executions, torture, forced labour and the policy of shooting to kill at the border can constitute crimes against humanity and from which , according to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, more than 400 000 Eritreans have fled, I have not been able to vote in favour of the European Parliament's resolution since the position of this Eurochamber is that the European Union does not grant funding from the European Development Fund. Eritrea is going through a food crisis that has reduced crops in the region by between 50 and 90 per cent; Parliament's position to cancel development aid to the country has to do with its willingness to promote regime change in the country, at the cost of sanctioning the Eritrean population by denating this development aid to a country with one of the lowest human development index indicators in the world.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. I am sorry for any human rights violations in Eritrea, but the EP resolution will not change that. It should not be Parliament's role to make a case for iniquity around the globe.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Eritrea became independent in 1993 and democracy, the rule of law and respect for fundamental human rights and freedoms were expected to be strengthened.  Unfortunately, a 2015 UN report noted that Eritrean authorities are engaged in systematic and widespread human rights violations. An increasing number of refugees from Eritrea are reporting monthly, all accompanied by cases of human trafficking. The resolution calls on the Eritrean authorities to respect human rights, release all political prisoners and journalists and ensure the delivery of food in all parts of Eritrea, so I supported the proposal for a resolution.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing – The Eritrean state is one of the poorest countries in the world, officially ranks among the presidential republics.  In fact, however, there is a one-party dictatorship. Eritrea ranked 186th out of 188 countries in the 2015 Human Development Index. The absence of the rule of law, a weak economy, high levels of poverty, disregard for human rights, restrictions on religious freedom and freedom of speech, impunity discrimination and violence against women, together with the government's refusal to help the government of this country, are the reason for the high number of refugees in this area. By not edging this situation, the number of refugees and the suffering of the population will increase. Therefore, all international branches, bodies and organisations, governments and business entities operating in Eritrea must take all necessary steps from their positions to ensure that the Government of the Republic of Eritrea secures democratic elections and that the process of democratisation in that country begins.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Eritrea, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 9/3/2016, and because this motion for a resolution is complete and well documented.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This timely resolution notes with great concern the continuing deplorable human rights situation and the complete absence of rule of law and media freedom in Eritrea.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Eritreans need help. The fundamental rights of citizens are constantly being violated. I am saddened that 89 % of women are victims of FGM. We cannot allow the people of Eritrea to starve, with the danger that crops will be lost. We must help the Eritreans, and that is why I support the motion.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. In this Parliament, we are very concerned about the situation in Eritrea, as we have seen the deplorable human rights situation and the total absence of the rule of law and freedom in the media persist. That is why my support for the Resolution in which we call for the correctness of all these shortcomings and support the development of EUR 200 million from the European Development Fund in order to promote poverty reduction and socio-economic development, address the fundamental economic and political causes of migration and finance projects related to renewable energy , energy efficiency and economic governance.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the situation in Eritrea. This country records gross human rights violations. Residents can be detained and imprisoned for government criticism, journalistic activities, informal religious practices, attempts to flee the country. Detainees and children are detained in inhumane conditions. Women in detention face the risk of sexual violence.  I agree with the EP resolution's calls for the Eritrean Government to honour its obligations under the United Nations and other international agreements and to cooperate with UN inspectors and international observers so that they can carry out a targeted, unmittained inspection of prisons in accordance with the requirements of the Convention.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution, which examines the political and human rights situation in Eritrea.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The affable European Union would like to impose its interference in the affairs of Eritrea. I do not believe that his "right-of-hommist" compassion has the legitimacy to interfere in matters that do not concern him. If only the European Union had an in-depth understanding of the situation, these words would have some interest. But it seems to me that the last Western interventions were catastrophic enough not to repeat these ideological recklessness.  As a result, I voted against it.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I signed and supported this cross-party resolution on the situation in Eritrea as it highlights the dire humanitarian situation in the country. It also expressly calls for the Commission to ensure that any development aid is not simply sent to the government of the country but reaches the people so as to maximise the potential for positive change in the recipient locality.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – Expectations were high when Eritrea gained independence in 1993. With the help of the international community, the country itself would take the reins to build a free and prosperous country for its people.  Today we note that Eritrea is ranked among the poorest and least developed countries. This translates not only into a dramatically hopeless economic situation, but also in the observation that human rights are constantly and widely violated, that free media are excluded, religious freedom is non-existent and the country is bathed in a culture of violence.  Moreover, the regime imposes on everyone an endlessly long military conscription, thus finally facite any chance of individual self-development. All this means that a large proportion of Eritreans are making the crossing to Europe. This resolution calls for an end to this long military service. The European Commission is also being asked to ensure that the benefits of European development aid are not directly felt by the government, but the population; furthermore, the European Commission is called upon to step up its efforts coherently and unequivocally to ensure that the Eritrean Government respects fundamental freedoms and implements democratic reforms.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – The errated situation in Eritrea in relation to human rights violations, compounded by compulsory and constant military levies, means that thousands of Eritreans are forced to leave their homes every month and seek international protection in neighbouring states. The absolute lack of regard for the ruling class in establishing democracy, respect for human rights or an open pluralistic society makes it necessary for the EU, but also the entire international community, to deal with this serious situation. More than 200 000 citizens have fled the country since 2004, mostly to Eastern Sudan and Ethiopia, due to harsh violations of human rights and fundamental freedoms, de facto non-existent freedom of speech, association or religion, and numerous cases of illegal detention and imprisonment. With the ultimate goal of getting to Israel, such Eritrean refugees are frequent victims of Egyptian traffickers making money from their misfortune. Without a change in the political situation, economic progress is also not possible – the necessary investments will not flow into the country, unemployment will remain high and access to basic health care, education or electricity sources will continue to be limited. I believe that it is necessary to mobilise our forces in order to protect the Eritrean people, which is why I am voting in favour of the proposal on the table.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Eretria because the human rights situation in the country has long been deteriorating: civilians are regularly arbitrarily detained or arrested for a number of unjustifiable reasons – criticising or opposing the government, practising journalism, practising an unofficial religion, evading or deserting mandatory national service, trying to flee the country or having a relative who has fled. Recently a report by the UN Special Rapporteur noted that Eritrea has one of the worst human rights records in the world, with no improvement in sight. Eritreans fleeing the country now constitute the third largest group of refugees making the perilous journey to Europe. The purpose of this resolution is not only to highlight and call for improvements to the appalling human rights situation, but to consider how EU aid and resources can be best focused to address the situation and help bring about change.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The human rights situation in Eritrea has forced many women, men and children to flee the country, risking further abuses in the hands of smugglers and human traffickers, in order to reach safer grounds. The ones who stayed behind face an oppressive regime and severe problems with indefinite conscription, food security, restrictions, abuses and repression of all basic freedoms. I therefore support this resolution and strongly hope that the international community will use all diplomatic tools available to intervene before this crisis becomes even worse.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing.
