The EU has supported Eritrea since 1993, the date of its independence from Ethiopia, taking into account the initial promise to establish democracy and the rule of law after independence. There are reports by the UN Special Rapporteur, the UN Commission of Inquiry on Human Rights and Human Rights Watch describing human rights violations, torture, forced labour, lack of religious freedom, homosexual practices such as illegal and discrimination and violence against women. The UN Special Rapporteur on human rights in Eritrea highlights the following concerns: the enjoyment of economic, social and cultural rights, including the right to decent accommodation; smuggling and trafficking in human beings and the increase in the number of unaccompanied minors who are among the more than 5 000 people fleeing the country each month. I argue that the international community should press the Eritrean government to authorise foreign aid to support vulnerable communities and that the EU take steps to ensure assurances from the Eritrean government that it will implement democratic reforms and ensure respect for human rights.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The vote on such a resolution would have constituted total interference in Eritrean internal affairs, which are de facto only for the Eritrean government and people. That is why I voted against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which presents the current situation in Eritrea, which now ranks 186th out of 188 countries in terms of the human development index. 400,000 Eritreans have already fled their country and UNHCR estimates that 5,000 people leave their country each month.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. In the face of a humanitarian situation of great concern, Parliament's resolution on the situation in Eritrea calls for an end to repression and respect for fundamental rights. In addition, the resolution condemns the DECISION of the EDF Committee that goes against Parliament's recommendations. The European Union supports the Government of Eritrea in its fight against poverty, but has a duty to ensure the proper use of European funds. As such, I support Parliament's resolution.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 is 2016 and the situation in Eritrea is still very bad. After the referendum in 1993 calling for Eritrea's independence and the adoption in 1997 of a constitution that respected fundamental human rights, we had every reason to expect positive change. However, the expected reforms have not arrived and the people of Eritrea still do not have the rights entred in the constitution.  The report, which I voted in favour of, calls on the country to change, stressing the serious consequences of the daily violations of fundamental rights.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution, which calls for more transparency and good governance in respect of public finances and calls on the EU Delegation to closely monitor the political situation in the country in order to make sure that the continuation of EU development cooperation is dependent on substantial progress being achieved in the areas of human rights and democratisation , in particular freedom of speech, freedom of the press and freedom of assembly.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The situation in Eritrea remains very bad. The decisions allocate money to Eritrea, which must be used to meet the needs of the Eritrean people for development, democracy, good governance and security. The EU delegation must ensure that the money is used accordingly.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. Eritrea is one of the poorest and most closed countries in Africa and is one of the world's fastest countries. The situation in the country is constantly deteriorating. Systemic, widespread and serious violations of human rights are taking place. The rule of law and the principles of media freedom are completely disregarded. In this context, immediate action is necessary.  In particular, the financial support granted to the Eritrean Government should be suspended and monitoring mechanisms set up. The aid granted cannot be authorised to finance repression or any other forced labour-related activity. The Commission must ensure that the funds allocated are not used by the Eritrean government, but are strictly allocated to the needs of the Eritrean population in terms of development, democracy, human rights, good governance and security. In order to stabilise the situation in the country, it is essential that the President and government of Eritrea undertake reforms to help Eritrea to ensure compliance with international and human rights commitments.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report. We do not recognise the authority of the European Union or the European Parliament to take decisions or positions on foreign policy issues. In particular, the humanitarian crisis has led to Eritrea becoming one of the biggest source countries for migrants in the ongoing crisis. On balance, we abstained.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation in Eritrea has been getting worse and worse for some time now. In addition to the scourge of poverty and housing shortages, the UN and Human Rights Watch specify that a massive violation of human rights is taking place. In fact, summary executions without trial, disappearances, torture, compulsory conscription and a lack of political opposition make eritrea's economic development impossible. In expressing my deepest concern, I would vote in favour of it.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on Eritrea, as it raises a number of difficult topics regarding the situation in this country, which have long been urgently needed to address. In particular, it is critical, in my view, as the report also stated, that the elections that were planned for 1997 were never held, and the constitution of the same year was not implemented. There is also an important focus on regional elections, which should have been held as early as 2009, but this has still not happened. The legislation is not passed by parliament at all, but is done by the government itself. The report therefore describes well the lack of democratic processes in this country, which largely inhibits its further development. In view of the difficulties listed above, I believe it was necessary to adopt this resolution, as it will in future represent the official position of the European Parliament and, therefore, the European Union towards this country, and will also represent some political pressure from the international community on this country to carry out the much-needed democratic reforms.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this report and welcome the fact that the situation in this far-off country is being monitored. But it is clear to all of us that it is not enough just to speak and list the numerous problems that are an integral part of the life of the population there, and because of which about five thousand people leave the country every month, of which a large number of them in this way try to avoid military service, which in reality represents forced labor and from which no girls are exempt. Last year, Reporters Without Borders named Eritrea the worst country in the world in terms of freedom of the press, worse even than North Korea.  The population of Eritrea is subjected to various forms of violence and discrimination, including on the basis of religion. We must continue to insist on respect for human rights, eradicating poverty and boosting investment in energy policy, as many rural parts of the country still do not even have electricity.  Eritrea needs to help restore the rule of law, end authoritarian rule as well as residents' fears of imprisonment, torture and other types of violations of basic human rights.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because the Union must take all necessary measures to put pressure on the Eritrean Government and must ensure that European funds meet the needs of the people, setting up structures that will allow the enjoyment of economic, social and cultural rights in the country.  Discrimination, violence and repression pervade every area of Eritrean society: the EU's commitment to establish democracy and the rule of law in the country has never been fulfilled. In the penultimate place in the 2015 human development indices, Eritrea is the worst country in the world when it comes to fundamental rights. There is no freedom of the press or religion in the country, homosexuality is illegal, there is no protection for LGBT groups or women who are victims of sexual violence, it is estimated that 89 % of girls have been subjected to genital mutilation.  Prolonged national service, forced labour and the doctrine of "shooting to kill" at the border fall within the scope of crimes against humanity. Torture and prolonged detention without just cause are a practice. The food crisis caused by drought and the inability to access resources, especially for women and children, encourages desperate migration to Europe.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Eritrean civilians are being rounded up or arrested for a number of unjustified reasons, a vast population of Eritrea fleeing because of fear and oppression, five thousand new fugitives a month, making up the third largest group of refugees heading for Europe. In Eritrea, there is no truly public space in which civil society organisations are allowed to operate freely. I encourage the Eritrean government to implement urgent reforms, I stress that the right to leave the country is enshrined in international human rights law. I call on the government to allow freedom of movement and stop collecting a "diaspora tax" from Eritreans living abroad. I regret the increased risk of sexual and domestic violence for women, especially women in military service or in custody. I condemn the indirect involvement of foreign companies and their participation in the use of forced labour in Eritrea and demand greater accountability and assessment of their operations in Eritrea, with due diligence and reporting initiatives.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution on the situation in Eritrea is another example of the European Union's policy of interference aligned with the interests of the imperialist powers it represents. Since the economic and social situation in Eritrea is difficult, it has causes and responsible. The imperialist powers continue to look at certain regions, and in particular Africa, as colonies and not as independent and sovereign states.  If governments serve their interests of preying on the riches of countries and exploitation of peoples, they are supported, if the opposite happens, the wrath of the imperialists falls upon them. We believe that the problems that exist must be solved solely and exclusively by the action and struggle of the Eritrean people and not by any external intervention, take this the form it takes.  The Horn of Africa region has been affected by constant destabilization. Somalia and Uganda are an example of this. This is a region that, by its positioning and its riches, could free itself from dependence if there was peace in the region, something that the imperialist powers do not desire. We also stress that we believe that the European Union wants to hide, with this resolution, what is happening very close ly in the Yemen War.

name: Kati Piri (S&D)
text: in writing. – Cross-border kidnappings and aggression, compulsory national service stretching to a decade, and Eritreans’ involvement in the war in Yemen are reported by the UN Monitoring Group. This is the country to which the European Union has signed a 200-million-euro package of financial support in January for a four—year period. Each month, as many as 5 000 people flee Eritrea according to UN figures. The Eritreans are the third largest group of people who risk the journey across the Mediterranean to reach Europe. And even after they find new homes in Europe, they are not free of the Eritrean regime’s grasp. It was reported that some interpreters working for the Dutch immigration service were linked to the Eritrean regime. The regime also targets our free media! In the Netherlands alone, eight court cases have been launched against liberal newspapers, radio stations, websites who are critical of the authoritarian regime. The reports suggest that senior government officials are behind this campaign. Which monitoring measures does the Commission take to ensure that our support leads to the development of the country and to better living conditions of Eritreans, and not to the strengthening of this authoritarian government inside and outside of that country?

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I welcome the proposal for a resolution on Eritrea and fully support it. The human rights situation in Eritrea is particularly worrying and I am convinced that it requires greater engagement from the European Union. For more than two decades, Eritrea has been ruled by an authoritarian regime that systematically violates human rights to almost unprecedented proportions. The high number of political prisoners, torture and abduction of opponents of the regime, as well as persecution of members of religious minorities, require the strongest condemnation of the European Union.  In particular, I emphasise the fact that due to the extremely unfavourable economic situation and disregard for human rights, Eritrea is abandoned by around five thousand of its citizens seeking international protection in European countries per month, and many on this journey become victims of human smuggling or even lose their lives. Non-compliance with human rights is incompatible with the democratic principles on which the European Union is founded, and I therefore call on the Commission to put stronger pressure on the Eritrean authorities in order to finally put an end to systematic human rights violations in the country.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the plight of the failure to respect fundamental human rights in Eritrea, I have decided to support the report on the situation in this country. The degradation, humiliation and punishment of the fundamental rights of the population is deing migration flows not only to neighbouring countries, but also to the European Union. It is not possible for citizens to be imprisoned for criticizing government officials, practicing journalism, professing an unofficial religion, or for homosexuality. I am very sorry that Eritrea is not fulfilling its promise of democracy. I voted in favour of ending a dictatorial government that does not punish but even supports the commission of crimes against humanity, and I called on the European Commission to ensure that European funding for development aid does not serve the local government. It is primarily important that the citizens of Eritrea themselves reach for resources and other development aid. I believe that companies investing in Eritrea should be similarly correct. Certainly, on the basis of their business activities and interests, this unsatisfactory situation should not deteriorate further.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Eritrea to denounce the regime's innumerable failures to the fundamental values that drive democracy: freedoms, human rights, the rule of law. The leaders of this Central African country violate these principles, which guide our European states in particular and which should also frame the foreign policy of the European Union. Indeed, doubt hangs over the fact that the EUR 200 million in development aid granted by the European Commission in December 2015 to the Government of Eritrea will be used wisely, in the service of the people. It is indeed these people, through this resolution, that we wish to defend.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report. We do not recognise the authority of the European Union or the European Parliament to take decisions or positions on foreign policy issues. In particular, the humanitarian crisis has led to Eritrea becoming one of the biggest source countries for migrants in the ongoing crisis. On balance, we abstained.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution was tabled following a statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Eritrea. I welcome the document for agreeing that Eritrea should fully implement its ratified constitution and protect the rights enshrined therein. More specifically, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because it agrees with the following recommendations: (1) Eritrea should immediately sign, ratify and implement the United Nations Convention against Torture and other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment; (2) an end to arbitrary detention, enforced disappearance and indefinite detention should be placed without charge or trial; (3) the government should recognise the existence of human rights violations and ensure accountability for human rights violations committed in the past; and (4) an end to military service indefinitely should be placed. Finally, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I agree that the extremely high number of Eritrean refugees trying to cross the Mediterranean to Europe is worrying, and this is due to the anti-democratic and totalitarian regime in Eritrea, which should be the subject of immediate reforms.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union must make every effort to put an end to the detention of innocent opponents and civilians and to carry out fair trials for the accused and the abolition of torture and other inhumane treatment, such as restrictions on food, water and health care. The Government of Eritrea continues to implement policies that are attentive to human rights, a factor that is absolutely decisive for the numbers of emigration among its population.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Eritrea is a country that, after thirty years of war, gained its independence in 1993. Its further development continues to be linked to border conflicts with its neighbours, especially Ethiopia.  The EU-Eritrea cooperation framework is contained in the Cotonou Agreement, which includes cooperation in areas ranging from trade to the fight against poverty, to the protection of human rights and good governance. Despite all the efforts, the human rights situation has been progressively deteriorating, according to the United Nations. Free elections have never taken place in Eritrea, and the separation of powers from the state is unclear. Citizens do not enjoy freedom of expression and arbitrary detentions for undetermined periods, ill-treatment and torture are frequent practices.  This report demands immediate improvements in these areas from the Eritrean authorities to promote peace, development and sustainable prosperity through unwavering respect for human rights, which is why I cast my vote in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text of this resolution, which calls on the Commission to ensure that the funds and aid allocated do not go to the Eritrean government, but are strictly used to cover the development, democracy, human rights, governance and security needs of the Eritrean population, as well as freedom of expression, the press and assembly.  The adopted text also requires Eritrea to sign and immediately implement the UN Convention against Torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment and fully respect its obligations under the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights and the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights. , both of which prohibit torture.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report on the situation in Eritrea. On the other hand, after hearing and voting for another document of great concern, we did not hear the most important thing: what can we do to eliminate the causes of this terrible knowledge? The recent actions of the EU institutions, designed only to manage the flow of refugees, suggest that, so far, Europe is not acting like a very clever doctor who treats the symptoms of the disease, not the cause.  As regards the guidelines for a fair solution to the Eritrean crisis, I would like to draw your attention to the good practices that Europe has. In the 15 years, ethnic conflicts in the Balkans have rapidly stalled, with Europe making it clear that, in exchange for peace and stability, the countries of the region can get a European perspective. I would therefore very much like Mr Mogherini to explain whether the EU can offer the sides of the Eritrean conflict such economic and political benefits as to encourage them to take the steps we so desperately expect in ending this conflict and finally launching dmeocratic and market reforms? Or should we talk about the specific European military support for one of the sides of the conflict?

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the situation in Eritrea. According to the UN Special Rapporteur, the human rights situation in Eritrea is among the worst in the world. Eritrea urgently prioritizes the fight against the justice deficit, democratic governance and the restoration of the rule of law by ending authoritarian rule.  The resolution calls for the immediate release of political prisoners, the protection of women's and children's rights and an end to arbitrary arrests. It is regrettable that the Commission and the Council have not taken Parliament's recommendations into account in the adoption of the National Indicative Programme for Eritrea.  It will be necessary to ensure that the funds allocated by the EDF to Eritrea, amounting to EUR 200 million, are thoroughly monitored so that the funds directly benefit the people and not the Eritrean government.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution because we consider it essential to condemn the Eritrean regime and call on the EU to end its growing complicity with this regime for geostrategic and migration flow control reasons.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. Cooperation with Eritrea is essential if we are to have hope that Eritrea will enforce human rights and fight crime and corruption. That is why I support the agreement.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report. We do not recognise the authority of the European Union or the European Parliament to take decisions or positions on foreign policy issues. In particular, the humanitarian crisis has led to Eritrea becoming one of the biggest source countries for migrants in the ongoing crisis. On balance, we abstained.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation of human rights in the state of Eritrea has been deteriorating for a long time: civilians are regularly and arbitrarily detained or arrest for a number of unjustifiable reasons. Criticism of the government or, in anyway undermining the state by engaging in subversive journalism or practicing an unsanctioned religion is punishable in this country. I supported this resolution because it will not only highlight and call for improvements to the inexcusable human rights situation in Eritrea, but it will also consider how aid and resources from the EU can be best focused to address the situation in order to encourage change.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 The situation in Eritrea is very serious and complicated at the same time. Since the 1998-2001 war with Ethiopia, there has been a state of emergency in Eritrea, there are no possibilities for dissent or change, given that the political opposition is banned. Since 1993, there have been no national elections in the country and the regional elections scheduled for 2009 are yet to take place. The Eritrean Government is the sole owner of land and natural resources and the government uses this as a system of remuneration and punishment. Members of the military and parties seized land and seized property and businesses. As a result of fear and oppression, there are a huge number of Eritreans on the run, representing the third largest group of refugees heading to Europe, given the 5 000 refugees per month. Since Eritrean people are not allowed to leave the country without the permission of the government, which is based on the arbitrary issuration of an exit visa, and movement to the border zones is restricted, and the Eritrean Government has a shoot-to-kill policy, therefore those who leave the country cannot come back. For these reasons, I also supported the resolution on the situation in Eritrea, in which we call on the Eritrean Government to respect human rights and international conventions.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The context of repression and violence in Eritrea requires urgent action by the European institutions against the ongoing systematic human rights violations. Unfortunately, in the light of the report by the UN Special Rapporteur, eritrea has the worst results in terms of respect for human rights: it is a country in which citizens are regularly arrested or detained for unjustifiable reasons, such as expressing criticism of the government or evading compulsory military service of indefinite duration. Eritrea is one of the most repressive countries of freedom of expression in both the media and access to information, with an Internet access rate of 1 %. For these reasons, Eritreans fleeing their country constitute the third largest group of refugees to Europe. The aim of the resolution is not only to promote a strong stand in favour of human rights, but also to ensure that the EU continues to support Eritrea by ensuring that aid actually meets the need to alleviate the suffering of the Eritrean people, that is, by making this support conditional on an end to human rights violations, the launch of democratic reforms and the normalisation of the country's governance.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union is based on a great commitment to promoting and protecting human rights, democracy and the rule of law worldwide and these principles are woven into the EU's founding treaties. The UN Special Rapporteur on the human rights situation in Eritrea lists three main areas of concern: the enjoyment of economic, social and cultural rights, including the right to adequate housing. Smuggling and trafficking in human beings and the growing number of unaccompanied minors belong to a group of more than 5,000 people fleeing the country each month.  I call on the Eritrean authorities to release all political prisoners, to reform and shorten the duration of military service, to stop all forced evictions and demolition of buildings, and to cover more people through the process of allocating social housing. It is important that Eritrea respects and applies the right to education without coercion, for which so many young Eritreans flee the country.  I therefore call for respect for international human rights norms and standards relating to refugees, and I believe that Eritrean refugees fleeing human rights violations should be provided with international protection.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ There are still very worrying underlying problems in Eritrea that contribute to the already chaotic state of the country. The situation in Eritrea is serious because citizens of the state suffer, which contributes to instability in the region. The European Union fully supports and promotes the protection of human rights, democracy and the rule of law in the world and ensures that respect for human dignity, the principles of equality and solidarity, the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms are also available beyond the EU's borders. Unfortunately, as the UN Special Rapporteur on the human rights situation in Eritrea pointed out, problems arise with the enjoyment of economic, social and cultural rights, including the right to adequate housing, and smuggling, trafficking in human beings and the number of unaccompanied minors belonging to those fleeing the country on a daily basis. The government of Eritrea itself is the perpetrator of systematic, widespread and serious violations of fundamental human rights for which it must be held accountable.  I support the proposal for a resolution on the situation in Eritrea because I believe that the rights and freedoms of the individual must be ensured for every citizen, and in Eritrea there are cases of serious violations of them, some of which can be classified as crimes against humanity.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the European People's Party resolution at the conclusion of the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. The situation in Eritrea with regard to the protection of human rights, democracy and the rule of law is serious and worrying. A very worrying figure was provided in 2015 by reporters without borders, who declared Eritrea the worst country in the world about journalistic freedom. As we all know, without journalistic freedom, there is no democracy. There are also numerous violations in the country in the area of extrajudicial executions, torture and forced labour, according to the UN. I, too, express my deep concern at the lack of freedom of expression and the continued presence of political prisoners, whose imprisonment is a violation of the rule of law.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The continued violation of human rights, the complete lack of the rule of law and freedom of the press, institutionalised violence, the detention and torture of innocent people (including a European journalist) have forced an estimated 5 000 Eritreans to flee their home countries every month, including to the European Union. In its resolution, the European Parliament expresses its concern, condemns the authoritarian actions of the Eritrean Government and urges the restoration of the protection of human rights. In its motion, the European Parliament appeals to the European Commission, on the one hand, to obtain assurances on the implementation of democratic reforms in Eritrea and, on the other hand, to encourage the international community and its Eritrean development partners to put the autocratic government under pressure.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report, in particular in the hope that the astonishing facts contained there thereto will finally reveal to the European institutions and governments how to find an explanation for the relatively large number of Eritrean citizens and the proportion of refugees arriving across the Mediterranean or drowning in the sea while fleeing. The report makes it clear that in this case it is not a war, but a ruthless authoritarian regime that does not deter violence, torture and humiliation against its own citizens.  Against this background, it is clear to me that, especially in the light of the inefficiity of the pressures of the international community so far, a harsh regime with such an extreme policy needs to be taken much more effectively and urgently than before, especially from the EU and the European External Action Service. I believe that this could also address one of the important causes of the migration wave, which is challenging for the Union, locally.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Thousands of people flee Eritrea each month because of the country's regime. Many of them reach Europe in search of help and support. It is important that European development aid does not help an authoritarian regime, but a poor and war-torn society. Under the 11th More than EUR 200 million will be transferred to Eritrea in the coming years. There are legitimate concerns that this money will largely be spent by the ruling authoritarian regime to pacify civilians. The EP report rightly emphasises that democratic governance, the building of transparent and efficient public institutions and the protection of human rights should form the basis for the Union's granting of financial support. When deciding whether to transfer Eritrean development funds, the Commission seems to have forgotten this, focusing solely on the support of the energy sector.  Parliament's calls to change the Commission's position so far have been ignored, which is why the adoption by the EP of a resolution on the situation in Eritrea is so important. Indeed, there needs to be a clear and strong signal that transparency and better cooperation between the EU institutions in development programming must be respected.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has in recent years become a champion of the protection of human rights at international level. In this respect, the European institutions have reported situations of violations of fundamental rights in various parts of the world, encouraging the development of fair democratic systems based on citizens' sovereignty. Today, the situation in Eritrea has become critical of arbitrary measures by the authorities, which have put a considerable number of people behind bars for criticizing the government, practicing independent journalism, practicing informal religions, not satisfying compulsory military service or trying to leave the country. The recent UN report concluded that Eritrea has one of the lowest degrees of respect for human rights in the world, with no prospects for immediate improvement. A significant fact is that the citizens of Eritrea are numerically the third group of immigrants to go to the countries of the European Union during this period. In these circumstances, the Union must act, with the resources at its disposal, to put an end to this situation, which is not favourable to either the citizens of Eritrea or the Member States. As representatives of European citizens, it is our duty to support this resolution.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. In this resolution, we call on Eritrea to fully implement the Constitution it has ratified and the rights enshrined in it, including Articles 17 and 19. On the other hand, we encourage Eritrea to sign, ratify and implement without delay the UN Convention against Torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment and to fully respect its obligations under the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights and the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights. , both of which prohibit torture.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Eritrea is deplorable, and the country has one of the worst human rights records in the world. Led by the same president since 1993, it is a regime that systemically violates human rights with arbitrary arrests and tortures, uses the mandatory military service to forcibly enslave the population for labour, in a country where freedom of expression is violated, freedom of religion is repressed and the state of emergency is permanent. I voted in favour and co—signed this resolution, to highlight the fact that we need to ensure that the EUR 200 million the European Union plans to allocate to Eritrea over coming years will not flow into the pockets of this regime, but will rather help to reduce poverty and promote socio—economic development for all Eritreans. This aid should be conditional on putting an end to human rights violations and re-orientating the country’s energy policy to make energy accessible for everyone.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The current political and social situation in Eritrea is quite complex. After more than thirty years of war, following the dispute over the definition of borders and the new conflict of 1998, we are witnessing a progressive militarisation and severe restrictions on civil rights.  My vote in favour of this resolution serves to reaffirm the need for the Eritrean Government to fulfil the international commitments it has entered into, including the commitments established by the Convention against Torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Eritrea must also ensure greater transparency and a willingness to cooperate with UN inspectors and international observers so that they can seriously and uninderedly assess detention facilities and verify the living conditions of detainees.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Eritrea is a country that won independence in 1993 after a 30-year guerrilla war, but democratization has never been carried out, and conflicts with neighbours, primarily Ethiopia, have put it in a major economic and social crisis and it is now one of the poorest countries in the world, and has one of the most repressive regimes in the world where systemic violations of human rights and fundamental freedoms are taking place. In this African horn state, which has been under isaias Afwerki's strict and repressive regime for more than 20 years, the population is arrested for no reason, tortured and killed, often on religious grounds. People living below the poverty line are fearful of unlimited military recruitment and forced labour, constant psychological and physical bullying, leading to four thousand Eritreans leaving their country every month to save their lives and the lives of their fellow human beings. After Syria, Eritrea is the second largest source of migrants risking their lives to cross the Mediterranean and reach the coast of Europe, often on deadly routes, exposed to the constant danger of human trafficking. Any violation of human rights, anywhere in the world, is also a problem for the European Union, which cannot and must not close its eyes to this pressing problem. That's why I supported this resolution.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on Eritrea because I believe that Eritrea is a country that needs our help. We have supported it since independence itself, although democracy and the rule of law have not yet been established there. There is a high level of repression and violations of fundamental human rights in Eritrea, and their position is among the worst in the world. Large numbers of young people have fled the country from a repressive government and compulsory military service, which can also be indefinitely, hampering the country's economic growth. There is still a great deal of torture, oppression and government intervention on citizens who are members of the religion. There is a high degree of discrimination against and violence against women, and such practices go unpunished. The EU is an important partner of Eritrea in the area of development aid and support, and we must therefore strive to help citizens, even though the government unilaterally cut off aid in 2011 and does not recognise public cooperation and partnership with the EU.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution because we consider it essential to condemn the Eritrean regime and call on the EU to end its growing complicity with this regime for geostrategic and migration flow control reasons.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. Eritrea has been under a state of emergency since the 1998-2000 war with Ethiopia. In many cases, Eritrean citizens are arbitrarily detained or arrested for unsustainable reasons, such as government criticism or defiance, journalistic activity, the practice of unofficial religion, circumvention or desertion of compulsory military service, cooperation with foreign organisations, attempts to leave the country or the escape of a family member.  Between 2012 and mid-2015, almost twice as many Eritreans applied for asylum in Europe as syrians. More than 400,000 Eritreans - 9% of the total population - have fled the country, according to the UN High Commissioner for Refugees. I voted in favour of the S&D position.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution because we consider it essential to condemn the Eritrean regime and call on the EU to end its growing complicity with this regime for geostrategic and migration flow control reasons.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the situation in Eritrea. The report agrees to the allocation of EUR 200 million over the next six years to the National Indicative Program to Eritrea for promoting poverty reduction and socio-economic development as a way of tackling the root causes of migration, provided that Eritrea fulfils all international obligations, shows transparency and good governance and protection of human rights. However, concern is expressed regarding the human rights situation in the country, as Eritrean refugees are among the largest groups of asylum seekers arriving in Europe, while many of the political prisoners have been jailed without charge for more than a decade. I believe that, as much as this country can benefit from EU financial support, the aid must be targeted prudently at the communities in need, and the country has to have a good record of human rights protection and show transparency in the way the aid is being used.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The Resolution agrees with the allocation of 200 million over the next 6 years in favour of the National Indicative Programme under the 11th European Development Fund to promote poverty reduction and socio-economic development. It also addresses the fundamental political and economic causes of migration and proposes to finance projects related to renewable energy, energy efficiency and economic governance. It also urges Eritrea to provide evidence of transparency and good governance, expresses its deep concern about the human rights situation in the country, and calls on the international community and Eritrean partners to put pressure on the Government of Eritrea to allow foreign aid in support of vulnerable communities to prevent the current crisis from escalation. In short, we are talking about a constructive resolution for the country, which deepens the current needs, so I consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'According to the UN, human rights in Eritrea are being violated constantly and on a large scale, and there does not appear to be any improvement in this. Eritreans fleeing the country are the third largest group of refugees making the perilous crossing to Europe. That is why I support this resolution which calls for an improvement in the appalling human rights situation in the country and a better use of European aid to improve the situation in Eritrea.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation in the region is marked by numerous conflicts. Eritrea is very close to Yemen, where there is still a war. We have the Horn of Africa region marked by instability. These situations only serve imperialist interests in their attempt to turn countries against countries, to stimulate internal problems. In this way these countries remain dependent and subjugated to their interests. The Horn of Africa region could be very rich if there were not so many problems and if there were understandings between the different countries, this is because it is a resource-rich and geographically well positioned region.  These draft resolutions propose further interference in these countries. If there are problems, the peoples of these countries must solve them. External interventions and pressures, always with their economic and geostrategic interests behind them, will only delay any possibility of resolution.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Security is to be ensured in the country. Corruption is to be reduced by this motion. It also calls for the Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment to be signed, ratified and, without delay, enacted by law. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: n/a
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the situation in Eritrea. I am particularly concerned to move forward with the peace process in Eritrea and to reduce human rights violations. I condemn the Eritrean regime for its use of torture, compulsory military service similar to slavery and its violations of mandatory judicial requirements under the rule of law.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to use this opportunity to raise the issue of the situation of women in Eritrea, and how European authorities treat women refugees. This is especially important in the context of the report on women refugees that Parliament adopted this week. Eritrea has ratified all major human rights conventions, including the Convention for the Elimination of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW), and yet has one of the most appalling human rights records on Earth.  The majority of Eritrean women are subject to female genital mutilation (FGM), and refugees from that country are likely to have experienced FGM. European authorities receiving Eritrean refugees on our borders and across Member States must be trained and equipped to deal with those who have undergone FGM, in terms of healthcare and psychological support, as well as taking into account FGM (and the complexity of dealing with it) in asylum requests.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the resolution on the situation in Eritrea. Although the country gained independence back in 1991, its constitution was never implemented and its only president since independence introduced an autocratic way of government. The citizens of Eritrea, both men and women, must undergo compulsory military service, which in fact also exceeds several times the period laid down by law. If they want to travel abroad, legal options for obtaining travel documents are very limited. Moreover, trials in this country could hardly be described as fair, and the persecution of religions contributes to an overall intolerable situation. Therefore, the people of Eritrea often see no other way out of the country. In the resolution, we therefore called on the Government of Eritrea to ratify the Constitution fully, to adopt the UN Convention against Torture and Other Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment without delays, and to abandon indefinite military service. I hope that the expression of the European Parliament's opposition, as well as the call for an immediate improvement in the situation, will put moral pressure on the Government of Eritrea, and that the situation will soon improve so that the more than 440 000 refugees currently in the surrounding states can safely return home.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I was happy to support this report, which describes the current situation in Macedonia and addresses the process of this country's approach to the European Union.  I believe that in the long term we must offer the countries of the Western Balkans the opportunity to become members of the European Union. In the case of Macedonia, I express my great joy at this and my thanks for macedonia's role in the migration crisis and its monitoring of its border between Macedonia and Greece. It thus substitutes the role of Greece, which unfortunately is unable to properly guard its border.  So this, too, is why we should support Macedonia. Why should we see it as an important partner towards the European Union? I regret to say that, unfortunately, it is Greece that is blocking the next adoption process because of the name of that state. I think that such petty things should not decide whether or not Macedonia becomes a member of the European Union.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Similarly, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is in the same bad condition in the process of adding Bosnia and Herzegovina and Turkey as a candidate country. The country's name disputs with Greece, strained relations with Bulgaria – not only do these two factors play a fundamentally burdensome role in the negotiations with Macedonia and the European Union. To a large extent, they have not even been initiated for the purposes of the Council's position, but one of the most fundamental problems is political instability in Macedonia: internal instability, widespread corruption, the negative aspects of the rule of law, freedom of expression, freedom of the press. And while reforms in this country are gradually not being implemented, unfortunately there are no clear enough changes in practice.  But, of course, I voted in favour of this resolution, perhaps it will add Macedonia to something to step in for the European Union.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, Vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí anseo go léir taobh amuigh de cheann amháin agus is é sin Leasú 17d mar baineann sé le ECAT agus mar sin de agus ós rud é gur tír neodrach í Éire, staonamar sa vóta sin. Ach taobh amuigh de sin, glacaim leis na pointí atá anseo. in particular I would like to support the point of view of the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) that political parties in Macedonia must assume their respective responsibilities and ensure without delay the full, constructive and timely implementation of all their commitments, in a sustainable and negotiated manner, including their commitment to strengthen good neighbourly relations in order to maintain the positive recommendation to open EU membership negotiations. This is a very important point. I also agree with AFET’s demands to engage in a constructive political dialogue, particularly in preparation for the elections on 5 June 2016, which are going to be critical for the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, it is true that Macedonia is facing the biggest political crisis since 2001. It is also true that the voice of civil society in Macedonia is increasingly heard and is actively involved in resolving this crisis. Destabilisation of Macedonia means blocking important projects that delay the development of society. Macedonia is making efforts for accession and they should not be ignored. For years the Commission has been recommending that the Council be given to Macedonia a date for the start of negotiations and the Council refuses due to Greece's intervention. It is time for Greece to stop at these efforts and give free free access to integration efforts and work in Macedonia. Macedonia's involvement in resolving the migrant crisis is important and we have already seen measures taken by the authorities. Macedonia's fragile situation demands our help, while making the political commitments Macedonia has made. And we must respect our commitments to Macedonia, otherwise we lose our credibility.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report addresses the current situation in Macedonia. FYROM's accession negotiations have slowed down due to a serious political crisis. That is why the European Union has been pressing for new elections to be called by the Macedonian Government. It also reiterates the importance of freedom and independence of the media, expressing deep concern at the political pressures, hate speech, constant polarisation and lack of independence and pluralism affecting the media.   I voted in favour because I believe that the negotiations with the EU can only have a positive impact on bilateral dispute resolution efforts and will at the same time provide a boost and incentive for essential reforms, specifically concerning the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary and the fight against corruption.

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report on progress in the process of EU membership of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, inter alia because it concerns the pending dispute with Greece on the name as a 'bilateral' issue, when I understand that this is an issue to be resolved within the framework of the United Nations and in accordance with international law. In addition, our group opposes the neoliberal agenda, the privatisation policies and the economic model of EU membership, which have proven to have catastrophic effects on the European population, so I voted against it.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report supports a further enlargement of the European Union to the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. I strongly oppose this as this will exacerbate the difficulties in the European Union. That is why I voted against this proposal.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which deals with the 2015 report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The recent political crisis has shown the need to increase the transparency and public accountability of the Macedonian institutions, including appropriate supervisory mechanisms for key services and internal structures. The European Parliament is encouraging Macedonia to find a way out of the political impasse, to ensure the return of the opposition to parliament, the implementation of reforms to the rule of law and the strengthening of good neighbourly relations. The influence of politicians on the media, judicial authorities and the public administration system and corruption remains also an important issue. I support calls for political parties to take appropriate responsibility against citizens and to ensure, without delay, the full and constructive implementation of all commitments, including the commitment to strengthen good relations with their neighbours, in a timely manner.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. In its expansionist will, the European Union always puts forward two demands that seem to condition the admission of new Member States more than others: membership of NATO, whose existence is no longer justified since the dissolution of the Warsaw Pact, and the promotion of gender ideology with its procession of communitarian demands.  For example, Article 22 of the resolution calls for following the UNION's so-called model of discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and gender identity. A vague concept that justifies the delusions of obviously disturbed ideologues. But the obsessions of the Eurocrats prevent them from seeing the real problems facing Macedonia. Fortunately, Macedonian officials, starting with President Georges Ivanov, seem to have understood that it was better to rely on their visegrad group partners!

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this report, which recalls in particular that the early parliamentary elections on 5 June will be an important test for the country's democratic process and insists that all political parties make efforts to create favourable conditions for credible early elections. The report obviously stresses the crucial importance of holding free and fair elections in full compliance with international standards and in accordance with the recommendations of the OSCE/ODIHR. Finally, the report considers it important, from a strategic point of view, to continue to support the country's progress towards accession to the Union and notes that the recommendation to open accession negotiations should depend on the full implementation of the June and July 2015 political agreement and on a significant step forward in implementing priority reforms to be implemented as a matter of urgency.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. This proposal recommends opening accession negotiations with Macedonia, which has been a candidate for EU membership since 2005 and has been constantly interrupted by this process as a result of political instability and lack of compliance with the requirements for EU membership. I voted in favour because I support Macedonia's accession to the EU and because this document conditions progress in its accession to significant progress in urgent reforms that are a priority for bringing macedonia into line with Community standards. However, I do not share the measures taken by the Macedonian Government during the refugee crisis. Unilateral decisions that have jeopardized security and in many cases violated the rights of refugees. The Macedonian authorities must respect and implement the Geneva Convention and work with the European institutions in this crisis. I also want the next elections on 24 April to be held fairly, freely and transparently. Macedonia has an opportunity in these elections to strengthen the democratic character of its institutions and meet the Copenhagen criteria in order to advance its accession to the EU.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the 2015 report on the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The country, which has been a candidate for EU membership for more than ten years, is one of the most advanced in terms of alignment with the acquis communautaire.  Despite the continuing dispute over the official name, which sees the country confront Greece, the young Republic has embarked on a path of détente that has allowed the development of bilateral relations with the Hellenic Republic. Strengthening stricter procedures for holding elections, promoting systemic reforms of the rule of law and fundamental rights and strengthening the role of parliament are decisive steps that will bring the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia closer to the EU and contribute to the consolidation of democracy.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the report as it does not reflect the country's real situation with regard to recoil in critical areas and the magnitude of breaches of the Copenhagen criteria. While reference is made to political problems, a lack of progress in fair election obligations, ongoing corruption, and a lack of accountability for the wiretapping scandal, the text could have been much more stark. The authorities of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia have not been able to avoid irregularities or in ensuring media independence.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this Resolution on the 2015 report on the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia urging Macedonia to break the political deadlock it is in, to hold free and fair elections soon, and to return to the path of reforms to begin negotiations on its access to the European Union. The country faces a critical moment as it has not only waited too long at the EU door as a candidate but has also faced the challenge of thousands of refugees at its borders, but the time has come to face new steps that will benefit all its citizens.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which is once again part of an irresponsible prospect of unlimited enlargement of the European Union. The drafters of this resolution, in particular, are attacking the Council, which once is not customary, has the common sense to prevent the progress of the country's accession process, in particular because of the unresolved conflict between it and Greece over its name. Indeed, it is incredible that the Euro-federalists are pushing hard for the integration into the EU of a country that is in open conflict with a state that is already a member. Moreover, the professorial tone used by Brussels to impose reforms on sovereign nations, and then to judge the quality of them, seem to me to be a true negation of the principles of freedom and independence! The Eurobeats are constantly trying to drown diversity in a process of uniformity of states that would then be at its helm. That the European Union can continue to give lessons in democracy to the rest of the world, even though it is the oligarchy most in need of democratic legitimacy, seems to me to be the pinnacle of bad faith.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2015 report on the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has some critical issues and some passages that I do not agree with, so I did not intend to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia submitted its application for EU membership in March 2004. Despite repeated requests for negotiations by the Commission and Parliament, the Council blocked the start because of the conflict over the country's name with Greece; conflict which should not be an obstacle to the official opening of negotiations and should be resolved as soon as possible in accordance with United Nations principles. This report, for which I voted in favour, considers the prospect of EU membership to be a great incentive to introduce reforms in the country and promote political stability, highlighting the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia as the most advanced candidate country in terms of the level of adaptation of the acquis. However, a number of problems persist in the accession process: lack of constructive dialogue between government and opposition, deteriorating media freedom, corruption and nepotism in public administration, and high unemployment rates. Greater efforts are needed to depoliticize the public administration and the judicial system and to combat corruption of the state apparatus and against discrimination against minorities such as Roma.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which discusses the 2015 report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The European Parliament believes that civil society must be well organised, but remains concerned about the difficult conditions in which it operates and the public attacks on civil society organisations by politicians and the media. Calls on the authorities not to discriminate against civil society organisations on any grounds, such as political affiliation, religious opinion or ethnic composition. Regrets, furthermore, that there is insufficient cooperation with civil society organisations on policy-making and legislative issues, both at central and local level. Calls on the authorities to encourage civil society organisations to participate actively, reviewing the entire electoral process. Furthermore, urges the Government to recognise the added value of civil society organisations in consultation with them in the legislative and policy-making process, to draw up an appropriate action plan for 2015-2017, to establish a cooperation council with civil society organisations, to facilitate the necessary dialogue and to involve civil society organisations in policy-making on a permanent and structured basis. Parliament also recalls that education and cultural training can help to ensure tolerance and promote reconciliation between different ethnic groups.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In its 2015 report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Parliament highlighted that recent political crises in the country show a lack of effective institutional checks and balances. According to the report, the only way out of this situation is the full implementation of the Przsino Political Convention. In line with this report, I draw attention to the importance of voting and its raising to its highest international standards, including the guarantee of free and fair voting procedures. Parliament has also identified further shortcomings in the area of media freedom and media reforms. However, the report rightly highlights the progress made, and welcomed the constructive rules on regional and international cooperation and high-level cooperation with neighbouring countries in order to develop the region. The country's NATO relationship can contribute to greater security and political stability in south-eastern Europe. However, the increase in elite migration, especially among young people, is worrying. The country's education system faces huge challenges and I would like to stress the need for a comprehensive analysis in this regard. It is essential to reduce the exodus of highly qualified and professionals.  To sum up, the 2015 report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia became a balanced report, the adoption of which I voted in favour of.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe it is important to continue negotiations with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia in order to enable the country to carry out the much-needed constitutional and economic reforms.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has made significant progress both in terms of democratic structural reforms and in its relationship with Greece and other neighbouring states. However, this progress cannot yet be considered sufficient: the practice of systematic interception of citizens, the control of the mass media, the boycott of oppositions together with a still widespread practice of clientelism at every institutional level, the high corruption of the political and bureaucratic system, both state and regional, disproportion in the use of force by military and police forces. , lead us to advise the Macedonian Government and people to continue with greater vigour the path of democratisation and development that they have embarked on.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Again, the 'no' vote is also our substantial opposition to further EU enlargements.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the 2015 report on the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. It is one of the candidate countries to join the European Union. Unfortunately, there are still strong tensions in the internal political situation, and there is a state of inter-ethnic tension throughout the country, unrest and clashes between police and demonstrators, which are occurring with increasing frequency.  Added to this is Macedonia's uncooperative approach to the ongoing migration emergency. The restrictive measures introduced by several Balkan countries, including Macedonia, are having the effect of blocking thousands of people in Greece.  The alignment of Macedonia with the decisions of the European Union is a key element in the process of European integration. I believe that it is difficult to support the application for membership of countries that have not clarified their basic strategic political choices.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report which is, on the whole, very good. Many issues have been addressed, a crucial one concerns the migration crisis.  The report recognises that FYROM is facing an unprecedented challenge (500 000 people in transit in 2015) and calls on the Commission to help the country manage its borders by giving Macedonia access to the Union's relevant instruments and programmes. The Macedonian authorities are also asked to avoid any kind of violence or the use of force that could put the lives of refugees and migrants at risk and, more generally, that any action taken is in line with EU values and respects human dignity.  The report also calls for an improvement, with EU help, in the country's receptivity and, at the same time, in improving coordination and the flow of information with neighbouring countries and EU Member States, with the aim of combating violations such as trafficking in human beings.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We vote against the report and recall that accession negotiations can only begin after the nomenclature has been resolved.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this because Parliament has highlighted that the political crises in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has shown the deficiency of an effective system of checks and balances in the institutions and the necessity to increase transparency and public accountability including adequate mechanisms of oversight of the main services and internal structures. Only the full implementation of the Pržino political agreement is a way out of the political stalemate. The Parliament underlines the necessity to prepare the elections to the highest international standards, including ensuring free and fair election procedures and enhancing media freedom, while expressing concern about the slow pace of the audit of the voters’ list and media reform.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The report presents a detailed, very comprehensive and factual diagnosis, touching all the essential points for future macedonian entry. Among the various problems identified, we highlight, for example, the problems that still persist with the independence of the judiciary and the weak supervision of the secret services. However, there are positive points, such as developments in the context of children's rights. In any case, I do not think this is the right time, or in the near future, for another enlargement of the Union. Which is why I abstain.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is committed through the implementation of new reforms to meet the requirements for access to the European Union. Unfortunately, however, much still needs to be done with regard to respect for fundamental rights, especially for women and minorities. In view of the goodwill of that country, I felt I had to vote in favour.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The prospect of EU membership is a major incentive for further reforms, particularly with regard to the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary and the fight against corruption. Unless these are eradicated from the system no further progress can effectively be registered on the basis of the enlargement Copenhagen criteria.   I welcome the source of hope for a prosperous future for young generations in fYROM and the positive response to Europe reflected in the polls induces political dialogue and to pursue efforts to restore public trust in fYROM institutions. I agree with the development of a designated training programme for public administration staff, something which the Commission can play a role in providing assistance.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report on progress in the process of EU membership of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, inter alia because it concerns the pending dispute with Greece on the name as a 'bilateral' issue, when I understand that this is an issue to be resolved within the framework of the United Nations and in accordance with international law. In addition, our group opposes the neoliberal agenda, the privatisation policies and the economic model of EU membership, which have proven to have catastrophic effects on the European population, so I voted against it.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report includes the latest developments in the country, notes the vote of the Macedonian Parliament on 23 February, which sets a new date for holding early parliamentary elections for 5 June 2016, but regrets, at the same time, that there was no consensus among all parties involved. The report makes, for the first time, a recommendation towards the opening of accession negotiations, conditional on the full implementation of the June/July 2015 political agreement (Pržino Agreement), as well as substantial progress on the implementation of urgent reform priorities. The report reiterates that bilateral issues should not be used to block the EU accession process, but should be addressed in a constructive spirit as soon as possible in the accession process, taking into account the principles and values of the UN and the European Union. Negotiations with the EU have a positive influence on efforts to resolve bilateral disputes, generating momentum and mobilisation for much-needed reforms, in particular with regard to the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary and the fight against corruption, strengthening multiethnic cohesion, and ensuring the credibility of the EU's enlargement policy.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Every year a report is prepared on the progress of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia on its path to integration into the European Union. It covers many areas of the country's internal and external m.in, such as the current political crisis and the ways out of it; previous elections in line with international OSCE/ODIHR standards and recommendations; the need to reform the judiciary, eliminate discrimination and achieve cohesion between different ethnic, national and religious communities; the lack of media freedom and the need for urgent reform of the public media to ensure an independent regulatory body. After examining the document, I supported it in the vote.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report outlines the reform efforts of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and the areas that need to be given further attention by implementing the relevant strategies and agreements. The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is preparing for Parliamentary elections on 5 June 2016. The European Commission made recommendations this year which support the beginning of accession talks, ‘conditional’ on the implementation of a 2015 EU-brokered political agreement - the Pržino agreement. In light of this, I voted in favour of the European Parliament’s 2015 report which recommended, for the first time, that the EU open accession negotiations with Macedonia conditional upon the full implementation of the Pržino agreement. Since this report highlights fundamental issues, such as better gender equality policies amongst others, I voted in favour of it.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report and its support for the improvements and political and judicial reforms in Macedonia as it continues accession talks begun in 2012. Macedonia’s progress is one part of the ongoing efforts to increase stability in the Western Balkans, which is a key goal for the UK in its engagement with the region.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. In this resolution, the European Parliament stresses that the political crises in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia reflect dysfunctions in the balance of power between institutions, and the need to increase transparency and public accountability through adequate control mechanisms.  We also call for elections to be held in accordance with the rules of procedure and freedom of the press. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution on the 2015 report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. As far as the fight against corruption is concerned, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia must not relax its efforts to prevent and punish corruption. The same is true of the fight against radicalisation, where a strategy and action plan to prevent and combat radicalisation is needed. Faced with an unprecedented migration flow in 2015, the country has been able to act as a responsible partner to the European Union and implement effective border management measures.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the 2015 report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Parliament highlighted that political crises in the country show a lack of an effective institutional system of checks and balances. The only way out of this situation is the full implementation of the Przsino Political Convention. The report draws attention to the importance of voting and its raising to its highest international standards, including guaranteeing free and fair voting procedures. Parliament has also identified further shortcomings in the area of media freedom and media reforms. However, the report also highlights the progress made, and welcomed the constructive rules on regional and international cooperation and a high level of cooperation with neighbouring countries in order to develop the region. The country's NATO relationship can contribute to greater security and political stability in south-eastern Europe. To sum up, the 2015 report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia became a balanced report, which I voted in favour of.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, although we cannot talk about any progress in the past year.
