The situation in the country is extremely difficult – Macedonia has fallen into the most serious political crisis in years, fundamental human rights of the Bulgarian community are violated, there is a strong politicization of the judiciary and public administration, the media is controlled by the ruling party, the reforms are stalled, and the pre-accession process itself – frozen.  Despite the problems in the country, I support its aspiration for membership of the European Union, because European integration is an extremely demanding and reform-promoting process. Although I would like to see more texts related to the problems of the Bulgarian community in Macedonia, I am pleased with the final version of the resolution reached, which included many of my proposals and established formulations acknowledging the existence of a community with Bulgarian self-consciousness in the country. In addition, we have achieved great success in developing the part on relations with Bulgaria, including formulations encouraging the conclusion of a good neighbourly contract with Bulgaria, the joint celebrations of events and personalities of general history and the establishment of expert committees on history and education.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Negative, because when the EU intervenes in states that are at war or generally unstable, it only manages to create more problems and migrants to Europe.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. "The resolution addresses, among other things, the difficult situation on the Macedonian-Greek border and emphasises the importance of cooperation in Europe in order to resolve the situation we are now facing. I therefore also voted in favour of proposals to strengthen the humanitarian efforts required in the situations that arise when countries close their borders. I also believe that we must seriously consider the consequences of closed borders for our responsibilities under international law, which is why I voted in favour of Amendment No 14.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The prospect of EU membership of the Republic of Macedonia is an important incentive for further reforms, including on the rule of law, independence of the judiciary and the fight against corruption, as well as a source of hope for a prosperous future for the young generations. The process of this republic takes 10 years of existence and is one of the most advanced. I welcome the fact that a number of obligations under the Agreement have been fulfilled within the agreed deadlines and objectives, but I regret the tendency to delay some of the commitments as well as some setbacks. I agree that all parties place the interests of the country above party interests.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a report that is part of the follow-up of the proposal for eu membership by the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. There is an unstable political situation in this country. This report is still present with the divergence with Greece related to the designation of the country that remains soured by nationalist rhetoric, to which the EU wants to add interference, which instead of bringing peoples away. This issue should not be resolved with pressure, but under international law and under the auspices of the UN.  There are also very present interferences in the country's politics, particularly at the political, economic, financial and social level. It should be underlined the EU's proposal for the country to pursue a policy of budgetary discipline, in the image of the EU Member States, and to strengthen the internal electricity market which it in other words means, liberalisation. Alignment with EU foreign policy is another of the impositions, as is the process of NATO membership. The border control policy to respond to the migration crisis is partly praised, which deserves our deepest repudiation.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I welcome the fact that the leaders of the country's most powerful political party are committed to strengthening good neighbourly relations on the basis of the Agreement of 2 June 2015, thus moving slowly towards membership of the European Union. I consider it essential that urgent reform priorities on systemic reforms in the field of the rule of law and fundamental rights are met without delay in the interests of the democratic process. Public authorities and civil society should take appropriate measures to achieve reconciliation in order to overcome differences between and within different ethnic and national groups.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because, in this time of crisis, there is no immediate need to enlarge the EU to other countries.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the 2015 progress report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, because there are several misplaced comments and vagueness and it does not mention at all the most important, which is the name issue and that this comes from the attitude of the Macedonians.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I take note of the decision by the Macedonian Parliament on 23 February to set a new date to hold early parliamentary elections on 5 June 2016. The fact that there was no consensus with the opposition party is highly regrettable and represents a missed political opportunity. Further media reforms and inter-party talks may now be delayed until after the elections. I strongly believe all the political parties in Macedonia should make efforts to create the conditions for credible early elections and that an all-party agreement remains essential to fulfil all elements of the Pržino Agreement. Moreover, substantial progress on the implementation of the urgent reform priorities has to be made. Bilateral issues should not be used to obstruct the EU accession process but should be addressed in a constructive spirit as early as possible in the accession process, taking into account the principles and values of the UN and of the EU.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Macedonia is located in the middle of the EU and is not only of strategic importance for its neighbours. For years, there has been a broad majority in favour of EU membership. Further reforms on the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary and the curbing of corruption are still needed to achieve this objective.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the report as it does not reflect the country's real situation with regard to recoil in critical areas and the magnitude of breaches of the Copenhagen criteria. While reference is made to political problems, a lack of progress in fair election obligations, ongoing corruption, and a lack of accountability for the wiretapping scandal, the text could have been much more stark. The authorities of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia have not been able to avoid irregularities or in ensuring media independence.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. I welcome the European reform process in Western Balkans. It has, through Mr Vajgl, played an important role in the mediation efforts between government and opposition to end the domestic political crisis.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Macedonia is referred to as a reliable partner at a time when it is taking reprehensible unilateral actions such as closing borders and using force against refugees. Macedonia should be called upon to respect international treaties on refugees and to guarantee the possibility of safe and permanent transit for all people in need of international protection regardless of their origin. In addition, the issue of Greece-Macedonia relations is neither a bilateral issue nor limited to the nomenclature. It is an unresolved international and regional problem that must be solved under the auspices of the UN. Resolving it is a prerequisite for good neighbourly relations, which are a key element in the enlargement process. For these reasons, we consider this vote to be an appropriate position.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Macedonia has been a candidate country for EU membership since December 2005. Its integration process has been somewhat stalled in recent years, however. While Macedonia’s membership has been backed by the European Parliament and the Commission, the Council has blocked its progression as a result of the naming conflict with Greece. The recent political crisis in Macedonia which came about as a result of a wire—tapping scandal and the intimidating of journalists is another factor in Macedonia’s lack of progression in EU membership. This has caused considerable tension in the run up to Parliamentary elections this June. I support this report’s reiteration that in order to ensure continuity of support to the Macedonian progress towards EU membership, Macedonia must prepare these elections to the highest international standards and support the right to freedom of speech while also improve its overall policy alignment with those of the EU’s.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this motion for a resolution on the 2015 Report. I agree with the resolution, but abstained on Amendment 17 as Ireland is a neutral country.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the recommendation to open EU accession negotiations for Macedonia, as long as authorities will align themselves with the implementation of the urgent reform priorities. I believe that a great first step in this direction would be a cross-party effort to organise credible early elections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ By voting, I supported the progress report of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia for 2015, as the EU membership negotiation process should be a major boost to reforms, especially when it comes to the rule of law, judicial independence and the fight against corruption. I agree with the allegations in the adopted Resolution, which welcomes the agreement of the four most important political forces from 2 June and 15 July 2015, urging political parties to take responsibility towards citizens, calling on all parties to put the interests of the country ahead of party interests, and highlighting the need to prepare elections to the highest international standards. It emphasises parliament's key role in the country's democratic development, highlighting concerns that Macedonia's public administration remains subject to political influence. The report highlights concerns about widespread corruption, particularly in state and local government, public procurement and the financing of political parties, and welcomes the strengthening of the capacity of the police and the Public Prosecutor's Office to fight organised crime. It also notes the contribution to efforts to combat Islamic radicalism and notes that coexistence among ethnic groups remains fragile.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the one hand is an opportunity for further EU interference in Macedonian affairs. Several amendments are in favour of this, and others in particular are in favour of a pro-immigration policy. On the other hand, I am opposed to the logic of enlargement ever further east. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the 2015 report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The country can now claim entry into the European Union, as the obstacles that presented themselves have been overcome. The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is now trying to break the political deadlock and hold free elections while continuing the reforms it has pledged to take in the July 2015 agreement. I agree with this text which rewards the efforts of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, which has been a responsible partner in the refugee crisis. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting against the resolution on FYROM. Basically, there are some important points, but the strong emphasis on the Euro-Atlantic integration of Macedonia is, in my opinion, going in the wrong direction, because it would only further worsen the EU's tense relationship with the non-EU states of the former Eastern Bloc.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it urges the country’s political leadership to implement the June/July 2015 settlement agreement in full and deliver urgent reforms. This would help the country to overcome its political crisis, prepare for early free and fair elections and pave the way for the start of EU accession negotiations.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Macedonia is a republic that was one of the few not interested in the break-up of Yugoslavia. It is a poor Balkan country hit by mass immigration in recent decades, especially of the Albanian population. We therefore logically encounter the same problems here as in Albania or in the illegally seceded provinces of Serbia, Kosovo and Metochie. The high unemployment and non-anchoring of part of the population, together with the issue of national diversity, is complemented by a classic oriental corrupt atmosphere and poorly developed infrastructure. In the country there are very good conditions for the development of agriculture, but very little developed industry. In the context of the refugee crisis, it is macedonia that is trying to put a dog's head on. This is despite the fact that the conditions for participation in the Schengen area do not apply to Macedonia, but to Greece, Hungary, Slovenia and Austria. It is these states that should identify arrivals at their borders and, at detention points, so-called hotspots, decide who is and who is not "entitled" to asylum, while agreeing whether the country to which these immigrants are going will accept them. Some of the measures taken so far under PRESSURE from the EU – e.g. merging municipalities – are completely meaningless, in other proposals it is necessary to ensure that they are implemented with funds (environment). Macedonia deserves our help, but also increased attention regarding the actual application of the newly adopted laws.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the 2015 report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, for the simple reason that I oppose the further enlargements of the European Union. The more we want to expand the EU, the more problems we create for all the states concerned. This obsession with permanent and systematic enlargement must be put to an end.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because I am opposed to any enlargement of the EU, including with regard to the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. This resolution is also interfering in the internal affairs of that state.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report on progress in the process of EU membership of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, inter alia because it concerns the pending dispute with Greece on the name as a 'bilateral' issue, when I understand that this is an issue to be resolved within the framework of the United Nations and in accordance with international law. In addition, our group opposes the neoliberal agenda, the privatisation policies and the economic model of EU membership, which have proven to have catastrophic effects on the European population, so I voted against it.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The EU is meddling in Macedonia's domestic affairs. She also argues that Macedonia wants to join the EU and it is the way to prosperity for it. It encourages Macedonia to depend on subsidies – "considers that the EU must facilitate grant allocation procedures and increase funding for research and innovation" – and ridiculously "encourages the Macedonian Youth and Sport Agency to recognise the role and support of the National Youth Council and to establish a permanent mechanism for cooperation with this body; welcomes the development of a national youth strategy for 2016-2025 and stresses the need to allocate appropriate resources to its implementation." The European Union has no say in macedonia's Youth Agency's cooperation with the National Youth Council.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Macedonia has a lot of work ahead of it in improving the rule of law, reforming the judiciary, fighting corruption, media freedom, but other countries have done so much better in the negotiation process. I supported this Parliament report, which clearly shows that Macedonia is ready for negotiations, so it is important to start them as soon as possible.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing – Macedonia is one of the most advanced EU candidate countries in terms of adopting and incorporating the acquis into the country's legal system. The report assesses the economic, economic and political state of the country, including the country's foreign policy. In addition to the internal problems associated with the existence of several ethnicities, minorities and religions, this country, like other European countries, is exposed to problems linked to globalisation and its effects. Unemployment is 31%, mainly affecting young people.  This is linked to their departure from the country for work. Macedonia is particularly negatively affected by the impact of the refugee crisis, as it has become a transit route for refugees. A particular foreign policy problem is territorial disputes with Bulgaria and Greece.  With a view to integrating Macedonia into the EU, the Commission needs to closely monitor the reforms adopted while further strongly supporting the country's democratic processes.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution on the 2015 report on Macedonia, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 9/3/2016, and because Skopje has for several days closed its borders, resulting in more than 15,000 refugees being stranded in Idomeni. This action by Skopje violates international law and in particular the 1951 Geneva Convention on Refugees, as UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon said. However, the Commission has not taken any action to force Skopje to comply with the obligations arising from international law. Skopje also a few days ago violated greece's territorial integrity by throwing flash grenades, tear gas and chemicals into Greek territory in order to repel the stranded refugees, so as not to approach the barbed wire of shame and shame they have raised.  Furthermore, the rapporteur, in his report, must use the term 'YROM' and not 'Macedonia', which he wrongly uses, in violation of the UN resolutions recognised by Skopje under the name FYROM. I declare once again that I am strongly opposed to any possible accession of Skopje to the EU.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution notes that, according to the June/July 2015 Agreement, the new government was to be sworn in on 15 January 2016, 100 days before the agreed date for early parliamentary elections; takes note of the vote by the Macedonian Parliament on 23 February 2016 to set a new date for early parliamentary elections of 5 June 2016; regrets, however, that an opportunity was missed to find a consensus between all parties; recalls that these elections will in themselves be an important test for the democratic process of the country; insists that all the political parties make efforts to create the conditions for credible early elections and underlines the paramount importance of these elections being free, fair, in full compliance with international standards and in line with OSCE/ODIHR recommendations.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is making real progress towards reforms that meet the requirements for access to the European Union. As a member of the LIBE and FEMM Committees, however, I would like to stress that FYROM still needs to make progress towards improving the situation of civil liberties and women's rights. In addition, FYROM needs to improve its relationship with minority groups. Nevertheless, noting fyrom's progress, I voted in favour of this motion.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is making steady progress in a line that facilitates its accession to the EU. My support for the 2015 report on the situation in this country, with my hope that work will be made in line with political and economic reforms to increase relations between Macedonia and the EU.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the 2015 report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and its progress towards EU membership. I support the provisions contained in the resolution calling for the independence and capacity of the judiciary, the police, the public prosecutor's office and the State Commission for the Prevention of Corruption to be strengthened. I also share the position that political parties and civil society organisations should step up their efforts to strengthen coexistence and dialogue between different ethnic, national and religious communities and to respect the activities of civil democratic organisations.  While the EP resolution welcomes the creation of market economy conditions, simplifying the regulatory framework, it points out that the poor implementation of the rule of law, the ineffective judiciary, the large-scale shadow economy and corruption pose significant barriers to business.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it is necessary to maintain adequate checks and balances together with increased transparency over internal structures.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the one hand is an opportunity for further EU interference in Macedonian affairs. Several amendments are in favour of this, and others in particular are in favour of a pro-immigration policy. In addition, I oppose the logic of enlargement ever further east. As a result, I voted against this text.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that draws attention to the work that the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (fYROM) needs to do to ensure free and fair election procedures and protect media freedom whilst also commending the positive role that it is playing in to foster regional cooperation.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has made European and NATO integration its strategic priority. This perspective should be an incentive for the government to accelerate the necessary reforms.  In the annual evaluation report, the EP takes stock of the progress made in the accession process. Relations with Greece have been subject to a slight thaw, although it remains appropriate to find a mutually acceptable solution to the protracted name issue. Both countries are committed to working together on education, culture, energy and domestic affairs.  Applying for an EU ticket implies that one subscribes to Europe's core values. This means that the media in FYROM must be able to do their editorial work independently and freely, without any political interference. In order to tackle air and water pollution, FYROM will need to make significant efforts. At the same time, it is necessary to align the energy market with European energy policy, including an ambitious growth path for renewable energy.  In order to ensure a sustainable political democracy, it will be necessary, in addition to organising transparent elections and organising a genuine parliamentary political culture, to eliminate widespread corruption at all levels of government.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing — The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (Macedonia) has been a candidate for EU membership since December 2005. Since then, Macedonia has managed to implement a number of reforms that have made it one of the most advanced countries in the south-eastern European region. However, the fact remains that both the political elite and society still have a lot of work to do on its European path. It is essential that an effective system of brakes and counterweights is in place in the country, essential for a properly functioning democracy. No less important element is ensuring the respective scope of powers of the Special Prosecutor's Office in order to combat effectively the persistent high level of corruption in public institutions. In this context, it is crucial what political reality can be created after the early parliamentary elections scheduled for June 2016. All political parties must make efforts to ensure that these elections are free, fair and in full compliance with international standards. In the interests of good neighbourly relations and fruitful regional cooperation, it is desirable that Macedonia and Greece be able to reach a final agreement on a long-standing problem with the name of the country, and I see the resumption of bilateral visits at foreign ministers' level after more than a decade of delay as a positive step forward. At the same time, I believe that this conflict cannot under any circumstances constitute an instrument preventing Macedonia's progress internationally and be a source of political frustration. I am voting in favour of the proposal tabled.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the 2015 report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia because it is important to stress that all the political parties make efforts to create the conditions for credible early elections and that an all-party agreement remains essential to fulfil all elements of the Pržino Agreement. The report includes the most recent developments in the country: it takes note of the vote by the Macedonian Parliament on 23 February to set a new date to hold early parliamentary elections on 5 June 2016 but regrets that there was no consensus between all parties. The report for the first time makes the recommendation to open accession negotiations conditional upon the full implementation of the June/July political (Pržino) agreement and substantial progress on the implementation of the Urgent Reform Priorities. The report reiterates that bilateral issues should not be used to obstruct the EU accession process but should be addressed in a constructive spirit as early as possible in the accession process, taking into account the principles and values of the UN and of the EU.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia since its independence in 1991 has faced some opposition from the Greek side, in particular its nomenclature.  In 2004 the FYROM applied for membership of the Union, achieving candidate status in 2005. However, to this day, negotiations have not yet begun and it is predicted that it will only be possible if the government complied with the quadrilateral agreement of June/July 2015.   I am in favour of this report, which calls for negotiations to begin as soon as possible. The country faces problems of political instability and violations of freedom of expression, the media, the independence of the judiciary, which can be solved with the support of the Union.  Despite the controversy I believe it is extremely important that we support the political, social and economic development of the people of the FYROM. Nor should we forget that the country has faced an unprecedented influx of refugees passing through its territory. The solution found must also be to support this country.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. In addition to the interference in the affairs of the countries of the former Yugoslavia that envelops this text, the resolution is full of pro-accession recitals, which will facilitate enlargements; what we're opposing. That is why I voted against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has been a candidate for membership of the European Union for ten years. This resolution underlines the undeniable progress that the State has made over the past decade. However, it still points to shortcomings, particularly in its political system and culture, which do not allow it to claim immediate membership of the European Union, which must be vigilant about respect for all negotiating chapters. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. The resolution highlights the progress, shortcomings, and objectives of the government and society of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia during 2015. In particular, it highlights the national and European political issues of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. I welcome and support the resolution as adopted by the European Parliament.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution that underlines the strategic importance to ensure continuity of support to the Macedonian progress towards EU membership and stresses the area that need improvement such as public administration, transparency and the enhancement of professionalism, neutrality and independence at all levels.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I support this report as it is in the interest of both the EU and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to ensure continued support of Macedonian progress towards EU membership. The agreement on 11 confidence-building measures with Greece is encouraging.  However, the findings of the Rapporteur also suggest that there is still much scope for improvement in areas of media freedom, autonomy of the Special Prosecutor, oversight and control of intelligence services as well as corruption in state and local administration, party financing and public procurement. Finally, to help cope with the big pressure of migration the Commission should support the strengthening of border management capacity and enable the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to access relevant EU instruments and programmes to handle the migration flow.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. Although the report contains a number of important points, it emphasises too much the importance of Macedonia's Euro-Atlantic integration, which in turn would only further worsen the EU's tense relationship with the non-EU states of the former Eastern Bloc. I voted against this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is important to maintain the prospect of Macedonia's accession to the EU, but the country has a lot of work to do to do so. Among other things, the political impasse must be ended and that early parliamentary elections in June are free and fair.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The integration of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia - the official name of the country overlooked in the "progress report for 2015" - into the European Union aims to strengthen European capital in the Balkans as an energy corridor, an investment field and a geostrategic front of confrontation with Russian interests. The people of the country will pay even harder for the plans of the domestic bourgeoisie. The process of integrating FYROM began with war, the dissolution of Yugoslavia, protectorate states of NATO and the European Union. Today, as a result of its EU integration, FYROM has made the unacceptable closure of its borders, with a savage crackdown on refugees trapped in Greece. In this barbarity, the EU also puts its signature on its decisions. The policy it reproduces in the European Parliament and the so-called "Friends of Macedonia" group cultivates ethno-religious divisions, altruisms, challenges of sovereign rights, turning the Balkans literally into a "powder keg". It turns out that the EU, urban governments and the system they serve mean exploitation, poverty, competition and war. That is why the peoples need to overthrow them by paving the way for a society without exploitation, with them in charge of their own country.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On the basis of the political agreement signed between June and July 2015 between the EU and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, it is noted that important acts have been adopted on time and in accordance with the intended objectives. However, some other obligations are not yet subject to urgent reforms. In calling on the Macedonian Government to make the required changes as soon as possible, I would vote in favour of the

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Macedonia has met all the conditions for its negotiations with the EU to open. Of all the candidate countries, it has made the utmost efforts to adapt its legislation to the acquis. Macedonia is among the five European countries experiencing the highest economic growth. Its role in the migrant crisis is an indication that Macedonia is guarding the EU's external borders. Further delaying the opening of negotiations can only deepen the political crisis Macedonia is in due to opposition demands for early elections, which were then postponed again due to opposition demands. The mediation of EU representatives in this crisis has not been successful, and with the EU's inconsistent policy towards Macedonia, the EU is losing credibility by setting discriminatory standards that are contrary to already established and adopted rules. I note that it is important for the political stability and security of this part of Europe that Macedonia join nato as soon as possible. I therefore call on all EU Member States that are also NATO members to support Macedonia's entry into this alliance. The outstanding bilateral issues other states have with Macedonia must not be an obstacle on Macedonia's path to Euro-Atlantic integration. In this regard, I also call on Greece to join the dialogue with Macedonia in the spirit of European values and principles and stop blocking its European path.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Republic of Macedonia has been an EU candidate country for ten years, still considered one of the candidates to have made the most progress in aligning legislation with the acquis of the Union. With Parliament's support, the Commission has repeatedly called for the opening of accession negotiations and stressed the importance of negotiations as a key driver of the necessary reform process. Maintaining the status quo would only multiply the problems facing the country, but the real danger is that they become chronic or even spill over its borders. The EU can prevent such scenarios if member states finally give Skopje genuine support to continue on a path that has been blocked for too long.  Equal effort is needed to get out of the refugee crisis in which Macedonia is one of the most exposed countries. Macedonia is a geographically small, multi-ethnic country, but plagued by serious internal rifts in a turbulent geopolitical environment. Problems, such as accusations of illegal eavesdropping on thousands of citizens, threats against journalists, widespread corruption and the frequent intertwining of party and state activities have resulted in deep divisions in society and the absence of political dialogue. That is why delaying agreed reforms, despite formal political consensus, would further deepen distrust and delay the European perspective. In conclusion, I stress the need to prepare elections according to the highest international standards, including ensuring free and fair electoral procedures.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This is a report which is part of the process of monitoring the proposal to join the European Union by the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, a country which maintains a political unstable situation. The report continues to see the divergence with Greece related to the country's designation, to which the European Union adds a position of interference which, instead of bringing peoples closer together, drives them away. This issue should not be resolved with pressure, but under international law and under the auspices of the UN.  There are also very present interferences in the country's politics, particularly at the political, economic, financial and social level. It should be underlined the European Union's proposal for the country to follow a policy of budgetary discipline in the image of the countries of the Union and to strengthen the internal electricity market, which, in other words, means the liberalisation of prices and services. Alignment with the European Union's foreign policy is another of the impositions, as well as the process of joining NATO. The border control policy to respond to the migration crisis is partly praised, which we reject.  We voted against it.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the 2015 report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. I did so because I support this country's membership of the European Union. Although Macedonia is currently more plagued than some Member States by the migration problem, it is important that macedonia does not stop its efforts to implement the necessary reforms. It is not possible for a state with significant shortcomings in the field of the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary and the media, or the fight against corruption to become a full member of the 28-member European grouping. I do not support mere bilateral pressures between Member States that hinder Macedonia in the accession process. By this I am referring to the unexplained question of the official name of Macedonia. On the contrary, I support a constructive approach to finding a solution. I firmly believe that all relevant political parties can find a way to create an optimal environment for the organisation of elections and that they will respect the provisions of the political agreement concluded in July last year with the mediation assistance of the European Union. I support Macedonia's progress towards membership of the European Union, but I must strongly point out that this support also requires considerable effort to be made by Macedonia's representatives themselves.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, despite the progress made in starting EU accession negotiations, must break the current political deadlock, prepare for early, free and fair elections, and implement the necessary reforms.  However, we must recognise that the country is facing a critical moment with the challenge of thousands of refugees at its borders. I therefore hope, with today's vote in favour, that the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia will be able to make all the necessary efforts for the EU accession process.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The annual report on the progress of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia on its path to integration with the European Union examines a number of internal and external policy areas of the country, including: the current political crisis and the way out of it, the issues of early elections in line with international standards and recommendations of the OSCE/ODIHR. The report also concerns the full implementation of urgent priorities and the submission by the Commission to Parliament and the Council after early elections; the need for judicial reform; discrimination and achieving cohesion between different ethnic, national and religious communities; the lack of media freedom and the need for urgent reform of the public media to ensure an independent regulatory body; regional cooperation and strengthening good neighbourly relations; progress in solving the 'name problem' with Greece; the conclusion of negotiations on a treaty on friendship, good neighbourliness and cooperation with Bulgaria and the need to improve the alignment of EU foreign policy. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of adopting the 2015 report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, to encourage the country to make the necessary reforms. At a time when the country is currently going through a difficult political situation, the elections scheduled for 5 June 2016 will have to be free, democratic and peaceful.  In the context of the migration crisis, the country must be supported by the European Commission because it, like other European states, faces unprecedented flows of migrants.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution was tabled following statements by the Council and the Commission on the 2015 Report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. I voted in favour of this document because it contains the need for macedonia's four main parties to engage in political dialogue and to continue efforts to restore public confidence in the institutions in order to maintain political stability, speed up the country's reform programme and, consequently, ensure the Euro-Atlantic integration of the country. To this end, recommendations are made with which I agree and highlight: (1) the importance of the leaders of the main parties seeking to strengthen good neighbourly relations as a determining factor in bringing the country closer to the EU; (2) the need for better budgetary discipline; (3) the importance of freedom and independence of the media as a fundamental value of the EU; (4) improving the overall level of alignment with EU foreign policy; and (5) the opening of NATO accession negotiations, which could contribute to increased security and political stability in South-East Europe. In view of the foregoing, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The country has been a candidate for eu union for ten years and is regarded as one of the most advanced candidates. The Commission, the Council and Parliament agree that maintaining the positive recommendation for the country's membership is dependent on the full implementation of significant progress in implementing urgent reform priorities. The recent political crisis has shown that macedonian institutions do not have an effective system of checks and balances and that transparency and public accountability need to be increased, including through appropriate supervisory mechanisms for major internal services and structures. Critical issues of the reform process include political interference in the media, the judiciary and public administration, as well as corruption.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia submitted its application for EU membership in March 2004. Despite repeated requests for negotiations by the Commission and Parliament, the Council blocked the start because of the conflict over the country's name with Greece; conflict which should not be an obstacle to the official opening of negotiations and should be resolved as soon as possible in accordance with United Nations principles. This report, for which I voted in favour, considers the prospect of EU membership to be a great incentive to introduce reforms in the country and promote political stability, highlighting the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia as the most advanced candidate country in terms of the level of adaptation of the acquis. However, a number of problems persist in the accession process: lack of constructive dialogue between government and opposition, deteriorating media freedom, corruption and nepotism in public administration, and high unemployment rates. Greater efforts are needed to depoliticize the public administration and the judicial system and to combat corruption of the state apparatus and against discrimination against minorities such as Roma.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. We called on the political parties of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM) on Thursday (March 10th) to "hold as soon as possible all their commitments" related to the political agreement of 2 June and 15 July 2015, "in a comprehensive, constructive and timely manner, and in a spirit of negotiation". The text of the resolution stresses that an "agreement between all parties remains essential to implement all the elements" of the agreement "which would put the country back on the path to a Euro-Atlantic perspective". It thus calls on political parties to "constructively engage in political dialogue and to continue their efforts to restore public confidence in the institutions, so as to preserve political stability and accelerate the reform agenda". Priority urgent reforms include media and assembly freedom, public administration, the rule of law and fundamental rights, the judiciary and the fight against corruption.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report. Macedonia is an important neighbour of the EU seeking to become a member. The EU's enlargement objective is to ensure that future Member States are already well prepared to participate in the single market, respect human rights and freedoms, and withstand competitive pressure on their economies in the EU. The EU enlargement process will not be stopped, even if it is not possible, which is the legal foundation of the Founding Treaties, and for this reason we must all strive for the new Members to be properly prepared. The Commission therefore has an important role to play in monitoring how candidate countries are preparing for EU membership and, where appropriate, in assisting or transmitting knowledge of all the worrying processes, some of which are also mentioned in the report under consideration.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this follow-up report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM) for 2015. Each year, Parliament adopts a report on the candidate states for EU membership, including FYROM, a candidate country since 2005.  There is an urgent need for the FYROM government to implement the political agreement adopted in June 2015 and the resulting reforms. It is essential for the democratic process that priority systemic reforms in the area of the rule of law and fundamental rights be carried out without delay. This would help the country emerge from the political crisis and prepare for free elections, which have been set for 5 June 2016. This resolution calls on the Commission to support FYROM in its reforms but also in the management of the refugee crisis. Finally, the text calls on FYROM to combat widespread corruption, which affects local and state governments, public procurement and the financing of political parties.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the report as it does not reflect the country's real situation with regard to recoil in critical areas and the magnitude of breaches of the Copenhagen criteria. While reference is made to political problems, a lack of progress in fair election obligations, ongoing corruption, and a lack of accountability for the wiretapping scandal, the text could have been much more stark. The authorities of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia have not been able to avoid irregularities or in ensuring media independence.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. It is important to support the political developments taking place in Macedonia. A cooperation agreement will strengthen political institutions and promote human rights. That is why I support the agreement.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the 2015 report on the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia because of the need to address the political crisis. This is reflected in the lack of an effective system of checks and balance satisclosed by the need to create transparency and public accountability, particularly with regard to services and internal structures. The parliamentary elections in Macedonia, which is both an EU and NATO candidate, will take place in April 2016 and will be held according to the highest international standards from the point of view of the European Parliament, ensuring free and equal elections while preserving media freedom.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report as it makes credible recommendations to open accession negotiations on the condition of the full implementation of the political agreement in Pržino last summer as well as make substantial progress on the implementation of the urgent reform priorities. The report reiterates that bilateral issues should not be used to obstruct the accession process to the EU, but should be addressed in a spirit that is constructive and as early as possible take into account the principles and values of the EU and the Un in its accession process. It is important that all political parties in the FYROM make an effort towards creating the conditions for credible early elections and that an all-party agreement remains essential.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I abstained in the case of the European Parliament resolution on Macedonia in 2015. I share the Positive View of the European Parliament on the progress made by Macedonia, as well as the call for the need to continue reform efforts in the country. However, I cannot agree with the pressure exerted by the EU to promote the LGBTI agenda. That is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the 2015 report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia because it exhaustively describes political and social developments in the country, while at the same time focusing on the necessity of improving professionalism, neutrality and independence at all levels of public administration. The report calls for accountability of both the government and the opposition and for ensuring sustainable political dialogue and co-operation, which are important for the democratic development of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The inclusion of expert opinions of NGOs is very important in this process, and media freedom and expression are one of the fundamental values of the European Union. I also believe that in addition to democratic objectives, it is important to achieve energy goals, in particular energy efficiency targets and modernising public transport with neighbouring countries for which initial plans have been presented.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Macedonia has been a candidate country for EU membership for 10 years and has made considerable progress in implementing reforms during this time. At present, the country is struggling with an unprecedented influx of refugees through its territory, so cooperation with the EU must now also be intensified. The progress report notes the progress made in improving respect for children's rights, but concerns are raised by inter-ethnic coexistence, which is still fragile. It is therefore necessary to promote an inclusive and tolerant multi-ethnic and multi-religious society. Macedonia has achieved a GDP increase of 3.9%, but concerns are linked to high unemployment, which is 27.4%, and the chances of being employed mainly for young people and women are very low. For this reason, there are also concerns about the increasing brain drain, especially in the case of young people, which is why a reform of the education system with links to practice and labour market needs is needed.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 The country has been a candidate country for membership of the Union for 10 years. As opinion polls show, its citizens fully support their country's accession to the Union. Despite the many major advances that have taken place in the country, some key issues for its accession to the Union remain unresolved. These include, in particular, systemic reforms in the field of the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM) has been a candidate country for eu accession for ten years. During this time, it has become one of the most developed candidates and has achieved a high level of alignment with EU legislation and rules. But now FYROM is at a foreroad. Fyrom is in deep political crisis as it prepares for early parliamentary elections because of last year's government wiretapping scandal. At the same time, a great deal of political control over the media and the judiciary prevails. A higher level of reform is also needed in the area of electoral law and democracy. Meanwhile, the prospect of EU membership remains one of the main incentives for continuing the relatively successful reform work so far. It is therefore crucial that we support FYROM in its ongoing reform process, especially in the area of respect for the rule of law and the fight against corruption. I therefore welcome Parliament's decision to involve FYROM in strategies for regional cooperation and strengthening neighbourly relations, which is also an essential condition for resolving the dispute with Greece and getting closer to the EU. As part of the deteriorating security situation in Europe, I support FYROM's efforts to join NATO.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. –in 2012 Macedonia has been a candidate country for EU membership for ten years and is considered one of the candidates who has made the greatest progress in aligning legislation with the acquis of the Union. Opinion polls show that EU membership has considerable public support. With Parliament's support, the Commission has repeatedly called for the opening of accession negotiations and stressed the importance of negotiations as a key driver of the necessary reform process. I welcome the commitment of the leaders of the largest political parties to the agreement of 2 June 2015 in working to strengthen good-social relations as a key element for bringing the state closer to the European Union.  I also hold an important 3.9% increase in GDP in real terms in the first quarter of 2015, but I express concern about the continued high unemployment of 27.4% and poor labour market participation, especially for women and young people.  I would emphasise the importance of media freedom and independence and expertise and impartiality in public administration as one of the fundamental values of the EU and the foundations of any democracy. Negotiations with the European Union can only have a favourable effect on efforts to resolve bilateral disputes, while also launching and encouraging much-needed reforms, in particular as regards the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary and the fight against corruption, as well as ensuring the credibility of the EU enlargement policy.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The prospects for MEMBERSHIP in the European Union are a major boost to reforms in Macedonia, especially in terms of the rule of law, judicial independence and the fight against corruption. Corruption is a serious problem in Macedonia, which is present in state and local governments. Macedonia is considered the country that has made the most progress in comparing legislation with the acquis of the Union. Bilateral issues should not be used to disrupt the EU accession process. More transparency is needed in Macedonian institutions as well as more media freedom. Urgent media reform is needed to ensure an independent regulatory body and objective and professional reporting. Parliament in the country plays a key role for democratic development and political dialogue needs to be established. Also, authorities and civil society should take appropriate measures to achieve reconciliation to overcome divisions between the country's different ethnic groups. Macedonia's contribution to regional efforts to combat radical Islamism should be commended. I support this report because I believe that the measures outlined in this report are good guidelines for Macedonia's further rapprochement with the European Union. I also believe that Macedonia's membership in Euro-Atlantic organisations should be supported because it will contribute to increasing security in the region.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the 2015 report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. In these challenging circumstances, when Europe is facing a refugee crisis, Macedonia has proven to be an active, responsible and reliable player in its management. In these challenging circumstances, macedonia has become a member of the European Union and the European Union. Europe, more broadly, is facing a refugee crisis, proven to be an active, responsible and reliable player in its management. Despite the challenging internal and political situation, despite the upcoming elections, this non-EU member better protects European interests and Schengen better than some members of the Schengen area.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report assessing Macedonia's preparations for European integration in 2015. The compilation also points out that the country, which has already made many sacrifices in order to prepare for EU membership and has been forced to bear much of the burden of the refugee crisis, is still hampered by a number of internal and external factors. In agreement with the authors of this report, I believe that now that there is a concrete chance of alleviating the extreme internal political divisions and accelerating the reform programme in the wake of the early elections in June, it is finally time to go ahead with the period of the so-called name dispute, an external factor that has long crippling the accession process.  I think it is important that the report essentially recognises that, in addition to the UN's efforts, this is primarily the EU's responsibility and states that it is not acceptable that the enlargement process will continue to be blocked by a bilateral dispute between an EU Member State and an important Western Balkans partner. I hope that, as an MEP, I will urge the Commission, in the near future, in cooperation with both parties and the other European institutions, to draw up a timetable for a mutually acceptable political solution, following the report and the EP's resolution.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The prospect of EU membership is a major incentive for further reforms, especially in the areas of the rule of law, judicial independence and the fight against corruption, as well as a source of hope for a prosperous future for young generations. Macedonia has been a candidate country for 10 years and, despite improvements in its internal situation, has continued to face many economic, social and political problems in recent years. In the last year, there has been a significant political crisis, which has led to a boycott of the national parliament by the main opposition party and a further decline in confidence in public institutions. Action is now needed to restore stability in the country and to strengthen public confidence in the authorities. The EP report rightly points out the need for cooperation between the EU and Macedonia on the unprecedented number of refugees moving through the country. In addition, attention was paid to EU support for the organisation of parliamentary elections in June this year and for the implementation of priorities for urgent systemic reforms. I have chosen to vote in favour of the text of the report and I believe that steps can be taken to stabilise within the country so that Macedonia can start the process of accession to the European Union as soon as possible.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The tense political situation in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has lately been a concern for the entire international community. As a candidate country for integration into the structures of the European Union, Macedonia had, until that point, had a promising path, characterised by peaceful interethnic coexistence, regulated by the Ohrid Agreement (2003). Unfortunately, the conflicts of recent times have diverted the country from this road. Only the vigorous intervention of the European Union and political groups in the European Parliament have avoided the degeneration of the situation into violent forms. The signing in July 2015 of the Przino Agreement between the country's relevant political forces, under the auspices of the EU, brought new hopes for the normalisation of the situation. Elections scheduled for June this year could bring a clarification of the situation. This resolution recommends making the EU accession process conditional on the implementation of the reforms agreed in the agreement. As regards the question of the country's name, which Greece has been complaining about for two decades, it should no longer be a hindrance to the country's European integration. This document reflects the situation in practice and is useful for the positive development of the EU's relationship with Macedonia.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We wanted by this vote to highlight the need to prepare elections in accordance with the highest international standards, including by guaranteeing free and fair electoral procedures and strengthening the freedom of the media. We are concerned about the slow pace of electoral roll control and media reform. It should also be noted that the National Electoral Commission must have full powers to carry out its work and that a methodology should be agreed by all parties to control the electoral rolls, by carrying out the necessary checks on the ground to ensure perfect legitimacy; stresses further that it is important that all political actors respect the results of elections and actively participate in parliamentary activities.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution calling on the political parties of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (fYROM) to keep all their commitments as soon as possible that are linked to the political agreement of 2 June and 15 July 2015. Indeed, I believe that an agreement between all the parties in fYROM is essential in order to implement all the elements of this agreement, which would put the country back on the Euro-Atlantic path. fYROM’s political parties must start a constructive political dialogue and to continue their efforts to restore public trust in institutions, so as to preserve political stability and accelerate the reform programme. The urgent priority reforms include freedom of the media and of assembly, the public administration, the rule of law and fundamental rights, the judiciary, and the fight against corruption. Finally, I believe that the recommendation to open accession negotiations should depend on the comprehensive implementation of the political agreement and significant progress in implementing the priority reforms.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. I voted for the 2015 report on the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, as I believe that a certain level of readiness in the fight against corruption, organised crime has been achieved and that the Macedonian legal framework for the protection of human rights is in line with European standards. I also believe that Macedonia enjoys a stable macroeconomic environment, maintains good relations with other candidate countries and plays an active role in regional co-operation. On the other hand, Macedonia's European path is rather thorny and burdened by many internal and external weaknesses, and we must at the same time be strict and fair to the Macedonian candidacy. However, I believe that Macedonia pays an expensive toll for its political position and I am of the opinion that the European Commission should act as an honest and genuine partner in this case and provide it with adequate support.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 I would support the 2015 report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, as I believe that Macedonia is a country that has made greater progress in alignment with the acquis and has fulfilled a number of obligations under the June/July 2015 agreement. But they still have a lot of work to do. I believe that the inevitable implementation of reforms, particularly in the area of the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary and the fight against corruption, is essential for the stability of the country. Macedonia is a country that is also currently facing a political crisis and parties will have to put the country's interests ahead of party interests, as the all-party deal is indispensable to meet all the goals set out in the June/July 2015 deal.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the report as it does not reflect the country's real situation with regard to recoil in critical areas and the magnitude of breaches of the Copenhagen criteria. While reference is made to political problems, a lack of progress in fair election obligations, ongoing corruption, and a lack of accountability for the wiretapping scandal, the text could have been much more stark. The authorities of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia have not been able to avoid irregularities or in ensuring media independence.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Many advances have been done in Macedonia towards the values and economic, social and democratic European approaches, but after 10 years there is still work to be done for full membership. I support this proposal because I agree on the measures proposed and encourage European authorities to include this country in macro-regional strategy in South—Eastern Europe, which will bring stability and prosperity to the region.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has been an EU candidate country for 10 years and remains one of the most successful candidates in terms of alignment with the ACQUIS. The prospect of EU membership is a major incentive for further reforms, in particular as regards the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary and the fight against corruption. In the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, a large number of people support EU membership. I voted in favour of the S&D position.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the report as it does not reflect the country's real situation with regard to recoil in critical areas and the magnitude of breaches of the Copenhagen criteria. While reference is made to political problems, a lack of progress in fair election obligations, ongoing corruption, and a lack of accountability for the wiretapping scandal, the text could have been much more stark. The authorities of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia have not been able to avoid irregularities or in ensuring media independence.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the four-party agreement of 2 June and 15 July 2015 and the fact that it has been facilitated by the Enlargement Commissioner, three MEPs and an EU mediator on the ground.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the 2015 report on Macedonia, of which I was Rapporteur. The text acknowledges the deep political crisis that the country has been going through since February last year, and clearly points out that the parties will have to respect the so-called Przino agreement, a deal brokered in July 2015 between the government and the opposition, under the auspices of Commissioner Hahn and 3 MEPs. The resolution urges all sides concerned to carry out the necessary reforms that will pave the way for anticipated elections, which will take place on 5 June 2016. The resolution also takes stock of the progress that Macedonia has made so far, reiterating that the Commission´s recommendation to open access negotiations will this year be conditional upon substantial advancements in the Urgent Reform Priorities and upon the carrying out of free, fair and democratic elections.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 We are talking about a report that reflects the current situation of the country and establishes the recommendation to open accession negotiations provided that the implementation of the political agreement established in June/July 2015 continues and considerable progress is made in the implementation of priority reforms. I hope that by implementing the Przhino Agreement the country will be able to overcome the current political crisis it is going through and take up the path of reforms towards the EU, since I am in favour of supporting the European perspective of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, provided that the conditionality required by the Copenhagen criteria is met, as well as with the requirements laid down by the Reports of the European Commission. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report calling on macedonia's political leaders to implement urgent reforms. This will help the country to overcome the political crisis and will also be a step in the right direction for the start of negotiations on accession to the European Union.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 As in other republics of the former Yugoslavia, the situation in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is unstable and is a destabilisation factor for the whole region. The negotiation with Greece on the designation of the country remains, in a process surrounded by nationalist rhetoric that, instead of bringing peoples closer together, drives them away. This proposal comes once again to speed up the date for the start of accession negotiations, which is disrespecting the sovereignty of the peoples of both countries and only contributes to exacerbating existing divisions and divisions. EU membership is a sovereign decision-making process for each people, as is the right to economic and social development. The free decision must be made for each people, without any external interference, based on a free and in-depth debate based on reality and not on the myths never confirmed about EU membership. It is unacceptable that the interest of FYROM's membership of NATO, the process inseparable from the militarisation of the EU and the enlargement of its areas of influence in the strategic Balkan region, overlaps with the interests and rights of the people.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report promotes Macedonia's accession to NATO and the integration of Macedonia into The Euro-Atlantic. Macedonia is not eligible to join the EU due to unresolved disputes with Albania and Greece. I therefore reject this report.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. Under the circumstances, Macedonia's prospect of accession to the EU and NATO cannot be in the interests of a non-aligned, independent and sovereign Europe. Rejection was required here. Even in view of Macedonia's border-tight policy, which had to be enforced on its own, Macedonia's increased links with the EU is not worth supporting.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the 2015 report on the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. I am opposed to any enlargement of the EU until the fundamental problems of its constitution and design have been resolved. I call for a renegotiation of the European Treaties.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to thank my Labour colleague for his unrelenting work on this subject, working with parties in Macedonia in order to resolve their differences. I feel I must express my deep concern at the treatment of refugees by Macedonian authorities on the borders of the European Union. Thousands stuck in makeshift conditions, being moved around and caught in the crossfire of tensions between governments. It is the most vulnerable who pay the price of diplomatic bickering. Macedonian and Greek authorities, with support from the EU, must ensure that refugees in their territories have access to humane conditions of shelter, sanitation, healthcare, and education.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ on 16 December 2005 Macedonia became a candidate country for EU membership. After more than a decade, Macedonia is considered one of the most advanced candidates in terms of the adoption of European Community law. The forthcoming elections represent an important test of the maturity of democracy in the country.  One of the reasons why a country cannot move to the next stage of the EU accession process is the unresolved problem of the official name of the state. I find it humiliating if, thanks to Greece's inequity, this name is still associated with dictator Tito's Yugoslavia. I therefore very much appreciate that, after more than 10 years, Macedonia and Greece have resumed bilateral visits to each other at the level of foreign ministers. I consider this to be an important step, which is why I supported the report in the vote.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I agree that the offer of membership of the European Union can be a significant driver of the reforms that are necessary for Macedonia to become a full member of the EU. However, I consider it essential that Macedonia work strongly to improve the functioning of public administration, especially in order to truly combat corruption, even in the highest places. Further progress must also be made in the area of freedom of expression and the media. The coexistence of ethnic groups on the territory of the state is still very fragile. In my opinion, the issue of the coexistence of minorities must be approached very sensitively, but at the same time comprehensively.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Extending the European Union towards the Balkan states is a natural process that can bring many benefits to both sides. However, this year's report on the progress of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia in implementing the necessary reforms shows that the road to accession to this particular country is still very long. Despite some successes, it is difficult to unequivocally positively assess Macedonia's progress in the fight against corruption, the lack of sufficient democratic procedures, inefficient control over special services or the need to regulate ethnic relations on a partnership and coexistence basis. Much remains to be done on the issue of difficult relations with Greece, the permanent regulation of which is a prerequisite for macedonia's closer integration into the EU. However, the thesis of this report cannot be ignored, highlighting the effort and commitment made by the authorities of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia in the fight against the unprecedented immigration crisis that has hit Europe in recent months. The uncontrolled wave of migrants, which soon ended up within Macedonia's borders, is a challenge beyond the capacity of the local authorities. The EU should appreciate the efforts and responsibilities of the Macedonian Government in this difficult situation and realistically support its actions, including by earmarking funds for the training and retrofitting of macedonian border services. I believe that the report presented is based on facts and correctly assesses the situation in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Despite the internal political problems between the forces of the opposition in Montenegro, which began their accession negotiations with the European Union four years ago, it can now be described as one of the most successful countries. The fact that the national currency of the country is the euro greatly increases the effectiveness of the necessary reforms. It is clear that in recent years positive results have also been achieved in strengthening the regulatory framework, which is gradually being implemented in practice. And the situation with judicial independence, of course, is not improving as quickly as perhaps we would like, but it also goes to the right. Finally, I join in welcoming the reform of montenegro's education system, especially in pre-school and primary schools. This reform is going well. Overall, I also welcome this report very positively.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, arís vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí anseo go léir a bhaineann le Montainéagró agus is dóigh liom nach raibh sin ródheacair mar tá ciall ag baint leo. Freisin caithfimid a rá go bhfuil an dul chun cinn á dhéanamh ag Montainéagró ar a lán slite agus tá súil agam go n-éireoidh leo a bheith ina mBallstát iomlán den Aontas Eorpach lá éigin, go luath amach anseo. Ach ag an am céanna, caithfimid a rá gur maith an rud é go bhfuil tíortha ag iarraidh teacht isteach san Aontas nuair atá an Bhreatain ag caint faoin Aontas a fhágáil, agus is maith seo, go bhfuil tíortha ag iarraidh teacht isteach.
