Ach ag an am céanna tá a lán dul chun cinn le déanamh acu, go háirithe mar a bhaineann le cearta sibhialta agus cearta daonna cosúil le foréigean i gcoinne na mban. Níl aon chiall leis sin agus ní féidir linn cur suas leis, agus caithfidh siad é sin a cheartú sula dtiocfaidh siad isteach. Freisin fostaíocht, go háirithe na daoine óga agus troid i gcoinne an bhochtanais, ach is féidir linn cabhrú leo, agus lá éigin go luath, le cúnamh Dé, beidh siad ina mBallstát den Aontas Eorpach.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Montenegro has opened 22 chapters, two of which are already partially closed. It's an important step towards the Union. The visible effort the government is making in the fight against terrorism and Islamic jihad should be underlined. Returning, however, to the country's unresolved essential problem, this is corruption. Adopting codes of ethics for judges will not change reality. These so-called soft laws cannot be applied and will not take effect in the countries of this region. There are no convictions of great corruption, there are no serious and effective investigations on such files and, as such, there are no confiscations. The adoption of legislation, especially when it comes to legislation quite loose, so to speak, without sanctions, is unnecessary. Only reality and only the concrete effects calculated in the number of conviction files can show or prove the real fight against corruption. The same is true of organised crime, and money laundering is also an unresolved emergency in Montenegro. I know it's hard, but it can! With determination and courage, and not with fear of the political class.

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report on progress in Montenegro's EU accession process, inter alia because it mixes two issues which I understand to be independent, such as EU membership with NATO membership. In addition, our group opposes the privatization policies and economic model promoted by the EU, which have proven to have catastrophic effects on europe's population, and which we do not want to expand or implement in other countries.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This European Parliament progress report on Montenegro for 2015 refers to the country's progress towards European integration. It welcomes the steady progress made in the accession negotiations and underlines the additional steps that need to be taken (mainly in the area of press freedom, the fight against corruption and the lack of coordinated cooperation between the government and the opposition). Finally, in the report I voted in favour of and in which I am shadow rapporteur we succeeded in adopting an amendment underlining the need to separate Montenegro's accession path to the EU from the NATO accession process.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is a pretext for further EU interference in Macedonian affairs. Several amendments also support a rapprochement with NATO, which has had no reason to be for 25 years. So I voted against it.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on the 2015 report on progress in montenegro's accession negotiations. Corruption remains a major problem and concerns remain with organised crime and freedom of expression. Further action should also be taken to combat unemployment, social discrimination and poverty, as well as to strengthen labour and trade union rights. I support the calls for the Republic of Montenegro to hold free and fair elections and to implement the reforms envisaged.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Do we vote for a resolution of the European Parliament or NATO?... Decidedly, some are working to warm up the Cold War...

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights Montenegro's progress in the process of European integration and highlights some positive developments such as the significant progress made in improving the legislative framework to strengthen the independence, accountability and professionalism of the judiciary, but also some negative elements such as the serious problem of persistent corruption.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. This report points to Montenegro's progress in the nine chapters opened in the last year towards its accession to the EU, while being vigilant in the face of the current climate of polarisation and the implementation of the new electoral law.  I supported this report with my vote because I believe that Montenegro is making great efforts to adapt its legislation and institutions to the criteria and requirements required to be part of the EU. I also consider it positive that this text highlights the need for fair and free elections to be ensured, in the face of increasing social polarisation, and corruption to be tackled more forcefully and effectively. On the latter point, the Government must take exemplary action in the cases affecting the cabinet of ministers the itself. I supported the amendments aimed at clarifying that Montenegro's EU accession process is independent of that of NATO.  Admitting that Montenegro's accession to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is positive for the EU's strategic and geopolitical interests, both accession processes are different as the criteria for entry are not and should not be the same.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I supported the 2015 report on Montenegro. The Balkan country, after the opening of two further negotiating chapters, is now the most advanced country in the process of accession to the European Union.  Progress in the field of public administration is combined with progress on strengthening the legislative framework, with the stated aim of improving the independence and professionalism of the judiciary. While montenegro's corruption data remain worrying, it has embarked on a serious process of combating this type of phenomenon by setting up an anti-corruption agency and a specialised prosecutor' s office, which must be operational as soon as possible.  The Balkan country is also operating in the field of counter-terrorism, an effort that has resulted in increased controls to prevent the recruitment of citizens by jihadist organisations and to prevent possible terrorist attacks. The Balkan Republic has undoubtedly moved towards a path of strengthening the rule of law and fundamental freedoms, and the Union must therefore support this process and encourage the work of reforming the country that has been launched with conviction in recent years.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstain in the vote on this report because, despite agreeing on some of its considerations, we consider that it ignores the social problems that weigh on Montenegro's citizenship. The group disagrees with the privatization process imposed under the accession process, nor the EU's implicit pressure and interference with the country's foreign policy and its external relations decisions that the report supports.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. In the same way that I supported the FYROM report, I have also supported that of Montenegro. Montenegro's progress and reality are very positive and in 2016 it will be ten years since independence. Parliamentary elections will also be held and the country will hold negotiations crucial to its potential entry into NATO. Despite Montenegro's progress on its way to the EU, corruption remains a serious concern, especially in public tenders, health, education or the construction sector. It is therefore necessary for Montenegro to make the fight against corruption one of its priorities.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I opposed this resolution, which is part of a logic of unlimited enlargement of the Union, all with a view to vassalisation of European countries in NATO. Here, The lever of action of Brussels is once again based on interference: it is a question of shaping sovereign nations according to its will, so that, once malleable, they blend into the soft belly of the European monster. Thus, the Union is once again granting itself a legitimacy which it lacks in terms of foreign policy, all in the hope of being able to subject Europe totally to the Atlanticist diktat. I note in passing the indecency of the drafters of this resolution who dare to condemn the very symptoms of a healthy democratic exercise in Montenegro, namely that European parliamentarians "are deeply concerned about the internal political divide and the boycott of parliamentary activities by part of the opposition". Members, having debates between different opinions is called democracy, but it is true that you are no longer quite used to it. Finally, I will simply recall the principle of reality that, since the Union is taking on water from all sides, the question of enlargement seems to me to be incongruous and bordering on ridiculous.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although this report is partly to be welcomed, there are still undeveloped aspects that are critical, and I remain opposed to further ENLARGEMENT of the EU, so I did not support the text with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Montenegro was appointed by the Official Accession Candidate Council in December 2010. The Association and Stabilization Agreement entered into force in May 2010 and the negotiating phase was opened in June 2012. Today, it is the most advanced country in the accession process, with a total of twenty chapters being opened for negotiation, two of which have been provisionally closed. However, in the Competition and Environment Policy chapters, the negotiating opening criteria are still far from met. This report, which I voted in favour of, reiterates that greater cooperation between the ruling coalition and the opposition is needed to further progress in the accession process, and expresses deep concern at the extreme polarisation of Montenegrin policy. It also urges the Government to fully implement the new electoral legislation before the holding of new elections in 2016 and to ensure their transparency. In addition, more efforts are needed to improve the consultation mechanisms of civil society organizations, freedom of the media and Roma community access to social services, among other areas.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution, which deals with the 2015 report on Montenegro. The European Parliament welcomes the continued progress of accession negotiations with Montenegro and calls for tangible progress to be made in meeting the criteria in order to close the chapters already under negotiation and to open new chapters. Parliament welcomes the significant progress made in improving the legal framework for enhancing the independence, accountability and professionalism of the judiciary and expects the relevant rules to be fully implemented in practice. Calls, however, for the legislative and administrative capacity to be improved in the area of asylum and migration and urges the Commission to provide support for this purpose. Parliament commends the Montenegrin Government for its actions to assist stateless persons on its territory in addressing their status and calls on Montenegro to continue its efforts in this area, in particular with regard to children, including by further facilitating birth registration and subsequent registration or re-registration in civil registers. Parliament also calls on the Government to further strengthen the legal and institutional framework in the fight against corruption and to ensure effective protection of whistle-blowers. Calls also on the government and representatives of all sectors of public life and civil society to be more involved and more effective in the prevention of corruption.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the report before the European Parliament, I welcome the progress made in the accession negotiations with Montenegro and the efforts made to implement the legislation. The 2015 Country Report is a balanced, objective document that mentions the progress made over the past year, but also draws attention to the shortcomings of the country, where it needs to make significant progress. Montenegro's foreign policy is commendable as the country successfully coordinates its foreign policy with the European Union. Given that NATO and the EU's accession conditions are similar, the country's membership in NATO will result in better preparedness in the accession negotiations. However, parliament's report also points out that Montenegro needs to take a stronger fight against corruption, which is swaying the country's democratic foundations and social and economic development. The issue of media freedom, fair and equal access for parties to the media and the self-organisation of the media have also been important in the report this year. In my field of expertise, it is important that the report commands the government's commitment to extending quality early childhood education and welcomes the increase in pre-school enrolments in the wake of the targeted campaign. In my view, improving the quality of education, and in particular early childhood education, is generally going in the right direction, and enhancing the skills of educators. As the report realistically presents montenegro's current situation and its achievements over the past year, I voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe it is important that the negotiations for Montenegro's accession to the European Union continue and that Montenegro continues to implement political and economic reforms to allow accession to take place as soon as possible.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Montenegro is currently the most advanced of the candidate countries for accession to the European Union.  The progress made, the transparency of the negotiations and the political will shown by the government are welcome and must be supported. However, it should also be remembered that Montenegro should achieve further solid results with regard to the rule of law, which is a fundamental prerequisite for EU membership. Free, fair and transparent parliamentary elections are fundamental to montenegro's democratic future, as is the fight against corruption, which has confirmed itself as a serious problem along with organised crime and threats to freedom of expression that are still frequent and widespread in the country.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2015 report on Montenegro captures the steady progress made in the accession negotiations. Significant progress is noted in the government's public administration reform in 2011-16, with the depoliticisation of public administration being an important aspect in the accession process and alignment with Union values. The principles of merit, depoliticisation, accountability and transparency in administration must be reflected in sustained efforts, all the more so since the internal climate in Montenegro is polarised. I welcome the remarkable progress made in strengthening the legislative framework for strengthening the independence, accountability and professionalism of the judiciary, as well as reducing the delays accumulated for certain types of outstanding cases. Montenegro also stood out for its active involvement and constructive role in regional and international cooperation, including the process of regional reconciliation. It has also made a significant contribution to crisis management operations among the common security and defence policy, showing its real interest in aligning with union principles, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 'no' vote is also our substantial opposition to further EU enlargements. The report calls for more efforts to combat corruption and organised crime, in order to guarantee freedom of expression and to implement the rule of law reform. It is noted that corruption remains a serious problem, particularly in the area of public procurement, health care, education, spatial planning, privatisation and construction. Montenegro is called on to do more 'to combat corruption as one of its priorities' and welcomes the establishment of the anti-corruption agency in this regard. It expresses its concern at the lack of freedom of the media and urges the country to guarantee the independence of the public broadcasting service and to resolve pending cases of violence and threats against journalists. The resolution congratulates Montenegro 'on its full alignment with the EU in foreign and security policy', contributing to EU-led crisis management missions also in the context of the annexation of Crimea to Russia deemed illegal. It also welcomes 'NATO's decision to invite Montenegro to join the alliance'. It calls for measures to facilitate and protect Roma minorities, and LBGTI.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2015 report on Montenegro today because we must acknowledge the important improvements that montenegro has made and which bode well for the continuation of negotiations with the EU. However, I believe that further progress and reform is needed. I am thinking in particular of improving the rule of law, which is a fundamental prerequisite for EU membership.  We must also record that Montenegro has also had an uncooperative approach to the issue of the migration emergency in recent months. The restrictive measures decided by several Balkan countries, including Montenegro, are having very serious repercussions, causing thousands of people to be blocked in Greece. The alignment of Montenegro with eu ropean Union decisions on immigration is also an important element in the process of European integration. In this respect, the country needs to have a more collaborative approach with other EU countries.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The encouragement for the depoliticization of public administration and for greater meritocracy, the denunciation of the scourge of corruption, the fight against terrorism while respecting human rights, the approval and encouragement of interreligious dialogue, the denunciation of high youth unemployment and the call for the government to prepare policies for inclusion in the world of work, as well as the call for greater commitment by the country to migration policies are some of the most acceptable points in this report.  Despite some reservations, mainly due to the approval of Montenegro's accession to NATO, which is supported in the report without taking too much account of the geopolitical and economic effects that this could have for the entire Western Balkans region, I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report on Montenegro by applauding the steady progress of accession negotiations with Montenegro. It is noted that 22 trading chapters have been opened so far, including Chapters 23 and 24, and two of them have been temporarily closed. However, we stress that progress in the negotiations must be accompanied by the strict implementation of relevant action plans and strategies, while overall progress in the negotiations depends on progress in the implementation of the rule of law and in recording visible performance in this regard.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report in which the Parliament welcomes the progress reached in the accession negotiations with Montenegro, and stresses that overall progress in the negotiations depends on the progress in the implementation of the rule of law and visible track record.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report presents a detailed diagnosis, very comprehensive and factual, touching on all the essential points for future accession of Montenegro. Among the various problems that persist, there is a need to strengthen the National Election Commission, as well as improvements still in the field of asylum policy. However, developments in certain areas, such as the social system and the role of civil society organisations in the legislative process, should be underlined.  In any case, I do not think this is the right time, or in the near future, for another enlargement of the Union. Which is why I abstain.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the opening of another two negotiation chapters which make Montenegro as the most advanced enlargement country in the negotiation process. All depends however on the overall progress in the negotiations, in particular the progress in the implementation of the rule of law. I support the call upon the Montenegrin parliament to improve access to accession-related information and welcome the newly adopted Code of Ethics which will improve public trust in the Montenegrin Parliament. Finally I support the call for effective measures against trafficking in human beings welcoming the 70 arrests for trafficking in human beings towards Italy in the wake of investigations carried out by the Montenegrin authorities.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Tannock report contains elements that are more than acceptable and other problems, I certainly agree with the approval of the negotiations for Montenegro's accession, as well as with the depoliticisation of the PA, the search for greater meritocracy and the increase in policies to resolve the situation of youth unemployment and include in the world of work the redundancies created by the current crisis.  I also agree with the encouragement of interreligious dialogue and mediation between Montenegro and its neighbours, such as Serbia and Kosovo. However, major problem points remain in the report, such as Montenegro's accession to NATO, an issue that does not look at the possible problems that this would create for the entire Western Balkans region.  I believe it is essential for the EU to guarantee a coherent foreign policy, looking in detail at the possible difficulties that could arise from its political choices. Although I agree with many of the points in the report, I am abstaining because of the problems that have been encountered.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report on progress in Montenegro's EU accession process, inter alia because it mixes two issues which I understand to be independent, such as EU membership with NATO membership. In addition, our group opposes the privatization policies and economic model promoted by the EU, which have proven to have catastrophic effects on europe's population, and which we do not want to expand or implement in other countries.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The draft resolution welcomes the progress made in the negotiations, noting that twenty-two chapters have so far been opened, two of which have been provisionally closed. The resolution commends the reforms carried out in a number of areas, including state administration, the economy and the rights of persons with disabilities.  However, it is also concerned about the deeply polarised internal atmosphere in the country and calls for steps to be taken to improve the quality of legislation and to continue efforts to combat corruption. The text welcomes the decision of NATO foreign ministers to invite Montenegro to join the alliance and to promote a rapid and effective negotiation process. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report includes an assessment of the progress that Montenegro has achieved in the EU integration process negotiations. Montenegro achieved a steady progress in the accession negotiations. However, I believe that Montenegro needs to address issues related with the fundamental basis of the Union such as media freedom and anti-corruption. I voted in favour of this report as it highlights these fundamental issues, such as the enforcement of human rights.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Following successful domestic, judicial, economic and human rights reforms, I support Montenegro’s ambitions to play a full role in the Euro-Atlantic community. As my colleague Charles Tannock’s report notes, Montenegro has clearly made progress in its domestic anti-corruption reforms and has taken useful steps in tackling terrorist threats, all of which will serve it well in its ambition to join NATO.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution on the 2015 report on Montenegro. With this resolution, the European Parliament reiterates the need to eradicate corruption and welcomes the establishment of the anti-corruption body inaugurated in January 2016. In order to prevent possible terrorist attacks, Parliament also encourages Montenegro to strengthen its regional and international cooperation through the exchange of information and good practices.  I welcome Montenegro for its adoption of a counter-terrorism strategy for the period 2016-2018. I would like to point out, however, that it is necessary for the European Union to take a lasting break from its enlargement policy.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament welcomes the progress made in the accession negotiations with Montenegro and the efforts made to implement the legislation. The 2015 Country Report is a balanced, objective document that mentions the progress made over the past year, but also draws attention to the shortcomings of the country, where it needs to make significant progress. Montenegro's foreign policy is commendable because it successfully coordinates its foreign policy with that of the European Union. Given that NATO and the EU's accession conditions are similar, the country's membership in NATO will result in better preparedness in the accession negotiations. However, the parliamentary report also showed that Montenegro needs to take a stronger fight against corruption, which is swaying the country's democratic foundations and social and economic development. The issue of media freedom, fair and equal access for parties to the media and the self-organisation of the media have also been important in the report this year. As the report realistically presents montenegro's current situation and its achievements over the past year, I voted in favour.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported montenegro's progress report as the country has made real progress over the past year.  With its 22 open negotiating chapters, two of which are closed, Montenegro can be described as a champion in the pre-accession process, showing tremendous will and willingness to move towards deeper European integration. Despite the progress made, the European Parliament requires more reforms to improve the quality of legislation and further efforts to combat corruption. On the other hand, although in a separate process, Montenegro has gone through rapid and efficient nato entry negotiations and is expected to join the Alliance by the end of the year. From a security point of view, Montenegro's membership in NATO is extremely important because, in addition to the serious problems throughout the region related to the increasing threat of terrorism and jihadist organisations, the Western Balkans remains one of the main strands of expansion of Russian interests.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Negative, because once again the EU is trying to trap a state in the classic ways of indirect threats and is urging another state to be enslaved to its rules.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The report states that further progress has been made in the accession negotiations with Montenegro and that two other negotiating chapters on transport and energy have recently been opened.  However, sustainable dialogue and constructive cooperation between the ruling coalition and the opposition are essential for the process of participation to continue progress and free, fair and transparent parliamentary elections fundamental to that country's democratic future. I also agree that the progress of the negotiations must be accompanied by rigorous implementation of the relevant strategies and action plans and is dependent on parallel progress in the implementation of the rule of law.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a report that is part of montenegro's follow-up of the EU accession process. After having divided, attacked and opened wounds among the peoples of the former Yugoslavia, the great powers of the EU and NATO continue to want to broaden their economic dominance, exploit these peoples and their natural resources.  The measures in this report are attentive to the sovereignty of this people, representing at all levels inadmissible interferences in the economy, foreign policy, the political organization of the State and elsewhere, which we reject. The policies followed are already having negative social consequences such as increased poverty and youth unemployment.  We reject the role of NATO and the pressure that the EU is making in this report to join this organisation. We repudiate the praise that is made of the country's alignment with the EU's foreign policy and, in particular, the sanctions imposed on Russia, which once again demonstrate the EU's alignment with the assumedfascist forces that are part of the Government of Ukraine.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ it must be acknowledged that, after a thorough examination of the current situation in Montenegro, it is clear that progress has been made in the area of legislative changes, but corruption persists in the country, especially in the areas of public procurement, healthcare, education, spatial planning, privatisation and construction. Corruption must be eradicated at all levels because it undermines democratic principles and negatively affects social and economic development, and therefore the elimination of corruption must become one of the priorities of local government. The political stability of the region, the promotion of mutual tolerance and inter-ethnic and religious dialogue and further progress towards the European Union are essential conditions for strengthening cohesion and security in the Western Balkans. However, local government will also have to focus on the fact that in some parts of the country many citizens live in relative poverty and that youth unemployment and long-term unemployment are still at a high level, and to try to integrate civil society organisations and social councils more intensively into labour policy-making and improve social dialogue.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because, in this time of crisis, there is no need to enlarge the EU to other countries.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the 2015 report on Montenegro, because once again the EU is trying to trap a state in the classic ways of indirect threats and is urging another state to be enslaved to its rules.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the steady progress in the accession negotiations and the fact that this report highlights the further steps to be taken (most importantly in the fields of media freedom, anti-corruption, and the lack of constructive cooperation between government and opposition on EU matters).  Montenegro should further develop a solid track record on the rule of law and respect for democratic values, which is a fundamental prerequisite for EU accession. I truly hope that all political forces, in government and opposition alike, will re-engage in sustainable dialogue and constructive cooperation within the Montenegrin parliament. Finally, I welcome the decision of NATO to invite Montenegro to join the alliance.  NATO and EU accession criteria are similar and, therefore, that NATO accession will lead to a better preparedness in the EU accession negotiations. However, I believe that we have to make a clear that NATO and the EU accession are two different processes.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome the progress of Montenegro's accession negotiations, in line with what has been said on Macedonia. This is also a good result in terms of relations between the Western Balkans and should be further encouraged and supported.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstain in the vote on this report because, despite agreeing on some of its considerations, we consider that it ignores the social problems that weigh on Montenegro's citizenship. The group disagrees with the privatization process imposed under the accession process, nor the EU's implicit pressure and interference with the country's foreign policy and its external relations decisions that the report supports

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. I support the European reform process in Western Balkans and the efforts made by Montenegro in the domestic reforms and in the accession talks.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 As a group we support Montenegro's accession path, but we are critical of the persistence expressed in the report in linking the EU accession process with that of NATO. We consider each process to be independent. Let alone be welcomed in the report and stressed that possible NATO membership will strengthen stability in the region! We believe that this process, on the contrary, militarises and creates further destabilisation in the Western Balkans region and in the country itself.  We also disagree with the privatisation policies promoted through the accession process and the social problems that accompany these policies. These economic models have proven to have had such a negative impact on the peoples of Europe that we do not need to impose them on the countries that are currently seeking to join the Union.  That is why we have held a position of abstention.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support the progress report for 2015 on Montenegro. I welcome the steps forward made by the country however I do note that there are still problems to be solved in different sectors which need to be overcome. Although Montenegro is the most advanced Western Balkans country on its way to European Union membership, there is much still to be done within the country to ensure that democratic principles are promoted and guaranteed. The judiciary, freedom of media, the fight against corruption, weak civil society, are all still topics of concern. The highly polarised political scene is a challenge for both the government and the opposition. Transparent, free and fair next parliamentary elections are crucial for the future democratic development of the country. Thankfully, all of these concerns were strongly outlined within the resolution and sends a clear message that any accession of Montenegro into the EU must be based on the liberal democratic principles.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the progress reached in the accession negotiations with Montenegro.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I salute the progress made by Montenegro in the negotiations for the accession to the EU, most notably in the fields of media freedom and anti-corruption.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported montenegro's progress report for 2015, while the Resolution notes the importance of continuing negotiations with 22 open negotiating chapters so far, calls for greater parliamentary scrutiny of the accession process, highlights concerns about division in society and a boycott of work in parliament, further welcomes the significant progress in strengthening the legislative framework for greater independence, accountability and professionalism of the judiciary and progress made in public administration reform from 2011 to 2016. The report notes that Montenegrin police have stepped up control across the country to prevent possible terrorist attacks and the recruitment of Montenegrin citizens to jihadist organisations. Macroeconomic stability and favourable economic developments are praised, although a large number of people still live in relative poverty. There are concerns about media freedom in Montenegro, which is only ranked 114th in terms of freedom of the press according to the annual press freedom index published by Reporters Without Borders. Particularly important is NATO's decision to send Montenegro an invitation to join and encourages a quick and efficient process of accession negotiations. The resolution welcomes the negotiated resolution of border issues, i.e. calls for accelerating the resolution of unresolved issues with neighbouring countries.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is first and foremost an opportunity for further EU interference in Macedonian affairs. Several amendments are in favour of this, and others in particular are in favour of a rapprochement with NATO, which I do not endorse. In addition, I oppose the logic of enlargement ever further east. That is why I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the 2015 report on Montenegro. I welcome the progress of the negotiations with Montenegro on its accession to the European Union. 2016 will be an important year for the country, which will hold parliamentary elections and conduct negotiations to join NATO. Nevertheless, widespread corruption remains a problem. This must become the priority of the authorities in this country. I also welcome Montenegro's participation in crisis management operations in Europe. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting against this resolution. In principle, there are some important points, but the strong demand for Montenegro to be adapted to the CSDP and CFSP is, in my opinion, premature and therefore leads to the wrong direction being taken for the country.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it welcomes Montenegro’s steady progress in the accession negotiations and highlights the further steps to be taken, most importantly in the fields of media freedom and anti-corruption.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Montenegro has not been a state since its disconnection from Serbia, which was achieved by a very curious amendment to the electoral law, which has not been closely monitored by the EU in other countries. Even the report submitted does not deal with them. These are mainly citizens of Montenegro who have long-term permanent residence outside the territory of the Republic on the one hand and, on the other hand, which is highlighted in the report as a positive step, the Government of the Republic provides broad civil rights and freedoms to those who do not have citizenship of the Republic.  In this situation, the national situation and the boycott of the parliamentary activities of part of the opposition are being ed. The poor Balkan country cannot afford a substantial expansion of social benefits, which is linked to the reform of the social and childcare systems. The EU needs to support the improvement of the situation in this area. Montenegro's big problem is the large community of illegal immigrants. The report rightly notes the need for the police to further step up checks in order to prevent the recruitment of citizens and non-citizens of Montenegro to jihadist organisations.  It is naïve to believe that this report will significantly support the economic development of the Republic. In paragraph 33, Montenegro's 100% foreign policy consensus with the EU is downright damaging to the country's further economic development. This fully impacts cooperation with the Russian Federation. Nevertheless, I support the report.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the 2015 report on Montenegro, for the simple reason that I oppose the further enlargements of the European Union. The more we want to expand the EU, the more problems we create for all the states concerned. This obsession with permanent and systematic enlargement must be put to an end.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because I am opposed to any enlargement of the EU, including with regard to Montenegro. This resolution is also interfering in the internal affairs of that state.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report on progress in Montenegro's EU accession process, inter alia because it mixes two issues which I understand to be independent, such as EU membership with NATO membership. In addition, our group opposes the privatization policies and economic model promoted by the EU, which have proven to have catastrophic effects on europe's population, and which we do not want to expand or implement in other countries.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. This is interference in national affairs, such as the enforcement of the Minority Act. The European Parliament calls on the Montenegrin authorities "to promote better representation of ethnic minorities in public sector employment" and calls on them "to adopt a new law on minorities in line with European standards and in consultation with all stakeholders."

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The eu accession process is much more than just negotiations. It is about democratising society and adopting the values of partnership, competitiveness, an open single market, common European policies. That is why I am pleased that the establishment of a favourable business environment that means an efficient judiciary and fast and simple public administration is particularly emphasized. Chapters 22 and 32 are particularly interesting, and there is unfortunately modest progress, and these chapters indicate Montenegro's willingness to have transparent management of public finances.  I supported this Report, but it is important to step up technical assistance to help Montenegro with any changes ahead. In the process of joining the EU, it is important to resolve outstanding issues with neighbouring EU member states, and for Croatia it is essential to resolve the border at Prevlaca, property succesion and reparations for the victims of Montenegrin camps.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing – Montenegro is one of the youngest European countries. It declared its independence in June 2006. Negotiations on a Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the EU started in September 2006.  With regard to the negotiation process, Montenegro is the EU's most advanced candidate country. Of the 35 chapters in the accession process, 24 were opened, 2 were closed. Some slowdown is caused by a polarised domestic political scene and dissatisfaction with the performance of tasks in the areas of the judiciary, the fight against corruption and organised crime. Montenegro is also a NATO candidate country.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the 2015 report on Montenegro because it is not complete.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution, which welcomes the steady progress in the accession negotiations with Montenegro, noting that 22 negotiation chapters, including chapters 23 and 24, have been opened so far, two of which have been provisionally closed; encourages tangible progress in meeting the benchmarks for the closing of chapters already under negotiation and for the opening of new chapters; stresses that progress in the negotiations must be accompanied by the strict implementation of relevant action plans and strategies; reiterates that overall progress in the negotiations depends on the progress in the implementation of the rule of law and the visible track record thereof.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Montenegro still has a lot of work to do before it is considered for EU membership. I support this motion because I agree with the call for an improvement in the rule of law. The country must also devote more attention to the protection of minorities, women and LGBT people.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. During 2015, Montenegro has shown that it is making significant improvements and that is why we are pleased that there is steady progress in the EU accession negotiations. We must, however, continue to make improvements to enable us to move forward in this area, as the 2015 report on Montenegro, which I have supported in plenary, points out.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution to encourage a fair and level playing field to combat corruption and to strengthen core democratic principles.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is first and foremost an opportunity for further EU interference in Macedonian affairs. Several amendments are in favour of this, and others in particular are in favour of a rapprochement with NATO, which I do not endorse. In addition, I oppose the logic of enlargement ever further east. As a result, I voted against this text.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it stresses the work that needs to be done to tackle corruption in Montenegro as well as protecting the freedom of the press in the press and access of all political parties involved in elections to media.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – In the annual progress report on Montenegro, the European Parliament takes stock of progress/decline in accession negotiations. With the opening of the important chapters on justice, security, transport and energy, Montenegro is the fastest country to progress among all the candidate countries in the Balkans. Despite this positive evolution, a number of important obstacles still need to be overcome. Although Montenegro is experiencing rapid economic development, additional structural reforms are needed to strengthen business competitiveness, eliminate legal uncertainty, diversify the economy and tackle high and structural unemployment among young people.  In addition, corruption at all levels is still a highly disruptive factor in Montenegrin society. The fight against trafficking in human beings and organised crime will also need to be stepped up. The energy market is developing slowly and, moreover, it is recommended that Montenegro align its energy production with the EU's environmental and energy objectives.  Finally, in order to improve the highly polarised political climate, all parties benefit from the full implementing of the new electoral law and free and transparent elections to strengthen parliamentary democracy.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – In view of the 22 chapters that have been opened so far in the accession negotiations with Montenegro, two of which have been provisionally concluded, Montenegro is making the most progress among the Western Balkan states. The country has so far pushed for a number of important changes on the domestic political, economic, social and cultural scene, while also actively participating in activities at regional level. The basic precondition for further progress is the elimination of increasing political polarisation between the government and the opposition and the fight against corruption. In this context, the establishment and functioning of the anti-corruption agency is crucial. In the area of respect for human rights, Montenegro needs to cope with the lack of media freedom and social pluralism and to ensure sufficient protection of minority rights. The state of independence of the courts and prosecutor's office, or the professionalism and impartiality of judges and other administrative staff in the country, is insufficient and needs profound change. I welcome the recent progress made by the country in protecting children's rights, whether through the adoption of the necessary legislation, the provision of social care or access to education. I support the proposal as it stands.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the 2015 Report on Montenegro, which welcomes the steady progress in the accession negotiations and highlights the further steps to be taken (most importantly in the fields of media freedom, anti-corruption, and the lack of constructive cooperation between government and opposition on EU matters).

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2006 Montenegro declared its independence from the State of Serbia and in 2008 it applied for accession to the Union. Four years later the Council approved the opening of negotiations granting Montenegro candidate country status.  The Copenhagen criteria have been implemented by montenegro's entities, in particular in their political, economic and social dimension, as well as the implementation of the acquis communautaire.  Despite the progress made in the negotiations, there is a fear that political instability could affect the real implementation of the reforms. I would also like to stress that the conditions of freedom of expression and media information must be guaranteed, as it is a cornerstone of a rule of law.  For the above, I am voting in favour of the efforts made by Montenegro, its entities and its citizens.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. In addition to the interference in Montenegrin affairs that permeated this text and the pro-NATO arguments, the resolution takes up pro-accession recitals, which will facilitate enlargements to new member countries, which we oppose. Moreover, this report lends the EU legitimacy to act abroad, which is why I voted AGAINST.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution which notes that Montenegro, the most advanced country in the process of negotiating entry into the European Union, has made important commitments notably to reform its social system, but which calls on that state to achieve goals in terms of the rule of law and democracy, the fight against unemployment, social discrimination. corruption and poverty. The European Union must be very vigilant about respecting all negotiating chapters before accepting further enlargement.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. The resolution welcomes the progress made by the Government of Montenegro in the political, economic and social fields. It also shows its support for the necessary reforms to be undertaken. Moreover, the resolution shows the satisfaction of all Members of the European Parliament in the face of progress in the process of Montenegro's accession to the European Union. I am therefore very much in favour of the resolution as adopted by Parliament.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution that calls for more parliamentary scrutiny over the accession process and stresses the need to improve its access to accession-related information. The report also calls on the government and prosecution service to intensify their efforts to fight impunity in war crimes and to demonstrate a more proactive approach in following up on outstanding allegations of war crimes while noting the improvements in the fight against high level corruption.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The report highlights concern about gender based violence against women and girls, corruption and representation of ethnic minorities in public life and education, and it urges for more parliamentary scrutiny. However, Montenegro has also shown positive signs of improvement in terms of strengthening and enhancing the judiciary and it is applaudable that the government is committed to expanding good quality early childhood education. I welcome and support this report, as it remains important to encourage Montenegro in its EU accession negotiations while continuing to stress the need for institutional reform and democratic strengthening.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. In principle, the resolution contains a number of important points. However, it also calls for Montenegro to be strongly adapted to the common security and defence policy and to the common foreign and security policy, which I believe is premature for the country. I voted against this resolution.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Progress has been made in Montenegro, and nato's call for accession to Montenegro is also welcome. However, a number of areas, such as the fight against corruption, poverty reduction and improvement of the political climate, need to be promoted continuously.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report submitted. It should be noted that Montenegro has made progress in the negotiations on EU membership. It is to be welcomed that the country has made progress in the areas of the rule of law and fundamental rights, including the fight against corruption and organised crime. However, it is necessary to continue to encourage Montenegro to continue to take measures towards the fulfilment of the criteria in order to close the chapters already under negotiation and to open new chapters. Particular attention must be paid to combating unemployment and social discrimination. Cooperation in the field of Euro-Atlantic integration needs to be strengthened. This would be an important guarantee of stability throughout the Western Balkans region.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Progress in accession negotiations with Montenegro is now certain and the two transport and energy negotiating chapters were announced at the Intergovernmental Conference in Brussels on 21 December 2015. This state therefore needs more support from the Eu ropean Union, and I would therefore have voted in favour of it.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Montenegro's rapprochement with the European Union, but also NATO, is an important step, not only in stabilising this country but also for peace and security in that part of Europe. In this regard, I welcome the efforts made by the Montenegrin authorities on their country's path to full membership in the Union. But first of all, I believe that this country must show better results in the area of freedom and independence of the media, the fight against corruption and organised crime, and better cooperation between civil society and state authorities.  I also call on the Montenegrin authorities to start working in the spirit of European values to improve the position of national minorities, especially the rights of the Croatian minority, which is one of the main ities of any democratic society, and to solve remaining issues such as the unresolved border with Croatia, the issue of the Prevlaka peninsula, the prosecution of war crimes, but also the ensuring fair compensation for the victims of Montenegrin camps.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome montenegro's many progress in its integration process with the European Union. I am thinking in particular of the reform of public administration, with its progressive depoliticisation, and the strengthening of the rules for the independence, responsibility and professionalism of the judiciary. I hope that these reforms will now be fully and quickly implemented.  I also welcome the commitment shown by the Montenegrin Government to stateless persons and children's rights, with the extension of quality education, the reform of the social care system and children. Much remains to be done, however, in other areas such as freedom of expression and pluralism in the media. The independence of the public broadcaster must be guaranteed and it is essential to ensure the safety of journalists, who have been victims of physical attacks and smear campaigns in the past by identifying and condemning the perpetrators of these acts of intimidation.  The high level of corruption and the presence of organised crime are also still a cause for concern. Despite many positive legislative changes, much remains to be done. Just as much remains to be done with regard to domestic and sexual violence against women. There are still very few complaints, given the very little commitment of the judiciary and the police, which does not contribute to the creation of a climate of trust.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Further progress has been made in the accession negotiations with Montenegro, two more negotiating chapters have been opened, we can conclude that Montenegro is the most advanced country in the enlargement process in terms of the negotiation process. There are problems of corruption, organised crime and threats to freedom of expression, and action should be taken to combat unemployment, social discrimination and poverty and to strengthen the rights of workers and trade unions in line with EU standards. Montenegro should continue to perform well in the area of the rule of law.  I welcome the progress of the accession negotiations with Montenegro, and the significant progress in strengthening the legislative framework for greater independence, accountability and professionalism of the judiciary. I also welcome Montenegro's proactive participation and constructive role in regional and international cooperation, including in the regional reconciliation process, and its contribution to crisis management operations under the Common Security and Defence Policy. I support and welcome NATO's decision to send Montenegro an invitation to join and encourage a swift and efficient process of accession negotiations.  Despite the greatest progress of all candidate countries, Montenegro is divided by a period of time in which it will have to resolve many more internal open issues of adapting to European standards. But it is equally, if not more important, to establish and maintain an open dialogue with the domestic public about the cost of reforms.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a report that is part of montenegro's follow-up of the accession process to the European Union. After having divided, attacked and opened wounds among the peoples of the former Yugoslavia, the great powers of the EU and NATO continue to want to broaden their economic and exploitation of these peoples and their natural resources.  The measures in the report are attentive to the sovereignty of this people, representing at all levels inadmissible interferences in the economy, foreign policy or the political organization of the State that we reject. The policies followed are already having negative social consequences such as increased poverty and youth unemployment.  We reject the role of NATO and the pressure that the European Union is making in this report to join this organisation. We repudiate the praise that is made of the country's alignment with the European Union's foreign policy and, in particular, the sanctions it has imposed on Russia over the annexation of Crimea which once again demonstrate the alignment of the European Union with the fascist government of Ukraine.  We voted against it.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the 2015 report on Montenegro, as I welcome the progress made in the European Union's access negotiations with this country. Montenegro has shown that it is serious about its commitment to reforms in several areas. Although the country has made very substantial progress, it should not slow down its reform efforts. I am thinking in particular of strengthening parliamentary oversight, which is not only one of the key factors in the negotiation process. Furthermore, it is important for the country to work to depoliticize public administration, to resolve issues related to the impunity of war crimes, the fight against organised crime and corruption, which should be eradicated at all levels. I am very pleased that there has been an improvement in the involvement of organised civil society in policy-making and there have been no further attacks on journalists. As a professional activity, news is an integral part of democracy. Candidate countries, as well as member countries, should therefore ensure that it is not politicised and that it is effectively threatened by its proper functioning, including by media owners.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Among the countries that have embarked on the accession process, Montenegro is the one that is most advanced in the negotiations. Corruption, however, remains a serious problem, particularly in the areas of public procurement, health care, education, spatial planning and construction.  That is why Montenegro should make the fight against corruption one of its priorities. To this end, I believe that the establishment of the Anti-Corruption Agency, inaugurated on 1 January 2016, is an important step forward.  Furthermore, I would like to stress that NATO's decision to invite Montenegro to join the Atlantic Alliance must not interfere in the PROCESS of EU membership, as the two processes must remain separate, so as to avoid overlaps between two international bodies that must retain their autonomy.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The annual resolution welcomes the progress made in the negotiations, noting that twenty-two chapters have been opened so far, two of which have been provisionally closed. The resolution commends the reforms carried out in the country in a number of areas, including state administration, the economy and the rights of persons with disabilities. However, it is concerned about the deeply polarised internal atmosphere in the country and calls for steps to be taken to improve the quality of legislation and to continue efforts to combat corruption. The resolution welcomes the decision by NATO foreign ministers to invite Montenegro to join the alliance and to promote a rapid and effective negotiation process. It also notes the growing terrorist threat posed by jihadist organisations and welcomes the swift action taken by the government to combat it. A total of 155 amendments have been tabled to this report. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report. This Western Balkan country has made steady progress. Nevertheless, it is a reminder of the importance of making the fight against corruption a priority for Montenegro.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution in which progress in the accession negotiations with Montenegro is welcomed, as I agree that the overall progress of the negotiations depends on parallel progress made in the implementation of the rule of law and on achieving visible results in this area.  However, and recognising the need to consolidate the capacities of the Montenegrin parliament, I believe that greater parliamentary scrutiny of the process of access is indispensable. To this end, all political forces must resume sustainable dialogue and constructive cooperation in the Montenegrin parliament.  I therefore voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I agree with the recommendations on Montenegro's accession to the EU, of which I would like to note: (1) further depoliticisation of public administration; (2) ensure the independence of the judicial system; (3) allocating adequate resources to policies and services related to children's rights and in the field of asylum and migration; (4) strengthening the legislative and institutional framework to combat corruption; (5) adoption of additional measures against trafficking in human beings; and (6) strengthening the SME sector and providing support by improving legislation and funding.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 further progress has been made in the accession negotiations with Montenegro. This is the candidate country whose negotiation process is at the most advanced stage. Montenegro must continue to develop an irreprehensible track record in respect ing the rule of law, a key precondition for accession to the European Union, noting that sustainable dialogue and constructive cooperation between the ruling coalition and the opposition are essential for the accession process to continue to progress.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Montenegro was appointed by the Official Accession Candidate Council in December 2010. The Association and Stabilization Agreement entered into force in May 2010 and the negotiating phase was opened in June 2012. Today, it is the most advanced country in the accession process, with a total of twenty chapters being opened for negotiation, two of which have been provisionally closed. However, in the Competition and Environment Policy chapters, the negotiating opening criteria are still far from met. This report, which I voted in favour of, reiterates that greater cooperation between the ruling coalition and the opposition is needed to further progress in the accession process, and expresses deep concern at the extreme polarisation of Montenegrin policy. It also urges the Government to fully implement the new electoral legislation before the holding of new elections in 2016 and to ensure their transparency. In addition, more efforts are needed to improve the consultation mechanisms of civil society organizations, freedom of the media and Roma community access to social services, among other areas.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Concerned about the internal political divide and the boycott of parliamentary activities by some of the opposition in Montenegro, we called on all political forces on Thursday (March 10th) to re-establish lasting dialogue and constructive cooperation in the Montenegrin Parliament. "Dialogue and compromise are the foundations of any democratic decision-making process," stresses the text of the resolution on the 2015 report on Montenegro. The adopted text also considers it "essential, in a democracy worthy of the name, that any protest be expressed peacefully and in accordance with the relevant legislation", expecting the competent authorities to carry out, in due course, a thorough investigation into all acts of violence committed during the demonstrations. Finally, we urged all opposition parties to consider the invitation to be part of the government until the October 2016 elections "in order to guarantee, without further delay, conditions conducive to the organisation of free and fair elections".

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report. Montenegro is a small but important neighbour of the EU seeking to become a member. The EU's enlargement objective is to ensure that future Member States are already well prepared to participate in the single market, respect human rights and freedoms, and withstand competitive pressure on their economies in the EU. The EU enlargement process will not be stopped, even if it is not possible, which is the legal foundation of the Founding Treaties, and for this reason we must all strive for the new Members to be properly prepared. The Commission therefore has an important role to play in monitoring how candidate countries are preparing for EU membership and, where appropriate, in assisting or transmitting knowledge of all the worrying processes, some of which are also mentioned in the report under consideration.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this follow-up report on Montenegro for 2015. Each year, Parliament adopts a report on the candidate states for EU membership, including Montenegro, a candidate country since 2010. It is worth noting the steady progress of Montenegro, which is celebrating the tenth anniversary of its independence this year. In addition, 2016 will be an opportunity for parliamentary elections to be held and crucial negotiations to be held on its potential NATO membership.  However, this progress must be accompanied by the strict implementation of action plans, particularly in the area of anti-corruption, democratic control, freedom of expression and minority rights. But it is above all corruption that continues to be a serious problem, particularly in the areas of the public sector, health care, education, land use planning and construction. Finally, Montenegro must adopt additional measures and improve its legislative and administrative capacities in the area of asylum and migration.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament must continue to support and stimulate the Balkan countries on their path to accession to the European Union. Montenegro has made a great deal of progress in the implementation of the rule of law, but there is still a long way to go, in particular the fight against corruption must be the next urgent step, not only because it undermines fundamental democratic principles but also because it negatively hampers social and economic development.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstain in the vote on this report because, despite agreeing on some of its considerations, we consider that it ignores the social problems that weigh on Montenegro's citizenship. The group disagrees with the privatization process imposed under the accession process, nor the EU's implicit pressure and interference with the country's foreign policy and its external relations decisions that the report supports

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. This cooperation agreement with Montenegro will support and strengthen the fight against serious crime and will contribute to improving judicial cooperation, in particular in the field of organised crime and terrorism. That is why I support the agreement.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 2015 report resolution on Montenegro as I very much welcome the progress made in the accession negotiations on the implementation of the rule of law and the country's visible track record. On the other hand, however, it remains important to strengthen the importance of media freedom, to abolish corruption and to ensure that democratic principles are not undermined, which has a negative impact on both social and economic development. The amendment to support Montenegro's accession to NATO has unfortunately been rejected, which would have prepared the country much better for possible ACCESSION to the EU.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We are now almost four years into the accession process of Montenegro, and it is great to see the progress which the country has made. I voted in favour of this report as it highlights the steps which need to be taken towards the country’s accession to the EU; most importantly, steps need to be made with regards to press freedom, anti-corruption and the lack of constructive cooperation between the government and its opposition on EU matters.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this annual resolution from my colleague Dr Tannock, on the progress towards the accession of Montenegro to the EU. It is encouraging that another former Yugoslav nation takes strong steps to reform the administration and judiciary whilst seeking to eliminate corruption. I look forward to their being welcomed into membership when these steps are complete.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the 2015 Report on Montenegro, as the country's top foreign policy priorities were remaining joining the European Union and joining NATO. In 2015, montenegro, along with external political goals, strengthened its overall framework for fighting corruption by establishing a Code of Ethics in the Montenegrin Parliament and enabled greater involvement of civil society organisations in the formation of public policies. The current political crisis in Montenegro should not be an obstacle in joining the EU or NATO, as Montenegro, according to the Report, has continued to implement its international obligations and obligations under the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) and at the same time has stood out as a constructive partner in the region.  Developing a functioning market economy has remained a priority for establishing macroeconomic stability in Montenegro, as well as reducing unemployment. The upcoming phases of the negotiations will require Montenegro to develop stronger administrative capacities to effectively implement EU legislation, as well as to focus on the importance of freedom of speech and expression and media freedom.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Further progress has been made in the accession negotiations with Montenegro, which is why further chapters of the negotiations on transport and energy were opened in December 2015. Although Montenegro is the most advanced candidate country, it still has many areas where it has to make progress. Corruption, public procurement, healthcare, education are of the greatest concern,... Corruption undermines democratic principles and negatively affects social and economic development. The polarisation of the domestic political scene and the boycott of parliamentary activities by part of the opposition are also of concern. The report also draws attention to the disparity between the education system and the labour market and the wider socio-economic gap between the north and south of the country. That is why Montenegro must take active measures on the labour market in order to increase employment, especially for young people. Tax evasion must also be combated more effectively and socially fairer taxation introduced. The report also commends Montenegro for its active participation and constructive role in regional and international cooperation, including its participation in regional reconciliation and crisis management operations within the framework of the common security and defence policy.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ the European Parliament, when assessing Montenegro's activities towards its membership of the Union, particularly appreciated its considerable progress in several areas: strengthening the legal framework to increase the independence of the judiciary, efforts to increase access to and quality of education, or continued progress in accession negotiations. However, there are still areas that require reforms so that Montenegro can become a Member State of the European Union.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the evaluation of political events in Montenegro for 2015, because I consider its content to be factual and objective. Despite Montenegro's progress in accession negotiations, the country still has shortcomings in certain areas. In a country where part of the opposition is boycotting parliamentary activities, constructive cooperation within parliament must be restored. I appreciate Montenegro's proactive participation in regional and international cooperation and agree with the adoption of the Law on International Restrictive Measures, particularly in the context of the illegal annexation of Crimea and the events in eastern Ukraine. I was happy to support my faction's (PPE) amendment, which supports NATO's decision to invite Montenegro to join the alliance and calls for a swift and effective accession negotiation process. It is good that this text has been able to be put into the resolution.
