As shadow rapporteur for the Cooperation Agreement between Montenegro and Eurojust (an organisation dealing with judicial cooperation between European states), I also welcome the inclusion of point 6 on strengthening the legislative framework to increase the independence of the judicial system. The state has major corruption problems in this regard. The agreement will help in the fight against cross-border and organised crime.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒further progress has been made in accession negotiations with Montenegro and two more negotiating chapters were opened at an intergovernmental conference held in Brussels on 21 December 2015, namely on transport and energy, and Montenegro is the most advanced country in the enlargement process in terms of the negotiation process. I would stress the importance of strengthening the SMEs sector and supporting better legislation, funding, industrial policy implementation and reducing the informal economy and accelerating the electronic registration of companies across the country.  I would commend macroeconomic stability and favourable developments in the economy supported by the World Bank's 2016 Report on Business Conditions, which measures the ease of doing business index in a country where Montenegro is 46th in the world.  I also call on the government to further strengthen human rights institutions, such as the Ombudsperson and the Ministry of Human and Minority Rights, and to allocate adequate resources to enforce respect for human rights and minority rights, including those of the Croatian minority. I would highlight the importance of media freedom and pluralism, as well as freedom of expression more broadly, as one of the key values of the EU and a cornerstone of any democracy.  I welcome NATO's decision to send Montenegro an invitation for membership and the accession negotiation process with which Montenegro should continue to reform the security sector.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Montenegro must continue to perform well in the area of the rule of law, which is a fundamental precondition for joining the Union. However, the country faces a serious problem of corruption and organised crime. Further steps are needed to combat unemployment and poverty. Also, the role of the Montenegrin parliament needs to be strengthened, and the adoption of a code of ethics is a good step in that direction, but more measures are needed to increase public confidence in the Montenegrin parliament. Montenegro must step up efforts and take a more proactive stance to punish war criminals, as well as ensure fair and fair reparations for victims. Montenegro's reforms of the security sector as well as participation in THE COSD missions led by the European Union are also commended. Progress has been made on the border problems with Bosnia and Herzegovina, but the remaining border problems, including those with Croatia, need to be addressed. I support this report because I believe that Montenegro has made progress on its road to the European Union. Much work is still needed to bring this process to an end, but Montenegro needs to be supported because I believe that the country's membership in NATO and the EU is essential for security in the region.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the resolution on the 2015 report on Montenegro. I welcome the report on Montenegro for 2015, which has made the greatest progress among all the countries of the Western Balkans. Still, there's still room for progress. There is still a lot of margin for election, which must be free, fair and inclusive and respect for the fundamental principles of the rule of law. The authorities must also make even more effort to combat corruption and organised crime. I therefore welcome the fact that the Montenegrin Public Prosecutor's Office in some Montenegrin municipalities has begun to prosecute several officials in relation to high-level corruption.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on Montenegro's preparations for European integration in 2015 and on the state of the accession negotiations, which gives a fundamentally positive, accurate picture of the country's performance. The report also points out that, despite all the political divisions and undoubted contradictions in montenegro's democratisation, the EU is a leading partner in the western Balkans accession process, with good results in European harmonisation and socio-economic inclusion.  For my part, I believe that this is in itself a value that the EU should use through a more active and flexible accession negotiation strategy to motivate and stabilise Montenegro and the whole region for European integration. This could, above all, serve to regain credibility and then re-dynamicise the european Union's entire enlargement policy, supported by a number of facts and arguments in the report that has just been adopted.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. I highlight my concern about the reported number of convictions in organized crime cases and on seizures and confiscations of criminal assets that remain very low. There is a need for enhanced and improved cooperation between the judicial authorities and the security forces.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which express serious concerned about the internal political divisions in Montenegro and the boycott of parliamentary activities by an opposition party. It is now important that all parties re-engage in sustainable dialogue and constructive cooperation within the Montenegrin Parliament. Moreover, despite positive legislative progress, corruption continues to pose a serious problem in the country. In this resolution we invite the government to tackle corruption by allocating sufficient human and budgetary resources to it and by continuing to further strengthen the legislative and institutional framework.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Montenegro is taking important steps on its path towards the European Union. However, much remains to be done in the fight against corruption, particularly in the areas of public procurement, health care, spatial planning and construction. Furthermore, the boycott of parliamentary activities by part of the opposition cannot be considered positive. Dialogue and compromise are cornerstones of any democratic decision-making process. With a view to the future enlargement of the Union to include the Balkans, it is important for the European Union to accompany the accession process of these countries with determination and with the utmost attention to the defence of union values.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the 2015 report on Montenegro, as Montenegro has proven to be one of those Balkan countries where progress in accession negotiations is commendable and obvious. Although Montenegro is still facing many problematic challenges, particularly in the area of justice and the fight against corruption, I believe that many positive legislative changes are an important step towards a proactive and constructive rapprochement with the Union.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstain in the vote on this report because, despite agreeing on some of its considerations, we consider that it ignores the social problems that weigh on Montenegro's citizenship. The group disagrees with the privatization process imposed under the accession process, nor the EU's implicit pressure and interference with the country's foreign policy and its external relations decisions that the report supports

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ They are positive, but not enough, the slow progress for the democratic future of Montenegro. It is explained in more detail in this report but noteworthy efforts in strengthening institutions for the defence of human rights, the fight against arms trafficking and preventing terrorist attacks, and include macroeconomic stability and favourable evolution of the economy of the country. I encourage the competent authorities to further improve the situation in Montenegro in order that they become part of the European family.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Further progress has been made in the accession negotiations with Montenegro and two new negotiating chapters (transport and energy) have been opened at the Intergovernmental Conference in Brussels on 21 December 2015. Montenegro is the most exclusive of the countries involved in the enlargement process. It is crucial for the democratic future of the country that parliamentary elections are free, fair and transparent. Montenegro needs to show further convincing results in the rule of law, which is a prerequisite for EU accession. I voted in favour of the S&D position.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstain in the vote on this report because, despite agreeing on some of its considerations, we consider that it ignores the social problems that weigh on Montenegro's citizenship. The group disagrees with the privatization process imposed under the accession process, nor the EU's implicit pressure and interference with the country's foreign policy and its external relations decisions that the report supports

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the significant progress made in improving the legal framework for improving the independence, accountability and professionalism of the judiciary, and I hope that the relevant rules will be fully implemented in practice.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the 2015 Report on Montenegro. The Republic of Montenegro is the most advanced enlargement country in the negotiation process, which represents a stability factor for the Western Balkans and for the European Union itself. Montenegro has made remarkable progress in the implementation of reforms within its path towards EU membership, showing steady efforts in respecting European values and obligations. Moreover, NATO’s decision to invite Montenegro to join the Alliance will further strengthen its commitment to promote peace and foster stability in the country and in the wider region.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 We are talking about a report that reflects the current situation of the country and establishes the progress of Montenegro between October 2014 and September 2015. In the report we can see the country's need to move forward on issues such as competition, the environment, climate change and especially those relating to the rule of law, fundamental rights and freedom, security and justice. I am in favour of Montenegro's accession to the European Union as long as the country meets the conditionality required by the Copenhagen criteria. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report because it welcomes Montenegro's steady progress in the accession negotiations. It also highlights the further necessary changes that need to be achieved, such as in the area of the fight against fraud and freedom of the press.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 After having divided, attacked and opened wounds among the peoples of the former Yugoslavia, the great powers of the EU and NATO want to impose their economic dominance, exploit their peoples and their natural resources.  In other words, what is at stake here, and which is presented as a condition for the association, is the amendment of its labour legislation, the electoral law, the end of the sovereign mechanisms of protection of the economy and productive activity - destroying SMEs and production of small and medium-sized farmers - the realization of privatizations, among other neoliberal measures that are contrary to the interests of montenegrins. This proposal welcomes Montenegro's commitment to joining NATO and the contribution to its missions, calling it a positive step towards EU membership, demonstrating once again the link between EU enlargement and NATO, with the first being the European pillar of the second.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Montenegro's planned accession to the EU should be viewed with caution, as the corruption situation is part of society and poses a threat to democratic institutions. Above all, there is concern about the influence on the independence of the judiciary. Moreover, Montenegro's forced accession to NATO must be clearly rejected. I therefore reject this report.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. Montenegro's accession perspective to NATO and the EU, highlighted here, is not in the interests of a sovereign, independent and non-aligned Europe. Furthermore, the rejection of an alleged external influence on political processes in Montenegro refers to an anti-Russian thrust in the motion for a resolution. Rejection was required here.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the 2015 report on Montenegro. I am opposed to any enlargement of the EU until the fundamental problems of its constitution and design have been resolved. I call for a renegotiation of the European Treaties.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Montenegro is the most advanced candidate country in terms of negotiation procedure. It is clear that the country has already implemented a number of reforms, which is why I have decided to support this positive report. Despite the progress made in the framework of the reforms, I consider it important that Montenegro continues to work to improve the administration, in particular in the fight against corruption, in strengthening the legislative framework to further increase the independence of the judiciary and in other contentious areas. The intensification of police control activities in order to prevent possible terrorist attacks and recruitment into terrorist organisations is seen as very positive. The adopted anti-terrorism strategy for 2016-2018 is also key. I also agree with the call for strengthening human rights institutions.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I supported this annual resolution on the situation in Montenegro. The report touched not only on the progress made in the country in the context of the accession negotiations, but also on the need for a strengthened fight against corruption and an overall improvement in the fragmented political climate. In parliament, however, we particularly welcomed the reforms of public administration, the judiciary, but also reforms supporting the status of people with disabilities. Montenegro's rapid response to the increasing threat of terrorism is also very important.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur As is known in 2012, as a response to the euro zone crisis, a new Union-wide banking policy was initiated, which led to the transfer of responsibility for the control of this sector from Member State level to supranational. That is very good, and we must continue with this vector.  I join in calling for the structural reform of the banking system to be implemented as soon as possible, which would at least partially minimise the likelihood of recurring crises and the effectiveness of overcoming them. By the way, the same applies to the supervisory system, firstly in the case of large banks. But in general, investors and bank customers will win, because one of the most important moments of recognition is the call to guarantee the maximum possible security of deposits, both in principle and in the case of compensation, regardless of the geographical situation of the Member States, so I support this document.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I voted against this banking union report because I feel that we in Europe have been fairly well looked after, a little too well, of our banks, and it can be said that European taxpayers and depositors have ultimately paid for the reckless policy of the banks. There are many examples of this along the crisis of recent years. Now I fear that the European Union, through this banking union, is also becoming a debt union, a union of common debt. Personally, I am opposed to this type of development. I am a pro-Europe and I want to see the European Union develop as a body for cooperation between independent states, but I am a little alienant to these types of structures, which would indeed bring more solidarity, and I believe that the banking sector must be kept on a sound footing and, very much, free from the Union's common policy.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I compliment you on the efficient manner in which you chaired today’s proceedings, also occasionally with a little bit of humour. Humour is not something we associate with banks, and certainly there was very little to be humorous or joyous about in relation to how the banks conducted themselves prior to, and during, the economic recession. None more so than in my own country. I am absolutely delighted that the European Union is taking charge of the supervision of the banks and that we have stress tests, etc., and rules applying across the European Union because, in a small country like Ireland, it is too easy to be palsy-walsy – as we saw – and this can lead to many malpractices. Now we have an opportunity to create a real Union, for people to see that our banks are working efficiently and that the taxpayer will not be having to pick up the pieces. I hope we never again have to listen to the phrase ‘too big to fail’ when it comes to banks. They will all have to toe the line and do so properly, in accordance with the European Union’s rules, which would apply to the 28 Member States.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: – The financial crisis, which has been turning almost the entire Western world upside down since 2007, has led politicians to seek to eliminate risks in the sector. Banks need to maintain more capital ratios, so higher buffers to absorb shocks in financial markets. It's a good thing.  However, the European Union is taking advantage of the opportunity and, as it always does when a problem arises, is rejoining its unification ambition. It immediately wants an entire European banking union, with a deposit guarantee scheme in the third phase. Such a system at EU level will increase the risk of a new transfer union from north to south, and so, as with the euro, we are in a low street with no end. Partly because of this point, I voted against the Gualtieri report today.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I voted for this report because I believe in the need for a banking union, which plays a key role in financing investments, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises. If bank risk is reduced, credit risks for SMEs also decrease. I believe in the single surveillance mechanism, but it is obviously necessary to have quality surveillance. It is not necessary to transfer all the risk to customers, especially SMEs, due to excessive caution in the banking system. Financing conditions for SMEs are very important in order to have access to finance and not to block innovation and retrofitting. That is why I voted for the report, and I am pleased that the report provides for the responsibility of the Commission, which must guarantee a level playing field in the internal market.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has spoken for the first time on the banking union but, if not accompanied by structural reform of the banks, this instrument does not solve the causes of the recent financial crises.  The major absentees from this report are a concrete analysis of the effect of the derivatives market, the conflict of interest between monetary policy management and supervision by the ECB and, lastly, a convincing assessment of the legality of the so-called bail-in. Furthermore, this report removes the possibility for central banks to play their natural role of deposit guarantee. For these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This non-legislative report paints far too rosy a picture of the state of the EU’s supervision of the banking system, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this first report on banking union because I agree with the positive assessment of this new step in European construction, which is essential to form a genuine economic and monetary union in the federal key.  I think it is appropriate to assess the Single Supervisory Mechanism since its launch in November 2014, as well as to support the proposed European Deposit Guarantee Scheme, fourth, and absolutely necessary, the leg of the banking union, together with the single regulation for the twenty-eight, the supervision by the European Central Bank for the nineteen and the restructuring and/or liquidation of financial institutions domiciled in the euro area.  In this regard, it is very important that Parliament does not delay the processing of the proposal on the European Deposit Guarantee Scheme for the benefit of the more than three hundred million citizens living in the euro area, or that it be linked to other matters which are not the case.  It cannot therefore be interpreted as introducing the setting of limits on the purchase of sovereign debt by financial institutions outside the framework of Basel.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This non-legislative report paints far too rosy a picture of the state of the EU’s supervision of the banking system, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I believe that the banking union has only served to extend on a continental scale the exception policies developed with financial bailouts to the European periphery. In particular, we are witnessing a strengthening of institutions lacking democratic legitimacy, such as the ECB, while promoting an oligopolistic and transnational banking market that consolidates the power of finance over the European economy. Those aspects that could be positive, such as European solidarity in the event of bank failure, remain unevalued, so once again European construction serves only the institutionalisation of neoliberal policies.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The intention behind this new Union and the report was supposedly to break the link between banks and sovereigns so as to avoid future taxpayer-financed bailouts (like those that were given to the banks between 2009-11). Today, eight years into the crisis, there is still no meaningful regulation at either EU level or in Ireland which effectively breaks up the ‘too-big-to-fail’ banks and downsizes them. The European banking sector and the Irish banking sector are as concentrated and interconnected as ever. None of these problems were addressed in Gualtieri’s annual report. Nor does the report address Mario Draghi’s obvious conflict of interest. As the Banking Union has been placed under the ECB, Draghi has become the EU’s chief bank supervisor. At the same time he is a member of the private G30 club of top executives from the world’s biggest banks. The annual report, which is the first of its kind, has two purposes: 1) to congratulate and rubberstamp the birth of a new bogus European institution; 2) prepare Parliament’s position in the upcoming negotiations on the third and final pillar of the Union, a European Deposit Insurance Scheme. It was for these reasons that we voted against this report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Banking Union report, because it is one of the EU's key achievements, since the beginning of the financial crisis in 2008, to ensure security and resilience for the financial and banking sectors, as well as to restore investment confidence in the real economy and to have a high level of protection for citizens from the failure of banks and financial firms. We have fully supported the first steps: the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), the operational ones from November 2014 and the Single Resolution Mechanism, which has been fully operational since the beginning of this year. The third pillar is a joint deposit for the insurance system. Unfortunately, there is still a lack of common financial protection available as a last resort in support of the Single Fund, a resolution that has not yet been launched. In the absence of these missing elements, the Banking Union cannot be considered to have been completed and must therefore be able to fulfil its ambition and reduce risk. It should be a priority for the European Parliament for next year.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This text does not take the measure of what should be done to limit the power of banks. The EU is once again in the illusion by miming firmness but remaining very accommodating with the banks. So I voted against this report.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is essential to break the link between banks and taxpayers. In this sense, the banking union is an indispensable tool for the financial stability of the Member States of the European Union. Nevertheless, the banking union in good condition is still incomplete and cannot protect us in the event of a systemic shock similar to the 2008 crisis.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this first report on banking union because I agree with the positive assessment of this new step in European construction, which is essential to form a genuine economic and monetary union in the federal key.  I think it is appropriate to assess the Single Supervisory Mechanism since its launch in November 2014, as well as to support the proposed European Deposit Guarantee Scheme, fourth, and absolutely necessary, the leg of the banking union, together with the single regulation for the twenty-eight, the supervision by the European Central Bank for the nineteen and the restructuring and/or liquidation of financial institutions domiciled in the euro area.  In this regard, it is very important that Parliament does not delay the processing of the proposal on the European Deposit Guarantee Scheme for the benefit of the more than three hundred million citizens living in the euro area, or that it be linked to other matters which are not the case.  It cannot therefore be interpreted as introducing the setting of limits on the purchase of sovereign debt by financial institutions outside the framework of Basel.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the 2015 report on progress in strengthening the Banking Union. Although the EU is already taking its first steps towards a banking union, a common system of bank deposit guarantees still needs to be established. The banking union aims to ensure financial stability and protect taxpayers from the cost of bailing out failing banks. The creation of a single banking supervision mechanism in November 2014 took the first step towards this union. A unified bank resolution framework followed, including a special fund to cover the losses of problem banks, common rescue rules and updated deposit protection rules. The creation of a common deposit guarantee scheme is currently being pursued. Under the European Commission's legislative proposal, citizens' deposits of up to 100 000 people are not eligible for aid. euro area guarantee.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This annual report on the banking union of the ECON Committee focuses on the three pillars of the banking union: the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), the Single Resolution Mechanism (MRU), and deposit protection. On the MSU, the report welcomes the establishment of prudential control bodies throughout the euro area and the work carried out with the monitored financial institutions in order to obtain the necessary information for this monitoring. On the MRU, the report welcomes the establishment of national resolution authorities and stresses that the Single Resolution Council (CRU) should, as a priority, define the resolution plans for institutions of systemic importance... left to the ECB's sole discretion, etc. In short, another report of complacency that accompanies the ongoing communication operation of the Eurocrats. However, the reforms put in place are far from what would be needed to limit the nuisance power of banks. Eight years after the crisis, the banking system has only grown, especially in the shadow banking sector.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The banking union is one of the main achievements created since the financial crisis in 2008 that can guarantee security and resilience in the financial and banking sectors and restore confidence, investments in the real economy and a high level of protection for citizens in the event of the bankruptcy of banks and financial companies. We have supported the first steps: the Single Monitoring Mechanism (SSM), which has been operational since 2014, and the Single Resolution Mechanism (MRU) since the beginning of this year. The third pillar - a common system of insurance deposits - is unfortunately still missing and the common tax receiver (common tax backstop) which should be available as a last resort to support the Single Resolution Fund has not yet begun.  In the absence of these missing elements, the banking union cannot be considered complete and capable of fulfilling its ambition and reducing risks. This should be our priority for years to come.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Annual Report on the Banking Union for 2015. This is a thorough analysis that effectively highlights how the UB is a key element of EMU and an essential requirement for ensuring stability and restoring confidence in euro area banks.  Against a background of uncertain economic growth, encouraging investment financing means promoting economic development and employment throughout the Union. From this point of view, the role played by stabilising the regulatory and supervisory framework is crucial. We must continue along the path of simplifying legislation by making a real effort to establish an integrated European code on financial regulation and consumer rights. In highlighting the successes of the Banking Union, the importance of the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) and The Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM), instruments that have represented a step forward in the direction of a common market in banking services, should also be emphasised.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report, which qualifies as a success in the first year of the banking union' journey. In our view, the main problem that the project faced, the existence of systemic banks (too-big-to-fail), has not been solved at all, with the addition that some of these banks (such as Deutsche Bank) are now in a state of insolvency that threatens again the stability of the Union as a whole. With regard to the supervisory body, the SSM, we consider that its performance during the Greek crisis, as well as the violation of its own assessments by the ECB, deserved an investigation and condemnation of those contained in the report. Finally, with regard to the issue of deposit guaranteeing, which would prevent contagion from private debt to public debt and to equate the level of risk of the various European banks, the report is ambiguous in reflecting the disagreements that exist in this regard between the different conservative sectors.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on the banking union, which calls for structural reform of the banking sector to address the problem of institutions too large to go bankrupt; in addition, the legislative process needs to be carried out without delay. We also call for a level playing field for the insurance sector, which is increasingly involved in financial services, to adequately protect the consumer.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which is reduced to a vast communication operation in favour of the Banking Union. The rapporteur thereby merely welcomes the establishment of prudential control bodies throughout the euro area within the framework of the Single Supervisory Mechanism or welcomes that of the national resolution authorities within the framework of the Single Resolution Mechanism. However, no systemic challenge is presented, despite a still growing banking sector. The EU still refuses to separate retail and investment activities, which should be the first step in protecting deposits. Furthermore, no details are given in this report on crisis resolution for systemic banks. Until a real questioning of the Banking Union takes place, it will be impossible to regulate banking activities in order to protect our economy.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I found Mr McDerman's report. Gualtieri not balanced and not acceptable. I believe that this text is too optimistic both on the single supervisory mechanism and on the bail-in, and takes no account whatsoe of the ECB's responsibilities in the current banking crisis affecting Italy and small savers; for all these reasons I voted against it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this first report on banking union because I agree with the positive assessment of this new step in European construction, which is essential to form a genuine economic and monetary union in the federal key.  I think it is appropriate to assess the Single Supervisory Mechanism since its launch in November 2014, as well as to support the proposed European Deposit Guarantee Scheme, fourth, and absolutely necessary, the leg of the banking union, together with the single regulation for the twenty-eight, the supervision by the European Central Bank for the nineteen and the restructuring and/or liquidation of financial institutions domiciled in the euro area.  In this regard, it is very important that Parliament does not delay the processing of the proposal on the European Deposit Guarantee Scheme for the benefit of the more than three hundred million citizens living in the euro area, or that it be linked to other matters which are not the case.  It cannot therefore be interpreted as introducing the setting of limits on the purchase of sovereign debt by financial institutions outside the framework of Basel.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because the Banking Union is an important tool for ensuring the stability and re-establishment of euro area banks, increasing financial integration, reducing the risks and risk of irresponsible behaviour of the European banking system, contributing to the termination of the links between states and banks and promoting risk-sharing in the monetary union. The European Parliament calls for broad representation in the Banking Union, involving and inviting the national competent authorities of non-participating Member States to participate in future legal rules and procedures, as well as closer cooperation with third countries outside the EU. Furthermore, it confirms that, in order to ensure effective regulation and supervision of banks of systemic importance, it is essential that national competent authorities coordinate their activities more closely across the EU and internationally. Parliament welcomes the fact that the European Central Bank aims to improve the macro-stress test model in order to integrate more realistic dynamic elements into the stress test model and to include appropriate liquidity stress tests, as well as to integrate the negative effects in the banking system and the two-way interaction with the real economy and the shadow banking sector into the broader model.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The first two pillars of the Banking Union (SSM and SRM), which have been in operation since November 2014 and January 2016 respectively, are producing the first results. Through these instruments, the EU aims, on the one hand, to ensure uniform supervision of Member States' banks while respecting their diversity and operational models, and on the other hand to promote uniform rules and procedures for the orderly resolution of banks in disre compliance, with minimal effect on the financial system, the real economy, public finances and the citizens of Europe. There is room for improvement of the two instruments in terms of transparency, homogenisation of rules, streamlining of procedures and improvement of prevention mechanisms, which Parliament is focusing on. I therefore voted in favour of Mr McDerman's report. Roberto Gualtieri, who also argues for the completion of the Banking Union with a common deposit guarantee system financed through contributions from the financial sector.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this Banking Union Report - Annual Report 2015  The final compromise reached in the Economic and Monetary Policy Committee (ECON) includes key priorities regarding the need to support the first achievements of the SSM to complete the Single Mechanism through a common fiscal blockade.  I also support the achievement of avoiding any reference to a sovereign insolvency process or any change in sovereign debt treatment as a precondition for achieving the achievements of the Banking Union.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Banking Union is key to ensuring stability and restoring confidence in euro area banks, strengthening financial integration, promoting risk-sharing within the Monetary Union and helping to break the link between sovereign entities and banks at national level. The banking union's assumption is that the Single Code is complemented by a Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), a Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM), a Deposit Guarantee System (SGD) and effective budgetary support at EU level. According to the 2015 Annual Report on the Banking Union, the establishment of the SSM has yielded excellent results both from an operational point of view and in terms of the quality of supervision. The same applies to the work carried out by the Single Resolution Committee in cooperation with the national authorities of resolutions which have ensured the proper functioning of the SRM. Parliament must therefore support the presentation by the Commission of a legislative proposal concerning the first measures with a view to the introduction of a European Deposit Guarantee Scheme (EDIS), through the creation of an EU-wide reinsurance mechanism for national deposit guarantee schemes.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Banking Union is an indispensable component of the monetary union, being a main element for the creation of a genuine economic and monetary union. However, what is happening in the international economy is because of the inflexibility shown by the entire banking system – from the US to Germany and from Germany to Russia. I believe that the circuit of money in the economy is of crucial importance. At the same time, when unpredictable situations arise in the relationship between borrowers and banks, measures must be taken to support those in difficulty in payment. The Banking Union has a central role in stimulating economic growth and creating jobs across all Member States. Moreover, it has a key role to play in ensuring stability and restoring confidence in euro area banks, strengthening financial integration and reducing risks in the European banking system. I was in favour of this report because I believe that the role of the Banking Union is fundamental in order to ensure economic prosperity.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report paints too rosy a picture with regard to the Single Supervisory Mechanism and underlines the importance of the 'bail in' instrument; we also find a premature and unjustified opening of credit to SSM (single supervisory mechanism) and a criticism of the "national banking systems" identified as an obstacle to uniform supervision. Unjustified – and all to be verified – the ECB's recognition of the revision of its ethical rules (there are no effective rules on conflict of interest and guarantees against the undue influence of the financial sector). In the meantime, there is no clear reference to the fundamental principle that the ECB must fully guarantee bank deposits in the event of bankruptcy. Finally, considering that the Banking Union, designed in this way, is one of the fundamental pillars for the monetary governance of the euro, I voted AGAINST the report.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this first report on banking union because I agree with the positive assessment of this new step in European construction, which is essential to form a genuine economic and monetary union in the federal key.  I think it is appropriate to assess the Single Supervisory Mechanism since its launch in November 2014, as well as to support the proposed European Deposit Guarantee Scheme, fourth, and absolutely necessary, the leg of the banking union, together with the single regulation for the twenty-eight, the supervision by the European Central Bank for the nineteen and the restructuring and/or liquidation of financial institutions domiciled in the euro area.  In this regard, it is very important that Parliament does not delay the processing of the proposal on the European Deposit Guarantee Scheme for the benefit of the more than three hundred million citizens living in the euro area, or that it be linked to other matters which are not the case.  It cannot therefore be interpreted as introducing the setting of limits on the purchase of sovereign debt by financial institutions outside the framework of Basel.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The banking union is the European response to the economic and financial crisis of 2008. The banking union is made up of three pillars: the single supervisory mechanism, the single resolution mechanism and the European deposit guarantee system.  The first two pillars have recently been put in place. They help prevent potential crises by monitoring the behaviour of banks and to be prepared in the event of proven crises to ensure that the European economy is impacted as little as possible.  The last pillar has yet to be determined. This should provide additional insurance for savers. Discussions on this third part of the banking union are currently under way in the European Parliament. I voted in favour of this text, which is Parliament's first report on banking union.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reflection and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the report on the Banking Union – Annual Report 2015, as I believe it is necessary to implement and strengthen the Banking Union, as part of a genuine Economic and Monetary Union, and I am convinced that moral hazard and non-risk-sharing within the monetary union is a major damage to the entire world economy. With a view to reducing risks in the banking system, the quality of financial standardisation and governance is strategic, as is greater transparency in the legislative process in financial services. In addition to these processes of good governance, the ECB's monetary policy instruments, such as the Single Supervisory Mechanism, which has performed well in operation and in terms of the quality of supervision, must be used, as is evident from the report with which I agree. There is no doubt that the economic recovery is under way, but it is fragile due to the lack of structural reforms: from a macroprudential perspective, the emphasis must be on preventing fluctuations and not just strengthening resilience to shocks; From a microprudential perspective, a working deposit guarantee scheme can prevent banks from bailing out with taxpayers' money.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The intention behind this new Union and the report was supposedly to break the link between banks and sovereigns so as to avoid future taxpayer-financed bailouts (like those that were given to the banks between 2009-11). It was for these reasons that I voted against this report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This non-legislative report paints far too rosy a picture of the state of the EU’s supervision of the banking system, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report expresses the European Parliament's position on the state of the Banking Union by analysing its three pillars: single supervisory mechanism (SSM), single resolution mechanism (SRM) and the European Deposit Guarantee Scheme (EDIS).  I voted against the adoption of this report because it expresses diametrically opposed assessments of my position on the subject. The report, in fact, expresses great satisfaction with the results achieved so far with very little criticism. The 5-Star Movement deplores the concept of a banking union if not accompanied by structural reform of banks. The SSM is a highly critical tool for the way in which it is conducted, i.e. for the fact that it does not consider the risks of derivatives, thus distorting the systematicity of banks.  Another important issue that is not denounced in the report concerns the obvious conflicts of interest in the management of monetary policy and supervision by the ECB. Finally, with this report, the European Parliament does not deplore the illegal application of bail-in.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Launched in 2012, following the decision taken by the European Council in response to the financial crisis that began in 2007, the Banking Union wanted to be the European response to protect euro area countries from new crises that could further destabilise financial markets. This decision led in 2014 to the creation of the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) which assigns direct banking supervision to the ECB and the Single Resolution Mechanism (MRU), which is responsible for preparing measures in the event of bank disead de stability. These are instruments designed to create a single framework for the management of the financial market and for the gradual transfer of banking supervision to Union level. The evaluation report on the activities of the Banking Union has highlighted the important role played by the SSM and the MRU, although, as the text shows, there are still some malfunctions in its operation. The completion of the Banking Union can be achieved when the deposit insurance system (EDIS) is launched, which is necessary to protect savers in the event of a bank accident. I voted in favour of this report because it identifies areas for improving the functioning of the Banking Union so as to make the financial sector safe, robust and transparent.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and recall that, together with the SSM and the SSM, a substantial TF should ensure the ability to provide a uniform and high level of deposit protection, regardless of their geographical location.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This non-legislative report paints far too rosy a picture of the state of the EU’s supervision of the banking system, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The banking union is an essential component of the Economic and Monetary Union of the European Union and comprises three fundamental pillars: the single supervisory mechanism, the single resolution mechanism and a uniform deposit guarantee scheme. I support this report, which is the first annual report of the banking union and which reinforces the ustake of a common European response to the banking system in general by reducing the risk of a repeat of the negative effects felt throughout the Union with the recent crisis, thereby contributing to the security and soundness of credit institutions and to the stability of the financial system. I welcome the Commission's proposed package of measures on risk sharing and reduction in the banking union, as the proper functioning of a deposit guarantee scheme financed by financial sector contributions is one of the proven ways to prevent the rescue of banks with taxpayers' money.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support the initiative to produce an annual report on the Banking Union. As co-legislators, we have a responsibility to restore confidence in our banking system. It is quite positive that the SSM is showing success both in its structure and in terms of the quality of supervision. Through this supervisory mechanism, we promote a level playing field in the banking market, with sound credit institutions and stable financial systems.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This non-legislative report paints far too rosy a picture of the state of the EU’s supervision of the banking system, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that this is an own-initiative report representing the first annual report on the Banking Union, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The banking union plays an important role towards a genuine economic and monetary union which reduces risks of abuse in the European banking system. Within such a system, however, we cannot place more obstacles to SMEs. Tools such as the SME Supporting Factor are important, and initiatives for improved SME and innovation funding should be made more accessible to start-ups and SMEs.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report welcomes the current state of the Banking Union, noting its three pillars, the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM) and the European Deposit Guarantee Scheme (EDIS). Although the report highlights the positive results achieved by the Banking Union, I believe that it has repeatedly highlighted its weaknesses. Indeed, the Banking Union has not been able, for example, to resolve the causes and consequences of the current phase of the European crisis, since the existence of the UB alone is useless if not accompanied by a structural reform of the banks.  It is now clear that the functioning of banks is based on conflicts of interest between the ECB's monetary policy and supervisory policy. As a result of the problems raised in the report and because all our complaints have been rejected, I can only oppose it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I believe that the banking union has only served to extend on a continental scale the exception policies developed with financial bailouts to the European periphery. In particular, we are witnessing a strengthening of institutions lacking democratic legitimacy, such as the ECB, while promoting an oligopolistic and transnational banking market that consolidates the power of finance over the European economy. Those aspects that could be positive, such as European solidarity in the event of bank failure, remain unevalued, so once again European construction serves only the institutionalisation of neoliberal policies.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Banking Union is the European Union's response to the 2008 economic crisis and an essential instrument for ensuring the stability of the single currency and the European financial system.  The European Parliament resolution is the first annual assessment of its operation. With my vote in favour, I note the significant progress that has been made during 2015, with regard to the creation and start-up of both the activities of the Single Supervisory Mechanism and the Single Resolution Mechanism. At the same time, I believe that the structure of the Banking Union is still incomplete because it needs to be further improved in detail, in particular with regard to the possible unfair effects of bail-in on savers at least in a first phase of transition, and with regard to risk-sharing through the rapid adoption by the European institutions of a European deposit insurance mechanism.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the European Parliament's first report on the Banking Union. It includes an assessment of the implementation of the Fully Operational Single Supervisory Mechanism, as of November 2014, of the Single Resolution Mechanism, charged with resolution operations in January 2016, as well as other challenges for the Banking Union, in particular the achievement of the third pillar through the creation of a European Deposit Guarantee Scheme and additional initiatives to reduce risks in the banking sector. The Banking Union has been one of our key achievements since the start of the 2008 financial crisis, which can secure and resilient financial and banking sectors, restore trust among citizens and develop investment in the real economy. In the absence of these elements, the Banking Union cannot be considered as completed and therefore able to achieve its objectives and reduce the risk.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The annual report focuses on the situation in a banking union based on three pillars – supervision, resolution and harmonised deposit insurance. Although the Banking Union has improved the resolution of banks, there is still a lot of work to be done to implement a system of reorganisation proceedings against banks in the EU. The BRRD is not yet fully implemented and banks and countries are still dependent on each other on solvency.  Unfortunately, the report also touches only briefly on the need to abolish the zero risk weight for bonds. The report demonstrates the need for a 'uniform and high level of protection of deposits, regardless of their location'. However, harmonising protection against deposit risks will redistribute risks in the EU, which may lead to lower levels of deposit protection in some countries, while exploiting others. With this in mind, I have decided to abstain.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Following the financial crisis of 2008, the Banking Union aims and implements mechanisms to restore confidence in the banking sector. I am in favour of this report, as it welcomes the stability of restoring the confidence in euro area banks as well as taking into account that more needs to be done in order to have a fully functioning Banking Union. We need to continue working on the implementation of the Single Resolution Mechanism as well the finalisation of the Banking Union, with the completion of the EDIS. I positively believe that we need to continue progress towards a safe and resilient financial and banking sector, and it is fundamental to protect our citizens from the failure of banks and financial firms. For these reasons I voted in favour of this report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The Banking Union annual report highlights how it has been a great achievement encouraging future representation in the Banking Union of national competent authorities and non-participating Member States. The ECR’s amendments, which acted as a counter-weight to these views, were rejected. In addition, this report does not contain an explicit reference stating that the interests of non-Banking Union participants should be respected in light of the European Deposit Insurance Scheme. Furthermore the Single Supervisory Mechanism should not drive the legislative framework for non-participants of the Banking Union. Regarding the ‘too big to fail’ issue, since the UK has adopted its own legislation in this area, a swift agreement at EU level in this field would not be welcomed if it were to undermine the UK’s own regime. As a result, I voted against this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report presents the European Parliament's position on the state of banking union in its 2015 annual report. We call on the European Commission and supervisors to consider solutions to increase the European Union's lending capacity. As such, one of the preferred avenues is the increase in the Union's capital. The report also discusses the proposed deposit guarantee system, aimed at securing citizens' savings in banks. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report on the banking union. It is important that this report be delivered annually in order to report on the various mechanisms. The single supervisory mechanism and the single resolution mechanism, two of the key elements of this banking union, are becoming more effective. They allow for harmonisation at European level of the regulation and supervision of banking activities. The legislative package on the European deposit guarantee system, presented by the European Commission on 24 November 2015, will make this banking union stronger, improve financial stability and strengthen deposit protection.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Banking Union is, without doubt, one of the most important initiatives that were taken during the economic crisis and at the same time redesigns the financial and economic sector by taking up the principles of the Treaty of Lisbon.  Indeed, the Banking Union, together with the Capital Markets Union, is a decisive step in the formation of efficient and direct channels for monetary policies, which do not always manage to achieve economic activity due to inefficient and un competitive financial systems. Financial integration is a key element in reducing moral hazard and breaking the vicious circle between sovereign debt and the national banking system, which has dramatically amplified the effects of the financial crisis.  Furthermore, this report addresses two fundamental problems: the critical issues in banking supervision and the failure to implement the third pillar. In fact, the ECON Committee considers it essential to change some of the parameters concerning the potential risk of derivatives in banks' balance sheets and at the same time to enhance banks that have a greater propensity to expose themselves to the real economy. Finally, it is necessary to ensure uniform protection of deposits regardless of their location. With conviction, I am voting in favour of this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained on the annual report on the Banking Union because I think it will take a long time for supervision to become fully effective. The assumption that supervision will now be able to address the pressing problems of weak capitalisation of individual credit institutions or even entire national banking systems is unrealistic.  The report characterises the Banking Union as delivering many improvements for banks, but at the same time there are many more aspects that need to be improved in order for it to work without regression for taxpayers. I also disagree with the harmonisation of deposit protection rules. I believe that this approach could have a negative effect by reducing the level of protection in some Member States.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The pursuit of a global economic mobilisation to achieve more and better quality bank capital crushes national economies and leads to citizens' impoverishment. In the context of structural reform of the banking sector, the creation of a single resolution mechanism and a single supervisory mechanism with a view to uniform banking consolidation at EU level have the effect of burdening citizens, especially Greek taxpayers and depositors.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe has taken important steps towards building a Banking Union, but it is necessary to create a single deposit guarantee scheme for the project to be completed. The next step should be taken in favour of the creation of a single deposit guarantee scheme that offers protection on deposits above EUR 100,000 as a way of ensuring the credibility of the project. On the other hand, it is necessary to implement measures that reduce risk in the banking system and, in parallel, to create a single deposit guarantee system, thereby avoiding further delays in the progress of the Banking Union. I voted in favour.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this first report on banking union because I agree with the positive assessment of this new step in European construction, which is essential to form a genuine economic and monetary union in the federal key.  I think it is appropriate to assess the Single Supervisory Mechanism since its launch in November 2014, as well as to support the proposed European Deposit Guarantee Scheme, fourth, and absolutely necessary, the leg of the banking union, together with the single regulation for the twenty-eight, the supervision by the European Central Bank for the nineteen and the restructuring and/or liquidation of financial institutions domiciled in the euro area.  In this regard, it is very important that Parliament does not delay the processing of the proposal on the European Deposit Guarantee Scheme for the benefit of the more than three hundred million citizens living in the euro area, or that it be linked to other matters which are not the case.  It cannot therefore be interpreted as introducing the setting of limits on the purchase of sovereign debt by financial institutions outside the framework of Basel.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it: this is a communication operation, the reforms put in place are a far cry from what it would take to limit the nuisance power of banks.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Banking Union is another demonstration of the false solutions and leaks ahead to solve the deep crisis in the EU and the EU, deepening capitalist integration.  In addition to deepening the attack on the sovereignty of states and promoting the monopolistic concentration of the financial sector at EU level, this Banking Union is based on a banking supervision system that has already proven its short existence that is not effective, as we painfully know in Portugal. The resolution system and its common resolution fund is short and clearly insufficient, even after shareholder losses, so taxpayers will surely be called back to pay to save the systemic banks. It is, moreover, significant that we move forward with this Banking Union before the promised restructuring of the banking system with a pseudo-separation that represents another thing, to give the impression that something is being done by staying the same. As our position of principle against the Banking Union is known, our vote on this report could not be any other than against. What is required is the recovery of public control of the banking and the financial system, as a guarantee of a financial system at the service of the economy and truly secure.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: In writing ‒ there is no doubt that the economic recovery in Europe is continuing, but especially given the lack of structural reforms, convergence and investment and the over-reliance on external factors, the improvement in the situation is still fragile and only moderate, while inflation remains below the target. Although progress can be observed, lending dynamics are still subdued in many jurisdictions, and large volumes of NPLs are burdening many European bank balance sheets, limiting their ability to finance the economy. The creation of a European deposit insurance scheme requires the implementation of a single set of rules, as well as the first and second pillars of the BÚ, as well as the transposition of the Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive and the Deposit Guarantee Schemes Directive for all participating Member States and other measures to achieve a significant reduction in the risks of the European banking system.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report, which does not reflect the reality of the situation, and continues to praise the euro, a currency to which I have always been opposed.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The quest for global economic mobilisation, in order to achieve more and better quality bank capital, is crushing national economies and leading to citizens' impoverishment. In the context of structural reform of the banking sector, the creation of a single resolution mechanism and a single supervisory mechanism with a view to uniform banking consolidation at EU level, has the effect of burdening citizens, especially Greek taxpayers and depositors. For the above reasons I am voting against the Report on the Banking Union - Annual Report 2015.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Banking Union is one of our key achievements since the financial crisis in 2008 to ensure safe and resilient financial and banking sectors to restore confidence, investment in the real economy and a high level of protection for citizens from the failure of banks and financial firms. I have fully supported the first steps: the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), operational from November 2014, and the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM), fully operational from the beginning of this year. The third pillar – a common deposit insurance scheme – is unfortunately still missing, and work on a common fiscal backstop to be available as a last resort to support the Single Resolution Fund has not yet started. Together with the SSM and the SRM, the capacity to afford a uniform and high level of protection of deposits, irrespective of their location, should be ensured in an effective Banking Union. In the absence of these missing elements, the Banking Union cannot be considered as completed and therefore able to fulfil its ambition and reduce risk. It should be our priority for the coming year.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this first report on banking union because I agree with the positive assessment of this new step in European construction, which is essential to form a genuine economic and monetary union in the federal key.  I think it is appropriate to assess the Single Supervisory Mechanism since its launch in November 2014, as well as to support the proposed European Deposit Guarantee Scheme, the fourth leg of the banking union, together with the single regulation for the twenty-eight, the supervision by the European Central Bank for the nineteen and the restructuring and/or liquidation of financial institutions domiciled in the euro area.  In this regard, it is essential that Parliament does not delay the processing of the proposal on the European Deposit Guarantee Scheme for the benefit of the more than three hundred million citizens living in the euro area, or that it is linked to other matters which are not the case.  It should the the the case the no case be interpreted as supporting the introduction of limits on the purchase of sovereign debt by financial institutions outside the Basel framework.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing.
