name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 We today approved the 2015 State of the Banking Union report, which highlights how the establishment of the Single Supervisory Mechanism can be a positive instrument, both operationally and in terms of supervisory quality, but it is important to stress that there are still a number of shortcomings and significant room for improvement.  In particular, there is a need for coordination between micro- and macro-prudential policies, also with a view to the necessary, and I hope swift, revision of the Basel III rules. Credit crunch, while mitigated, is still a heavy brake on the recovery of SMEs, the real engine of the economy. Credit access requirements must therefore be reformed as soon as possible in order to provide liquidity for our companies.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The Annual Report of the Banking Union is a fundamental part of the Economic and Monetary Union. A functioning system of the Banking Union plays an important role both for the real economy and for job creation. Stability and confidence in this are of enormous importance to me.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This non-legislative report paints far too rosy a picture of the state of the EU’s supervision of the banking system, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. The 2008 crisis revealed what was suspected: the irresponsibility of the financial sector, or even its ability to harm the real economy. I am afraid that despite some regulatory efforts, including at European level, this has not changed. You have also taken advantage of the situation, as usual, to give a little more power at the European level, with the banking union. The aim is to centralise the supervision of euro area credit institutions and decisions on their rescue in the event of a default, by breaking the link between sovereign states and national banks. And from now on, it will be the customers of the banks who will be called upon to save them.  But you are not tackling the bottom line: without the bank separation, which you refuse, the banks will continue to speculate with depositors' money; you are not seriously attacking shadow banking, which banks use to circumvent your prudential rules; the ECB continues to inject more liquidity into the markets, but they do not benefit the real economy. As long as you put yourself at the service of finance rather than forcing finance to be at the service of the economy, nothing will move forward.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report, which qualifies as a success in the first year of the banking union' journey. In our view, the main problem that the project faced, the existence of systemic banks (too-big-to-fail), has not been solved at all, with the addition that some of these banks (such as Deutsche Bank) are now in a state of insolvency that threatens again the stability of the Union as a whole. With regard to the supervisory body, the SSM, we consider that its performance during the Greek crisis, as well as the violation of its own assessments by the ECB, deserved an investigation and condemnation of those contained in the report. Finally, with regard to the issue of deposit guaranteeing, which would prevent contagion from private debt to public debt and to equate the level of risk of the various European banks, the report is ambiguous in reflecting the disagreements that exist in this regard between the different conservative sectors.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The report as adopted in ECON welcomes the evolution of a Banking Union and the establishment of the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) and the Single Resolution Board (SRB). It supports the regulatory induced process of increasing banks’ capital and reducing leverage, but also points to the possible negative effects that may have on lending.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this first report on banking union because I agree with the positive assessment of this new step in European construction, which is essential to form a genuine economic and monetary union in the federal key.  I think it is appropriate to assess the Single Supervisory Mechanism since its launch in November 2014, as well as to support the proposed European Deposit Guarantee Scheme, fourth, and absolutely necessary, the leg of the banking union, together with the single regulation for the twenty-eight, the supervision by the European Central Bank for the nineteen and the restructuring and/or liquidation of financial institutions domiciled in the euro area.  In this regard, it is very important that Parliament does not delay the processing of the proposal on the European Deposit Guarantee Scheme for the benefit of the more than three hundred million citizens living in the euro area, or that it be linked to other matters which are not the case.  It cannot therefore be interpreted as introducing the setting of limits on the purchase of sovereign debt by financial institutions outside the framework of Basel.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my group, fully supported the Annual Report on the Banking Union. This report, which follows up on the implementation and evolution of financial supervision in the EU, the so-called Banking Union, is paramount to monitor the harmonisation of supervisory tools at EU level. This will help to ensure that the financial crisis of 2008 will not be replicated by strengthening capital requirements and depositor protection and ultimately establishing a Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) and a Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM) for the euro area. I was happy to support the regulatory induced process of increasing banks’ capital and reducing leverage, but I was also glad that the report pointed to the possible negative effects this may have on lending. Concerning the SRM, thankfully the report called for the rapid drawing-up of banks’ resolution plans and minimum requirements for assets to be bailed-in (so-called MREL, Minimum Requirements for Eligible Liabilities) in a possible bank resolution to shield against negative effects on the real economy.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that a strong Banking Union is crucial for jobs and growth in the eurozone. It is right that we have a review of the Banking Union measures already put in place and make changes if necessary. Ultimately, this is all about the lending environment. Too many banks are still not in a position to lend properly to businesses and SMEs. Any further development of our Banking Union needs to put this at the forefront of the agenda.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The 2015 Annual Report on banking union welcomes all three pillars. The first pillar is the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM). This is a mechanism by which the ECB is supposed to supervise large eurozone banks, thereby ensuring the security and soundness of the European banking system. The second pillar is the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM). This provides for uniform rules for the resolution or recovery of distressed European banks. According to the third pillar, deposits of all savers are to be insured jointly. I reject the Banking Union, as the supervisory mechanism inevitably presents the ECB with significant conflicts of interest. The Aim of the SRM is to create a community fund to pay for the restructuring of the banks in need. However, since it is much more likely that southern eurozone banks will need help, the SRM will lead to a de facto redistribution of funds. The common deposit guarantee leads to a redistribution and thus to savers in northern Europe taking on the risks of southern Europe. Such a redistribution will not solve the divergences caused by the lack of an exchange rate mechanism and must therefore be rejected. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This non-legislative report paints far too rosy a picture of the state of the EU’s supervision of the banking system, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the European Parliament's first report on the Banking Union. The financial crisis in 2008 reminded us that the European project is far from complete. We need a profound reform of the regulation and supervision of the financial system in order to ensure sustainable and job-generating economic growth in the European Union. The first steps were taken: the Single Supervisory Mechanism, which has been in operation since November 2014, and the Single Resolution Mechanism, fully operational since the beginning of this year. The third important pillar, a common deposit insurance system, is in a jam. At the moment we can say that the banking union is not completed. It should be our priority for next year.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Banking Union Report - the 2015 Annual Report, as the Banking Union is an indispensable part of monetary union and a fundamental element of the EU's Economic and Monetary Union, and essential for the stability of trust in euro area banks, strengthening financial integration, reducing risks and moral hazard, and contributing to promoting risk-sharing within the monetary union. The Banking Union plays an important role in financing investment and boosting economic growth. I support the establishment of the three pillars of the Banking Union, and in this regard I support the results achieved by establishing a single supervisory mechanism that has proven successful both from an operational point of view and in terms of quality of supervision; results achieved in the establishment of the SRB and the establishment of NRAs in the Member States. A successful banking union should also have the ability to provide a high and uniform level of deposit protection where a deposit insurance scheme financed by financial sector contributions is one of the proven ways to avoid saving banks with taxpayers' money.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report therefore provides an overview of the progress of the banking union and the weaknesses still present. It should also be noted that, eight years after the crisis, the banking system has only grown, especially in the shadow banking sector. Even though the MSU improves bank supervision and capital requirements have been increased, banks remain a huge danger to the global economy.  In addition, no details were given on the resolution of the crisis for systemic banks. Beyond a balance sheet of 30 billion euros, the resolution is the responsibility of the ECB and not the MRU. The work carried out by the European institutions in the context of the banking union is a communication operation aimed at making it seem that the European Union is taking the bull by the horns. However, the reforms put in place are far from what would be needed to limit the nuisance power of banks.  The first step should be to separate retail and investment activities in order to protect deposits, which is categorically rejected by the European Union. So I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This non-legislative report paints far too rosy a picture of the state of the EU’s supervision of the banking system, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the state of the Banking Union. Europe has made significant steps towards creating a Banking Union but the work is far from over. To fully complete the job, we first need to restore trust in our financial system. It is vital to restore trust between savers and their banks but also between Member States themselves. This text also makes it clear that the European Commission and the European supervisory authorities conduct an in-depth assessment of the effect of increasing capital requirements in current and future legislation on credit supply, especially to small and medium-sized companies, which are the driving force of our real economy.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Roberto Gualtieri's report on the 2015 annual report on banking union. The banking union is making an undeniable move in Europe. Indeed, the major European banks are now supervised by the European Central Bank and there are common rules for troubled institutions. However, today, a common guarantee on bank deposits is mainly lacking. I support the progress made and the development of new measures within the framework of the banking union which can avoid financial panics like those we experienced in 2008. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am highly critical of the third pillar of the Banking Union, the Single Deposit Guarantee – following the introduction of the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) and the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM). A uniform high level of deposit insurance– regardless of the location of the deposits – reduces competition, invites free-riding and undermines bail-in settlements. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it highlights the state of play of the Banking Union as well as the challenges it is still facing.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The 2015 Annual Report on banking union welcomes all three pillars. The first pillar is the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM). This is a mechanism by which the ECB is supposed to supervise large eurozone banks, thereby ensuring the security and soundness of the European banking system. The second pillar is the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM). This provides for uniform rules for the resolution or recovery of distressed European banks. The third pillar is the common deposit guarantee. The deposits of all savers are to be insured jointly.  I reject the Banking Union, as the supervisory mechanism inevitably presents the ECB with significant conflicts of interest. On the one hand, it is intended to ensure that banks prosper as much as possible through its monetary policy, and on the other hand, it should impose conditions on banks if necessary. The Aim of the SRM is to create a community fund to pay for the restructuring of the banks in need. However, since it is much more likely that southern eurozone banks will need help, the SRM will lead to a de facto redistribution of funds. The common deposit guarantee also leads to redistribution and thus to savers in the northern Member States taking on the risks of southern Europe. Such a redistribution will not solve the divergences caused by the lack of an exchange rate mechanism and must therefore be rejected.  That is why I rejected the report.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This is the first report on Banking Union after the main elements have been settled: Bank recovery, the Single Resolution Mechanism and the Single Supervisory Mechanism. None of our amendments were included in order to improve the report. I regret the fact that the report is still vague on the main points, i.e. no criticism of the past achievements of the Banking Union, no explanation of how the ECB will handle its power concentration. This is why I voted against this report.

name: n/a
text: in writing. The Banking Union is key to ensuring stability and restoring confidence in euro area banks and strengthening financial integration, reducing risks in the European banking system.  I voted in favour because the Banking Union plays a key role in financing investment and, consequently, in promoting growth and creating jobs across the EU. The Single Code, in this area, must be complemented by a Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), a Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM) and a high level of deposit protection. In agreement with the rapporteur, I believe that, in addition to the SSM and the SRM, the ability to offer a uniform and high level of protection of deposits, regardless of their location, should be guaranteed. I also believe that the creation of the Single Resolution Committee (SRB) and the establishment of national resolution authorities in the Member States play a key role in the proper functioning of the SRM.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the annual report on banking union. The work carried out by the European institutions in the context of the banking union is merely a communication operation aimed at making it seem that the European Union is taking the bull by the horns.  However, the reforms put in place are far from what would be needed to limit the nuisance power of banks. The first step should be to separate retail and investment activities in order to protect deposits, which is categorically rejected by the EU.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it praises the Banking Union as a real danger to The Sovereignty of France. The real reform would be to separate deposit and investment activities from banks in order to protect depositors.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted AGAINST this report in order to express my disagreement with the ineffective European economic policy. The text presents the annual report on banking union. It is based on its three pillars, the Single Monitoring Mechanism (SSM), the Single Resolution Mechanism (MRU), and deposit protection. After reviewing the text, the observation is clear. Since the 2008 crisis, the banking system has grown, particularly with shadow banks. The reforms put in place are ethereal. However, it would be necessary to implement concrete and effective means such as separating detail and investment in order to protect deposits.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I believe that the banking union has only served to extend on a continental scale the exception policies developed with financial bailouts to the European periphery. In particular, we are witnessing a strengthening of institutions lacking democratic legitimacy, such as the ECB, while promoting an oligopolistic and transnational banking market that consolidates the power of finance over the European economy. Those aspects that could be positive, such as European solidarity in the event of bank failure, remain unevalued, so once again European construction serves only the institutionalisation of neoliberal policies.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The banking union is an indispensable component for a true economic and monetary union. Annually, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs produces a report on the banking union.  This report conducts an assessment of the results of some of the instruments used, such as the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) and the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM). Parliament welcomes the creation of the SSM, which has been operationally and operationally sound in terms of the quality of supervision, and considers it an important achievement in view of the complexity of the project and the limited time available. It also welcomes the effective implementation of the Single Resolution Board and the establishment of national resolution authorities in the Member States. These achievements, unthinkable five years ago, show that policies designed in the wake of the financial crisis are paying off. Closer coordination between competent national authorities across the EU and internationally is essential to ensure effective regulation and supervision. For all this I vote in favour of this report.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The 2015 Annual Report on banking union welcomes all three pillars. The first pillar is the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM). This is a mechanism by which the ECB is supposed to supervise large eurozone banks, thereby ensuring the security and soundness of the European banking system. The Aim of the SRM is to create a community fund to pay for the restructuring of the banks in need. The common deposit guarantee also leads to redistribution and thus to savers in the northern Member States taking on the risks of southern Europe. Such a redistribution will not solve the divergences caused by the lack of an exchange rate mechanism and must therefore be rejected. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the existence of a banking union in the EU, but I want the euro to be voluntary. The proposal also confirms the flawed regulation under which government and European bonds are classified as zero-risk assets in banking regulation, making it easier for governments to indebted and expose banks to moral hazard.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The establishment of the Banking Union, namely the first and second pillars and the single rulebook, has contributed to the stability of the financial system in the European Union. European banks are now much more stable and resilient than they were before the crisis. This is why it is necessary to complete the Banking Union, first and foremost to establish a European Deposit Insurance Scheme as soon as possible. We need to restore our citizens' trust in the banking system and protect their funds. Taxpayers can't bear the brunt of failing banks. Although more stable, banks are still burdened with high levels of non-payable loans, making lending difficult. And it is the financing of the economy, the more investment, that the European Union needs most in this current one. Completing the Banking Union and measures to reduce still-present risks will precisely allow for greater lending to the economy. More favourable and balanced financing of the economy throughout the European Union is the cornerstone of the functioning of the single market. Without equal access to sources of funding, there is no open and fair competition. The Banking Union is important for boosting growth and new employment, and I supported mp Gualtieri's report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing – The creation of a Banking Union is a response to the financial crisis. It is crucial for the European financial system. It brings new demands on those who cause debts. The aim is a thorough and correct risk assessment. I consider this to be the right step in terms of maintaining the financial stability of the Member States and the Union. The Single Supervisory Mechanism and the Single Resolution Mechanism shall be interconnected and coordinated to provide sufficient safeguards to prevent and prevent the emergence of 2007 situations. However, even these measures, without the active participation and adoption of measures by the Member States and the Union in cooperation with the banks, cannot and will not be effective. It is necessary to take concrete measures to make the bank resolution process operational and unify throughout the Union and to ensure genuinely high and real protection of bank deposits, which is a prerequisite for financial security.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the Banking Union – Annual Report for 2015, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 10/3/2016, and because this report is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This is the annual report on the banking union of the ECON Committee, which provides an overview of the progress of the banking union and the weaknesses still present. It should also be noted that, eight years after the crisis, the banking system has only grown, especially in the shadow banking sector. The work carried out by the European institutions in the context of the banking union is a communication operation aimed at making it seem that the European Union is taking the bull by the horns. However, the reforms put in place are far from what would be needed to limit the nuisance power of banks. The first step should be to separate retail and investment activities in order to protect deposits, which is categorically rejected by the European Union.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe must move towards creating a stronger banking union, creating a single deposit guarantee system that offers greater protection. And we must work to reduce banking risks. The 2015 bank union report delves into all these issues and, for that reason, I am voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. In contrast to other financial market liberalisation projects currently taking place, the banking union is one of the European Union's most sensible projects: controlling the risk of banks defaulting, ensuring that they bail out public money without appeal and guaranteeing the deposits of savers.  This report of Parliament's initiative, which provides the balance sheet of these three pillars of the Banking Union, is welcome. He gave a cautious but positive observation on the single supervisory mechanism of banks (the first pillar) by pointing out that he had estimated that Greek banks did not need, as the troika demands, a bailout of 25 billion euros, but a maximum of 14 billion euros. The Single Resolution Fund (second pillar) is on track, although it is reaffirmed that it must become a Community fund, not a sum of national funds.  Finally, the same problem applies to the deposit guarantee, the third pillar sorely lacking in the Banking Union, which, in order to play its insurance role, must be common and shared, not limited to national guarantees. Despite timid requests on this aspect, I voted in favour of the report calling for the completion of the project.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this annual report on the Banking Union welcoming the establishment of the Single Resolution Mechanism, and the important role of the Single Supervisory Mechanism.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This text does not take the measure of what should be done to limit the power of banks. I must say that the EU is once again in the pretences of making it believe in its firmness in order to remain in the end quite accommodating. Eight years after the crisis, the banking sector has only grown. As a result I voted against it.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report, which is the first annual report on the Banking Union. The report outlines the three pillars of the Banking Union: the single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM) and the third pillar, the protection of deposits. I welcome the conclusions on the state of the Banking Union.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. One of the biggest European buildings in the aftermath of the crisis is the banking union. It aims to stabilise the financial sector by guaranteeing common rules and guarantees, as well as European-wide supervision. It is now operational, notably through the single monitoring mechanism and the single resolution mechanism.  Some 128 banks in the euro area have been placed under the supervision of the ECB. However, the Banking Union is not finalized. It still requires the creation of a common bank deposit guarantee. This reform is under way as the Commission has tabled a legislative proposal on this issue.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – The Banking Union has played an important role in resolving the financial crisis, especially in the countries most affected by the economy. The establishment of a single supervisory mechanism was the right step in terms of strengthening the quality of supervision and success, especially in view of the short timeframe set for its creation. The future participation of the national competent authorities of non-participating Member States, and in particular closer coordination of the activities of those authorities, will make a significant contribution to ensuring effective regulation and supervision of important Union banks. The creation of a single resolution mechanism or the establishment of national resolution authorities in Member States also has great potential to ensure the effective functioning of the banking sector even in times of crisis. In this context, it is important that Member States fully transpose the Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive. The above instruments should ensure the ability to provide a uniform and high level of deposit protection, regardless of their location, which will contribute to breaking the link between banks and sovereign debt, restore depositors' confidence, create a level playing field and ultimately strengthen financial stability. I express my support for the proposal tabled.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the annual report on the Banking Union because it has been one of our key achievements since the financial crisis in 2008 to ensure safe and resilient financial and banking sectors to restore confidence, investment in the real economy and a high level of protection for citizens from the failure of banks and financial firms. I fully supported the first steps: the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), operational from November 2014, and the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM) fully operational from the beginning of this year. The third pillar – a common deposit insurance scheme – is unfortunately still missing, and work on a common fiscal backstop to be available as a last resort to support the Single Resolution Fund has not yet started. In the absence of these missing elements, the Banking Union cannot be considered as completed and therefore able to fulfil its ambition and reduce risk. It should be our priority for the coming year.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is the annual report on the banking union of the ECON committee. It revolves around the three pillars of the banking union: the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), the Single Resolution Mechanism (MRU) and deposit protection. This report therefore provides an overview of the progress of the banking union and the weaknesses still present. And it should be noted that, eight years after the crisis, the banking system has only grown, especially in the shadow banking sector. Even though the MSU improves bank supervision and capital requirements have been increased, banks remain a huge danger to the global economy. The work carried out by the European institutions in the context of the banking union is a communication operation aimed at making it seem that the European Union is taking the bull by the horns. However, the reforms put in place are far from what would be needed to limit the nuisance power of banks. The first step should be to separate retail and investment activities in order to protect deposits, which is categorically rejected by the European Union. We are voting against this report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The banking union is key to ensuring stability and regaining confidence in banks, strengthening financial integration and reducing risk in the European banking system.  The Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) is the first pillar of the banking union and aims to ensure uniform supervision of Member States' banks, to establish a level playing field in the banking market and to contribute to the security and soundness of credit institutions and to the stability of the financial system, while respecting the diversity of banks and their business models. I believe that the European Central Bank, in its supervisory strategy, should consider and safeguard the pluralism and diversity of banking models in the European Union, including mutual, cooperative and savings banks, and respect the principle of proportionality. The European Union must endeave to ensure attentive and effective banking supervision, with the ability to provide a high and uniform level of deposit protection, with the concern to regain the confidence of depositors, to establish a level playing field and, more importantly, to strengthen financial stability.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The work carried out by the European institutions in the context of the Banking Union is a communication operation aimed at making it seem that the EU is taking the bull by the horns. However, the reforms put in place are far from what would be needed to limit the nuisance power of banks. The first step should be to separate retail and investment activities to protect deposits. This is categorically rejected by the EU. That's why I voted AGAINST.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. The economic and financial crisis that the world experienced in 2008 prompted the European Union to adopt strong and effective measures to ensure that this type of crisis does not happen again.  The banking union system allows for the ECB's single supervision of European banks, a single resolution mechanism in the event of a bank's bankruptcy by mobilising a resolution fund financed by the banking sector and setting up a European deposit guarantee system so that depositors are not the victims of the possible failure of a banking institution. I am in favour of that mechanism. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. The annual report on the European Banking Union reports on the satisfactory implementation of the single supervisory and resolution mechanisms. Nevertheless, we remain attentive to the proper implementation of the deposit guarantee system. As it stands, I support the adoption of the report by the European Parliament.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As a response to the financial crisis that emerged in 2008, the European Commission pursued a number of initiatives to create a safer and sounder financial sector for the single market. These initiatives, which include improved depositor protection and rules for managing failing banks and stronger prudential requirements for banks, form a set of rules for all financial actors in the 28 Member States of the EU. This set of rules is the foundation on which the Banking Union sits. I voted for this report that calls, amongst other things, for the implementation of the Banking Structural Reform which was conceived to reduce systemic risk.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Banking Union plays a key role in financing investments and, therefore, in stimulating economic growth and job creation throughout the Union. This European Parliament report on the Banking Union includes an assessment of the implementation of the fully operational Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) as of November 2014, the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM), in charge of the January 2016 settlement operations, and other challenges for the Banking Union, in particular the achievement of the third pillar, through a common deposit guarantee scheme and additional initiatives to reduce risks in the banking sector. The Banking Union is one of the key achievements after the 2008 financial crisis, in order to secure secure financial and banking sectors and restore confidence, investment in the real economy and a high level of protection for citizens in the event of the failure of banks and financial firms.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution, which notes with satisfaction that the ethics rules of the ECB have been reviewed, and stresses the importance of effective rules on conflict of interests and safeguards against undue influence of the financial industry, on staff as well as on members of the governing bodies.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. – In line with the rapporteur and the ECON Committee, I welcome the introduction of the Banking Union and the establishment of the Single Supervisory Mechanism and Single Resolution Mechanism for the eurozone in the aftermath of the financial crisis of 2008. I voted in favour of this annual report, as oversight over the implementation and development of financial supervision at the EU level functions as an important safeguard mechanism.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome this report, which for the first time maps and assesses the situation in the Banking Union. The SSM and the Single Resolution Mechanism are a step towards a common market for banking services, but this must be followed by others, such as providing a high level of protection for deposits in the form of the creation of a European Deposit Guarantee Scheme (EDIS) or structural banking reform, which should aim to reduce systemic risk and address the problem of financial institutions that are too big to do so so that they can fall. The Commission, together with the ESAs, should also carry out a comprehensive assessment of the capital requirements contained in current and future legislation, in particular in order to analyse their implications in terms of financing conditions for SMEs and, more generally, the real economy.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because the entire existing banking union regime should be brought to an end. The set-up is based on three pillars, the third pillar of which concerns national deposit guarantee schemes. A uniform, high level of deposit insurance applies here, regardless of the location of the deposits. This set-up invites you to go on a free-riding and sets completely wrong incentives.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Banking Union was set up to deal with the economic crisis and an activity report is published every year, which is essential for an overview of its functioning and effectiveness. The report welcomes the creation of the SSM and the SRB and further underlines the importance of the banking union's action on risk-sharing and simultaneous reduction for the Member States of the euro zone.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This non-legislative report paints far too rosy a picture of the state of the EU’s supervision of the banking system, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Banking Union is an indispensable component and an essential element of a genuine economic and monetary union. This Union is essential to ensure stability and restore confidence in euro area banks, strengthen financial integration and reduce risks in the European banking system. Given that the Banking Union plays a key role in financing investments and, consequently, in promoting growth and creating jobs across the EU, I would have voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – With this report, that I have been particularly involved with as a shadow rapporteur, the European Parliament gives the deserved importance to risk-reduction measures, which will prevent moral hazard. It clearly states that if the costs for bank failures and insolvencies are to be mutualised, the risk must be contained to the maximum extent possible. The report anticipates further measures to achieve a substantial reduction of risks in the European banking system. Next to making sure that bail-in rules are consistently applied, it is paving the way for a review of the macro-prudential policy framework, the further reduction of national options and discretion and better handling of non-performing loans. Providing a clear incentive for reducing sovereign exposures and a balanced approach towards the third pillar of the Banking Union, the report makes a strong statement for a prudent and forward-looking system. I welcome the report and would like to thank all colleagues for their support and I look forward to our future work on Banking Union legislation.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. Such reports on the Banking Union will be produced annually, which I believe is a shift in the right direction for the right parliamentary cooperation. Given that it is the first in a series of these annual reports, a large number of amendments have also been adopted, which I believe have been successfully overcome through joint powers and compromises with other political parties. The most controversial part, where there was the most disagreement, was in the work of the report, which speaks of EDIS. In doing so, I must stress that uniform rules must be established for the whole EU, when and how this mechanism can be applied. Furthermore, I support the operation of the SSM mechanism, which is crucial for the functioning of the Banking Union. Indeed, in an extremely short period of time, despite the exceptional complexity of the system, it has successfully overcome the challenges, and the EU institutions will need to continue to be encouraged to implement positive regulatory changes in banking in the medium term to play a greater role in the global system, which should in no case affect the reduction of the availability of funds to finance Member States or interfere with market functioning and competition, thus affecting the financial stability of banks and Member States.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Single Supervisory Mechanism and the Single Resolution Mechanism have proven successful, but we must continue to work to improve them. A quality recruitment process, the compilation of supervisory manuals, the establishment of IT infrastructure and the establishment of joint supervisory teams have significantly improved the operational set-up of the Single Supervisory Mechanism, which should be welcomed. In my view, unnecessary administrative burdens should definitely be eliminated.  Members of the Economic and Monetary Policy Committee have taken good notice that structural reform of banks has yet to be implemented and that a level playing field in the insurance sector is important. In my view, particular attention should be paid to banks' off-balance-balance-off items, namely their supervision, and caution should be exercised regarding the development of the shadow banking sector. I join calls on the Commission to use regulations instead of directives to ensure a coherent implementation of the Single Supervisory Mechanism across the EU. It is necessary to establish effective cooperation between the SRB and NRAs under the SRB.  I also support the requirements for the development of resolution plans for systemically important institutions, a uniform level of deposit protection, as well as the view that those who take risks for them are also responsible.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Banking Union is a necessary component of monetary union and a fundamental element of a genuine Economic and Monetary Union. The Banking Union plays a key role in financing investment and accordingly in boosting growth and job creation across the European Union.  The need for a single supervisory mechanism is visible in order to improve the level of deposit protection. I therefore welcome the establishment of the Single Supervisory Mechanism, the SRB and the establishment of NRAs in the Member States, which have been an outstanding success. In my view, further progress should be pursued, despite the exceptional degree of efficiency reached by the SSSSs, in particular the aim should be to involve NCAs more effectively in the decision-making process. The Single Supervisory Mechanism and the Single Resolution Mechanism represent a step forward towards a common market for banking services, with cross-border consolidation becoming more attractive.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Banking Union is well demonstrated by the false solutions and leaks that are tested ahead to resolve the deep crisis in the EU and the EU in the process of deepening capitalist integration.  It continues and accentuates the attack on the sovereignty of states, promotes the monopolistic concentration of the financial sector at EU level, and is based on a banking supervision system that is manifestly ineffective. The system and common resolution fund are insufficient and will once again require taxpayers to pay to save systemic banks. We note and it is significant that we move forward with this Banking Union before the promised restructuring of the banking system. What is required, on the contrary, is the recovery of public control of the banking and the financial system, as a guarantee of an effectively secure and truly secure financial system at the service of the economy. As a matter of principle, we voted against the Banking Union.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I welcome this report and fully support it. Economic growth within the Banking Union remains strong enough and in this regard I particularly welcome the Rapporteur's recommendation to the Commission to encourage the removal of unnecessary administrative barriers both at European and national level that are primarily hampering the development of small banks. I also support the call for reform of the supervisory and regulatory framework of the financial sector as an important factor for the return of investor confidence, which can ultimately boost economic growth and financial stability.  I agree with the report that it is essential for the financial recovery that Member States also fully implement the Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive, which lays down, inter alia, the principles that fallen banks should not be saved with taxpayers' money, but that losses must first be covered by shareholders and creditors.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Annual Report on the Banking Union provides an opportunity for the European Parliament to identify the areas of critical issues and challenges posed by the new European supervisory architecture.  The completion of the Banking Union brings with it the need to accompany it with actions aimed at reviving growth and development and strengthening the economic governance of the euro. A more supportive idea of Europe, common rules and strong institutions could help to better meet the challenges of a globalised economy. After the Banking Union and the Capital Markets Union, the aim should be to achieve a fiscal union, at the service of the real economy and job creation. I believe that relaunching European industrial policy and solving the problem of access to credit for SMEs should be one of the Union's priorities.  I voted in favour of this report and hope that banks will continue to support the real economy by financing start-ups, artisans and small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it highlights Europe's progress on the road to banking union. It is important to remember that in recent years major European banks have been placed under the supervision of the European Central Bank. Also, common rules for helping troubled banks have emerged. Nevertheless, it will be a matter of being vigilant about the implementation of a common bank deposit guarantee.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This non-legislative report paints far too rosy a picture of the state of the EU’s supervision of the banking system, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution consists primarily of an analysis of the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), which I believe should be improved. I voted in favour of this document because I agree with the need to extend the representation of the banking union through the future involvement and participation of the competent national authorities of the non-participating Member States.  In addition to welcoming the operational structure of the SSM, I support the formulation of proposals aimed at reducing the operational load of structures at all levels and improving the effectiveness of the SSM. I voted in favour of this resolution because I also agree that internal resolution teams, as equivalent structures to the Joint Supervisory Teams of the SSM, are a good basis for organising cooperation under the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM). I would therefore stress the importance of good cooperation between the SRM and the competent national authorities. Finally, I welcome this document for stressing that the proper functioning of a deposit guarantee scheme financed by financial sector contributions is one of the proven ways to avoid the rescue of banks with taxpayers' money.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. At lunchtime, European financial integration was in the spotlight with the vote on the Gualtieri report on banking union. In this first annual report on banking union, MEPs highlighted the important step forward in the introduction since January 2016 of the Single Resolution Mechanism, which sets out the rules for bailing banks by private investors. A fair system based on a cascading approach: when a bank is to be saved, it is first its owners (shareholders) who will be called upon to contribute, then, secondly, the creditors and, secondly, the holders of deposits of more than 100,000 euros.  Progress remains to be made. MEPs have pointed to a priority project with the adaptation of the regulation of capital requirements (CRR and CRD IV) to the framework of the banking union. The European Parliament also stressed the importance of strengthening banks' capital without affecting lending capacity and credit distribution. A change in this regard is crucial as in recent months banks have "tightened the tap" of access to finance for individuals and entrepreneurs creating growth and jobs.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The first annual report on the Banking Union. The Banking Union is a mechanism to ensure the security and resilience of the banking sector, restore citizens' confidence in these institutions, provide investment in the real economy and ensure citizens a high level of protection from the bankruptcy of banks and financial firms. Among other things, this report makes an assessment of banking supervision, the single resolution mechanism, the proposal for a European deposit guarantee scheme, the financing conditions of small and medium-sized enterprises, etc.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this first report on banking union because I agree with the positive assessment of this new step in European construction, which is essential to form a genuine economic and monetary union in the federal key.  I think it is appropriate to assess the Single Supervisory Mechanism since its launch in November 2014, as well as to support the proposed European Deposit Guarantee Scheme, fourth, and absolutely necessary, the leg of the banking union, together with the single regulation for the twenty-eight, the supervision by the European Central Bank for the nineteen and the restructuring and/or liquidation of financial institutions domiciled in the euro area.  In this regard, it is very important that Parliament does not delay the processing of the proposal on the European Deposit Guarantee Scheme for the benefit of the more than three hundred million citizens living in the euro area, or that it be linked to other matters which are not the case.  It cannot therefore be interpreted as introducing the setting of limits on the purchase of sovereign debt by financial institutions outside the framework of Basel.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this draft report 2015 on the banking union, which welcomes the progress of the banking union in the euro area and the proposal to create a European Bank Deposit Guarantee System (EDIS). The text of the report calls for the completion of the banking union through the establishment of a single regime for bank deposit guarantees and a backstop for the Single Resolution Fund (SRF).

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this anthois. I welcome the establishment of institutions such as the Unified Supervisory Mechanism and the Unified Dispute Settlement Body.  The Banking Union is an important tool for ensuring the stability and reliance on euro area banks, increasing financial integration, reducing the risks and risk of irresponsible behaviour in the European banking system, contributing to the break-up of the links between states and banks and promoting risk-sharing in the monetary union.  The rapporteur rightly calls for broad representation in the Banking Union, with the possibility of inviting the national competent authorities of non-EU participating Member States to participate in the future, as well as closer cooperation with third countries, in accordance with established rules. I also welcome the call for closer coordination between national competent authorities across the EU and internationally in order to ensure effective regulation and supervision of systemic banks.  I welcome the European Central Bank's desire to improve the model of bank resilience tests on macro-stress conditions.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 There is much good about the Gualtier report, but it goes too far in proposing a deposit guarantee scheme for the whole of Europe. That is why I cannot support it.  A few arguments. The banking sectors in the north and south of Europe are very different. Risks also vary.  I understand that the report seeks to restore confidence in the banking sector. Confidence is, of course, the basis of all banking. The citizen does not deposit a single euro into his or her adjustment account without any certainty that the money will also remain in the balance. Unfortunately, a common deposit guarantee scheme covering the euro area would bring stability and faith mainly in those southern EU Member States where alarm bells should actually ring.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of the banking union for 2015. While this has been welcomed, further action is needed.  The banking union has placed Europe's largest banks under the supervision of the European Central Bank and established common rules on helping institutions that are struggling. The European Union must focus on implementing a common bank deposit guarantee to provide deposits with European protection of up to 100,000 euros.  I therefore voted in favour of this text, which recalls the significant progress towards a stronger banking union, but also the need for a common bank deposit guarantee.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report, which qualifies as a success in the first year of the banking union' journey. In our view, the main problem that the project faced, the existence of systemic banks (too-big-to-fail), has not been solved at all, with the addition that some of these banks (such as Deutsche Bank) are now in a state of insolvency that threatens again the stability of the Union as a whole. With regard to the supervisory body, the SSM, we consider that its performance during the Greek crisis, as well as the violation of its own assessments by the ECB, deserved an investigation and condemnation of those contained in the report. Finally, with regard to the issue of deposit guaranteeing, which would prevent contagion from private debt to public debt and to equate the level of risk of the various European banks, the report is ambiguous in reflecting the disagreements that exist in this regard between the different conservative sectors.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The Joint Banking Union is an important tool for securing the financial sector. Since the financial crisis, the Banking Union has contributed to an attempt to restore credibility, to new investment and a higher level of security for citizens who experienced a banking crash during the crisis. Although some measures put forward in the report still need to be completed, I support the conclusions of the report.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 2015 Annual Report on banking union, which, in addition to a supervisory and supervisory mechanism and a single banking resolution mechanism, also addresses deposit protection because it creates transparency and both distributes and mitigates risks throughout the Banking Union. It is important that changes to the European Deposit Guarantee Scheme, in cooperation with the European Systemic Risk Board, do not go hand in hand with reductions in the financing of Member States or financial instability.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ After the financial crisis in 2008, one of the key achievements was the move towards a Banking Union. It was designed to ensure the resilience and safety of the banking and financial sectors, as well as – crucially – to restore confidence and investment in the real economy and highlight the high level of protection which citizens need from the failure of banks/financial firms. I have supported the steps that have been undertaken to achieve these measures, but I cannot consider the Banking Union complete. It lacks some key elements, such as a common deposit insurance scheme. In conclusion, this report has analysed the current situation of the Banking Union and raised priorities for where it should go from here. Hence, I voted in favour of this report and thank my colleague Roberto Gualtieri for the effort and work that he put into writing it.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the Banking Union is an integral part of monetary union and a cornerstone of genuine economic and monetary union, and participation is also open to Member States whose currency is not the euro. The Banking Union is a tool to ensure stability and restore confidence in euro area banks, reduce risk in European banking and play a key role in financing and thus in boosting growth and creating jobs across the EU. The Single Supervisory Mechanism in the Banking Union is the first pillar of the Banking Union and aims to ensure uniform and coherent supervision of the banks of participating Member States, to create equal conditions in the banking market and to contribute to the security and financial soundness of credit institutions and the stability of the financial system, while respecting the diversity of banks and their business models. The Single Resolution Mechanism is the second pillar of the Banking Union and aims to ensure uniform rules and procedures and a common decision-making process to smoothly address the problem of banks on the brink of bankruptcy, with minimal impact on the rest of the financial system, the real economy, ordinary citizens or public finances across Europe.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The 2015 Annual Report on banking union welcomes all three pillars. The first pillar is the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM). This is a mechanism by which the ECB is supposed to supervise large eurozone banks, thereby ensuring the security and soundness of the European banking system. The second pillar is the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM). This provides for uniform rules for the resolution or recovery of distressed European banks. The third pillar is the common deposit guarantee. The deposits of all savers are to be insured jointly. I reject the Banking Union, as the supervisory mechanism inevitably presents the ECB with significant conflicts of interest. On the one hand, it is intended to ensure that banks prosper as much as possible through its monetary policy, and on the other hand, it should impose conditions on banks if necessary. The Aim of the SRM is to create a community fund to pay for the restructuring of the banks in need. However, since it is much more likely that southern eurozone banks will need help, the SRM will lead to a de facto redistribution of funds. The common deposit guarantee also leads to a redistribution and thus to savers in the northern Member States taking on the risks of southern European countries. Such a redistribution will not solve the divergences caused by the lack of an exchange rate mechanism and must therefore be rejected. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 The Banking Union has an irreplaceable place in financing investments and creating jobs. The issue of transparency and trust in market participants and the public is all the more important. In particular, financial stability needs to be strengthened and appropriate solutions found for the management of banking crises in the future, through a thorough assessment of the options available, in particular on the basis of Union legislation.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Banking Union is essential for stability and restoring trust in eurozone banks, strengthening financial integration, reducing risks in the European banking system and moral hazard, and contributing to severing ties between states and banks and promoting risk-sharing within the monetary union. The Banking Union plays a key role in financing investment and, accordingly, in boosting growth and job creation across the EU.  There should be a single supervisory mechanism, a single resolution mechanism, a high and uniform level of deposit protection and effective fiscal protection at EU level in addition to uniform rules. In a successful Banking Union, in addition to the Single Supervisory Mechanism and the Single Resolution Mechanism, there should also be the ability to provide a high and uniform level of deposit protection, regardless of their location, as this would contribute to effectively breaking the vicious cycle between states and banks, restoring savers' trust, creating a level playing field and strengthening financial stability.  I also believe that any deposit protection scheme must always avoid the emergence of any moral hazard and ensure that those who take risks are also responsible. A functioning deposit insurance scheme financed from financial sector contributions is one of the proven ways to avoid saving banks with taxpayers' money, and I therefore supported the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which recognises that the Banking Union is instrumental in ensuring stability and restoring confidence in euro area banks, enhancing financial integration, reducing risk in the European banking system and moral hazard, contributing to breaking the link between sovereigns and banks and fostering risk-sharing within the monetary union.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Banking Union is a fundamental element of the Economic and Monetary Union, necessary for stability and trust in banks in the European Union. In addition to the Single Bank Union Regulation, the SSM Single Supervisory Mechanism, the SRM Single Resolution Mechanism and the Common Deposit Insurance Scheme have been established to ensure effective fiscal protection at EU level. The objective of the first pillar of the Banking Union is to ensure uniform supervision of EU banks, contribute to the security and stability of credit institutions and the financial system and establish a level playing field on the banking market. Pillar 2 of the SRM guarantees a joint decision-making process for the resolution of failing banks. Pillar 3 is currently concerned with harmonising national deposit insurance schemes and can over time guarantee the same level of protection for all deposits in the EU, regardless of location. To avoid new cases of bank bailouts with large sums of money, restore investor confidence and support growth and financial stability, we need to strive for higher, better quality bank capital and stabilisation of the supervisory and regulatory framework. I welcome the annual Report on the Work of the Banking Union, in particular the establishment of an SSM which has proven to be extremely successful from an operational point of view. Taking into account the short deadline for the establishment and complexity of the project, I fully support the Report and look forward to the future successes of the Banking Union.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the Banking Union – Annual Report 2015. Confidence in the banking system and in banks in the euro area has fallen sharply during the economic and financial crisis. The banking sector has been hit hard by the crisis, but it has also highlighted a number of weaknesses for banks. It was the same in Slovenia. One of the problems we faced in Slovenia was the large volume of poorly secured credit, which banks granted to companies at a time of high economic growth. Because of poorly secured loans, the banks never saw this money again. I welcome the establishment of a single supervisory mechanism, which has been successful since its creation both from an operational point of view and in terms of quality of control. However, there are still plenty of opportunities for improvement, for example at the level of planning of control measures.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2015 Annual Report on the Banking Union. The Banking Union has been one of the EU's most important achievements since the global financial crisis. It was created with the aim of re-establishing confidence, fostering an increase in the volume of investments in the real economy and providing citizens with a higher level of security against possible bankruptcies of banking and financial corporations. The reporter gave a complete picture of the performance of the two pillars, the Single Supervisory Mechanism and the Single Resolution Mechanism, which are now fully operational. Among the many constructive recommendations, the idea of extending initiatives to better finance SMEs to start-ups, micro-enterprises and mid-caps is particularly welcome. In addition, I also support the stabilisation of the supervisory and regulatory framework, which is an important element in restoring investor confidence. Furthermore, like the reporter, I am calling for the creation of an integrated European rulebook on financial regulation and consumer rights, which would replace the current complex legislation.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Banking Union is crucial to ensure stability and restore confidence in banks in the euro area, strengthen financial integration, reduce risks in the European banking system and moral hazard, helping to break the links between countries and banks.  The EP's report on the Banking Union (UB) adequately emphasises the benefits of its creation and the problems that the UB continues m.in to face, such as the European Central Bank's non-compliance with the principle of proportionality to a sufficient degree.  The report focuses on three pillars of the UB: the Single Supervisory Mechanism, the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM) and the protection of deposits. Particular focus has been on the new third pillar of the UB, which is to bring together, as yet uncoordinated, national deposit insurance schemes.  I am pleased that the Annual Report contains issues relating to the SSM, which has been a success since its creation, both operationally and in terms of the quality of supervision.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Banking Union is one of the main gains in the financial crisis that affected the European Union in 2008. As a result of this, member states and european institutions have strengthened the financial and banking sectors, ensuring their safety and resilience, and trust in banks has been restored, while investing in the real economy and a high degree of protection for citizens. The establishment of the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) in November 2014 and the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM) were the first steps towards the emergence of a new pillar of regulation of the financial-banking sector at European level. Unfortunately, this pillar is not yet fully structured, in the absence of a common means of fiscal protection to support the Single Resolution Fund. In the coming years, it is necessary to develop the Banking Union in this direction by setting up a European Deposit Guarantee Scheme (SEGD). The current document is a first step in the right direction; I therefore support its adoption.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The banking union is an indispensable component of a monetary union and one of the main foundations of a genuine economic and monetary union (EMU), and is open to the participation of Member States whose currency is not the euro. We encourage broad representation within the banking union through the future engagement and participation of the competent national authorities of non-participating Member States, in accordance with established legal rules and procedures, as well as through the intensification of cooperation with third countries outside the European Union. Closer coordination between the relevant national authorities within the EU and at the international level is essential to ensure effective regulation and control of systemically important banks.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The economic crisis that hit Europe in 2008 led not only to a catastrophic loss of jobs, but also to a major loss of confidence in the market and our national banking institutions. In response, we created the Banking Union, which has been indispensable in restoring stability and confidence in euro area banks, strengthening our monetary union, and above all leading to market confidence, boosting jobs and investment. While, eight years later, our recovery remains modest and the risks high, the Banking Union remains the best instrument to put the European economy on the right path again. This is why I voted in favour of the Banking Union’s 2015 report. I particularly welcome the creation of the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), which aims to ensure a uniform and homogeneous supervision of European banks, creating a level playing field in the banking market, and contributing to its safety and soundness, while endorsing the idea that the administrative burdens caused by this instrument must be kept to a minimum.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ As a necessary component of monetary union and a fundamental element of a genuine Economic and Monetary Union, the Banking Union plays a key role in financing investment and, accordingly, stimulating growth and job creation across the EU, which is why this report is of unassailment as it toes the pressing problems of all EU Member States.  One part of the report states that deposits could be protected in a unique and high level across Europe. The planned resolution of community-wide risk insurance will reduce the level of protection in some countries, while other countries will profit from it. As a result, redistribution does not contribute to the provision of deposits. The economic recovery is fortunately ongoing, but the lack of structural reforms, convergence and investment and excessive dependence on external factors is still quite weak.  As regards the Single Supervisory Mechanism, the report paints an overly optimistic picture, as it will be a long time before the effective functioning of surveillance can begin. To consider that the surveillance system is already such that the pressing problems of insufficient capitalisation of individual credit institutions or even entire national banking systems can be identified has nothing to do with the real situation, so I voted abstaining.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - Report on the Banking Union - I would support the 2015 Annual Report, as identified steps have been taken in the EU over the past year to create a banking union. In the past, MEPs have managed to move the largest EU banks under the supervision of the European Central Bank, while also maintaining common provisions on tackling financial complexity and banks. I believe that creating an effective and transparent banking union remains a key area in which, in the future, in addition to an effective Single Supervisory Mechanism and the Single Resolution Mechanism, we will also need to ensure a genuine break-up of the link between the state and the banks, further strengthen investor confidence, create a level playing field and continuously improve financial stability. I believe that action in these areas will also lead to a more accountable functioning of those who take risks.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report, which qualifies as a success in the first year of the banking union' journey. In our view, the main problem that the project faced, the existence of systemic banks (too-big-to-fail), has not been solved at all, with the addition that some of these banks (such as Deutsche Bank) are now in a state of insolvency that threatens again the stability of the Union as a whole. With regard to the supervisory body, the SSM, we consider that its performance during the Greek crisis, as well as the violation of its own assessments by the ECB, deserved an investigation and condemnation of those contained in the report. Finally, with regard to the issue of deposit guaranteeing, which would prevent contagion from private debt to public debt and to equate the level of risk of the various European banks, the report is ambiguous in reflecting the disagreements that exist in this regard between the different conservative sectors.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The 2015 Annual Report on banking union welcomes all three pillars. The first pillar is the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM). This is a mechanism by which the ECB is supposed to supervise large eurozone banks, thereby ensuring the security and soundness of the European banking system. The second pillar is the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM). This provides for uniform rules for the resolution or recovery of distressed European banks. The third pillar is the common deposit guarantee. The deposits of all savers are to be insured jointly. I reject the Banking Union, as the supervisory mechanism inevitably presents the ECB with significant conflicts of interest. On the one hand, it is intended to ensure that banks prosper as much as possible through its monetary policy, and on the other hand, it should impose conditions on banks if necessary. The Aim of the SRM is to create a community fund to pay for the restructuring of the banks in need. However, since it is much more likely that southern eurozone banks will need help, the SRM will lead to a de facto redistribution of funds. The common deposit guarantee also leads to redistribution and thus to savers in the northern Member States taking on the risks of southern Europe. Such a redistribution will not solve the divergences caused by the lack of an exchange rate mechanism and must therefore be rejected. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The report therefore provides an overview of the progress of the banking union and the weaknesses still present. It should be noted that, eight years after the crisis, the banking system has only grown, especially in the shadow banking sector. Even though the MSU improves bank supervision and capital requirements have been increased, banks remain a huge danger to the global economy. In addition, no details were given on the resolution of the crisis for systemic banks. Beyond a balance sheet of 30 billion euros, the resolution is the responsibility of the ECB and not the MRU. The work carried out by the European institutions in the context of the banking union is a communication operation aimed at making it seem that the European Union is taking the bull by the horns. However, the reforms put in place are far from what would be needed to limit the nuisance power of banks. The first step should be to separate retail and investment activities in order to protect deposits, which is categorically rejected by the European Union. So I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Banking Union plays an essential role in ensuring stability and restoring confidence in euro area banks, promoting financial integration, reducing financial risks and moral risk within the European banking system, and contributing to the elimination of the relationship between the State and banks and the promotion of risk-sharing within monetary union. The Banking Union plays a key role in financing investment and, consequently, in promoting growth and job creation throughout the EU. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report, which qualifies as a success in the first year of the banking union' journey. In our view, the main problem that the project faced, the existence of systemic banks (too-big-to-fail), has not been solved at all, with the addition that some of these banks (such as Deutsche Bank) are now in a state of insolvency that threatens again the stability of the Union as a whole. With regard to the supervisory body, the SSM, we consider that its performance during the Greek crisis, as well as the violation of its own assessments by the ECB, deserved an investigation and condemnation of those contained in the report. Finally, with regard to the issue of deposit guaranteeing, which would prevent contagion from private debt to public debt and to equate the level of risk of the various European banks, the report is ambiguous in reflecting the disagreements that exist in this regard between the different conservative sectors.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the successful creation of the Single Resolution Board and the national resolution authorities established in the Member States. I note that, in accordance with the relevant EBA standards, the Single Resolution Board has developed resolution operational guides to promote a coherent, effective and proportionate approach to resolution tasks in the SRM.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Banking Union, Annual Report 2015. The Banking Union is an EU-level banking supervision and resolution system. It is one of the crucial components of the EU’s attempt to create a true Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) and to reinstate confidence in the banking sector, which was seriously damaged due to the financial crisis. The report assesses the work that has been done in 2015 as well as the mechanisms needed for supervision and regulation. The report equally focuses on the third pillar in the form of a European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS), which constitutes a single scheme for guaranteed deposits.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The report calls on the Commission and supervisors to assess how increasing capital requirements to banking in current and future legislation can affect creditworthiness and, consequently, the supply of credit. It also examines the proposal for a deposit guarantee system, the organization of the Single Resolution Fund and the rules on the exposure of banks to sovereign debt.
