We are talking about a balanced document which has had broad consensus, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this first report on banking union because I agree with the positive assessment of this new step in European construction, which is essential to form a genuine economic and monetary union in the federal key.  I think it is appropriate to assess the Single Supervisory Mechanism since its launch in November 2014, as well as to support the proposed European Deposit Guarantee Scheme, fourth, and absolutely necessary, the leg of the banking union, together with the single regulation for the twenty-eight, the supervision by the European Central Bank for the nineteen and the restructuring and/or liquidation of financial institutions domiciled in the euro area.  In this regard, it is very important that Parliament does not delay the processing of the proposal on the European Deposit Guarantee Scheme for the benefit of the more than three hundred million citizens living in the euro area, or that it be linked to other matters which are not the case.  It cannot therefore be interpreted as introducing the setting of limits on the purchase of sovereign debt by financial institutions outside the framework of Basel.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 During this plenary session, the first report on the Banking Union was voted on, which expressed a positive opinion that I do not consider justified. We believe, in fact, that the Banking Union has already amply demonstrated its fragility, because it is not very decisive unless accompanied by a structural reform of the banks that provides for a clear separation of speculative activities from traditional credit activities to the real economy.  In the context of supervision by the SSM, we have criticised how the asset quality review is conducted, which only considers credit risk and does not take derivatives into account appropriately, thus distorting real risk assessments in banks. In addition, we have highlighted the existence of conflicts of interest in the management of monetary policy and supervision by the ECB. With regard to the SRM, we have denounced both the illegality of bail-in and the futility of the single resolution fund, which does not have sufficient resources to manage banking crises of a systemic nature.  Finally, we believe that the EDIS proposal is too weak to really protect deposits, which should be guaranteed by a central bank acting as a lender of last resort. The final text, which is the result of the compromise between socialists and the people, has not included most of our demands, and that is why I voted against the report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this annual report on the European Banking Union. This report reflects a good state of affairs and highlights the challenges that still lie ahead.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report looks at consumer price indices. The Commission proposes to establish a uniform legal framework for the development, and dissemination of data on consumer and housing price indices (IPCH). The IPCH is used to provide a measure of inflation used to calculate economic values such as wages, rents, interest rates, etc.  Improving statistics in this area, making them as objective, impartial and comparable as possible in all Member States and for all products seems to me to be a good thing. However, we have seen with amazement that after the trilogue between the different institutions, the possibility of adding in the calculation of inflation the proceeds of prostitution, narcotics, and gambling which legitimizes these activities and will obviously distort the statistics. My group, the GUE/NGL, has tabled a series of amendments to remove these "products" referring to curious "consumptions". None were retained. So I voted against this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Banking Union, which is under discussion today, is another demonstration of the false solutions found to solve the deep systemic crisis in which the EU has been in the eu for more than a decade.  As is easily demonstrable, this Banking Union does not solve anything. It is based on a banking supervision system that has already proven, in its short existence, that it is not effective, as we painfully know in Portugal. The resolution system and its common resolution fund is short and clearly insufficient, even after shareholder losses, so taxpayers will surely be called back to pay to save the systemic banks. And read the regulation that says so, and I quote: "an effective resolution regime should minimize the costs to be borne by taxpayers" or later, "with minimal costs for taxpayers and the real economy". It is, moreover, significant that this banking union should be made before the promised restructuring of the banking system. Let us be clear, for us, there is no solid solution without a recovery of public control of banking and the financial system. Only then will we have a financial system at the service of the economy and truly safe for citizens.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), which aims to achieve uniform, homogeneous supervision of the banks of the participating Member States, is the first pillar. The Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM), which ensures uniform rules and procedures and a common decision-making procedure for an orderly resolution of insolvent banks, is the second pillar. The third pillar concerns national deposit guarantee schemes – a uniform, high level of deposit guarantee, regardless of the location of deposits. This whole set of rules is intended to complete the Banking Union, which is why I voted against it.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I did not agree with Parliament's resolution on the Banking Union – Annual Report 2015. As shadow rapporteur, I have tried to improve this report. That has not been achieved. Even after its adoption, it does not address the problem of mixing monetary policy and banking supervision, it continues to advocate the socialisation of risks from national deposit guarantee schemes and ignores the fact that the provision of Article 127 TFEU chosen as the legal basis for supervision at the ECB is unfit. We did not even talk about the much more fundamental problems of the banking union in the parliamentary process. That is why I repeat here that the Banking Union is unfit to solve the problems of the banks and the euro as a currency. We are dealing with a crisis in the monetary system which has led to chronic bank over-indebtedness. This problem cannot be solved by shifting supervision to the European level. That is excluded. As soon as the crisis of the euro flares up again, it will become clear how helpless and helpless the banking union is. Instead, the ECB will once again bail out over-indebted big banks and governments at the expense of savers and money users.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the banking union is a pillar of the monetary union that the UK is not party to, the increased economic stability it will provide is of great benefit to the British economy. Such moves may well help prevent or mitigate the next financial crisis. I welcome the call in this report for banking union measures to take into account a diversity of business models, as cooperatives and mutuals have an important role to play in a more socially just and more democratic economy. We must always keep at the forefront of our minds that the banking and financial services industry is exactly that: a service for the real economy, that must result in inclusive and sustainable growth. Never again must we promote the growth of our financial industries as an end in itself. The banking sector must be regulated to guarantee responsible decision-making for the benefit of ordinary working people and for those who are without employment. Again, this is something that the EU can deliver, and that the UK, unfortunately, could not or would not do alone.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 For the first time, the European Parliament has expressed its views through an own-initiative report on the state of the Banking Union.  The report separately analysed the three pillars of the Banking Union: the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM) and the European Deposit Guarantee Scheme (EDIS). For each of them, satisfaction is expressed at the results achieved so far. Little criticism has been made and almost no proposals have been made to promote improvements. Contrary to what is expressed in the report, the mechanism set up with the Banking Union has already amply demonstrated its fragilities, not only in the case of supervision, but also in that of the resolution, as we have seen from the applications of bail-in. Although this union resolves some of the consequences of the crisis, it does not act on the causes and therefore remains a weak and ineffective instrument.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I welcome the report on the functioning of the Banking Union. Analyses indicated that the financial situation in the banking sector in Europe improved in 2015. Many weak banks have been recapitalised and have improved the quality of their management. The number of bank bankruptcies has fallen, so severe not only for the economy, but also for bank customers, that is, for virtually all Europeans. There is an improvement in public information on the functioning of banks. It is also important to strengthen the competences of the European Central Bank, which is now able to solve the various problems emerging in the financial sector more quickly and effectively. The common rules for the assessment of banks at European level are therefore increasingly effective.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Gualtieri report because I believe in a banking union capable of ensuring the security and resilience of the banking and financial sector while ensuring a high level of protection of citizens against the bankruptcy of banks and the insolvency of financial entities.  Since the first hour, the socialist group has supported the two pillars of this banking union: the Single Supervisory Mechanism and the Single Resolution Mechanism. However, I stress that the third pillar of this banking union is yet to be fulfilled: the European Deposit Insurance System. A robust deposit guarantee system financed by financial sector contributions could prevent the rescue of banks with taxpayers' money. In the absence of this missing element, the banking Union cannot be completed and therefore capable of fulfilling the ambition to which it is proposing. That should be our priority for next year.

name: Preşedintele. –
text: The period devoted to explanations of votes has ended.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Czesław Siekierski, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, on the price crisis in the European pigmeat sector (O-000020/2016) (2016/2581(RSP)) (B8-0118/2016).

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski
text: Author. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. We are taking up an important question because the problem is extremely difficult, which is very visible on the agricultural market for pigmeat in the European Union, which is very much felt by pig producers. We know that global trends are such that food prices have been falling for four years. In 2015, this reduction in world prices reached 15%, but one advantage, the value of the common agricultural policy, was to stabilise agricultural markets, to stabilise farmers' incomes, but also to stabilise the supply-demand relationship. We know that these achievements of the common agricultural policy are appreciated by the people of Europe, that they are also appreciated by farmers, but the situation has become extremely difficult and complex. We are aware that the common agricultural policy is increasingly dependent on the external dimension – on what is happening on world markets. I am referring to what I have mentioned: world-class food prices. I go to formulate a question that is familiar to you. Russia's continuing embargo on food imports has closed the EU's largest market for pig farmers to the pig sector, which has become an additional major problem alongside those mentioned earlier. This leads to strong down pressure on prices, going beyond normal cyclical developments in the pigmeat sector. So-called pig cycles are normal, but what is happening exceeds the crises that have occurred before. The average value of Class E pig carcasses fell by 9% in December alone. Let us remember that December was a pre-Christmas period, and therefore a time of increased purchases also on the market. Many Eu farmers produce pigs below the cost of production. Interest in the latest private storage aid scheme is much higher than in previous programmes. However, private storage support may not be enough to stabilise prices and strengthen the market. Future pressures on the market may arise and will probably occur when products start to leave the warehouses where they are collected, for which we pay for storage, and therefore there will be an increased supply to the market. This could again lead to another fall in prices and an even more difficult situation for producers.  The Commission therefore asks the following questions: does the European Commission intend to take further action in this situation after the private storage aid scheme? Secondly, what impact does the Private Storage Programme foresee by the Commission in terms of market impact and price stability (as I have already mentioned, because it is pork that will come back from stock, even if we keep it there now, paying for its storage)?  Will the Commission take steps to ensure that the available funds from the private storage aid scheme go primarily to farmers, I repeat – to farmers who are experiencing so much difficulty and need help – will they once again end up in the farmers' environment, to operators, to intermediaries? We know that in this field-to-table food chain, the farmer is the weakest link and usually all the problems and problems associated with falling prices move from trade through producers, intermediaries to the farmer. What action will the Commission take in the context of the Russian embargo, particularly with regard to the ban on pig fat, lard and offal products? We know that the introduction of the embargo had political overtones, it was not linked to the situation on the agricultural market, it was not the farmers who were at risk. And the situation we have is that the costs are borne by farmers, and the embargo is also politically uneasy.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The European pig sector is indeed in a very tense situation. The main cause is a significant increase in production over the last two years. The disappearance of Russia as an export market has exacerbated the situation, but it has not ultimately caused it alone. The Commission has responded to this situation within the framework of the common organisation of the market by aid for private storage of pigmeat, and in January this year 90 000 tonnes of pigmeat were stored with a budget of approximately EUR 27.6 million. The purpose of this measure is to withdraw meat from the market at short notice in times of low prices at the beginning of this year and to return to the market in doses after the seasonal price increase in early summer – since the barbecue season is in full swing. This also explains why the Commission can only use this market measure for a limited period of time. If the stored quantity is too large, the negative effects exceed the market effects of outsourcing the frozen products. The recent stockpiling halted the seasonal fall in prices in January and thus had a direct impact on agricultural incomes. So the safety net worked. Let me also make it quite clear that measures of the common organisation of the market, such as private storage, cannot and should not replace market forces either. However, they can support the necessary market adjustments. We are currently seeing clear signals that the market is reacting. In addition to direct market support measures, the pig sector benefits from the Solidarity Pact adopted by the Commission in September 2015. This includes the possibility of targeted measures in the livestock sector for a total volume of EUR 420 million. As regards Russia's sanitary trade restrictions on fat, bacon and by-products, the Commission initiated wto proceedings back in 2014. Although no official WTO decision has yet been taken, all preliminary information from Geneva points to confirmation of the EU position. This will undoubtedly strengthen the Commission's negotiating position on market access. Let me conclude by saying that the Commission is keeping a very close eye on the market situation and will, as in the past, take any necessary measures in a timely manner.

name: Daniel Buda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, agriculture at European level is going through extremely difficult times, generated by the embargo imposed by Russia and the impossibility of finding new markets. The pig farming sector is extremely affected. Today, 1 kg of meat is produced for 1.25 euros and sells for 0.78 Euros. This situation is intolerable, given that the price of meat on the shelf has not undergone correlative changes, asking us, not just rhetorically, who do farmers work for? Certainly not for consumers! The commission's recent measure to support this sector, namely private storage, even if it is superior to previous schemes, is not sufficient to stabilise prices and help pig farmers. Moreover, in some Member States this scheme has proved to be ineffective, whether we are talking about France or Romania, given that there is simply not enough space for private storage. The Commission should identify new support mechanisms for this sector and ensure that the money allocated really gets to the right place. I also call on the European Commission to reconsider its position towards the Romanian pig, which has been reared in a territory free of classical swine fever for almost eight years and to allow free trade with it in the European area. It is inadmissible that Romania has fulfilled all its veterinary obligations and that officials of the European Commission do not take the time to analyse this situation and unlock it.

name: Eric Andrieu
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr President, Commissioner, you are telling us that the incomes of farmers and pig farmers have stabilised. We must not live in the same Europe! In a country like France, today, a farmer commits suicide every other day, and has been for ten years now. Agriculture is in a deep crisis and this crisis is not specific to France. Across Europe, the situation is deteriorating. What is true for pork is also true for milk and fruits and vegetables. As such, I regret that we were not able to have a plenary debate on the global agricultural crisis - a debate at the beginning of the week - which would have allowed our fellow Members to be more numerous, and, above all, a debate in the presence of the Commissioner for Agriculture and Rural Development. Mr Hogan, your absence today is a sign of contempt for us, but especially against the thousands of farmers who are suffering and in despair. 30% of hog producers are in crisis and 10% have already gone bankrupt since the beginning of this crisis. Your Commission, Commissioner Hogan, has been wrong in its expectations for more than two years. We are facing a market crisis and, as you know, only the European Commission has the power to regulate. I ask you, Commissioner, once again, to listen to us before the Council on 14 March 2016. Use Sections 221 and 222 of the Single CMO, which allow you to take exceptional measures to reduce production, such as killing sows, reducing the weight of carcasses. 3 kilos less per carcass would solve today the problem of overproduction. Reopen private storage measures with a better adaptation of the list of stockable products that can be sold for export. Put in place the labelling on the origin of processed meats, as consumers are asking for and as we have been asking you for more than two years now. Finally, Commissioner, deploy, as Mr Siekierski has said, coherent and relevant diplomatic action to lift the Russian health embargo. Put all the necessary means into it. We measure the difficulty of the exercise, but today the solution is not to seek new markets on other continents of the world, but to solve the problem of the embargo with Russia.

name: Janusz Wojciechowski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking The situation of pig farmers in the European Union is difficult throughout the Union, but it is particularly difficult in some countries, especially in my country, Poland. Three geographical scourges have fallen on pig farmers in Poland: African swine fever, the Russian embargo and European agricultural policy – a policy that does not protect small producers, owners of small family farms in particular, but promotes the concentration of production and large farms.  Decisive action is needed to improve the situation, because in Poland, for example, eight years ago we had 19 million pigs, and today there is not even half of that number. Support is needed for pig producers, a return to pork storage subsidies is needed, new outlets, export subsidies, export subsidies are needed – these are measures that can and should improve a situation that is truly dramatic. Pig producers are really begging, asking and demanding help from the European Union.

name: Jan Huitema
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – The price of pigs has fallen sharply as a result of overproduction and a closed Russian market. The Russian market should be opened up to products that are not part of the political embargo, but are boycotted as a result of the alleged African swine fever. We need to open up alternative markets as the weed- weatherga. Japan is a good example of this.  But the most important thing is that we focus on structural solutions. The position of the pig farmer in the chain needs to be improved, for example through producer organisations. European pig farmers need to invest heavily to meet strict animal welfare and environmental requirements. These investments should be able to recoup pig farmers from the market. A level playing field in the EU is of unprecedented importance.  In some countries, money from Brussels is used to further increase pork production, while there is a surplus. Moreover, European agreements are far from being fulfilled in the right way everywhere. It is fantastic to see that the sector itself is also taking initiatives for a better market position such as product innovations. They should be given more space.

name: Miguel Viegas
text: gue/NGL Group. – According to a popular adage used in Portugal, "those who sow winds reave storms". The European institutions have decided to create a completely deregulated CAP, relying on market rules to solve all problems. The results are in sight and show that public instruments for regulating production are an indispensable tool. Portugal was, in 1993, at the opening of borders, self-sufficient in pork. Today we import 40% of what we consume. Prices are unbearably low, endangering the whole row.  Commissioner, the situation is urgent. It is not commendable with small palliatives and much less with more studies. We demand vigorous and immediate action. We want measures that allow producers fair remuneration in their work and put an end to the abusive practices of the large distribution. We want the right of each country to produce to be safeguarded in order to guarantee minimum levels of food sovereignty. What we do not want, Commissioner, is to see another vital sector disappear for our economy, like so many others that we have lost since joining the European Union.

name: Bronis Ropė
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – It is no secret that the pigmeat sector is in a deep crisis, just like the dairy sector and others. Today, pork buying prices are at their lowest in the last decade. They decreased by an average of 13 % per year. True, in shops, the price decreases much more slowly if at all it decreases. We all know that many pig farms have taken credit for modernising production, implementing animal welfare and environmental requirements. Therefore, low buying-in prices raise the question of: can pig farming in Europe survive? What is the reason for it? The reason is twofold. On the one hand, the global supply of pork has increased. On the other hand, we need, but costly, animal welfare measures in Europe. The behaviour of traders and the outbreak of African swine fever do not always play the last role. What can we do? Let us start with the unification of the conditions of international competition. Why do we force our farmers to comply with animal welfare requirements, but we allow imports of quarter-cheaper meat from countries such as the USA or Brazil, where animal welfare standards are virtually non-existant. In addition, we have the knowledge that there, butchers are fed with GMOs. I call on the Commission to take measures to restrict meat imports from third countries which apply animal welfare standards below European standards. It would be even better if the Commission took real action and proposed, at world trade organisation level, high global standards for the welfare of animals for fatmeat. Secondly, let us take measures to ensure a fair distribution of value added, to limit the arbitrary value of traders, to manipulate shelf fees. Thirdly, I recall that farmers are very much looking forward to real export promotion mechanisms. I am thinking, in particular, of the export guarantee system. And to the end, but no less important, is African swine fever. This disease, which has spread in some Member States, including my country, Lithuania, is damaging the reputation of EU pork and restricting export opportunities. The Lithuanian authorities have succeeded in stopping the spread of this disease, but farmers suffer significant losses due to its associated unfair commercial practices, when collectors offer a very low price for healthy pigs grown on farms that enter even the relatively safe zone III. (The speaker agrees to answer the blue card question of the person who raised the Blue Card (Rule 162(8)).

name: Stefan Eck (GUE/NGL)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I am sure you know for yourself that it is impossible for the EU to demand animal welfare standards outside the EU. My question to you is this: do you really want to lower the few standards in the field of animal welfare that we have struggled, hard to achieve here in the EU, only to get back to a market-oriented price? Surely it cannot be!

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: answer to the blue card question. – Thank you very much for your question. It is indeed a very good question. I said in my speech that European standards are high enough and should not be the case in a way that comes from other countries by much lower standards, which lowers prices and our pork market cannot compete, and in this way farmers receive low buying prices, and some people eat the bad product they bring.

name: Dominique Bilde
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the European pork sector is now going through a major crisis, which is a direct consequence of the sell-off of our agriculture organised with the complicity of European and national political leaders. First, the Russian embargo, as a result of European sanctions, is ruining many producers in Europe and France. It is more than urgent to raise it, which will have a direct impact on prices. Then there is an imbalance between supply and demand. In Europe, production will increase by 3% this year, i.e. an additional ten million pigs on the European market. For example, French producers are direct victims of German or Spanish producers, who practice social dumping by hiring seconded workers paid 4 or 5 euros an hour, in the case of Germany, or by applying fewer charges and standards, as is the case in Spain. In France, the government has proposed a floor price of 1.40 euros per kilo, a price that served as a small price for French farmers to survive. Industrialists and supermarkets obviously considered this minimum price too high in the face of foreign competition and boycotted the national reference market. The fight by quality, in respect of animal welfare, and in particular the 2008/120/EC directive on the protection of pigs, should not penalise French producers in relation to certain States that have little regard for standards or the importation of pork meat from non-European countries, whose social, health or environmental standards would not be identical to ours. How can one think that the European Union really cares about the fate of farmers when it refuses to suspend the negotiations of the transatlantic treaty, which will expose our breeders to competition from American breeders whose costs are 40% lower than their own or when, under pressure from the Commission, France renounces to impose labelling of the origin of meat.

name: Norbert Lins (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I would like to express my sincere thanks for the urgent debate that is taking place.  However, in view of the position that I believe agriculture should take in European policy and the acute crisis that many farms are currently in, I would like to stress that I find the timing of the debate to Thursday afternoon very unfortunate. In my home region of Baden-Württemberg, too, the number of pig farmers has fallen by a quarter in the last five years. Trend: sharply rising. The long-term low-price phase is causing income and liquidity problems for our farmers. With a slaughter price in my region of about EUR 1.30 per kilo, no pig farmer can survive permanently. Due to the persistently difficult market situation, new action is needed. In the short term, as in 2015, we should put together a new aid package spread across all Member States. Only 1 550 out of 25 700 processing companies in Germany will be able to benefit from the current programme. In the long term, we need to promote and open up new markets. Another problem is the responsibility of market partners and food retailers. They must recognise and assume their responsibility for domestic agriculture.  Finally, I hope that sensible measures will be adopted at the meeting of the Agriculture Council on Monday.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: – Monsieur le Président, chers collègues, il est inacceptable que ce débat ait lieu sans le commissaire responsable, M. Hogan. La situation est grave, le revenu des agriculteurs a fondu, les secteurs laitier et porcin, notamment, s'enfoncent dans une crise dont l'Union européenne semble ne pas mesurer l'ampleur et la gravité. Dans mon pays, la Belgique, la situation est particulièrement grave. La crise du secteur laitier affecte tout le pays, tandis que celle du secteur porcin touche principalement le nord du pays, la Flandre. Je vais d'ailleurs continuer à m'exprimer en néerlandais. The situation of Flemish pig farmers is dramatic. Currently, each pig brought to the slaughterhouse yields less than 1 euro per kilo, while the breeder needs 1.30 euros to get out of his costs and 1.50 euros to earn his living. The price the grower receives for his meat is not sufficient to cover the rising production costs caused by higher food and energy prices. Pig farmers are forced to sell at a loss, while sales at a loss are prohibited in all economic sectors except farmers. With its ultra-liberal vision and its commitment to conquering new markets, the European Commission is heading for catastrophe. With its proposals, which are intended to deal with the crisis, it has at no time succeeded in bringing the situation under control. Commissioner, I have repeated it several times in this House, the price has to be set taking into account the cost of production and should never be lower than these costs. The urgency forces action. We need concrete measures to limit supply. We must also urgently set up a monitoring centre for pork prices to gather information on the price, production level and number of slaughters, inseminations, profit margins, stock and evolution on the market. In addition, a rapid negotiation must be made on the lifting of the Russian embargo. Commissioner, it is urgent. Let's stop thinking, let's take action.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: – The crisis in the pig sector has been going on for far too long. On behalf of the sector organisation in my country, the Netherlands, some questions. Is the Commission prepared to consider alternative measures instead of private storage? This is, after all, an exceptional crisis situation. The sector considers that temporary early slaughter is a more effective measure than the storage of meat. The price then improves without risk of market distortion afterwards.  Secondly, reopening the Russian market is of great importance. Now that the WTO is coming up with a negative assessment of the Russian measures, a technical solution with Russia should be settled quickly.  Finally, I would like to stress, with my colleague Huitema, the need for a level playing field within the EU and beyond.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr In the discussions on the problem of EU pig farmers, it is often said that the main problem is the conflict with Russia. That's not true. Some countries have had very little exposure to Russia, while others have had real problems finding alternative markets. The major problem is that the European Commission and policy have focused on short-term measures, such as support for private storage. These measures do not solve the problem in a structural way, but rather exacerbate the problem after a while.  What is needed are new, comprehensive and more market-based solutions and another policy. Efforts should be made to strengthen the competitiveness of European agriculture, and tougher demands should be placed on the protection of the animals of those who export their products to the EU in order to achieve fairer competition. It is only by tackling the problem in a structural way that we can tackle it, through measures with the help of producers, industry and consumers.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL).
text: – The pig industry has been bumping from one crisis to another for decades. This crisis is not new. We have had crises from swine fever, swine flu crises, crises due to the collapse of markets, crises caused by hormone scandals, you name it. And only because Europe wants to be the butcher for the whole world! Millions of pigs are kept under appalling conditions to turn into cheap ham rags and chops as quickly as possible. Many pigs are neutered without anesthesia. Tails and teeth are cut off when the animals are less than seven days old, even though this has been banned for 20 years. The problems are not due to the collapse of the market in Russia. There is simply more supply than there is demand. Instead of reducing production, we store the meat in freezers and advertise eating pork. Europe must no longer allow itself to be put at the forefront of the livestock industry by growing this animal-unfriendly, environmentally polluting and sickening industry against will and thanks. Now is the time to shrink and reform the sector. This pig industry is sick and is as shaky as the pigs that live in this industry. That's why we don't have to take a dime here. That is also why I believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: – As always, pig farming is the last item on the agenda. Nevertheless, this issue is important, because in the Netherlands and in the other Member States, the water is on the lips of many farmers because they can no longer even pay for animal feed, doctor's fees and manure disposal and go bankrupt. Often there is also no more money for the household.  Since the Russian boycott - and hopefully it has been resolved quickly - supply and demand have been completely out of balance. While European pig production is still increasing, prices are falling. At the same time, the cost in the Netherlands has increased enormously in recent years due to the stricter application of environmental and animal welfare standards, Mrs Hazekamp. As a result, farmers in the Netherlands have an extra 20 euro cents in costs per kilogram of slaughter weight compared to 7 cents in Germany and Denmark. The pig market therefore completely lacks a single European level playing field.  The EUR 10 million granted by the Dutch Cabinet from the additional crisis pot of EUR 500 million to pig farmers is a small consolation. The money does not end up in the farmer's wallet to pay the costs. We also need to help those who want to stop moving forward. So: 1) good guidance for the growers who want to stop; 2) help for those who want to restart; and 3) help for pig farmers who wish to expand their holdings. Should this not be addressed, Commissioner, the crisis reserve of the agricultural budget? Crisis money is for all sectors, right? Finally, improving the negotiating position is an important part of the solution. Last year, with the farmers' actions in Brussels, I received a good plan from copa-COGECA. It describes how farmers, feed suppliers, chain stores and the government come to a fair price. Shouldn't this be an example for Europe?

name: Karol Karski (ECR).
text: – Due to the long-overdue crisis in agricultural markets, farmers across the European Union have found themselves in a dire situation, some of them have serious financial problems due to very low agricultural prices and may lose their entire lives. Already in September 2014, at the initiative of the ECR Group, the European Parliament called on the Commission to take immediate action to support farmers facing the crisis caused by the Russian embargo and other problems.  The disastrous situation on the pigmeat market in Poland is due to poland's burden and the consequences of securing the Union against the spread of African swine fever. Poland suffers losses due to the inability to export, even though the disease has already been controlled. Polish pig farms must be supported by the Union, as they are at a disadvantage due to low prices due to African swine fever and the embargo than farms from other Member States. Polish farmers have also suffered particularly from last year's drought, which caused very serious problems in the livestock sector due to a lack of feed and an increase in their prices.  I call on the European Commission to take action and resolve this huge crisis in the agricultural markets immediately.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr. President, we need a short-term and long-term solution. The short-term solution should be one that will diversify our product in such a way that we will conquer new markets, especially the Chinese market. We are able to conquer the Chinese market and I suggest that we have a one-time subsidy for pigmeat producers and that Mr. Hogan "fly away", so to speak, according to this planet of ours and that a short-term solution resolves this situation. This will also be a partial long-term solution, as we will have a market diversification, and on the other hand one day the Russian market will return. What I would like to call specifically is for an inspection to be carried out in Croatia as soon as possible, in order to establish that there are no more traces of swine fever in Croatia, because Croatian pigmeat production has the possibility of large exports and I ask that the Commission do so as soon as possible.

name: Stefan Eck (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The EU produces more pork than is in demand, for various reasons: on the one hand, cheap imports, embargoes, and, on the other, because more and more people want to give up cheap, disease-causing pork. And now there are calls to tap into new export markets to boost demand. Apparently, no one is bothered by the fact that we are destroying the farms in these importing countries sooner or later. I thought we had learned lessons from the milk crisis. The massive price falls that we are now witnessing are nothing more than the expression of a misguided agricultural policy and company policy, because the large retail chains now have such a great power in the market that they can dictate prices. The solution is that the production volume must be based on demand, and pigmeat producers should finally be prepared for a very strong increase in the number of meat reducers and vegetarians in the future.

name: Anne Sander (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the situation is serious. Farmers have been selling at a loss for months. In France alone, 15-20% of hog farms are on the brink of bankruptcy. The first reason for this crisis - the Russian embargo - is cyclical. What is the Commission doing to help farmers bear the costs of our diplomatic choices? The second reason, structural, is the imbalance in the value chain. We need to adapt our competition law to allow farmers to come together to put more pressure on pricing. Finally, beyond pork, it is all agriculture that is in crisis, and if Europe wants to remain a sustainable agricultural power, there is an urgent need to act.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I attended a meeting on Monday night with the Commissioner for Agriculture, Mr Hogan, I am here today, and there is no doubt about it: there is actually a growing awareness of the crisis, but there are no solutions for the crisis. So I have three questions for Commissioner Hahn to answer. Firstly, is the agricultural sector – we are talking about the pig sector now, but I refer to the agricultural sector in general – carrying the can for the rest of Europe on the Russian bans? Secondly, what prospects are there, short-term, medium-term and long-term, for growing our markets outside the European Union? Thirdly, what efforts are being made to grow our sales within Europe and indeed abroad, especially in view of what the previous speaker said about moves to turn people off eating meat because of all sorts of strange contradictory surveys that come out almost daily?

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Sánchez-Neym. The causes of the fall in the price of pork are more than clear: it is a war of sanctions with Russia, which several of my colleagues have already said here, but, as we know, before the war on sanctions began, trade between the European Union and Russia amounted to more than one billion euros a day. At this point, Latvian farmers are suffering very heavy losses, and in fact it happens that the agricultural sector is the most regulated in the European Union, but what can we do with our own regulations? They are powerless. So it is imperative that we open the Russian market back to Eastern Europe, my country, Latvia, because Russia is a traditional market for the European Union. It is to be welcomed that sanctions have actually been removed from Belarus, and perhaps European pork farmers could also enter the Belarusian market, but be aware that this will not happen tomorrow or the day after tomorrow. It takes time. Finally, I would like to say that, once, Latvian pork was very famous throughout Europe. Soon, if we do not accept urgent measures, we will have memories of Latvian pork.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR).
text: – On behalf of Polish pork producers, I would like to express my growing concern about the protracted destabilisation of the pigmeat market in Poland and the lack of effective action by the European Commission. My country bears the main burden and impact of securing EU borders against the spread of African swine fever, and this directly translates into huge losses for pig meat producers. The action taken so far by the European Commission has proved insufficient to improve the income situation of pigmeat producers, who suffer further losses on a daily basis.  I therefore fully support my country's demands for further financial support for the pig meat sector, and I look forward to solutions from the European Commission that will have a real impact on improving the situation of pigmeat producers. A country that has become a kind of barrier to protecting the market of the entire European Union should be particularly supported and not left to itself. Question for the European Commission: will it finally take effective action to ensure decent prices in the supply chain from field to table?

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, I express my full support for the Committee on Agriculture, which raised this issue, because EU farmers, pigmeat producers are in crisis, and the question is whether this crisis will eventually be greater in the future.  The Commission plans to open warehouses and market frozen meat in the summer, and the question is whether this will be the best time to do so. I emphasise the importance of that part of the issue that will help the funds earmarked for farmers actually get into their hands, and I call on the Commission to strengthen programmes to help private warehouses, as not having private warehouses makes farmers particularly vulnerable, subjected to blackmail and manipulation by traders, which is not just the case in meat production. In Croatia, fruit producers are particularly exposed in this regard. Finally, I welcome suggestions from colleagues that the European Commission should try to increase the European market and introduce higher measures of production standards in countries from which the EU imports meat.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the price crisis in the European pork sector, I am convinced, is well known. Price pressure will lead to a reduction in the number of farmers to devote themselves to raising pigs. I believe that a long-term vision is lacking, and I believe that the role of the common agricultural policy is also to maintain the balance between supply and demand when external factors arise, as the embargo with Russia has emerged. We are talking, in the European Union, about the internationalisation of business. What is being done in the framework of agricultural policy to be able to be exported to other markets, to third markets, not only within the European Union? And, Commissioner, perhaps, within your portfolio, you can tell us something: what is going on with the relationship and embargo with Russia? Because the Commissioner for Agriculture is missing and I think he deserves a vote of no confidence. My country and other countries in the European Union are traditionally breeding, have this tradition of raising pigs and processing meat. There is only talk here about the effect, but we also need to think about the long-term effect. Jobs are disappearing, Commissioner! It's a whole segment that deals with pig farming and processing. What do you want to do next to eliminate the crisis?

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: – The European Union has always been proud of the quality of agricultural production, the honest work of its farmers in the Member States. The current crisis in the pigmeat sector raises the question of where our vanity and non-respect for the work of human hands goes. I have two points of view. One is financial losses because of sanctions against Russia. This has caused a significant drop in the exports of our breeders and it is our duty to help them financially overcome this liquidation situation. It is therefore necessary to further compensate our producers and, in the short term, to increase support for private storage and to support efforts to attract outlets in third countries in the long term. The second thing is that we still have equals and equals here. Despite the promises to offset subsidies for all Member States, farmers in countries such as Slovakia are subject to much worse conditions than producers from Member States with higher subsidies. Without regulation by quotas for maximum production for countries, we cannot compete with them from Slovakia. This is how the possibility of introducing a country-specific maximum production quota system needs to be addressed, and the suitability of this system is evidenced by the problems in the milk sector that have ariseed throughout the EU following the abolition of this area.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE).
text: "In this form, I could ask you to speak to add short comments. Commissioner Hogan is in Poland at the invitation of the Minister of Agriculture, which has been known for 6 weeks. Today's deadline is a decision by Parliament's leadership, and it is a pity that this was not linked to the discussion on Monday when we discussed points in the area of agriculture, when Commissioner Hogan also participated. But I think it may be good for the matter that Commissioner Hahn is, because there are also very important issues relating to the embargo, as she said.  At the same time, we must point out that consumption is decreasing on the European market, not least because we are constantly hearing in the media: lactose harms health, red meat harms health. This also affects the level of consumption on the European market. However, competition on the world market is increasing and we must answer ourselves today: we want to win this competition, the scale of production must increase. What we would not want is industrialisation – it is very difficult to support small farmers in this situation, it requires special instruments to support small-farm production, which is important for agriculture, for the nature of European agriculture.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Thank you and thank you for pointing out why my friend and colleague Phil Hogan cannot be here today. However, I can assure you, also on behalf of the Commission as a whole, that we take the market situation in the agricultural sector very seriously. Next Monday, in the Council of Agriculture Ministers, market issues will be high on the agenda. Commissioner Hogan will comment specifically on the situation in the field of animal production. Both the Member States and this House have set a clear legal framework with the common organisation of the agricultural market. This provides for a safety net, and the Commission is making use of it. A strong rural area requires economically stable farms, and it is in everyone's interest to support them in difficult economic times. However, we must not forget that, as we all want, the common agricultural policy has transformed into a market-oriented agricultural policy as part of several reform steps. The European Parliament has always supported this development. An agriculture that produces past the market is not socially consensual. However, market orientation also means that market forces act and influence production structures. This is a logical process that is particularly clear in times of crisis, but which is also continuous under normal conditions.  However, anyone who denies this structural change is not honest either, and we want an honest agricultural policy. Whether pork, milk or whatever agricultural product, the Commission will responsibly use the room for manoeuvre set by Parliament and the Council when it comes to cushioning difficult market situations, in the sense of a sustainable and competitive common agricultural policy. Since I have been referred to my actual dossier by a number of speakers, I can tell you that it is precisely representatives of this House who have spoken and contributed very strongly today that are constantly raising the issue of the situation in eastern Ukraine and the consequences that this entails. We are very confident that a positive solution will soon be found. I am very optimistic about that. I hope that this optimism does not crush me, and if that is the case, then new situations will arise, which should obviously also have a positive effect in the agricultural sector.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. – In view of the serious crisis in the Pig sector in Europe, which is destroying many farmers, I find it outrageous that the European Parliament is only dealing with this issue on Thursday afternoon, when many of my fellow Members are no longer here because of their other obligations. I therefore demand that the debate be repeated in 'prime time' at the next plenary session. I call on the European Commission, on the one hand, to adjust the intervention price for pigmeat to the real cost of production and, on the other hand, to restart the private storage aid for the pig that is now being run.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. - I welcome the question raised by the Agriculture Committee to the Commission on the problem faced by pig farmers due to the pigmeat market crisis. So far, the Commission's efforts to address this problem unfortunately do not prove sufficient and appropriate. Private storage aid only delays the resolution of the problem, does not stabilise the market, but opens it up more to speculators, and ultimately is suffered by producers due to an additional fall in the prices of agricultural products sold directly from farms.  Croatia survived the meat import crisis in 2014 when, according to data from the Croatian Agricultural Agency, pigmeat production fell by 7000 tonnes or almost 10% in the first five months of that year. Croatia's production has not recovered, while meat imports have continued. At that time, we also experienced imports of frozen pigmeat, including from EU member states that were thawed and refreezed, which I have already spoken about repeatedly, and which is why I am committed to marking the full cycle of meat production, including the date of slaughter. The EU market is oversaturated with pigmeat, as with many other agricultural products, and an increase in the export rate to other markets, which today stands at 13%, I see as the only solution that must help stabilise the EU internal market.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – I am right about the concerns, because I think it is important to settle the situation of producers, if only because we have a strong common policy, the CAP. I understand that we Members, for the sake of the people and producers, are raising our voices and calling for a solution. Solutions to buy time, such as a private storage programme in the short term or the origin labelling of processed meats in the medium to long term.  On the other hand, consumer prices are also a problem in the midst of the price crisis, as are hunger and malnutrition in some regions of the EU. The EU has huge money to support agriculture. In many cases, however, this money does not go to farmers, but to wealthy landowners who only rent out the land. Part of the processing industry uses raw materials of uncontrolled quality from third countries. The producer can only sell his product at depressed prices, while the consumer already receives the goods at a gold price.  It is easy to ask the EU to take steps to lift the Russian embargo, but perhaps it would be more useful to take bold steps towards tax harmonisation and tax-free, affordable food. I would like to draw attention to the fact that the latter is an element of the Treaty concerning the CAP. We need to implement tax harmonisation in such a way as to increase producers' incomes, but also to reduce consumer prices. This is not a dream, but a commitment to a stronger EU that can be achieved by a common determination.
